column17: The energy investment climate in Canada is steady and predictable. Offtake risk is low; PPA tenor is typically 20 years, which gives both offtakers and developers significant financial certainty. Canada also has transparent distributed energy resource grid interconnection standards for market certainty. Although there isn't much pressure to build new resources since hydropower is so plentiful and cheap, most provinces have shown interest in transitioning away from fossil fuels. The Canadian Wind Energy Association found that there exists only a modest amount of curtailment of wind energy. However, renewable curtailment is likely to increase as variable renewable penetration grows.

Barriers to renewable energy development vary by region in the U.S. In markets like PJM there are unambitious renewable portfolio standards, relatively weak renewable resources, plenty of cheap natural gas and enduring market oversupply. Therefore, in PJM, there will continue to be plenty of gas build in the near future with relatively little renewable build. In other markets, where renewables are more competitive economically, the high levels of inflexible generation have already led to intermittency issues, reflected in blackouts in California and extreme price spikes in Ercot. Also in some markets, renewable penetration is high enough that power price suppression in renewable generation hours leads to systems cannibalizing their own returns.

While Argentina has taken important steps to foster its clean energy industry, important barriers remain and the country has a long road ahead to achieve its renewable energy targets. Efforts to rebuild international investor confidence are a work in progress, as Argentina continues to navigate significant economic volatility. Argentinas current crisis continues to hurt the ability of projects to obtain financing, especially those tied to the most recent auctions, RenovAr 2 and RenovAr MiniRen 3. Additionally, constrained transmission and distribution networks will inhibit new wind and solar build.

Renewable energy is hindered by Bolivia's reliance on heavily subsidized natural gas, which lowers power prices and blocks competition. The nationalized energy sector and foreign companies also lack clear incentives to grow renewable capacity, and projects must be financed without the option of PPAs. There is no in-country manufacturing capacity for solar or wind components, so those technologies must be imported.

Largely as result of economic and political instability, the Brazilian real has depreciated significantly, reaching a record low of 5.89 USD/BRL on May 12, 2020 and remaining generally above 5 USD/BRL since mid-March, down from an average of 4 USD/BRL in 2019. This has a detrimental impact on the cost of imported energy equipment and has significantly raised the capex of solar projects, while also hitting revenues of developers as power purchase agreements are in local currency.

The main barrier to renewables development remains the degree of interconnection between the two sub-systems. Interconnection is critical for enabling solar energy, in particular, produced in the northern SING sub-system and home to the best solar resources, to flow to the center of the country, where population and demand are concentrated. Curtailment of renewables began in Chile in August 2015. Since then, wind and solar power had been curtailed at increasing rates until Cardones-Polpaico was commissioned. Increasing wind and solar development and transmission infrastructure limitations will likely drive curtailment up again. Currently the country has only two transmission lines connecting the two sub-systems, with both operating at full capacity. The government is focused on increasing the flexibility of the grid to allow better integration of intermittent renewable sources.

2019 proved to be a tipping point for Colombia in terms of new pro-renewables policies and market changes, with growing interest from domestic and foreign developers catalyzed by the countrys first successful auction. However, clear barriers to renewable project development remain. Wind projects in particular face significant delays to commissioning as essential transmission infrastructure in the promising La Guajira region is held up. Home to many indigenous communities, La Guajira is an isolated and undeveloped peninsula located on Colombias northern, Caribbean coast. The region has excellent wind resources, but is poorly interconnected with the main Sistema Interconectado Nacional (SIN) grid. All of the wind capacity awarded in the auction is located there, which represents over 75% of total capacity awarded in the auction.

Formal barriers to development of renewables in Costa Rica are low. In 2010, the country established an import tax exemption for equipment and materials brought in to support renewable energy development. Law 51, which came in force in 2016, authorized power purchase agreements (PPA) for up to 20 years.

Formal barriers to developing renewables in the Dominican Republic are relatively low. An incentive regime for the development of clean energy has been in place since May 2007, consistent with the national energy plan (the Plan Energtico Nacional, or PEN). It includes an investment tax credit, external financing, tax reductions, and exemptions from taxes and import duties for industrialized goods and services. Renewable energy generators have dispatch priority and open access to transmission and distribution. However, the financial instability of the Corporacin Dominicana de Empresas Elctricas Estatales (CDEEE) and the subsidization of retail electricity prices both jeopardize project developers seeking financing. Lower power rates have also made it challenging for new energy technologies to thrive.

Ecuador faces barriers to the deployment of more renewable generation due to key characteristics of its power market. A combination of very low electricity tariffs, fossil fuel subsidies for electricity generation and low power demand growth produces a challenging environment for project developers. The country is able to meet peak power demand via its hydro capacity alone.

El Salvador has seen little economic growth since 2000, and its government is deeply indebted. Power demand has fallen from 1,093MW in 2016 to 1,001MW in 2019. High crime levels add to the cost of doing business. Moreover, El Salvador has high exposure to natural disasters, which increase operating risk.

Formal barriers to development of renewables in Guatemala are low. Tax incentives on the books since 2003 promote installations. These include import tax and value-added tax breaks for machines, equipment, materials and inputs for investment and construction; income tax breaks; and industrial tax breaks valid for 10 years from when a plant starts operating.

Haiti has faced many tragedies, including earthquakes and hurricanes, which have disabled most of its already weak electricity system. For instance, Haitis first microgrid was partially destroyed in Hurricane Matthew in late 2016. A total of 20% of the projects PV panels and all its cabling and poles were destroyed. In addition, EDH is regarded as poorly managed and corrupt, which adds to the challenges of doing business in the country.

There are limited formal barriers to renewables development in Honduras. PPAs with renewable energy generators last up to 20 years, but cannot be renewed following expiration. The condition of the countrys state-owned utility presents significant uncertainty, however. ENEE faces serious financial problems and has renegotiated earlier feed-in premiums with domestic and foreign companies owning clean energy projects in Honduras. In late 2018, the Honduran government announced an agreement to renegotiate the contracts. However, only domestic companies accepted the $0.03/kWh tariff cut. Meanwhile, ENEE continues to grapple with financial challenges. In addition, the Honduras transmission network remains shaky. On September 16, 2019, a blackout affected most SIEPAC countries and Mexico. The cause was said to be heavy storms in Honduras. The fragile conditions of Honduras and Nicaraguas transmission systems led to nationwide four-hour blackouts in both countries.

Clean energy development in Jamaica faces the same challenges as other potential investments in the country. Corruption, crime and bureaucratic red tape all can boost the cost of doing business. That said, official barriers to development of renewables in Jamaica are relatively low. Consumers with rooftop PV systems may participate in the JPS net billing program and receive the JPS avoided-cost rate plus 15% for power delivered to the grid. As of year-end 2019, 803 customers with renewable energy self-generation were grid-connected, constituting 17MW capacity. Jamaica also collects no value added tax (VAT) on components needed to build solar or wind projects.

While Mexico's energy reform has increased private participation in generation, the market remains highly concentrated in the hands of CFE, which controls approximately 54% of capacity. Efforts to strengthen state control under AMLO have raised questions around the durability of reform and undermined investor confidence in Mexicos clean energy market. An extended legal conflict around the validity of recently introduced policies raises the prospect of projects being delayed or potentially put on hold permanently. Additionally, AMLO has indicated that he may eventually support constitutional changes that would unwind energy reforms. If enacted, this would likely mean removal of benefits that renewable projects enjoy, such as CELs, and efforts to limit new renewable projects via barriers to permitting and/or interconnection. Steps to increase the power of the CFE, expand its role in planning of the grid and give priority of dispatch of state power plants would also be expected. Regulatory and policy resistance is also expected to affect the near-term growth of behind-the-meter solar. The proposed, but as yet unsuccessful regulatory changes introduced in 2020 also imposed additional barriers on distributed generation. These include regional limits on projects, additional smart inverter standards and a requirement to complete comprehensive interconnection studies aimed at identifying grid upgrades that solar owners would be required to make. While adding costs, these regulations could ultimately allow more solar to be hosted on distribution grids.

Nicaraguas general lack of direct policy supports for renewables is likely to inhibit the sectors growth in the country for the foreseeable future. The tax incentives the country offers to ease development represent exceptions and these have been extended until 2023. Nonetheless, very high power prices make it difficult to attract new business to the country. Moreover, the fragile condition of Nicaraguas transmission system jeopardizes service reliability.

Formal barriers to development of renewables in Panama are few. Since 2004, that country has had tax incentives for the construction, operation and maintenance of clean energy projects. Clean energy projects with installed capacities up to 10MW can enter into direct power purchase agreements (PPA) with the distribution utility as long as power sold does not exceed 15% of the distribution companys maximum demand.

From Paraguays total 59.2GWh generated in 2019, only 28% was directed to national consumption; the rest is exported to Brazil and Argentina. The Paraguayan power market does not have private players. The average level of import duties for components to build a solar or wind project is 14%. The average level of value added tax (VAT) for components needed to build a solar or wind project is 10%.

Perus energy consumption has been stable, averaging a 1% increase in demand over the past two years. There are indications the country is oversupplied with power assets, which would be the main explanation for the hiatus in renewable auctions. Aside from accelerated depreciation, Peru offers no tax incentives for clean energy, charging 18% of import taxes for common renewable equipment such as wind turbines and PV panels, and it collects a value added tax averaging 16%.

The main barrier to further Uruguay clean energy development is the countrys lack of growth in demand for electricity. It has already deployed significant new wind and solar capacity relative to the size of its market leaving little room for additions. During periods of 2017, hydro and wind projects were forced to stop selling power due to over-capacity issues. This created a $59 million bill UTE was forced pay because under Uruguay law, clean energy plant operators get compensated for all of their output  regardless of whether it gets put to use on the grid.

The energy sector currently faces many issues, predominantly driven by perceptions about the countrys political and security risk. This translates into high premiums for installing and commissioning projects, resulting in large funding gaps. In addition, a lack of expertise and weak public awareness about environmental issues have also not helped to propel the sector forward. As an incentivizing clean energy framework is currently not in place, more policy reforms will need to be implemented to attract large-scale project development.

Few barriers to investment exist in Armenia. There is domestic and international funding available to support projects and also tax incentives. The process to build and connect renewable energy is relatively straightforward and the domestic supply chain for PV services and equipment is gradually building. Smaller projects from 500kW to 5MW can receive licenses and a set tariff for at least 15 years. Although activity slowed when the new government came into power in 2018, steps are being taken to advance announced tenders and to update the regulatory framework for small-scale PV.

Regulatory barriers to invest in Australian power generation remain low. However, recent issues on the grid are making it more challenging to connect large-scale assets on the East Coast of the country. Policy and market uncertainties have reduced the length and certainty in offtake agreements in recent years, with many new projects now seeking to operate on a quasi-merchant or fully merchant basis. Foreign investors in large and/or key infrastructure projects must proceed through a review process, but to date, this has only resulted in the knock back of planned acquisitions in certain distribution network assets.

Azerbaijan provides tax breaks on imported renewable-energy equipment, and it has a domestic solar-panel factory. There have not been any renewables auctions, and the market is still awaiting on a standardized PPA process. The tenders that have been arranged do not have local content requirements or limit the ability of foreign companies to compete. This relatively open approach to renewables development is balanced by a slightly harder-to-navigate administrative system. Each project so far has been the object of negotiations with the authorities. The government has an informal target of 30% renewable generation by 2030, yet its unlegislated and its uncertain how high a priority it is.

Land scarcity and long drawn land acquisition processes are major barriers to investment in renewables in the country. Non-dispatchable renewable energy sources such as wind and solar have a negligible amount of grid connected capacity, thus, risks associated with grid balancing issues are low currently. If any curtailments do happen, then private independent power producers will be the first ones to face them. Bangladesh's supply chain for renewables is not well developed and is highly dependent on imports. Government subsidies for power generated from coal and gas power plants distort market pricing and increase the price competitiveness barrier for renewable energy projects.

The absence of clear regulations makes it very hard for solar developers to connect rooftop projects to the grid. Without any regulations on net metering, feed-in tariffs or export tariffs, only behind-the-meter projects with 100% self-consumption are possible. There is a hesitance to move forward with appropriate policy measures on EDCs side as the grid itself is old and not smart, and probably cannot handle a large number of intermittent small-scale resources. For utility-scale renewables, it can be difficult to obtain a generation license, which is required to export power to the grid, unless renewables can offer competitive prices.

Chinas strong local manufacturing capacity for wind and solar leaves little space for overseas players to compete. Many auctions only accept bids from companies with a significant track record in China. The government is opening up more segments of the energy sector  such as the distribution grid and electric vehicles  for domestic private and foreign investment. Even though the escalating tension with the U.S. looms large on growth, its impact on Chinas wind and solar developments, batteries and electric vehicles has been limited so far. What remains a relevant question is whether the incumbent grid companies will allow competition in the liberalizing retail power market. They have opposed the prosumer reforms since late 2017. New pilots announced in 2019 in 26 cities renew hope, though progress is still slow.

Georgia has few formal barriers to foreign investment and development. There is little domestic expertise in wind and solar, so most developers partner with a foreign business for equipment supply and construction. The political risk to new projects is low, as each one is considered individually as a proposal from the developer. New projects are virtually guaranteed a grid connection, though the operator can negotiate with developers on the location, to avoid grid constraints. Generators receive 10-year PPAs for all of their generation in the winter months. During the summer they may export their power to other countries through Georgias grid interconnections.

India is slowly increasing local content requirements for some solar projects to encourage domestic manufacturing. This is to replicate the countrys success in becoming an export hub for wind. Renewable projects can have 100% foreign investment without prior government approval. This has attracted top sovereign funds, venture capital/private equity investors, foreign utilities and oil companies to the market. Some projects have faced delays because of difficulties in land acquisition and grid connectivity. The government plans to alleviate this by creating renewable energy parks. The proposed reforms of electricity distribution companies should also reduce the large quantum of overdue payments to power generators.

Indonesia has strict rules on local content for the power sector. Solar modules and wind turbines are exempt from these rules. However, there are varying levels of local content requirements for other components, including local services. The lack of availability of local equipment and skilled workforce makes these legal requirements difficult to meet. Project development costs are also higher than in neighboring markets due to inconsistent tax incentives and high property prices that make it harder for renewable developers to undercut the costs of existing generation. Further, the Indonesian rupiah has seen high volatility against the U.S. dollar, which is a concern for foreign players if the project revenue or costs are in local currency. Developers also have to engage with multiple government agencies at the local and national level, which often delays projects. PLN, the single offtaker of power from all the grid-connected power plants, is highly reliant on government subsidies to stay afloat, which increases credit risk.
No local content rules are in place. However, a partnership with a local utility or developer is critical in offshore wind project development and stakeholder engagement.

Kazakhstans heavily regulated power market and currency risks remain as barriers in doing business. Although the government bodies are working together to address these challenges and modernize the power system, progress has been limited. The concentration of support for utility-scale renewable energy projects also limits the opportunity for small-scale and behind-the-meter renewable resources.

Opposition from local communities is one of the biggest barriers to developing power generation projects in Korea. Local communities including residents, farmers, fisheries and environmental groups often oppose power plant development, which may cause severe delays in permitting and even cancellation of projects. To address this, the government is making efforts to streamline the permitting processes and provide clearer compensation guidelines for local communities, but these measures are unlikely to fully resolve the complex challenges around local community engagement.

While there are no specific barriers, Kyrgyzstan's government and energy market players have expressed little interest in expanding the country's energy mix behind hydro and thermal generation, despite moderate solar and wind resource potential. Unless more supportive policy develops around clean energy and the country faces a power deficit (meaning not everyone will have energy access), it would be very difficult for a private-sector player to come into the country and develop a clean-energy project.

A dam collapse in 2018 temporarily put under-construction hydro plants on hold while the government investigated the incident. Work resumed in September 2018. An estimated 1GW of hydropower is under development as of 2020 and no priority has been given to other renewables technologies such as solar. Meanwhile, offtaker risk remains a significant obstacle to new projects of all types: projects with EDL as offtaker are not considered bankable due to the utilitys financial difficulties. Projects for the Thai market have been more successful because EGAT, Thailands utility, is considered a credit-worthy offtaker. However, as EGATs supply has slowly caught up with electricity demand, its interest in projects in Laos has levelled off. This means many new projects will likely have EDL or Vietnams utility, EVN, as offtaker, which will make financing more difficult.

Foreign investors are not allowed to have majority share-holding in renewable energy assets in the country. This forces foreign companies to tie up with local partners to participate in auctions and other feed-in tariff projects. Additionally, feed-in tariff projects are incentivized to use locally sourced equipment by providing bonus tariffs. Land for large-scale projects is a growing constraint, as much of the available acreage is high-value agricultural land. The average electricity tariff for residential consumers is significantly lower than that for commercial and industrial consumers. The electricity tariffs in the country have been left unchanged for the last five years. This makes it difficult for solar rooftop projects to compete in the residential segment.

Challenges lie ahead as the country works to clean its energy mix. Existing coal-fired plants have a low marginal cost of operation, and demand for additional capacity appears stagnant and easily satisfied by a few of the potential projects in the pipeline. Mongolia has no manufacturing capacity for solar or wind components. Imports of such equipment can be exempted from duties and VAT, based on their application and pre-clearance at customs. Foreign and private investment is welcome in the energy sector, but currency instability poses a risk given the tugriks history of depreciation. Policy instability, such as the upcoming revision of the renewable energy law and local administrative inefficiency, is also a potential investment barrier. Last but not least, Mongolia has four relatively independent grid regions, which adversely affect the wider dispatch/transmission of renewables output.

The major barriers for clean energy development include policy uncertainty as well as political and offtaker risks. There are no feed-in tariffs to support renewable power. Projects are subject to non-transparent negotiation with the government. Many large-scale hydro projects become a source of conflict and are held back by local protests, and this might impact future development of large scale wind projects as well. As the market is not yet liberalized, it is not clear if the state owned grid companies are willing to keep to the terms of the power purchase agreements. The 2020 solar tender was a positive move, but it was announced suddenly and gave foreign players little time to prepare for the bid.

Nepal aims to increase foreign investments in the energy sector, both in hydro and non-hydro renewable energy. Currently, the country has not been able to attract significant investment mainly because of the high risks related to the offtaker , curtailment and foreign exchange, as well as inadequate infrastructure and cumbersome government procedures. Projects under construction could be put on hold because of natural disaster and pandemic control in the country. Tariffs are not always considered to be sufficient to payback investors within a reasonable timeframe. As for foreign direct investment, China is now a new entrant with mature hydro technology and capital, but the cultural attachment of Nepal with India might prevent Chinese influence from going deeper.

New Zealand is an open and transparent market for investors in renewable energy projects and electricity infrastructure. However, a lack of activity can make it difficult for perspective investors to find openings in the market. Soft demand growth, a large amount of renewable energy penetration and sufficient levels of existing generation capacity mean investors may struggle to find new opportunities in the market, despite favourable regulation. Government programs are unlikely to offer direct subsidies to push new renewable projects in the market in the near term.

Pakistans power sector continues to suffer from inefficiencies and financial mismanagement in each segment. Off-taker risk is particularly high for generators, and investment is urgently required in transmission and distribution assets. The new government accepted a $6 billion IMF bailout in early 2019, focused on recovering costs in the energy sector and state-owned enterprises. Uncertainty over measures to implement the plan laid out by the IMF may impact investment in the country. The government is eager to grow the local manufacturing industry, but domestic business units have struggled to compete with tax-free imports from China.

The current feed-in tariff program for solar and wind has reached the targeted capacity and wont be expanded. The project permitting process may involve dozens of agencies, causing some developers to wait over five years for approval. Utilities have limited the technologies they will contract for. Legal obstacles have made it difficult to provide renewable power for behind-the-meter projects and areas with limited power. All of this hinders setting up renewable microgrids and net metering projects or entering into direct power sale agreements. Limitations on foreign ownership, a lack of transmission capacity and the Philippines archipelagic geography create additional challenges.

The market is limited in terms of scale and the slow pace of market liberalization. Project development is led by the government and public bodies. Investors looking to deploy capital to projects in the country require patience. The lack of transparency around the solar PV tenders  and the reasons for success of some bidders  is a barrier to new entrants hoping to understand the market.

According to World Bank, the foreign direct investment in the power sector is declining over the recent years due to policy uncertainties and the risk of currency depreciation. In terms of project development, the electricity act of Sri Lanka requires that the government should hold at least 50% share or certain shares determined by the Treasury and Ministry of Finance, which could potentially set barriers for both domestic and international investors. A host of pilot projects described as "exotic technologies" are in the pipeline: large-scale battery storage, ocean energy, small wind power vertical-type systems and hybrid power systems combining solar, wind and battery. Though the aspirational target of 100% clean energy is often cited, the fact is that new coal plants are part of the new long-term energy plan.

Regulators do not allow Taiwanese companies to import solar cells and wind turbines from mainland China, slowing down the decrease in project capex and levelized costs made possible by the mainland markets massive scale. Local so-called Nimby (Not-in-my-backyard) movements, taking the form of environmental protectionism, and land transfer challenges, are significant barriers to project implementation. Taipower has modified the feed-in tariff rules at least twice before: in 2010 to shorten the commissioning deadline for solar auction winners, and then in 2012-13, to renegotiate tariffs with thermal independent power producers. The Ministry of Economic Affairs also cut the 2019 offshore wind FiT, lowering the revenue for developers who secured projects in 2018, yet failed to sign power purchase agreements with Taipower before year-end. These changes increase the risks of investing in renewables in Taiwan.

There are numerous barriers to renewable energy development in Tajikistan, and market growth beyond the governments goals remains unlikely. While some policies have been introduced to support the renewables industry, the country does not have a feed-in tariff or auctions program. In addition to Tajikistans isolation, there are other barriers such as the high cost of credit and the lack of interest from foreign developers.

Thailand's power generation market is open to foreign investment. Development activities in power projects were on hold pending the revision of the PDP over the last two years. The latest PDP 2018 introduced an export tariff for residential rooftop solar, opening up opportunities in the small-scale PV sector. As much as 2.7GW of utility-scale floating solar projects are also in the pipeline. However, most of the capacity addition is planned for after 2025, limiting opportunities in the next few years.

There are numerous barriers to clean energy investment in Turkmenistan. First and foremost, the power sector is dominated by the state, making it extremely difficult for local or foreign IPPs to enter the market. Power is rationed and provided free of charge, further reducing the incentive to pursue clean energy project development. In addition, bureaucracy, and very slow processing of imports at the customs office, seriously inhibit trade.

No utility-scale clean energy projects have been developed in Uzbekistan to date, so it's difficult to gauge the development barriers that private-sector companies would face. Companies participating in the country's inaugural clean energy auctions should be conscious of challenges that will come with working with a utility integrating solar and wind power into the country's grid for the first time. A presidential decree in June 2018 listing components that are exempt from import duties doesnt mention materials used for large-scale renewables. Its unclear whether developers would need to pay import duties were they to develop a project in the country.

Vietnams power generation market is open to foreign investment with no foreign ownership cap. Equipment for renewable projects is exempt from import duties and there is a corporate tax exemption for project developers. The permitting process in Vietnam is lengthy with many different provincial and national ministries involved. Clauses in the power purchase agreement that deviate from international practices, such as the lack of international arbitration or take-or-pay arrangements, are a concern to international developers and financiers. The result of heavily subsidized retail tariffs can be seen in EVNs numbers. The absence of a government guarantee for EVNs payables presents a significant offtaker risk for some market players. Curtailment is, however, considered to be the highest risk at the moment. Solar and wind projects have congregated in the central and southern region where solar irradiance and wind resources are the best. More capacity than the grid can accommodate has been connected in some provinces, leading to curtailment for some projects.

A lack of transparency and concerns of possible fraudulent behaviors surrounding the first solar project tender led to skepticism in the market. Investors lack full confidence in contract enforcement and access to land for renewable project development. Curtailment risk is relatively low and power purchase agreements are of sufficient duration, but bureaucratic hurdles are high. OSHEE, the distribution system operator and supplier of electricity for regulated tariff customers, will act as the offtaker for new renewable projects. It is undergoing a reform, using a loan from the World Bank, to reduce its debt burden. At fault are low tariffs, electricity theft, and technical losses in the distribution system. OSHEE's perilous financial position means there is higher offtaker risk and power purchase agreements will need some form of guarantee by the government or development finance organization.

A shift toward auctions is under way, but the exact timing of the transition is unclear. Investors have little visibility on how the framework will ultimately work, adding to the uncertainty. The country has avoided retroactive renewables subsidy cuts seen in several European markets, but remains one of Europes slowest-growing markets for clean power. This is partly due to a nationwide trend  Austria has struggled to attract international capital flows, despite sporting a stable, specialized economy. Moreover, the country provides a robust framework for private investors, but setting up a company remains an onerous process. As in many EU countries, VAT rates and import duties are not reduced for renewables equipment.

The state monopoly and weak enabling framework are barriers to clean energy project development. Subsidized power tariffs could pose a further impediment to the market access of IPPs. The political events of 2020 have underscored country and political risk, which are likely to prove to be ongoing deterrents in the short- to mid-term.

Land constraints can complicate site acquisition for ground-mounted projects. Moreover, developers often struggle to navigate the various regulatory differences engendered by Belgiums federal structure. This complicates the task of accessing region-specific support mechanisms, or gauging national renewables ambition given fragmented target-setting. Yet once identified, available subsidy mechanisms are reported to be efficient. An exemption might be raised regarding the scheme governing green certificates, the trading of which was curtailed after oversupply led to plummeting prices over recent years. Meanwhile, import duties and VAT rates are not reduced for clean power equipment.

The countrys highly decentralized institutions and fragmented governance structure have long hampered the liberalization of the national electricity sector. Within southeastern Europe, BiH is consistently ranked as the worst performer in reforming its power market. A lack of communication among government departments and licensing procedures involving multiple levels of governance complicate project development. Matters are worsened by the lack of awareness of renewable energy throughout the general population, reducing the political pressure to promote its deployment. Local opposition can also significantly delay renewable energy projects, especially small hydro. In addition, the three public utilities are self-sustaining, but their financial results have worsened in recent years due to poor hydraulic conditions and ageing thermal assets. Curtailment is not an issue given the low level of variable renewables deployment to date.

Confidence in the renewables space remains fragile due to the retroactive policy intervention in 2012. The retroactive change of feed-in tariffs into feed-in premiums in 2015 had no significant impact on project revenue but added to the political uncertainty that has damaged investor confidence. Much domestic policy has focused on adding new small hydro capacity, but the country's ecosystem has already been damaged, and is unlikely to be able to support the volume of small hydro projects that have already received permits. Support for small-scale solar PV could restore some of the lost faith in the Bulgarian renewables sector.

Before 2020, the main bottleneck to clean energy investment in Croatia in the short to medium term was that the country was well ahead of its 2020 targets for the sector, whilst electricity supply and demand were broadly in balance after the recent economic slowdown. This is now set to change as Croatia has raised its decarbonization targets for 2030. Croatia continues to suffer from slow administrative procedures for clean energy projects despite improvements in recent years.

Any further retroactive subsidy cuts in the Czech Republic are now banned by the EU. However, the general public is still paying out to previous renewables support schemes, even though they closed to all but small hydro in 2014. In 2016, the cost of this support amounted to 1.4 billion euros, based on BNEF analysis. More generally, the most problematic factors to doing business in the Czech Republic are inefficient bureaucracy, tax regulations and, to a lesser extent, corruption, according to the World Economic Forum. The Czech government has pledged to cut red tape and application processing times for renewables.

There are few legal barriers to entry into the Danish power market, shown by the fact that there are several hundred local generators and around 50 suppliers active in the market. There is, for example, no local content rules to develop renewables projects onshore or offshore. However, the country promotes community ownership and has put an obligation on developers to offer 20% ownership for onshore wind farms taller than 20 meters to nearby communities. Denmark also has a cap on onshore wind turbines to be installed in the country by 2030 (1,850 turbines). This will require the number of turbines installed to approximately halve from today's installations. Since many of the onshore wind turbines in Denmark are old and relatively small, these could be replaced with fewer, higher capacity turbines to limit the impact of this cap on installed onshore wind capacity.

There are few regulatory barriers to entry for Finnish power markets. The country has been breaking down incumbent advantages in the retail sector. Distribution system operators were responsible for the smart meter rollout, which allowed the country to standardize smart meters in local regions. This made it easier for customers to switch retailers without their meters 'going dumb' and 11% of consumers now have dynamic tariffs tied to the wholesale price, which on average is 20% cheaper than standard tariffs. This has contributed to an annual switching rate of 14%. There are some constraints, however. A lack of sun during the winter makes it unlikely that large amounts of solar will be installed. Furthermore, the country is running out of premium onshore wind locations and the ease of the building permitting process varies somewhat between municipalities.

A dispute surrounding offshore wind tariffs awarded in 2012 has only recently been resolved  developers agreed to a 30% tariff cut. In September 2020, it became known that the government is seeking to shave some 600 million euros ($709 million) a year off feed-in tariffs awarded pre-2011. Although France has avoided the busts caused by retroactive cuts in other European markets, such moves reduce investor confidence even as the government targets ambitious renewables additions. Renewables additions have not reached high enough levels to warrant being curtailed, but local opposition and litigation are increasing. In response, the government enacted a range of measures to increase acceptance and overcome legal challenges over 2018-19.

Difficulties in developing new onshore wind projects are a central problem. Local regulatory barriers, widespread litigation and a lack of available land have led to a crash in onshore wind installations in recent years. This has translated to a slump in auction participation. Several attempts have recently been made to tackle this issue, whether by reducing project exposure to court cases, or increasing financial incentives for host communities. The effectiveness of such measures remains to be proven. Meanwhile, policy has flip-flopped on a number of issues, such as whether subsidies for small-scale solar would be terminated in 2020 (they were not). Meanwhile, domestic manufacturers of solar modules have long been outcompeted by international suppliers, while more resilient wind turbine makers have announced a wave of redundancies.

Greece appears to be on the road to recovering from the retroactive subsidy cuts that destroyed the market after 2014. Still, permitting bottlenecks are keeping the market from accelerating in line with investor interest. The government is taking steps to bring the permitting process down to under 2 years. Local opposition to wind projects has also been problematic. In 2017, the 154MW Kafireas wind farm was delayed for more than six months after a local environmental group challenged the validity of the project's environmental permit. Streamlining the permitting process while engaging with local interests will be a challenge as Greece aims to accelerate renewables deployment.

Clean-energy development in Hungary has been historically stifled by political gridlock,  focus on nuclear power, and opposition to renewables. In particular, several laws restrict the number of sites that can be used for wind turbines, and administrative barriers make licensing a wind farm essentially impossible. These barriers are driven by concerns around network balancing and landscape disturbance, and they have prevented the growth of Hungary's wind sector. In addition, under Metar, the premium awarded covers only the return on investment, not operating costs, and that for plants above 0.5MW, operators are responsible for grid balancing, thus increasing curtailment risk. It is also notable that the government introduced a levy of 114 forint ($0.38) for each kilogram of solar panel in order to deal with waste from discarded panels. This charge constitutes roughly 6% of the price of solar cells in the country. The history of government intervention in the power sector will also likely hinder investment.

Political and financial risk is relatively low. The government has just begun supporting renewables again with its Renewable Electricity Support Scheme, after a few years with no support following the end of Ireland's feed in tariff in 2015.  Public opposition and potential planning challenges may be the biggest barrier for project developers, particularly for onshore wind.

Italys biggest barrier to new investment is its fragmented politics, a problem that has plagued the country for decades. Lack of confidence in the government fosters uncertainty in the entire Italian economy, which in turn drags down the energy sector. Another barrier to new developments is the lack of interest in corporate power purchase agreements (PPAs). Creditworthy buyers tend to prefer market exposure to the predictability of long-term contracts. Permitting issues remain. Developers of small projects must apply with local authorities for building permits. Larger projects go through a central authority but also must liaise with local jurisdictions. Finally, Italy is notorious for being averse to onshore and offshore wind which is seen as invading the scenery and harming tourism.

Lithuania has recently removed many barriers to renewables and the liberalization of electricity prices in 2021-2023 will further support this development. Renewable energy auctions should help to drive capacity installations through 2025. As retail electricity prices are low, incentives to install residential solar panels are not as high as in other countries, but the rebate scheme that is set to run until 2023 is likely to make the investment more attractive. The synchronization to the European grid by 2025 remains a challenge.

Moldova has incorporated EU legislation into the national laws and has been quick in adopting targets for renewables and interconnection rules established by the EU. The difficulties lie in implementation, which is hard and slow because of a lack of funding and a largely state-controlled system that does not lend itself easily to modernization or change in general. The country continues to be extraordinarily dependent on electricity from non-market sources, which creates artificially low price competition for renewables technologies. The absence of a forward power market or scheduled power auctions leaves prospective developers with limited visibility on future prices.

Potential barriers to the government's offshore wind program include a lack of available sites in the North Sea, which is increasingly space-constrained and shared by multiple uses and stakeholders. Offshore power could create an over-capacity issue for the high-voltage grid on land, leading congestion to be a bigger problem as witnessed in such markets as Germany. Furthermore, the countrys high population density and substantial volumes of installed onshore wind capacity could lead to opposition against new wind farms, which could incite high levels of litigation as seen in France and Germany.

The highest barrier in North Macedonia to the expansion of renewable energy is political. New government regimes and turnover have led to lags and contributed uncertainty to the outlook for new solar and wind projects. There is also an unstable legal and regulatory regime alongside lacks of transparency on prices and other issues. Some of these have been diminished by the countrys efforts to join the European Union and expand renewable energy offerings in support of that objective. Power purchase agreements are of sufficient duration, and offtaker risk is minimal. Additionally, curtailment is not a problem.

There are few regulatory barriers to entry into Norway, as evidenced by the high number of competitors in retail and distribution. The country has almost completed its smart meter roll-out, with around 98% of metering points (2.9 million) now having one installed. This has led to increasingly dynamic retail tariffs at a lower price. This, together with an active consumer base, contributed to a customer switching rate of almost 21.4% in 2018 with around 60% of consumers having changed their power supplier at some point. Among those who never change their supplier, 15% have changed their tariffs or type of contract. The mixture of low electricity prices and high costs for materials and labor does represent a barrier, however, particularly within generation. A focus on hydro and wind also means that there is a constraint on the choice of generation technology.

Public opposition to onshore wind farms is a significant barrier in Poland, with a punitive wind act adopted in 2016 that severely limited the areas where such projects could be built. The restrictions were relaxed in June 2018, but distance restrictions remain despite longer-term targets for new onshore capacity. Poland's auction program was initially beset with delays, though these seem to have been overcome. The power sector is dominated by four major utilities, all controlled by the state, which can be called on to prioritize 'national interests' even in cases where the economics may suggest another direction. Several utilities broke off long-term contracts with renewables producers when REC prices plunged, arguing they were locked into higher tariffs that did not follow the downward trajectory of certificate prices.

Portugals relative isolation from continental Europe means export opportunities only exist to neighboring Spain. Overcapacity and limited interconnection increase curtailment risk and may pose a barrier to higher market penetration of unsubsidized utility-scale PV. France, Spain and Portugal have signaled steady progress on interconnector developments between the Iberian Peninsula and the EU internal market, but it is unclear whether these projects will mitigate oversupply. According to Bloomberg's country risk assessment, Portugal has very low financial risk but scores less positively on economic and political risk compared to its European counterparts.

Limited grid capacity, which has historically slowed renewables project delivery, has exacerbated the countrys green certificate oversupply, by not allowing for exports to neighboring countries. In addition, renewables developers have faced problems relating to land and planning due to a lack of transparency, uncertainty over ownership and red tape. Romanias program for residential solar grants was officially launched in February 2019, but it took until September 2020 before a single installation had been done through the program. The administrative issues of the grant scheme has led to financial difficulties for several small-scale solar installers.

High local-content requirements for wind and solar have proven challenging to meet, particularly for wind projects. Early auctions for wind projects were very quiet, as there was little availability of Russian-made equipment. Over time, however, these requirements have succeeded in advancing the local industry by requiring the partnership of foreign developers with local firms. The requirements have gradually risen over time, to currently 65% and 70% for wind and solar, respectively, and are expected to increase further after 2020. Currency fluctuations and weak growth in electricity-demand forecasts also act as a barrier to potential investment.

There are no obvious barriers to entry for clean energy development in Serbia. Technology capacity caps, as part of the feed-in tariff design, are the biggest challenge facing developers. Since they can secure a preliminary approval (termed 'temporary privileged power producer' status) in the capacity budget it leaves few opportunities for new developers. The administrative procedures for permitting, construction and licensing are still quite lengthy and burdensome, despite several simplification rounds. Until the Covid-19 crisis, offtaker risk was low, yet the recent temporary PPA payment freeze may prove offputting to developers.

Slovakia has no utility-scale wind farms. In 2009, investors were unable to obtain permission for projects above 10kW from the grid operator (SEPS) which considers wind unstable and prone to price fluctuations. Meanwhile, smaller turbines are hindered by regulation and legislation, including that for protected bird sites covering 23% of the country. As for PV, the government only offers household subsidy for projects up to 10kW.

The barriers to the roll-out of renewables are moderate, including the lengthy development process, lack of experience within government, and insufficient spatial planning. Such challenges are mitigated by the readily available information on the implementation process and payback of finances. The size and budget of the subsidy scheme will limit the deployment of renewables, unless a corporate PPA market emerges.

Investors have been wary of regulatory risks in Spain's clean energy market, given uncertainty around the regulated return on investment. However, the proposed rates did not fall as severely as expected in 2019. The country also faces a bottleneck with permitting for new renewable energy projects due to the very high volumes of applications. As of August 2020, more than 130GW of wind and solar projects have been granted grid access, while 117GW have had permission denied according to the system operator. According to Bloomberg's country risk assessment, Spain is a higher risk market than its mainland European counterparts, including Portugal (but lower risk than Italy), due to political and economic factors. In the past, a major barrier for small-scale renewables was the PV-plus-storage tax, which restricted financial compensation for feeding excess electricity to the grid. This barrier was removed in October 2018 by the government, and there has been a healthier pipeline of small-scale solar in Spain ever since.

Political and financial risk are low in Sweden, according to Bloomberg's country risk assessment. The government's clean energy policy is stable and provides visibility out to 2040, although there are unanswered questions around the support mechanisms with the discontinuation of the certificate scheme 10 years before. The volatility of electricity certificate prices and low wholesale power prices do make the Swedish market more challenging for investors, but corporate PPAs have been one way to overcome this issue in the short term. However, it is unclear if the PPA market will be deep enough to support the required investment in capacity to reach the 100% renewable electricity target.

Switzerland's renewables policy is stable, but the feed-in premium is oversubscribed and effectively prohibits new projects from seeking compensation. The waiting list of projects that have already applied is long enough to extend until the program ends in 2022.

Policy risk is currently a major barrier to new project development, as pre-licenses for development are only allocated via auctions. Energy policy overall has remained stable as President Erdogan consolidates his hold on power, but associated currency volatility raises offtaker risks. Turkish utilities already have considerable dollar-denominated debt, while distribution companies are required to pay the generous feed-in tariff in dollars as well. While the lira has fallen against the dollar, offtaker risk has grown accordingly. There is a risk of cuts to the feed-in tariff as the cost of the subsidy grows in relative terms. Local content requirements for renewables in Turkey are high, but the country benefits from a well-developed value chain in most sectors.

There are restrictions on the use of agricultural land for renewables projects and on the production of bioethanol by foreign companies. There also are untested rules around the ownership of strategically important energy assets by foreign companies. Probably of greater concern are risk perceptions. Political fears subsided after national elections of early 2019 took place with relative transparency and uncontested results. The governments approach to cutting the feed-in tariff though will shake the confidence of international players. The country still ranks poorly in international corruption assessments. Currency fluctuations have been a barrier to renewables deployment, though the feed-in tariff was linked to the euro to circumvent this issue. The administrative burden on foreign companies remains onerous.

Political and financial risk is relatively low in the U.K. compared to other EU countries and the U.S., according to Bloomberg's country risk assessment. Despite this, uncertainty following the 2016 referendum to leave the EU became a barrier to general investment conditions. The U.K. has closed subsidy programs earlier than planned and reduced support rates, but it does not have a history of major retroactive policy changes in the same way as several southern European countries do. Routes to market for new renewables projects can also be challenging. The government tightened rules around planning and permitting renewables projects, in particular for onshore wind farms. Of the three CfD rounds that have allocated capacity to date, only one has awarded CfDs to onshore wind and PV, and that was in 2015. The more recent rounds have been open exclusively to less mature renewable energy technologies like offshore wind. Mounting public pressure for the government to revise its policy around onshore wind has yet to create material policy change. The government also wants to strengthen the domestic supply chain for offshore wind but has not yet done so through local content requirements.

Local content requirements are the primary hurdle to the deployment of clean energy. Other hindrances are rules limited foreign ownership of joint ventures to 49% and the governments reluctance to issue sovereign payment guarantees, a concern in light of the possibility of Sonelgaz being restructured. While 2020 saw a loosening of limited foreign ownership rules in other sectors in order to attract more foreign investment, they still apply to energy and electricity. Amid its ongoing political strife, Algeria is seen as a risky market.

The 2015 Electricity Law established the legal framework for independent power producers (IPPs), and the government is working with the African Development Bank to implement a variety of measures necessary to modernize the sector and attract investment, including PPAs and feed-in tariffs. In the meantime, IPPs are still rare in Angola, and PPAs are negotiated on a case-by-case basis. The sector suffers from a number of inefficiencies: non-payment from customers is a challenge, with over 80% not metered. In addition, the cost of electricity production and distribution is high, the average consumer tariff is low, and official estimates of total sector losses are over 60%. While Angola does not have official barriers that would hinder import of renewables equipment, the average cost of importing in terms of border and documentary compliance far exceed Sub-Saharan Africa averages, according to recent surveys. Angola introduced a VAT regime in October 2019 at a standard rate of 14%.

Until mid-2018, CEB was the single buyer and producer for Benin, which discouraged IPPs from having a role to play in the market. Furthermore, the transmission grid is limited, making the development of large-scale project renewable energy projects particularly challenging. The reforms as part of the 2020 Energy Law could help to incentivize more private players to enter the market.

Botswana, much like other sub-Saharan countries, has introduced import duty exemptions for equipment and machinery including solar panels and inverters. The Manufacturing Investment Incentive is a broad policy to bolster the manufacturing sector. The incentives make no special provision for the renewables industry but do present an opportunity to develop a manufacturing industry, provided that the local market becomes more stable. Offtaker risk poses a potential hurdle to this market, as the BPC has historically run at a loss. However, more recently the BPC has managed to reduce its losses to a minimum under the guidance of the CEO, Stefan Schwarzfischer. Unlike its neighbors, Botswana has little currency risk with the pula strengthening against the dollar.

As one of the poorest countries in the world, there are multiple barriers to project development in Burkina Faso. The country is politically unstable, and a military coup caused national unrest in 2015. There are few incentives in place for development and the regulatory process can be vague. In addition, the lack of transparency, purchasing power and weak financial stability further thwart the countrys attractiveness to investors. The state utility is heavily indebted, and so there has been insufficient investment in grid maintenance and fleet modernization. The main grid is consequently unreliable and congested, leading blackouts to be a common and lengthy occurrence.

The country has faced difficulties attracting investment for energy infrastructure due to political instability and conflicts. The legal framework requires updating to attract private sector participation. The economic and political instability of the country has also affected human capital and the development of a skilled workforce. Bureaucracy and the purchasing power of the population are also an important barrier for clean-energy developers.

The main barrier to private-sector participation is the extent of Eneo's concession for generation, which limits those who can produce electricity in any given area. Another barrier is the inconsistent implementation of import duties for renewables, as Cameroon does not have an import tariff waiver. Equally, the governments prioritization of hydro development has impeded solar deployment, which has been seen as too expensive. Concerns over the impact of dry seasons on hydropower availability have encouraged the government to consider alternatives, including some demand response in the capital, Douala.

The desperate security situation in the Central African Republic significantly inhibits any form of business project. Currently, the majority of the country is controlled by armed groups, with hardly any basic services available for large parts of the population. The risks for developers and asset owners are therefore high. In addition to the lack of stability in the market, key barriers are also the absence of major policies to incentivize clean energy growth and a lack of sufficient finance and infrastructure. There are no exemptions for clean energy components or equipment. The government is considering whether to implement such measures, but this is unlikely to happen in the near future.

Chads fragile security environment is an overarching barrier to project development. Additionally, the lack of incentivizing legal framework, finance and transparency further hinder the countrys attractiveness to investors. The grid is in need of improvement and expansion prior to adding significant new-build. This has slowed down the development of the Djermaya solar plant, for example. State utility SNE is unable to recover its costs due to the mandated price subsidies, but seems to have been able to meet its contractual obligations so far.

The privatization of former public utility SNE has caused upheaval in the power sector, creating confusion with regards the assets owned by E2C and the general functioning of the new private utility. Offtaker risk was already high when SNE was a public entity, so it is unclear how reliable the newly privatized E2C will be. Fixed electricity tariffs that do not cover production costs further aggravate the issue of project viability. Finally, equipment required for renewable energy projects is taxable through both import tariffs and VAT, which increases capital costs.

Offtaker risk for power projects in the DRC is very high as SNEL, the state-owned utility, is not solvent. SNEL owns 94% of total installed capacity. This means the prospects for wind and solar developers to build new projects in the country are not very good, due to the high offtaker risk, pricing, currency volatility and political uncertainty. Additionally, poor energy infrastructure, particularly in the area of power transmission and distribution systems, makes it difficult for new entrants to scale up power production across a wider network. The DRC does not yet have any meaningful renewable energy incentives in place. Given the lack of utility-scale energy projects built in recent years, developers would also face a substantial amount of red tape. The DRC has no manufacturing capacity of any scale for its hydro or other renewable energy projects, so local content requirements do not exist. Smaller-scale companies also face import duties on off-grid solar products, unless they are granted an exemption.

In the grid-connected electricity market, only generation is open to private participation. Rules for interconnection are worked out on an ad-hoc basis with CIE. The CIE single-buyer status poses a direct barrier to the construction of mini-grids to electrify rural areas. Some 96 sites have been identified as suitable for the location of mini-grids for rural electrification (by the Rural Electrification program PDER), but it is illegal for third parties to operate them. An increasing number of mini-grids are also being integrated into the main grid as rural electrification improves in the country.

The Ministry of Finance backs utility-scale power purchase agreements signed with the Egyptian Electricity Transmission Company, which has a history of making payments in full.  Administrative barriers when dealing with government bodies have been cited as an issue in the past. That said, initial issues surrounding currency risk and arbitration have largely been resolved, leading to recent projects being completed relatively smoothly. In addition, developers benefit from reduced customs duties and VAT rates for renewables equipment. Developers must still bear some currency risk, however  only 70% of Egyptian pound-denominated tariffs are indexed to the U.S. dollar.

A variety of barriers impact clean energy deployment in Eritrea. One of the key obstacles to project development is the general security and political situation, although there are signs that it is improving following the peace talks with Ethiopia. The lack of regulatory framework in the power sector does little to counteract the countrys overall lack of transparency. The import of renewable energy components and equipment in general is a cumbersome process. Given that clean energy is completely in its infancy in Eritrea, with no incentivizing policies nor a real renewable value chain in place, there is little to attract new projects.

Financing in general is a big challenge in Ethiopia. The rapid devaluation of the Ethiopian birr has led to currency risk, and there is a general lack of a domestic and foreign commercial banking presence in Ethiopia. Most financing to date has come from traditional players in the development finance sector, like the World Bank. The currency risk also leads to uncertainty around the credibility of Ethiopia Electric Power as an offtaker. While off-grid solar products in Ethiopia are expected to be exempt from value-added taxes like the rest of East Africa, enforcement of this policy is spotty, and many importers have been dinged with additional charges. This enforcement will need to be improved to grow the countrys off-grid market.

In early 2018, the government enacted the Local Content and Local Participation Regulations (LI 2354) for the electricity supply industry, including the renewable energy sector. Non-Ghanaian companies that were already operating since before December 2017 have a grace period of five years to comply with the rule. Ghana offers import duty and VAT exemption on PV equipment, but it requires PV modules to be packaged together when they are brought into the country. Importers also report that the tax exemptions are not applied consistently and one solar company told BNEF that it pays higher import duties in Ghana than any other West African country. For utility-scale renewables, offtaker risk remains the biggest barrier as the government canceled or deferred approved renewables PPAs in 2018. Amid the oversupply of generation capacity today, Ghana is unlikely to support more renewables in the near term.

Access to finance is consistently identified as the biggest issue holding back the implementation of renewable energy projects in Guinea. Moreover, the absence of clear off-grid regulations or clean energy incentives has much to do with the countrys reliance on large hydro, and subsequent disinterest in developing renewables. A lack of experienced personnel within the project development supply chain further increases the upfront costs facing potential developers. Prospective investors must also take import duties and VAT into account, given that exemptions cannot be assured.

With less than half of bill costs recouped in addition to subsidized power tariffs, incentives for IPPs to enter the market are low. Offtaker risk is present, with payments known to be delayed. The weak grid infrastructure throws a further spanner in the works for project developers. On a macro level, perceived political and country risks are high.
License requirements may present a barrier to project developments.

Grid constraints are one of the key barriers to renewable energy integration in Jordan. The government froze renewable energy tenders in 2019, to allow for Nepco to review the feasibility of integrating more renewables into the system. Easing transmission constraints, through the Green Corridor Project, will go some way to rectifying the problem. A 900MW transmission expansion will boost the connection capacity from the renewables-rich south to the demand centers in the north. Local content requirements could prove to be another sticking point for renewable-energy developers in Jordan. A 35% local content requirement was proposed in Jordans last renewable energy tender, with tariff prices supposedly reflecting the degree of localization. Although the solar sector in Jordan is well established, there are no major wind component manufacturers in Jordan. All equipment used in renewable energy projects are exempt from import and sales tax. The National Energy Strategy also provides a 100% exemption from income tax over 10 years for independent power producers generating renewable energy.

Land access has been a challenge for both site selection and transmission connection. Developers usually spend two years negotiating with land owners to acquire land. They also need to identify the successors of the registered owners in cases where they cannot be located, which is sometimes difficult. They are not permitted to use agricultural lands. Generally, it takes a long time for administrative processes including grid connection and negotiating a power purchase agreement. For small-scale renewable energy projects, the regulatory framework only requires a permit for those with a generation capacity of 1MW or larger. Regulations for on-site generation are relatively light-handed.

Kuwait has a stable government with very low offtaker risk. The government is striving to attract foreign investment as a way to grow the local economy, create jobs, and promote technology transfer. However, the effort to grow the share of renewables in generation lacks a consolidated approach. Moreover, as the liberalization of the power sector nor the removal of power-price subsidies seem likely in the foreseeable future, this could be a hindrance to new market entry of IPPs.

In some regards, barriers to renewable investment in Lebanon remain low; so far, no tenders have stipulated local-content requirements, there are no restrictions on foreign investment, and renewable energy equipment does not attract import duties or tariffs (but it is subject to Lebanese sales tax). The country has some manufacturing capacity, but most renewables equipment will likely still be imported. In contrast to this, considerable red tape surrounds the current IPP tendering procedures and political considerations can increase the time taken to reach decisions. Finally, offtaker risk could be considerable, given the poor financial situation of EDL, in addition to curtailment risks in the form of transmission and distribution constraints in the underfunded grid.

Confusion is created by a number of overlapping energy-sector entities, including the Department of Energy, Lesotho Electricity Co., Lesotho Energy and Water Authority and Rural Electrification Unit, which results in an underdeveloped regulatory framework, a lack of equipment technical standards and slow implementation of energy-sector projects. There is also limited availability of suitable land for renewable energy development  the terrain is mountainous and access is difficult, and where it is accessible it is often already being used for agriculture or settlement.

A number of barriers are preventing clean energy from taking hold in Liberia. These include a lack of clear policy enablers, a financially-unstable utility and a regulatory commission that is still in the process of being set up. The distinct wet and dry seasons in Liberia also present challenges for planning and operating a system dependent on hydroelectric generation, which is increasingly difficult as the rainy season becomes less rainy with climate change.

Project developers face multiple challenges in Madagascar. Not only is access to finance generally limited, but administrative processes and land acquisition pose further barriers to clean energy deployment. Furthermore, the insecure nature of the grid is likely to cause stability issues for larger projects. International technical assistance has therefore recommended that most PV developers in Madagascar include a battery in their project (as in the 2018 Scaling Solar tender) and finance their connection to the grid. Finally, the state utility Jirama is the sole offtaker on the main grid and is under considerable financial stress, which creates significant offtaker risk.

Malawi's almost complete reliance on hydropower from the Shire River is a concentrated risk. If water levels remain low, the country will need a new fleet of generation assets to supply power. The local currency has experienced high inflation, which is a concern for foreign investors. There are no local manufacturers of equipment for solar, wind, or hydro, so everything is imported. To encourage renewable development, import tariffs have been removed for all renewable equipment. However, the quality of imports, especially for solar equipment, is often low or even non-functional. This has led to frustration and distrust among potential adopters of solar. Additionally, electricity theft is an issue and will weigh on developers' financial considerations.

Developing clean energy projects in Mali is inhibited mostly by the fragile security situation with multiple ongoing conflicts. The countrys clean energy incentives are also not always consistently applied, even if they offer comparatively more than neighboring countries. The regulatory framework more clearly sets out the roles of the state utility and rural electrification agency than in most other parts of the region, but a lack of transparency remains. For example, there have been instances in which privately developed mini-grids were ad hoc appropriated by the state, leading to sunk costs and frustration for investors.

Licensing and approval procedures in Mauritania are typically encumbered by strict bureaucracy, according to international agencies. Regulations can prove difficult to navigate, and there is no clear delineation between the remits of various relevant public bodies. Similarly, international donors have highlighted a lack of transparency regarding forthcoming legislation, which increases uncertainty about reforms. Other issues include the lack of an effective electrification agency, which slows down the implementation of a coherent regulatory framework to encompass private and off-grid generation. Finally, the countrys huge area and sparse population can make larger-scale project development challenging to bring about.

Moroccos political stability and business-friendly legal frameworks have combined with its excellent solar and wind resources to fuel consistent speculation on its renewables ambitions. The local content requirement of the 850MW wind tender awarded in 2016 was met, whilst also setting a world record-low tariff. Completed in 2017, the Siemens-Gamesa blade factory in Morocco is the only facility of its kind in Africa. Located in free-export zone of the port-city of Tangier, it is envisioned that this factory will enable further cost reductions for local projects in Morocco, whilst opening up export markets in Africa. The Moroccan renewable-energy agency, Masen, has been instrumental in reducing both barriers and risk in Moroccan renewables investment. Masen has borne forex risk, performed environmental studies and land preparation, issued green bonds, acted as an offtaker, and blended concessional finance to consolidate loans with debt profiles suited to both developers and Masen. All of these functions have contributed to the success of the projects to date and have helped streamline renewables investment in the country.

Developers face a difficult investment environment in Mozambique, with the country placing 138th in the World Banks ease of doing business index in 2019. A lack of standardization and clarity around licensing and concessions, the absence of a strong and independent regulator, as well as the challenging position of vertically integrated utility EDM compound a lack of incentives for renewables. Furthermore, development of vast offshore gas discoveries threatens to divert governmental resources and attention. Project development in Mozambique, whether conventional or mini-grids, remains hamstrung by a lack of regulation. Development of a power plant requires a concession from the government, while the lack of PPA standardization can result in prolonged negotiations with EDM, which is heavily indebted and undergoing major structural and operational changes. Internal politics at the state electricity company remain a potential challenge to project development.

Infrastructure limitations pose the biggest challenge for capacity additions, especially for projects over 30MW in size. Nampower recently announced that the transmission system is reaching the limits of how much intermittent generation it can sustain. The transmission system frequently experiences congestion. A new transmission line is currently under construction. No smart-grid management systems are in place, which would help with increasing intermittent generation. There are no local-content requirements for renewable-energy developers, as Namibia does not have a manufacturing industry. However, the government introduced ownership share rules that limit the share of foreign equity investment. To be eligible for the feed-in tariff program, projects need to allocate at least 30% of the ownership to local disadvantaged groups.

Security concerns inhibit project development in Niger and weaken the markets attractiveness to investors. In addition, the country offers little in terms of incentivizing policies or a robust regulatory framework for renewables, nor an accompanying clean energy value chain. Project costs are also much higher outside of the capital Niamey and bureaucratic constraints further contribute to a lack of market transparency. Low electricity tariffs and the populations lack of purchasing power further reduce the chances of viable project development.

Most major barriers to solar in Nigeria are financial, from debt availability to credit risk and foreign exchange hedges. Many developers in Nigeria wish that import tariffs were reduced and clean energy products prioritized at the ports. A proposed 'Zero Percent Import Duty for Renewable Energy Technologies' calls for a five-year import duty and VAT exemption on renewable-energy technologies, particularly solar components, which are most prominent in Nigeria. Currency-conversion risks are also substantial. Revenue for most solar projects is in Nigerian naira, which international developers need to convert to foreign currency. The Central Bank of Nigeria allocates U.S. dollars to local banks, but applies restrictions on converting naira into U.S. dollars. This poses a huge risk, particularly if a company holds U.S. dollar-denominated debt. As a result, the market is dominated mostly by local players that are more comfortable with owning naira.
