Currently, PV modules must pay a 5% import duty plus 5% VAT. Batteries are taxed a total of 27.5%, made up of 20% import duty and 7.5% VAT.

Oman has a relatively stable and open business environment. In terms of the power sector, Oman has allowed 100% foreign ownership of companies and properties, and has begun privatizing its electricity companies. While these moves can attract investment to renewable energy projects, Omans fragmented renewable-energy policies could hinder the roll-out of renewables projects. A comprehensive renewable-energy regulatory framework could help better integrate renewables projects into different power-market players. Development of renewables projects other than solar and wind and smart grid technology may help the country transition to a more diversified and efficient power market.

Resource potential, especially for PV, is high in the West Bank and Gaza, but in practice Israel's role in the Palestinian Territories is a barrier to renewables development. The importation of components to the Gaza Strip requires military authorization, and critical shortages of land make rooftop PV the only practical solution. In the West Bank, PV installations have been subject to demolition or confiscation by the Israeli military in cases where building permits are disputed. Offtaker risk is also an issue as retailers operate at a loss, and PETL, the TSO that purchases electricity from Israel, remains in debt to Israel Electric Co.

Qatar has limited barriers to develop renewable energy projects in the country. It is open to foreign investment and presents no off-taker risk as the wealthy Qatari government guarantees projects. Transmission constraints are non-existent, which limit curtailment risk. Indexation of the riyal and the dollar removes currency risk. Finding a suitable plot of land could however present a major challenge for renewable projects. Other barriers are minor, such as imported equipment being taxed and project developers being required to build the electric infrastructure to connect projects to the grid.

Being a landlocked country, importing components into Rwanda is an expensive endeavor, even if most pieces are exempt from value added tax. Access to local credit is a key challenge for off-grid companies, along with lack of purchasing power among the broader population. In addition, the Rwanda Energy Group (REG) said that it will not sign any new PPAs with developers, once the countrys estimated 86MW oversupply of generation capacity.

Besides a lack of visibility on future auction rounds, the fact that competitive auctions are only to procure 30% of renewables capacity needed to achieve the 2030 renewables target is a concern. The remaining 70% is to be overseeing by the Public Investment Fund, Saudi Arabias sovereign wealth fund. Deals with PIF are to award tariffs based on recent auction bids, keeping procurement costs competitive. But relying on opaque, bilateral deals comes at the expense of the clear investment signals which are vital to helping a nascent renewables market achieve scale. Meanwhile, local content requirements - 17% for REPDO's Round 3 - have raised development costs while doing little to stimulate domestic manufacturing.

As is common in the region, market-friendly policies are implemented at a slow rate. Off-grid developers have bemoaned the fact that import duty waivers do not apply to their products, pushing up project costs. However, developers have praised the fact that, despite lengthy bureaucratic processes, the authorities have been efficient when it comes to permitting projects. Senelec is said to pay IPPs in a timely manner and the utility is in better financial health than its regional peers, having restructured its finances while introducing a successful prepayment scheme.

The Energy Distribution and Supply Authority (EDSA) is the only organization authorized to buy power in grid-connected areas. It buys the electricity from the Independent Power Producers and collects revenue from grid customers, but since electricity is subsidized, EDSA has financing problems. Generation curtailment happens regularly due to the poor grid conditions. Finally, political risk is also important for mini-grid developers, since the Government prioritizes grid extensions over mini-grids or off-grid. Mini-grids built in an area where the grid will expand will be merged into the main grid.

Somalia's electricity sector remains almost entirely unregulated, so private power producers can enter the market without needing to compete with a national monopoly. However, the lack of national transmission or distribution infrastructure is a major barrier to developing grid-connected projects. The local workforce also lacks in technical expertise, and construction equipment is in many cases difficult to secure. Although Somaliland is more stable, the security situation in other areas is also a deterrent to investors and makes it difficult to achieve financing.

Investors remain wary of future policy stalemates, while Eskom is in a weak financial position and has yet to demonstrate its support for renewables. Eskom's financial woes continue amid weak power demand, non-payment by municipalities and governance issues - although a roadmap for unbundling the utility published in 2019 aims to resolve these challenges. Even though the 2019 Integrated Resource Plan bodes well for renewables, there are vocal opponents to so-called expensive technologies. Tariffs in forthcoming renewables auction rounds could increase, as the government imposes tougher local content requirements and there is reduced space on the grid with good resource potential.

The major obstacle to clean energy development and foreign investment in South Sudan is the ongoing fragile security situation. Moreover, the lack of an adequate transmission and distribution grid poses a serious barrier to both clean energy development and wider electrification. In addition to the security and political risks, there is significant currency risk due to the instable South Sudanese Pound. Adoption rates will remain low due to the little policy or financial means in place to support the deployment of clean energy.

Developers entering the Sudanese market face a number of obstacles  primarily the unstable macroeconomic and security situation. In addition to high capex costs due to country risk, the lack of market transparency, very low power tariffs and weak purchasing power pose further challenges to project development. The devolution of grid extensions to regional authorities impedes long-term planning, particularly given their lack of financial means to successfully plan and execute such projects. There is little visibility on future transmission projects, so many are being completed in a haphazard manner.

TANESCO is an unreliable offtaker. Many independent power producers operating in Tanzania have suffered from late payments from the utility, and there is little indication that TANESCO is working to amend this situation  in 2016 it lobbied for cheaper retail electricity to boost the countrys power demand, weakening its profitability. Another challenge is the enforcement of a value-added tax exemption for off-grid solar products. Many importers and distributors have been penalized due to unfamiliarity from tax officers, in general prohibiting the off-grid market in Tanzania from realizing its true potential. The government may look to adopt local content requirements: in October 2019, the Minister of Energy instructed the Rural Energy Agency and TANESCO to establish a plan to enable all of the equipment used in power transmission infrastructure to be manufactured in-country.

The country has limited energy value chain infrastructure, as no projects of scale have been fully developed so far. The new energy law has reduced import duties and tariffs, and encourages foreign capital to invest in Togo. The national effort and emphasis on energy sector development, carried by renewables, suggests that bureaucracy should be transparent and in favor of project developers. One major source of concern is represented by Togos two power utilities, which have experienced financial distress due to a combination of tariffs that are not cost reflective yet remain unaffordable. Poor revenue collection and operational inefficiencies are at the root of the problem. At the end of 2016, the CEET had accumulated arrears of 44 billion West African francs ($75 million) and arrears from CEET to CEB amounted to 29 billion West African francs ($50 million). Togos current grid infrastructure is also unreliable, even when energy is available, as the system suffers from ongoing voltage drops and system losses.

Uncertainties around political instability and a relatively recent law (2015) that allowed IPPs in the market are the main barriers for international investors. This indicates that support from development organizations in the form of concessional finance might be required to change the market-risk perception. Tunisia has a 0% import tax for wind and solar products from the EU and 30% for products from outside of the EU. The country also imposes a 19% VAT on wind turbines, towers, blades and PV panels, and 7% for inverters.

Several recent large-scale power projects have been dogged by allegations of corruption and opaque procurement practices. These include the 600MW Karuma and the 183MW Isimba projects, which were directly awarded to Chinese developers by a presidential decision in 2014. Uganda already has more than 1.2GW of commissioned capacity against peak load of approximately half of that amount, creating a situation of significant oversupply that will make developing further generation projects more difficult. Many donor agencies have curbed investment or set more stringent compliance guidelines for unlocking further funding. Transmission availability can be a significant risk for projects, with commissioning of transmission frequently lagging generation assets like Karuma, which is completed but awaiting interconnection. Projects with take-or-pay contracts are equally exposed to such risks if they are not connected to the grid. As a landlocked country, Uganda must import many power components overland from the port of Mombasa, Kenya, which raises costs and extends project timelines. And while many of these components are exempt from the countrys VAT, unclear guidance and enforcement prevents developers from benefiting from preferential tariff treatment as much as the government intended. While modules and solar batteries are exempt, other solar components that have applications outside of generation are not and can be subject to the 18% tax when imported independently of PV systems. Large-scale components required to build a wind farm are also not exempt, making wind a relatively more expensive technology. No wind farms have been developed in Uganda to date. A new local content law adopted in 2020 creates an obligation to give preference to local goods and services. It also creates a requirement to employ Ugandans and limits the employment of non-citizens.

As has been mentioned, state-owned utilities dominate the power sector  there is little sign that this will change. State utilities have single-buyer status, so private-to-private power deals are largely off the cards. Dubais net-metering program presents the only real option for corporate players interested in procuring on-site renewables from a private third party. The initiative has been restricted in May 2020 as the maximum system capacity was capped at 2MW, a response to a host of large systems being applied for by hotels and manufacturers. Yet, by and large, policy has been but stable and risks relating to the offtaker, currency and land negligible.

Zambia, along with most other sub-Saharan countries, has an import duty exemption on all renewable energy equipment and machinery for agriculture, aquaculture and mining. Although Zesco operates as a single-buyer monopoly, controlling almost all generation, transmission and distribution of electricity, the sector is increasingly open to IPPs. All non-hydro generation plants in the country are privately owned. The presence of the IFC and World Bank were a significant lever for the Scaling Solar auctions, which provides off-taker risk coverage and helps the country to attract investors and lenders and lower project tariffs. Power Africa has been working with African governments and private sector partners to remove barriers that impede sustainable energy development.

The Indigenisation and Economic Empowerment Act, which required that at least 51% of shares in any business be held by indigenous Zimbabweans, impeded foreign investment. In March 2018, the requirement was removed, and foreigners can now own 100% of a company in Zimbabwe except for platinum and diamond mining companies. This should open the door for more foreign investment. Corruption is a problem and it impedes international investment. A solar plant project that was earmarked to be built in Gwanda stalled after allegations that funds were misappropriated at the Zimbabwe Electricity Supply Authority.

Clean energy investment is focused around Canada's massive hydropower resources, and much of the country's clean energy policy reflects this hydro capacity. In the last decade or so, Canadian provinces have adopted various clean energy policies to increase the share of power from renewable resources and reduce emissions from the power sector. Any gaps in Canadas renewable energy goals that aren't met with hydropower resources are filled by solar and wind resources, mostly by public utilities or large independent power producers. Thanks to transparent tariffs and energy data, investment in Canadian energy markets is diverse and competitive.

The U.S. is the second-largest investor in clean energy in the world, setting a new record at $55.5 billion of investment in 2019. Renewable energy generation accounted for 18% of the total U.S. power mix in 2019, up from 10% in 2010, and has accounted for 56% of all capacity expansion in the last decade. This increase is driven largely by wind and solar investment and expansion, particularly in Texas and California; wind and solar build has hit around 20GW annually for the past few years and the combined generation of these two technologies rose by 13% in 2019 alone. Through the ITC and PTC, the rapid development of renewable technologies across the board cost the federal treasury around $8.7 billion in 2019. One driver of investment in the U.S. in particular is the corporate procurement of clean energy, a rising trend in which corporations purchase clean energy through power purchase agreements (PPAs), largely in Texas. In 2019, 13.6GW of corporate PPAs were signed, with Google signing 1.7GW alone.

A scarcity of capital, price-distorting subsidies and political risk combined to make Argentina an unappealing destination for clean energy investment in the first half of this decade. That began to change in December 2015 with the election of President Mauricio Macri. The Macri government sought to cut subsidies and liberalize energy markets to spur conventional and renewable project build underwritten with foreign capital. FODER, created under the administration, was backed by the World Bank, which provided guarantees of payment for the renewable tenders. The guarantees boosted confidence among foreign debt providers. Only then did Argentina begin to see financing for renewables, attracting over $6 billion since 2016 and peaking in 2018 at $2.5 billion, a record for the country. Recent progress notwithstanding, Argentinas latest economic crisis has kept investors away and created severe difficulties for auction-winning projects that have yet to secure financing.

Development of clean energy projects in Bolivia is led by state-owned Empresa Nacional de Electricidad (ENDE), with investment coming from international development banks and the Central Bank of Bolivia. The role of solar generation solidified in 2018, as ENDE commissioned 65MW in Tarija and Potos departments, a large increase compared to the 5MW project in Pando installed in 2015. A 50MW PV plant, financed by European development agencies, was also commissioned in Oruro in 2019. Bolivias first wind farm, Qollpana phase I (3MW) was commissioned in 2014 with a second phase (24MW) brought online in 2016. A pipeline of four wind projects, financed over 2017-18, may further the addition of 132MW of new capacity in the near term.

Brazil attracted almost $58 billion in new asset finance for utility-scale clean energy plants in 2010-19, by far the largest in Latin America over the period. Wind alone accounts for 58% of the total, while utility-scale solar attracted 9%. Distributed PV attracted another $3.2 billion over 2016-19, with 2019 accounting for over 71% of this total. Brazilian national development bank BNDES has played a major role in the development of the countrys renewable energy market. The bank is the top global lender to clean energy, having disbursed almost $24 billion for renewable energy projects (excluding large hydro) between 2010 and 2019. However, the bank had changed the methodology it uses to calculate interest rates. Those are now slated to increase gradually for new loans through 2023 until they reach par with commercial levels. Between now and then, we expect BNDES contributions to fade somewhat as private capital takes a more prominent role.

Chile attracted $16 billion in new clean energy investment over the last seven years. In 2019 alone, the country registered a record of $4.9 billion, up four-fold on the previous year. The country was the second-largest destination for new investment in clean energy in Latin America in 2019, overtaking Mexico. Chile has many types of financial organizations investing in renewables, with development banks, commercial banks and project developers all playing significant roles. The U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) has been the main lead arranger in the country. Although distributed PV generation expanded in 2019 to 42MW from 22MW in 2018, uptake of the technology remains nascent in Chile. In an attempt to boost distributed generation, the government expanded the size limit for installations from 100kW to 300kW in 2018.

Most investment directed to non-hydro renewable energy in Colombia to date has come from international development banks. From 2011 to 2019, Colombia attracted $1.3 billion in investment, with a substantial increase in non-hydro investments seen in 2018, in anticipation of the countrys first auction and other positive policy developments. Solar accounted for the entirety of this investment, attracting $200 million. Investment is expected to regain highs in the coming years as auction projects progress.

Costa Rica attracted $2.1 billion in new-build clean energy investment over 2010-2018. Over a third of that capital was directed to small hydro plants ($0.8 billion), followed by geothermal with $0.6 billion and wind with $0.6 billion. Investment peaked in 2014 with almost $0.6 billion provided to the three technologies, but dropped by half in 2017. In 2018 Costa Rica attracted only $13.5 million to its clean power sector.

The Dominican Republics clean energy sector attracted $1.5 billion of investment over 2010-2019. Wind captured the bulk of it, $764 million, followed by solar with $438 million. Over half the investment was recorded 2017-2018. In 2019, investment dropped to $138 million from $405 million the year prior. Most of the countrys renewable energy projects to date have been financed by project developers and multilateral investment banks. Commercial banks have had limited participation.

Investment in clean energy in Ecuador has been limited. From 2011 to 2017, the total invested amounted was only $489 million, mainly in small hydro assets. In 2018, the country did not receive any investment. In 2019, it attracted $100 million for wind projects. Development banks Inter-American Investment Corporation and Corporacin Andina de Fomento (CAF) are the biggest lead arrangers in the country, mainly investing in small hydro.

El Salvador clean energy attracted $1.1 billion in investment 2010-2019. Over half that was directed to PV plants, which received $663 million, followed by $261 million for biomass and waste projects. Largely due to successful recent clean energy auctions, over 71% has been deployed 2016-2019. In 2019 alone, El Salvador clean energy attracted $85 million, all for wind projects.

Guatemala attracted $1.4 billion in new-build clean energy investment 2010-2018. Over half ($728 million) the total was directed to biomass and waste projects, followed by small hydro with $343 million and solar with $173 million. Investment peaked in 2014, with $657 million provided. It then dropped continuously over the next four years, with no investment recorded in 2018 and 2019.

Haiti lacks specific legislation mandating microgrids and this has both slowed project development and kept risks high. Regardless, microgrids are appearing on the island. One, financed by the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB), the United Nations Environment Program and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), links the towns of Cteaux, Port--Piment and Roche--Bateaux and is managed by a newly created electrical cooperative. Another in Feyo Bien, is supported by IDB. Both microgrids are powered by hybrid PV-diesel generators. Sigora Solar has also developed a diesel generator-powered microgrid in Mole Saint Nicolas, to which it will add solar generation shortly. In 2019, the government of Haiti and the World Bank established a new financing instrument to incentivize private companies to develop clean off-grid energy projects in the country. With $17 million in funding, it aims to provide electricity to 200,000 households in the next 10 years.

From 2010-2019, Honduras clean energy attracted $2.7 billion in new investment, driven by $1.3 billion for solar from 2014-2019. These investments were boosted by a feed-in premium for renewables that came into force in August 2013. PV projects up to 300MW in size installed by July 31, 2015 were eligible to receive a base price for their energy equal to the short-term marginal cost plus $0.03/kWh plus 10%. However, this policy was cancelled in 2018 due to financial problems faced by state utility Empresa Nacional de Energia Electrica (ENEE).

Jamaica attracted $0.3 billion in new-build clean energy investment from 2010-18. Wind power accounted for the highest share of that ($180 million), followed by solar with $127 million. Wind investment peaked in 2015 due to renewable energy auctions. In 2019, Jamaica received no significant clean energy investment, but that is expected to change in 2020 and beyond once the country issues RFPs to hit its clean energy target.

Prior to the AMLO era, Mexico became a leading destination for clean energy investment due to a large increase in opportunities brought about by energy reform. Though efforts to strengthen state control at the expense of the private sector under AMLO have begun to deter investment, Mexico continues to see development activity. The second largest power market in Latin America, Mexicos installed renewables capacity represents 15% of its 88GW total. This share is expected to grow with ongoing investment, which is continuing despite the cancellation of the countrys auctions. The countrys three auctions held over 2016-17 catalyzed investor interest in the countrys strong wind and solar resources, producing a step change in Mexico new clean energy investment from 2017 on, which has averaged nearly $5bn per year since then. Mexicos financing landscape is diverse, with project developers, commercial banks and development banks all playing important roles. Both wind and solar projects have been successful in attracting investment. However, steps taken by the current administration have underscored its opposition to private investment in the power sector. Wind and solar, which are closely associated with market-opening energy reform and private investment, are all but absent from the CFEs current portfolio and pipeline. Official plans for the CFE are focused instead on revamping its large hydro fleet and expanding its fossil fuel portfolio, primarily with gas plants.

Nicaragua enjoyed a clean energy investment boom during the first half of the 2010s. The country attracted $942 million for new projects from 2010-16. Wind projects accounted for a third of the total, followed by small hydro with $218 million and geothermal with $215 million. The years since have been considerably quieter with no meaningful investment in projects registered in 2017-18 and just $2.1 million for solar projects in 2019.
Panama's clean energy sector attracted $1.78 billion in investment 2010-2019. Solar and wind installed capacity have jumped from virtually nothing in 2013 to over 460MW in 2019.
Because large hydro more than meets its needs, the country has not received significant clean energy investment in recent years. In 2011 Paraguay received $28 million for biofuels investments.

Peru attracted $3.2 billion in clean energy investment from 2010 to 2019. Most went to small hydro and onshore wind projects, equivalent to 35% and 22%, respectively, of the total. However, from 2016 to 2019, solar attracted most investment, registering $252 million in the period, compared to $165 million in wind. Peru saw a peak in investment throughout 2012-2014, mostly led by financing of auction projects. In recent years, clean energy investment in the country has faded, dropping to $300 million in 2017 and less than $2 million in 2018. In 2019, Peru attracted only $51 million for wind projects. The country has received capital from international and national commercial financial institutions, as well as development banks. The biggest lead arrangers are U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) and European Investment Bank, registering $235 million and $213 million on PV and onshore wind.

From 2011-2018, Uruguay received $4.5 billion in clean energy investment from commercial and international development banks. In 2015, annual clean energy investment hit a high-water mark at $1.2 billion with over 90% directed to wind plants. Just three years later, in 2018, renewables investment fell to what was then a low of just $5 million. In 2019, however, BloombergNEF recorded no substantial new clean energy asset financing in the country.

Clean energy investment in Afghanistan has been very limited to date, with the most significant deal so far being a $330 million small hydro investment in 2014. Over the past decade, the sparse investment has originated almost exclusively from foreign investors that mainly target solar projects. The major funders behind these projects are international donors such as the Asian Development Bank or USAID.

Investment in utility-scale PV is on the rise thanks to several auctions. Spains Fotowatio Renewable Ventures BV won Armenias first auction to develop the 55MW Masrik-1 PV plant in 2018, backed by the Scaling up Renewable Energy Program (SREP) and the World Bank. A further 55MW government-led tender is likely to be opened at the end of the year to support five smaller projects. The Armenia Renewable Resources and Energy Efficiency Fund (Anif), a non-governmental entity, is also running a tender for 200MW PV. Wind development has stalled following a decrease of the wind feed-in tariff from $0.09/kWh to $0.05/kWh in 2019. Since 2016, the Renewable Resources and Energy Efficiency Fund has provided concession financing for small-scale clean energy and energy efficiency programs.

Investment in Australian clean energy has seen a boom and bust over the past decade. Small-scale investments, supported by state-based feed-in tariffs and a federal SRES program, have frequently outpaced large-scale assets on an annual basis. Large-scale investment soared to new heights in 2017-18 after years of policy uncertainty which froze investment but then caused a rush-to-market of companies looking to secure sufficient capacity under the LRET policy. Sovereign capital plays a limited but important role in investments, with the Clean Energy Finance Corporation and the Australian Renewable Energy Agency seeking to catalyze private capital into clean energy.

The growth rate of renewables investment has been very small and largely focused on onshore wind and some solar. Investments have been supported by international development institutions like the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), as have many of the regulatory and legislative reforms aimed at stimulating investment. Financing has been made available to local banks through the development institutions. Royal Dutch Shell and Equinor have expressed interest in supporting or investing in renewables development in the country. Their existing experience in Azerbaijan means that they have a distinct advantage due to their familiarity with the relevant power authorities.

Clean energy investment in grid-connected projects is starting to pick up in Bangladesh  money is also flowing into some renewable projects, particularly solar. No new wind plants have been installed in Bangladesh in many years and there have been no announcements of new projects either. Land constraints, high equipment costs and lack of domestic supply chain are deterrents. Almost all renewables financing is provided by domestic lenders that in turn have access to credit lines from multilateral institutions and development banks like the World Bank and International Finance Corporation. IDCOL is the biggest recipient and disburser of renewable financing.

Like its neighbor Laos, Cambodia has directed power sector investment towards large hydro and coal-fired power plants, as well as transmission and distribution, to support electrification. Non-hydro renewables investment has been slower to take off. However, a drought in 2019 that caused wide-spread blackouts for months in a row, and growing power demand, made the government change direction. In February 2019, a 100MW solar tender kicked off. Grid-connected solar capacity has reached 150MW as of April 2020. More solar and onshore wind projects are in the pipeline. The investment in solar is expected to increase rapidly in the coming years. There are few Cambodian banks or other financial institutions with the ability to support renewable energy projects at present, although some small banks, with assistance from Japanese parent companies, are hoping to increase the availability of domestic financing with capacity building.

China's decade long clean energy investment rally snapped in 2018, as major policy revamps slowed the speed of wind and solar installations. A transition period is underway currently to phase out government subsidies. State-owned companies have grown their dominance in Chinas clean energy investments, with private investors narrowing exposure to a slowing market. China's clean energy investments are likely to stabilize, if not decline slightly, in the coming years on the back of stable new wind and solar installations, before subsidy-free economics and grid dispatch reforms boost further growth.

Financing is well-established and widely available for hydro projects, in which the country has domestic expertise. Wind and solar projects use both domestic and international concessional financing from the Georgian Energy Development Fund (GEDF) and USAID. The potential for new wind and solar development is bringing in European players. The wind and solar plants in operation have been majority-financed by the GEDF as demonstration projects.

New clean energy investment in India totaled $10.5 billion in 2019, which was 11% lower than 2018 as the costs of renewable energy projects declined. Solar continues to attract over 50% of the investments. Indias ambitious clean energy targets, stable policies and the favorable economics of renewables draws domestic and foreign capital. The investors in Indias clean energy sector are diverse  including sovereign wealth funds, pension funds, domestic power producers, oil majors, domestic conglomerates, private equity firms, development finance institutions and foreign utilities. Power producers are now looking to unlock equity invested in operational projects by bringing partners into joint ventures and setting up investment infrastructure trusts.

Indonesia has seen very limited investment in solar and wind power since 2015. These two technologies accounted for less than a quarter of all new clean-energy investments in the country during 2015-19. Geothermal power projects constitute the majority of clean-energy investments. Vena Energy commissioned two solar power projects with a cumulative capacity of 28MW in 2019  the only new utility-scale renewable energy projects commissioned that year. There is interest from commercial banks to participate in the renewables market but their involvement has been limited due to lack of investment-grade projects.

New investment in the clean energy sector in Japan has halved in 2019 since the peak in 2014. The boom between 2013 and 2015 was mainly due to the generous subsidy scheme. As the tariff rates dropped and competitive auctions became the norm, the investment volume also plunged. With the shift to the feed-in premium scheme from 2022, new investment to solar may be further limited while offshore wind could make up for the loss of solar, depending on the design of site tenders and grid connection.

Renewable energy capacity, excluding large hydro, has grown to 1,050MW in 2019 from just 135MW in 2010. More than 90% of the added capacity during this period came from utility-scale solar and onshore wind. Foreign institutions, notably the EBRD, have contributed to the majority of new renewable energy projects. Key priorities for the EBRD in Kazakhstan include supporting the countrys efforts in regulatory reform, addressing utility tariff setting and expanding renewable energy. Renewable energy auctions, held by Kazakhstan Electricity and Power Market Operator (Korem), have been the main driver for clean energy investments in the country since 2018. Currency risk associated with the Kazakhstani tengi, which depreciated 14% against the U.S. dollar in 2018, continues to be a challenge for renewable energy developers as well as for the bankability of the power purchase agreements in the country.

Koreas clean energy sector attracted some $2.4 billion of investment in 2019 with the majority flowing into utility-scale solar and wind projects. Annual investment has been relatively stagnant since 2016 as falling capex of renewable energy projects mostly offset the annual growth in capacity additions. Korea's 2030 renewables target aims for an injection of some $101 billion into the clean energy sector. The government vowed to provide $17 billion-loan for small-scale power providers. State energy firms, including Korea Electric Power Corp., will invest $47 billion to build new facilities. The government expects the remaining $37 billion to come from the private sector.

Over 80% of Kyrgyzstans capacity mix comes from large and small hydro projects, and almost no new capacity has been built in recent years.  JSC Electric Power Plants oversees generation and owns and operates almost all of the country's existing power generation, with no private sector involvement to date. The countrys Forty Steps program calls for the construction of 11 additional small hydro projects with a capacity of 161MW by 2021. No further announcements on these projects have been made since 2017.

The power market in Laos is currently oversupplied with carbon-free hydroelectricity, leaving little incentive for the government or local companies to invest in non-hydro clean energy technologies. The bulk of recent power sector investment  in large hydroelectric facilities and a single coal-fired plant  has been financed by Thailand and Vietnam for their own consumption. Only one 10MW solar project has been built to date in Laos, by a local company (EDL-Gen) but with significant support from international partners. China, Thailand, Japan and Vietnam are dominant players in the market. There is little to no domestic concessional financing available, and few banks in the country have the capacity to finance power projects.

The various policy initiatives like feed-in tariffs and auctions, along with tax and other incentives like the Green Technology Financing Scheme, have contributed to the growth of clean-energy investments. About $0.3 billion went into renewable energy projects in Malaysia in 2019. Solar projects continue to garner the most interest, biogas and small hydro have good potential, and biomass consists of mostly legacy assets. In June 2017, the country also issued the worlds first green sukuk (Islamic) bond, which was used to finance large-scale solar projects awarded under the first auction for that technology. Investments may pick up in the next few years on the back of government auctions and the new plan to promote rooftop PV projects.

Mongolia could potentially produce 8,000 TWh of wind power per year and 5,000 TWh of solar power. However, renewable energy investment began late in Mongolia, and remained limited, amounting to just $200 million over 2010-16. Then, a new investment record was set in 2017, at nearly $100 million, with a mild slowdown again in 2018. Due to the nascent state of the renewables sector, the vast majority of investment has come from international development banks and foreign governments. The single largest investor is the European Bank for Reconstruction & Development (EBRD), responsible for over a cumulative $120 million, and the largest local developer is Newcom Group. If the country is to meet its renewable energy target, it will need extra push for new investments in the coming years.

Myanmar's clean energy investment has been dominated by overseas concessional finance from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. Besides, utilities from China, Europe and Southeast Asian countries are investing and developing renewable energy projects in Myanmar.

Various funds have been set up by the government for the development of renewables, such as the Central Renewable Energy Fund and the Small Hydro Power Fund. However, the official authorities admitted that the lack of mobilization of credit and high dependence on subsidy has been hampering further investments in renewable energy. With huge potential of hydro and some wind,solar available, the country focuses on attracting foreign investors and drawing private players into the market. International donors such as World Bank, Asian Development Bank and UN have financed projects in the past, and policies and subsidies have been introduced to promote foreign direct investments as well. The country needs to attract more than 28 trillion Nepalese rupees ($268 billion) in foreign capital into the energy sector by 2045, according to estimates quoted in Nepals Investment Summit. China became a new major investor in Nepal with its own hydro technology and funding.

Hydro and onshore wind generation have dominated clean energy investment in New Zealand to date, due to their favourable economics and an abundance of high-quality resources. A fully liberalized market has resulted in most investment coming from the private sector, catalyzed by supportive regulations and government targets. The bulk of generation in New Zealand is owned by a handful of utilities: Contact Energy, Mercury Energy, Genesis Energy, Meridian Energy and TrustPower.

Clean energy investment in Pakistan peaked in 2015 and has been falling since. Some 300MW of new wind, solar and biomass was installed in 2019, down from 700MW in 2016. Wind has dominated Pakistans renewable energy market, while investment in utility-scale solar has been slow to follow. Rooftop PV installations have picked up pace as a means to avoid frequent power shutdowns and save on electricity costs. Overseas investors active in Pakistan's clean energy sector include Zonergy and Three Gorges from China and Zorlu Enerji from Turkey. Most projects rely on some form of concessional financing.

The Philippines has seen scattered renewables investment. Geothermal and hydro initially made up most of the build, but spiking demand caused the government to lean towards conventional power. Epira officially opened up power generation to the private industry in 2001. Since then the generation sector has been dominated by three major players. The country has had difficulty financing renewables due to the challenging policy environment as well as infrastructure constraints. The government allows no more than 40% foreign ownership in projects. For developers, becoming a Qualified Third Party or an Independent Power Producer is not easy, and bottlenecks in permitting make it difficult to secure financing for projects.

The SolarNova program has been the driving force for solar PV adoption. The first four tenders under the program, awarded in 2015, 2018 and 2019, yielded 236MW of capacity. A fifth tender that is pending award will add another 60MW of capacity. While not officially disclosed, it has been reported that the winning bid for the third tender was close to zero. This underlines the confidence that developers and investors have of recovering costs through the sale of excess generation. This excess can be sold into the wholesale market or directly to commercial and industrial customers. Apples agreement with Sunseap to power 100% of its Singapore operations with renewable-sourced electricity from the latter is an example of the direct sale model.

A large portion of Sri Lankas solar and wind projects are financed by domestic banks including DFCC Bank, Hatton National Banks and so on, as domestic investors are more willing to accept the small scale of non-conventional renewable energy projects and the risk allocation under the power purchase agreements or PPAs. These small sized projects of up to 10MW have been attracting private investment from local developers. However, multilateral lenders like Asian Development Bank, World Bank and International Finance Corporation are also playing significant roles in clean energy investment in Sri Lanka especially in large utility scale projects that require sizeable capital, lending funds and providing technical assistance in power sector reforms, renewable energy development, etc. ADB supported the development of a 100MW wind farm in Mannar Island as well as the Rooftop Solar Power Generation Project back in 2017.

Solar has so far attracted most of the clean energy investment in Taiwan though investment in wind is poised to grow significantly, largely because the government auctioned 5.5GW of offshore capacity in 2018. Taiwans local banks have lent to solar projects, and are becoming comfortable with offshore wind assets. BloombergNEF estimates that offshore wind investment totaled $7.8 billion in Taiwan in 2019, which pushed clean energy investment in the island market to a historical high and made it the second biggest market for offshore wind investment in the world that year, after mainland China.

Tajikistan has not seen any serious investment in renewable energy, with the last deal dating back to 2015. Although the government has called for the construction of small hydro plants and other sources of clean power, no renewables capacity aside from small hydro has come online. The Asian Development Bank approved a $10 million grant in 2013 to support green energy solutions in households, and Pamir Energy, a public-private partnership company, is investing in small hydro projects in rural parts of the country.

Stimulated by the attractive feed-in premium, also known as the 'adder', introduced in 2007, renewable energy capacity has grown significantly. Within two years of the release of the 2015 Power Development Plan (PDP), Thailand had installed almost half of its 2036 renewable energy capacity target. Among all technologies, solar accounts for majority of the growth. In the initial years of renewable energy expansion, there were concessional financing programs from the Clean Technology Fund, Asian Development Bank and International Finance Corp. Over the years, Thailand's conglomerates actively participated in the development of renewable energy projects. Local commercial banks have supported the energy transition in Thailand, and have actively financed projects in the country.

There are effectively no clean energy investments in Turkmenistan to date, and the investment climate is not very conducive. Turkmenistans policy of providing highly subsidized power limits commercial viability of renewable projects. Development finance institutions have been involved in strengthening the grid infrastructure.

Just 2%, or 215MW, of Uzbekistans power generation capacity comes from small hydro, the only operational renewable technology on the grid. Change is on the horizon, though: Masdar Clean Energy won the countrys first clean energy auction for a 100MW solar project, and Total Eren and Helios have negotiated contracts for 100MW and 40MW solar projects, respectively. A February 2021 auction  is expected to award two more 200MW solar projects, and a third auction will award 500MW of solar. The country also has soft plans to modernize 27 of its existing hydro facilities and build 35 more. All of these will lead to a fresh injection of clean energy investment in the coming years.

Vietnam has emerged as a hotspot for clean energy investment within Southeast Asia, driven by solar developments. Between 2012 and 2017, wind attracted $1.5 billion in investment, but only 189MW of wind was installed at the end of 2017. The introduction of the solar FiT in 2017 led to a solar boom over the last two years. The state utility Vietnam Electricity (EVN) reported 82 projects with a combined capacity of 4.46GW connected to the grid by June 30, 2019, achieving more than five times the countrys 2020 target. Activity in onshore and offshore wind development is picking up too after the upward revision of the FiT, with 7.8GW in the pipeline. In the infancy of the wind industry, development banks such as KfW and Vietnam Development Bank provided financing. There has been an increase in financing of renewable projects from local banks such as Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam, Vietnam Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development and Vietcombank over the last two years. Despite concerns over certain clauses in the power purchase agreements, financing from regional and foreign banks for renewable energy projects in Vietnam are on the rise.

Albanias renewable energy auctions began in 2018, but scaling and growing these has been slow. In 2020, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development helped support and prepare a tender for a solar energy project, which received a competitive price. The winning bidder was French company Voltalia. Albanias first solar auction, which was conducted in 2018, was also awarded to a foreign investor, but contention surrounds this transaction and it has not yet led to construction. Small hydro tends to draw largely domestic investors, while large hydro draws foreign ones.

Yearly investment in renewables fell to $0.3 billion in 2019, in tandem with technology costs, as new installations continued. Recent years have seen solars share grow substantially relative to onshore wind. Publicly owned players are the foremost project owners in terms of renewables capacity, with Land Burgenland and Verbund topping the ranking. By far the largest credit provider is the European Investment Bank, which has committed over $1.1 billion in clean energy projects as of the second quarter of 2020. The EIB is followed by Italian financial group UniCredit, and then a host of smaller domestic lenders.

Belarus has secured a small, yet steady amount of clean energy investment activity in the past decade. Small biomass and biofuels investments dominated in the late-2000s, while the most significant deals to date were small hydro investments at the beginning of the decade, in addition to a large solar deal in 2019. Wind investment has been slowly picking up since 2017.

Investment in Belgian renewables has varied over recent years  yearly investment has fluctuated from under $1 billion to $3.2 billion since 2016. This is largely caused by large jumps in offshore wind investment, with the amount going into funding PV remaining largely constant year-on-year. Belgiums acquisitions market is particularly dynamic, attracting nearly twice as much funding as new build over 2019 through to the second quarter of 2020. Historic players such as Engie and EDF own the largest chunks of renewables capacity. Meanwhile, a range of international lenders provide credit, diversified across Belgium, France, Germany the Netherlands and Japan. However, topping the ranking is the European Investment Bank, which has invested a total of $2.3 billion in the Belgian clean power sector.

The countrys first wind farm  the 50.6MW Mesihovina project  was commissioned in early 2018. The facility was built at a cost of $101.4 million. Siemens Gamesa provided the turbines and the project was primarily financed through a loan provided by KfW, a German state-owned development bank. Another wind farm, Podvelezje I, was financed in 2018. A July 2018 tender for the construction of a 65MW solar project was cancelled due to lack of bids. Most renewables investment has come from international concessional lenders, including International Finance Corp., the European Investment Bank and European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. In addition to domestic funds and government grants, organizations such as the United Nations Development Program, GIZ and USAID provide co-financing as well as technical assistance. Some small hydro projects are financed by local banks.

Clean energy investment remained at low levels and reached approximately $125 million in 2019, with the majority going to a waste-to-energy plant in Sofia. Bulgaria has recorded no significant volume of clean energy asset finance since the government introduced retroactive cuts to renewables subsidies in 2012. This followed a small renewables boom during which solar attracted $3.3 billion in investment and onshore wind $2.5 million between 2008 and 2012. The government did not allocate any new budget for clean energy investment before 2020 as the country is ahead of its target, but has announced that small-scale solar (<30 kW) will be supported after July 2020. The electricity component of Bulgaria's 2030 renewables target was recently increased to 30% after the European Commission urged the country to raise its ambition. Increasing solar investments would help meet this target, given the countrys sunny weather.

Croatia witnessed a small investment boom between 2010, the year after the new energy strategy was ratified, and 2014 when the regulator decided to cap the availability of feed-in tariffs. The wind sector attracted $842 million of the $1.015 billion in clean energy investment since 2010. This is to be credited to the more generous incentive for utility-scale onshore wind assets than for solar projects. BloombergNEF expects a boost in Croatias renewables investments as auctions for feed-in premiums and guaranteed purchase price take off.

Almost three quarters of new clean energy investment from 2004-2019 went to solar projects, totaling $5.5 billion. The Czech Republic saw a peak of $2.8 billion invested in 2010, although retroactive subsidy cuts brought funding levels crashing down, with financing plummeting to an average of less than $50 million a year between 2011 and 2019, among the lowest level in the EU. European commercial banks have been responsible for most loans to renewables projects, with Erste Group Bank and Commerzbank topping the list. In addition to dominating the power market as a whole, state-owned CEZ is the biggest renewables asset owner in the country.

Denmark's clean energy sector attracted $16.7 billion of investment from 2010-2019 (excluding acquisitions) but this total was not spread evenly throughout the period, with bumper years in 2011, 2014 and 2016. The main reason for the uneven distribution is the timing of financing for major wind projects. BNEF has tracked a total of $9.8 billion invested in the wind sector between 2004 and 2019, while solar PV received $3 billion in the same period. That was largely due to a boom in 2012, however, driven by a net metering scheme. Biomass and waste is the second-largest sector in terms of investment. The sector is important to Denmark's distributed heat sector and has been a popular fuel switching option for coal power plants (which must be phased out by 2030), and attracted investments worth $3.6 billion in the 2004-2019 period.

Finland attracted $9.5 billion of new clean energy investment over 2010-20, of which wind secured 59%. Wind capacity almost quadrupled since 2015, reaching 2.3GW by the end of 2019. Wind investments totaled over $2 billion in the past two years. The biomass and waste sector has also seen some investment, with more than $500 million invested in 2018. Finland is increasingly looking toward offshore wind as it is running out of suitable areas onshore. A 42MW pilot project of the worlds first offshore wind farm in icy winter conditions was commissioned in 2017.

The first two quarters of 2020 saw a leap in investment in clean energy to $6.7 billion, the highest level since 2011. That was largely the result of a jump in investment in offshore wind as the first projects reached financial close. Investment in PV has been constant over recent years while that in onshore wind has continued to grow. National champions Engie and EDF, which operate 5GW between them, are the top project owners by a sizeable margin. Japanese and German credit providers have made inroads in recent years, but domestic banks Crdit Agricole, BNP Paribas and Socit Gnrale top the rankings for renewables lending.

Clean energy investment has reduced in line with technology costs, but also due to difficulties in bringing onshore wind projects to financial close. Investment in onshore wind tumbled from $12 billion in 2017 to $3 billion and $2 billion in 2017 and 2018, respectively. Investment in solar has, for its part, remained stable over recent years. KfW, Germanys development bank, is the largest provider of credit for clean energy projects, followed by Hamburg Commercial Bank and the European Investment Bank. Meanwhile, historic heavyweights such as RWE and EnBW top the rankings in terms of renewables capacity owned, with renewables-focused players like Enerparc and Orsted close behind.

From 2012-2019, Greece attracted $4.7 billion in new clean energy investment. The countrys initial renewables boom was concentrated around solar, but retroactive subsidy cuts in 2014 saw PV investment plunge to near zero, where it remained until a 2.5GW PV project reached financial close in October 2020. Between 2015 and 2019, just 2% of new investment went to PV. The country's top lead arrangers for renewables over 2015-19 were Greek banks Alpha Bank and Eurobank Ergasias, though the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development also continue to play an important role in de-risking the sector in the aftermath of the 2014 subsidy cuts.

The introduction of the Metar renewables program led to substantial growth in solar investment, with about $1.6 billion invested between 2018 and July 2020. The most active investors in Hungary's renewables market are Enlight Renewable Energy, Erste Group Bank, and Greentech Hungary, all of which financed megawatt-scale new solar portfolios in 2018 and 2019. Some of these projects have been commissioned, and BloombergNEF forecasts indicate that at least 750MW of PV will be installed from 2018 to 2020. However, Metar has already hit a bump in the road: In May 2018, the government unexpectedly introduced a deadline for projects below 0.5MW that sought the feed-in tariff option, causing many small-scale PV projects to miss the application window. Policy uncertainty under a historically interventionist government could resurface as a deterrent for investors.

Renewable energy investment is mostly in wind technology, although there have been some sporadic investments into biomass and waste. Investment in renewable energy peaked in 2015, at $1.2 billion. Investment in 2019 reached $0.6 billion. Norddeutsche Landesbank-Girozentrale is the biggest backer of renewable projects in Ireland, committing more than $1.5 million. SSE Plc owns the biggest share of renewables projects, accounting for 548MW. Irelands first round of its new renewable energy auction scheme brought a surprisingly strong result for solar projects.

Investment in new clean energy has struggled to recover since the government stopped subsidizing the build of utility-scale solar in 2013. At $1.8 billion, 2018 investment was the highest since 2013 but still a fraction of the 2011 high of $33 billion, when Italy connected 9.5GW of PV to the grid. A mix of wind projects with contracts from the 2016 renewables auction, and merchant solar projects drove the 2018 increase in investment. In June 2019, the European Commission gave approval to Italys $6 billion subsidy support package, meant to run until 2021. The government allocated the money in mixed technology auctions with a goal to buy around 5.6GW of capacity. This, combined with rising interest in unsubsidized projects, should boost clean investment numbers in the coming years. In the long term, Italys 2030 NECP goal of getting more than half its electricity from renewables will also provide investors with clarity. Italy also has a very active secondary market for solar, with 744MW of capacity changing hands in 2018.

Lithuania attracted around $1.2 billion of clean energy investment between 2010 and 2020. Wind accounted for almost half of that total, although from 2016-2017, investment was dominated by biomass, which attracted $621 million. Lithuania's top lead arranger for renewables has been the European Investment Bank, which has been responsible for $204 million, around a third of the countrys total. The largest projects in the past five years have been carried out by Ignitis Group, which invested 205.6 million euros in waste-to-energy CHP plants in Vilnius and Kaunas, with the support of a loan from the European Investment bank. Lithuanias first large subsidy-free wind farm of 69MW secured financing from GE Capital and E Energija in August 2020.

To date, renewables investment in Moldova has been limited to multilateral finance institutions. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has solicited expressions of interest from consultants to manage Moldovas clean energy tender program. The World Bank is funding a competitive power market project with the objective of enhancing Moldovas access to the European energy market, which has a higher proportion of clean power. Spanish natural gas and electric utility group Naturgy Energy, an early investor in Moldovas energy distribution market, in 2019 sold its electricity and gas assets in the nation to Duet Private Equity for a total of 141 million euros ($159 million). The assets acquired by Duet, now doing business as RED Nord, together with Premier Energy serve 100% of Moldovas retail electricity market.

Together, onshore and offshore wind projects attracted the biggest share of clean energy investment between 2004 and 2019, at 47% of total investment or $18.4 billion. Solar investment has avoided the ups and downs that have characterized the PV sector in other European markets. Annual investment in the sector has remained between $0.9 billion and 3 billion since 2015. Most financing has come from commercial banks, with Rabobank topping the list for loans to renewable energy projects by a significant margin. The European Investment Bank, the EUs lending arm, has also been active in providing investments to the clean energy sector, and has come in second place.

North Macedonia relies heavily on lignite for its electricity, along with large and small hydro. To a much lesser extent, solar PV, onshore wind, and biomass have been added, but together they make up a small portion of total energy generation. However, auctions for wind power have arisen recently, in addition to those for solar PV. Procedures in the region regarding renewable energy development are still complex and nascent, which has led to uncertainty and investment concerns. However, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has lent to the state-owned electric company to transform a sidelined coal power plant into a solar operation; furthermore, Germanys KfW has played an important role in financing wind power in the country.

The Norwegian clean energy sector attracted around $20 billion of investment in 2010-19, dominated by small hydro early in the period. Wind has slowly taken over, accounting for 85%% of the $3.6 billion invested in 2017-19. This is driven by the Fosen Vind complex, which comprises six onshore wind farms with a combined capacity of 1GW. It is expected that wind power will continue to dominate clean energy investments in the next few years as the country builds out its onshore wind base. This could be hampered by local opposition to wind farms, however. In addition, Equinor is likely to invest in a floating wind project or two in the coming decades.

Poland saw just over $12 billion in new clean energy investment come in to the country from 2009-2018, an average of $1.2 billion per year. Some 20% of that total went to capex-heavy biomass investment, while 70% went to onshore wind, despite the punitive wind act introduced in 2015 that caused investment to drop. The auction program has helped investor confidence recover in wind as well as solar. The countrys largest asset finance deal since 2014 was a $182 million investment in a PV portfolio, concluded in June 2020.

Portuguese wind investment has been limited: $270 million invested over 2015-18 was for repowering existing assets, while the bumper $300 million invested in 2018 was largely due to a pilot floating offshore wind project. Solar has reached grid parity in Iberia, and several large unsubsidized projects have made headway by striking long-term power purchase agreements. Some $330 million was invested in unsubsidized solar projects over 2017-18 (more than the entire 2012-16 period for PV). An auction held in August 2020 for the first time allowed solar-plus-storage projects to participate and awarded 670MW of capacity. The biggest investors in Portugal's new energy sector have been Banco Comercial Portugues, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentina and Caixa General de Despositos. Recent investment by these has been limited to refinancing wind portfolios, while more active investors in new-build renewables projects in Portugal in recent years have been CaixaBank, Banco Santander, and ING Groep.

Changes to Romanias green certificate scheme have led investment to drop substantially. Romania attracted only $120 million in clean energy investment over 2018 and 2019, the majority going to a bioethanol plant. In contrast, 2012 annual investment reached $2 billion. Romanias renewable energy investment boom was short-lived as GC prices traded at the ceiling price (60 euros) until 2013. The government quota reductions in 2013 brought investment activity to an end, falling to just $40 million in 2015. With quotas cut and mounting GC oversupply, prices crashed to the official floor (30 euros) in 2014, where they have stayed since. Producers struggled to find offtakers for their GCs, causing distress to the point of developers disassembling operational wind farms. Clean energy investment has not recovered since. During the boom, major investors in Romania's clean energy market included BNP Paribas, UniCredit, and Citigroup in addition to the European Investment Bank and EBRD.

Russias renewables capacity accounts for less than 1% of total installed capacity, even though auctions have been running since 2013 and have awarded 5.5GW of renewables to date. However, as foreign companies, including Fortum, Enel and Vestas become increasingly active in Russias renewables auctions, this could drive more projects to complete. Just over 500MW of new PV capacity came online in both 2018 and 2019, showing the pace is stepping up. Fortum owns Russias first wholesale wind farm, commissioned in January 2018, and was the biggest winner in Russias 2018 auctions, securing both solar and wind capacity. Financing is a barrier to business in Russia due to international sanctions.

Serbia has secured consistent wind investments over the past three years, but other technologies have received little to no financing. Large-scale wind farms have been financed by domestic banks, foreign banks and impact funds. One of the biggest investors in Serbia's clean energy sector is MK Fintel  a joint venture between Serbia's MK Group and Italy's Fintel Energia  and it is expected to build around 60% of the country's 500MW wind-capacity target. Beyond traditional energy players, the country's wind sector has also attracted financing from Masdar, a subsidiary of Abu Dhabi's Mubadal Investment Co., where it bought a 60% stake in the recently commissioned 158MW Cibuk 1 wind farm.

Investment in Slovakia's clean energy sector has been limited by administrative barriers, policy uncertainty, and the focus on nuclear expansion. Solar saw a modest boom in 2010-11, attracting $2.5 billion in total. But this trend stagnated after the government made legislative amendments in 2011, removing support for newly permitted PV plants over 100kW. PV investment has since shown signs of recovery, with 56% growth seen over 2017-2018, thanks to a small-scale solar subsidy. Plans for a 560MW hydro power plant, financed and constructed by Chinese companies, were unveiled in April 2015. More recently, a solar investment deal worth $63 million was signed on January 2019 and could further boost the share of renewables in Slovakia's power generation.

Investment in clean energy over the last few years has been minimal, ranking last out of all EU member states in 2018. Investment levels should increase slightly, as the winning auction projects begin to close financing.

Spain's clean energy sector attracted some $115 billion of investment from 2004-2019. Of this sum, almost half ($48 billion) occurred in the 2007-2008 boom period, owing to a generous subsidy scheme that benefited mainly onshore wind and solar developers. Investment declined substantially following the economic recession and the retroactive subsidy cuts for renewables, falling to just $200 million in 2016. The sector has since rebounded with the successful rollout of auctions and has attracted significant volumes of investment since 2017. Both onshore wind and PV reaching grid parity in 2018, becoming competitive on an unsubsidized basis given the average power price of that year. This sparked new investor interest in subsidy-free Spanish wind and solar projects. The biggest clean energy investor as of September 2020 has been Banco Santander, totaling more than $17 billion since 2004.

New clean energy investment in Sweden averaged $2.3 billion a year over 2012-19, with about three-quarters on average going to the onshore wind sector. Sweden's biggest renewables asset finance deal was for an 844MW onshore wind project in 2019, amounting to $1.097 billion, with NORD/LB and DNB acting as financial advisers. In May 2020, Enercon sold 25% of the project to Credit Suisse Energy Infrastructure Partners for an undisclosed amount, with DNB acting as financial adviser to the seller. The country's top lead arranger for renewables has been Australian financial group Macquarie, which was responsible for $2.523 billion over 2012-19. The largest power purchase agreement (PPA) in the country was signed in November 2017 with Norsk Hydro for the output of 483MW from the Markbygden Pitea Ett Wind Farm, making this deal the worlds largest at the time, and the third-largest corporate PPA to date.

Investment in renewable energy in Switzerland peaked in 2013, at $1.2 billion. The majority of investment is into solar, although there are signs this could change given the governments enthusiasm for hydro projects. Almost $4 billion has been provided to renewable energy projects in the country between 2014 and 2020. IWB Industrielle Werke Basel is by far the biggest lender to projects, at almost $10 million. Three companies each own more than 65MW of renewable projects. These are BKW AG, Elektrizitaetswerk der Stadt Zuerich and Repower AG.

Clean energy investment grew steadily over 2012-2017, with wind leading and accounting for more than $1 billion each year over that period. Solar saw a surge in investment in 2017 as unlicensed projects rushed to commission before transmission costs increased. However, investment in clean energy has stagnated since 2018, amid policy uncertainty and ongoing currency fluctuations and an economic slowdown. Investment in 2019 amounted to $1.9 billion, a 16% drop from the previous year. Turkey holds auctions for pre-licenses, which are required for renewables projects to reach commissioning. After two auctions held in 2017 only one more, for wind capacity, is planned for October 2020, which leaves developers with little scope to bring projects online. Other than these, the Yeka auctions have been the other route for developers, but the progress on these have been very slow so far.

Regulatory and legislative reforms spurred a boom in clean energy investments in Ukraine across 2018 and 2019, in which there was more than $5 billion in new investment. The biggest single investment so far has been by Norwegian wind developer NBT, with a $210 million loan for the first phase of the Syvash wind project. Local developers, led by Ukraines largest non-state utility, DTEK, have played a large role in the development of the sector, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development has gone to lengths to present Ukraine as lower risk than previously perceived. Cuts to the feed-in tariff, which is backed by a sovereign guarantee, are likely to undermine this confidence, though smaller levels of investment may still be possible for projects that have secured feed-in tariffs, albeit at lower levels than expected.

New clean energy investment in the U.K. has stagnated since 2017 due to renewables policy changes and Brexit uncertainty. Annual investment averaged $8.3 billion between 2017 and 2019, compared to an annual average of $20.1 billion from 2013-2016.  The role of the European Investment Bank now that the country has left the EU poses significant concern to future investment. The organization is the U.K.'s top asset finance lead arranger  accounting for one tenth of the country's total clean energy investment from 2004-2018. Investment figures in the U.K.  as in several northern European countries  are shaped by offshore wind auctions: the sector reached a new record of $15 billion in 2016 after the second CfD round and 2020 is set to follow suit following the third CfD round. In the long term, BNEF expects costs for new onshore wind and PV projects to more than halve between 2017 and 2050, thanks to technology improvements and production cost reductions. However, investment in new-build renewables could struggle as other technologies receive capacity payments.

Most renewables capacity in Algeria consists of small-scale PV installations of around 15-20MW. Clean energy investments seem to have  petered out. While the domestic clean energy industry attracted investments totaling $668 million between 2006 and 2014, only two small deals were made in subsequent years, with the country recording no new deals since 2017. Finance has been lackluster for a number of reasons, including a national focus on developing new gas plants while modernizing the existing power fleet. Actors bidding into auctions must do so with a local partner and finance must be domestically sourced  a challenge as Algerian banks remain reluctant to back clean energy undertakings, despite their involvement in a handful projects over past years.

In 2019, hydro accounted for 70% of Angolas total generation and 52% of the 5.5GW installed capacity. The country aims to add 800MW of renewable energy capacity (500MW of biomass, 100MW of solar, 100MW of wind and 100MW of mini-hydro) by 2025, under the governments energy strategy "Visao Angola Energia. The $23-billion energy strategy for 2018-25 aims to reach 9.9GW of total capacity and boost electricity-access rates from around 34% in 2018 to 60%. By this time, natural gas is to meet 20% of generation, hydro will account for 64%, while 8% will come from other renewables. Of the 9.9GW of new build, just under a third will be developed through public-private partnerships. Angola has no substantial incentives such as feed-in tariffs or auctions to promote renewable energy deployment, though it has signaled its intention to eventually do so via its "Bet on Solar Energy Program", which aims to tender a total of 200MW of solar, divided into five 40MW lots, by 2022.

Benin has not been able to secure much clean energy investment to date, with the most recent deal dating back to 2017. The MCA II plans to invest $375 million to modernize Benins electricity sector and the government of Benin will contribute an additional $28 million. No large-scale renewable project is yet present in Benin, but at least 75MW of solar PV is planned. In December 2017, the French Development Agency (AFD) financed the 25MW Defissol PV project, which is planned to come online by the end of 2020. On top of new solar developments, the program intends to restore the 500kW Yripao Dam, and install a second turbine to increase production to 1MW.

Only one grid-scale renewable energy project has been commissioned in Botswana to date  the 1.3MW solar PV project close to Phakalane. It was financed through a $12.5 million grant from the Japanese government. This is the only utility-scale renewable project to be financed in the last five years, making the current share of foreign investment 100%. Botswana is open to foreign investment, but many project developers are unable to prepare the project proposals that meet the criteria necessary to attract international finance, according to the World Bank.

Clean energy investment has rapidly picked up in Burkina Faso since 2017, with a record $166 million invested in 2019 alone. Prior to 2019, the largest clean energy investments to take place in Burkina Faso were the 33MW Zagtouli PV plant, commissioned in 2017, and the 15MW Essakane PV plant, which came online in 2018. Together, these deals totaled $115 million of investment. The Zagtouli project, which signed a PPA with Sonabel, Burkina Fasos utility, was supported by the EU and the AFD. The Essakane plant has a PPA with gold miner Iamgold and is partly financed by Banque Internationale pour le Commerce, lIndustrie et lArtisanat du Burkina (BICIAB), a BNP Paribas Group subsidiary. It is therefore evident that commercial actors are willing to invest in solar in the country. Additional actors are slowly entering the market in the context of the governments 155MW solar programme, including French companies Quadran, GreenWish, GreenYellow and Urbasolar, and Belgian companies, Syscom, Naange and Soltech.

There has been significant under-investment in the energy sector. As a result, the country had an extremely low electrification rate of 11% nationally and less than 4% in rural areas by end-2019. The country has opened its energy sector to privatization. Uptake of this opportunity has been limited, but one notable investment in 2017 included a 7.5MW solar plant, in which Gigawatt Global signed a 25-year PPA with the national utility, Regideso. Other foreign investment in the energy sector in Burundi has primarily been made by the development banks. In 2019, the World Bank, European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, European Union, African Development Bank, Burundis government and national utility Regideso raised $270 million to start building the 50MW Jiji-Murembwe hydro power plant. The African Development Bank has issued a request for expressions of interest by consultants to conduct feasibility studies to incorporate solar capacity to two small hydro power plants. Investment in rural electrification is being undertaken by the Burundian Agency for Rural Electrification. The objective of this entity is to develop and implement rural electrification projects, including small-scale hydropower, solar and wind energy.

There are no examples of domestic commercial banks investing in renewable energy projects. The majority of finance that is available is from international creditors, mainly based in China. Of the renewable technologies, large hydro has received the most clean energy investment in Cameroon, with almost 8GW either announced or having secured financing as of September 2019. Some small-scale solar projects have also closed financing in recent years, particularly for rural electrification, but access to finance remains a large risk for small-scale solar and mini-grid developments. Investment in megawatt-scale projects has yet to gain traction. Cameroon is open to private finance. The biggest investors have been international organizations such as the World Bank, which financed $784.5 million in 2018 for the Nachtigal hydropower project. Investors from China, including firms such as Eximbank, are active in Cameroons hydro and solar sectors.

Clean energy investment has neither been a top priority for the state, nor has it been readily available. The majority, if not all, of clean energy financing has come from international development banks and Chinese companies, which are increasingly active in the country. Projects to date have focused on updating the existing infrastructure and generation assets, rather than expanding the fleet of clean energy generators. For instance, the China Gezhouba Group Corporation is involved in modernizing the Boali II hydropower plant, among other projects. This emphasis on upkeep as opposed to new-build is due to the ongoing conflict within CAR, which has destroyed much of the energy infrastructure, in addition to the lack of maintenance by indebted state-owned utility Enerca. There is also a general absence of supporting policies and financial means.

There are hardly any investments in clean energy in Chad. To date, all finance has come exclusively from outside the country and has been disbursed at concessional rates. There are less active financiers than in neighboring countries, with the main actors being the EU, the World Bank and the Islamic Development Bank. After a delay of two years, the 60MW Djermaya Solar plant was the first utility-scale renewable energy project to be announced in Chad in 2018. The EU is backing the project with a 6.35 million-euro ($7.3 million) grant. Funding is scarce. Indeed, the difficulties in securing financing were partly behind the repeated delays that affected Vergnets 1.1MW wind farm at Amdjarass, which finally came online for initial testing in late-2017.

Renewable energy investments in the Congo remain few and far between. Chinas Gezhouba Group and Sinohydro have been investing in hydropower projects, such as the 19.5MW Liouesso plant, as well as two prospective major dams in Sounda and Chollet.
