However, the plants have run into environmental and technical issues, making their future unclear. Finance for potential renewables initiatives would likely come from international donors, such as the French Development Agency, the African Development Bank and the World Bank, which have been involved with rural electrification projects in the country.

Investment in clean energy projects in the DRC has been limited for a number of reasons. The lack of a proper legal instrument to define the energy sector discourages investors from funding new projects. In Kananga, a private consortium composed of the DRCs 7th Engineering and South Africas Megatron built a 2.5 MW solar PV plant in 2015. The plant operated for 12 months as a joint venture between Megatron and SNEL, with the former generating power, the latter distributing and selling, and the two sharing the proceeds. The plant shut down due to SNELs apparent failure to collect tariffs. In addition, the dominance of the highly subsidized, state-backed company, SNEL, in the generation, transmission and distribution of power make the investment climate less competitive. The absence of government regulation and energy policy on renewable energy does not encourage long-term capital investment in the renewable energy sector.

Grid-connected capacity in Cte dIvoire is provided by 1,350MW of gas and 879MW of hydro. The gas generators are mostly owned by independent power producers, while the hydro assets are state-owned and operated by the CIE (Compagnie Ivorienne dElectricite).  Clean energy investments to date (other than hydro) include two solar projects agreed in 2018 and 2019 respectively: 37MW partially funded by the German development bank (KfW) and the EU, and a 60MW project under Scaling Solar, an IFC initiative. The cost of the first solar plant is estimated to be around 40 million euros ($47 million), of which 27 million euros will be provided by KfW and 9 million euros by the EU.

As in most leading emerging renewables markets, investment in Egyptian renewables has varied considerably year-on-year. New investment peaked at $3.3 billion in 2017 as many of the projects making up the Benban solar park reached financial close, while wind attracted the bulk of capital flows in 2019. Egypts renewables sector is one of the largest to be almost completely dependent on foreign capital. Top lenders include German development bank KfW, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, as well as multilateral backers such as the World Bank, and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Egypts renewable energy authority is the top project owner on a capacity basis. But taken together, independent power producers of the likes of Scatec Solar, Engie and Ib Vogt also account for a large share of installed renewables.

Eritrea has so far attracted very little foreign investment. There is no framework for public-private partnerships, nor incentives to attract international interest. Following the historic peace summit with Ethiopia in July 2018, and the subsequent reopening of the border, relations between the two countries are gradually normalizing, which could create a more attractive business environment to investors. However, the only investments in clean energy to date are Aggrekos 29.5MW diesel-solar hybrid project at the Nevsun mine, UNDPs 0.825MW wind pilot in Assab, plus two solar mini-grids by Solarcentury (1.25MW) and E-Tech (2MW). Aside from Solarcenturys announcement of a further 12MW of PV capacity, there are no other clean energy projects in the pipeline.

The majority of clean energy investment in Ethiopia has gone to hydro, though wind and geothermal have also received investment in recent years. This investment has been inconsistent year-on-year, usually correlating with the development of a large project. A lack of foreign currency reserves, due to high expenditure on big infrastructure projects, means domestic commercial and development banks play a much smaller role in the growth of the countrys clean energy industry. International development banks are picking up the slack  traditional players like the World Bank, the Danish Energy Agency and the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) all have boots on the ground and are actively involved in Ethiopias clean energy market.

The majority of investment in renewable energy in Ghana has come from foreign sources, with the largest commissioned solar project (20MW) financed by Chinese investors. More recently, a couple of onsite solar projects for commercial companies have been financed, including one for drinks company Kasapreko, and another financed by an impact investor at a recycling plant. German development bank KfW is also financing 17MW of solar, scheduled to come online in December 2020. The government is unlikely to approve new utility-scale projects under the feed-in tariff scheme due to the current oversupply situation. Distributed-solar startups have also attracted some investments. These include PEG Africa, a pay-as-you-go solar company, and Redavia, an on-site solar financer and developer.

All energy investment to date has come from outside of Guinea due to the limitations of domestic finance. There have been no more than a few residential solar panels and mini-hydro plants installed, while capital has been directed instead into large hydro projects. The most notable investments to date are China Exims $1.3 billion package for the 450MW Souapiti dam, Sinohydros $812 million for the 294MW Kouokutamba dam and Sintrams $400 million for the 100MW large hydro project. Further investments target electrification efforts, rebuilding the countrys distribution network and investments into four new interconnector lines. Despite the lack of non-hydro renewables to date, there is growing interest in investing into solar PV projects, and several MoUs have been signed with private sector actors.

While Iraq saw no new clean energy investment between 2010 and 2018, solar deals were recorded in 2019 and 2020. Financing renewables in Iraq is difficult, and private investors are forced to rely on local banks that lack experience in financing larger projects. Due to a variety of factors, such as the security situation, there is a high perception of risk surrounding investments in the countrys energy sector. The Ministry of Energy has tried to incentivize foreign developers to enter the renewables market with tax incentives. Projects in areas defined by the National Investment Council (NIC) are exempt from taxes and fees for 10 years from the date of completion. The NIC can also extend the period of exemption up to 15 years, if the Iraqi investor share of the project exceeds 50%.

Investment in renewables began picking up in 2009, reaching a peak in 2014 when solar projects received over $1 billion. Since then, investment has continued to drip in, with annual totals ranging from $0.4-0.9 billion from 2015 to 2020. Solar is by far the most backed technology type, though wind received about one-third of total investment in 2018. Bank Hapoalim BM and Bank Leumi Le-Israel BM are the two biggest project backers, each lending over $370 million to renewables projects in the country.

Wind and solar have been the focus of renewable investment to date, with $2.6 billion of utility-scale solar and $1.4 billion of wind financed as of 1H 2020. Traditionally, international development banks have provided financing for renewable projects, but an increasing number of domestic banks and private equity funds are active in the market. As such, financing for renewable projects in Jordan is well established, and the process of securing finance is less onerous than elsewhere in the region.

Clean energy investments in Kenya have been sporadic in the last decade, sustained by a small number of financings for geothermal and wind projects. In 2019, Kenya recorded $728 million of total clean energy investment, a reduction of 42% compared to 2018,  of which $401 million was directed to biomass projects. The majority of financing for large-scale renewable energy projects comes from development financing and donor organizations. Distributed energy startups such as pay-as-you-go solar companies, microgrid and on-site energy developers received financing from more diverse financiers, including private investors, commercial banks and utilities.

Clean energy investment in Kuwait has been limited to single deals in the past five years, with the deployment of renewables starting in 2016. No other renewable energy technologies aside from solar or wind are set to be developed, but some hybrid projects are in planning. The country does not have financial institutions solely dedicated to green investments, but domestic banks have been active in financing renewable energy projects. Increasing capacity is funded through the private-public-partnership (PPP) model. For example, the Az-Zour North Power and Water plant uses the PPP model to secure financing.

The current pipeline of renewables projects will ensure strong growth in the sector in Lebanon. The countrys first PPA for a 226MW of wind project was signed in February 2018 at a price of $113/MWh. The Ministry of Environment and Water was the main signatory, and state utility Electricite du Liban (EDL) provided access through a letter of credit signed by the central bank of Lebanon. An additional 180MW of solar capacity, launched through a tender in 2017, is progressing toward signing PPA agreements. A further 700MW of solar-and-storage and wind projects could sign PPAs in the coming years as a result of future tender rounds. The Lebanese Centre for Energy Conservation received considerable expressions of interest for its tenders, including both from local and major international developers such as ACWA Power, First Solar and Tesla, amongst others. Investment in the first round of auctions has come mostly from domestic sources. IRENAs Lebanon Renewable Energy Outlook, 2020, estimates that around $2.2 billion of investment is needed to develop the renewables sector to reach Lebanons ambitious targets.

Some 90MW of renewables are under development, with power offtake agreements in place. The 20MW NEO1 Solar project has been financed by the African Development Bank/World Bank, and the 70MW NEO2 Solar project has been financed and developed by Chinas Exim bank. When completed, they would more than double Lesotho's fleet size. Lesotho attracted $16 million for solar projects in 2019, the only investment seen in a decade.

The lack of a transparent and uniform policy framework has hindered clean energy investment in Liberia to date, but the country is focused on incentivizing private investment. Commercial lenders are yet to enter the market, leaving only concessional agencies to support the limited roll-out of rural electrification projects. Current projects are funded by NGOs and focused on extending grid access to the rural areas in the country.

Clean energy investment in Madagascar has so far been limited, with the main source of finance coming from international development institutions. French developer Green Yellow built the aforementioned 20MW PV plant, with support from the World Bank. In addition to development finance, domestic companies are joining force with international partners to develop projects. For example, Switzerland-based Meeco Group announced plans in mid-2019 to develop two 45-kilowatt solar installations in cooperation with Madagascan companies Groupe Filatex and Enelec. The AfDB has also made significant investment to improve the countrys electricity system.

While the government supports investment in clean energy, it has not made any investments itself. Almost all investment is foreign, and renewable developers operating in the country are all foreign subsidiaries as well. International development banks are a popular source of capital for renewable projects. Overall investment doesn't seem to be growing, which could be due to high inflation and volatile exchange rates shaking investor confidence. Malawi seems willing to experiment technology-wise, as PPAs have been signed for solar, wind and small hydro. Solar is the most commonly funded technology, and a 20MW PPA was recently signed for the country's first floating solar plant, financed by a German developer.

Clean energy investment has slowly been picking up in Mali since 2017, reaching a record year of $83 million in 2019. Most clean energy investments in Mali are international and concessional in nature, with a focus on off-grid projects. For example, the World Banks hybridization program from 2014 to 2020 has a budget of $44 million, and a $19 million hybridization project by the Abu Dhabi Fund has been launched from 2015 to 2021. The Islamic Development Bank, in conjunction with Moroccos lOffice National de lElectricit et de lEau Potable, is building two solar plants with a capacity of 1.3MW and 1.5MW respectively. In early-2019, the Green Climate Fund and West African Development Bank announced a 4.83MW solar mini-grid project, which they are supporting with $38.9 million of investment. In the case of Akuos 50MW Kita solar project, a domestic commercial bank, Banque Nationale de Developpment Agricole du Mali, was involved in its financing, but this is the only case of commercial finance to date.

The government has overseen a steady increase in clean energy capacity since 2013 and has heavily relied on concessional funding, often from Persian Gulf donors. Highlights include the completion of several large PV projects, such as the 50MW Toujounine PV plant commissioned in November 2017, of which the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development (AFESD) provided the majority of the projects $53 million total cost. Similarly, the AFESD is financing the development of the 100MW Boulenouar wind farm. Donors such as the French Development Agency and the EU are also active in clean energy through their efforts to improve electrification, notably the five-year RIM DIR program at a total cost of $13.4 million.

Moroccan solar tenders have stipulated storage requirements, in order to displace expensive generation from fuel oil currently used to meet Moroccos high evening peak demand. Concessional finance from the World Banks Clean Technology Fund (CTF) has been key in kick-starting the Moroccan solar thermal industry. CTF and CTF MDB (co-financing) have totaled $1.3 billion across the Noor I-III and Noor-Midelt projects. This financing has in turn attracted a further $3.3 billion from MDB and development banks. Developer finance and assumed equity make up the remaining $874 million of the Noor solar thermal projects as of 2018. In contrast, Moroccan wind projects have been successful in attracting significant amounts of commercial finance. Lured by Moroccos world-class wind resource, commercial finance has provided some $894 million of the disclosed $1,762 million invested in the wind sector since 2011. Total investment in the Moroccan wind sector is expected to reach $3.7 billion by 2020.

Mozambique has historically relied on its large-hydro resources, with the broader power fleet seeing little investment in recent years. More recently, investment has been directed to developing the domestic natural gas sector, which has grown rapidly since 2015. In terms of clean technology, the last decade saw Mozambique receive limited investment in biofuels and small but growing inflows into solar. However, 2019 was the best year in a decade for Mozambique in terms of attracting clean energy asset finance, with $176 million, of which $120 million was directed to wind projects and the remaining $56 million to solar. The 2019 investment level was equal to 69% of the total attracted since 2010. The countrys rural electrification agency, Funae, has developed mini-grid and pico-solar pilot programs in partnership with German aid agency GIZ and recently signed an agreement with Ignite Power to install individual solar energy systems in 300,000 homes in remote areas of the country. These will reach 1.8 million people over the next three years, and help the country achieve its objective of universal energy access by 2030, established via the Energy for All project (Projecto de Energia para Todos).

Unlike in many neighboring countries, retail power prices in Namibia are cost reflective and unsubsidized. Therefore, their prices are among the highest in sub-Saharan Africa, and have increased more than 5% annually for the last six years. Retail tariffs vary by season and time of use (peak versus non-peak), and contain high capacity charges for industrial and commercial consumers. These retail-rate structures are prime for battery development, which could reduce a sites peak load and shift consumption from high-priced to low-priced times of the day. The country is burdened by its inability to meet demand with domestic power. About 60% of electricity needs are met with electricity imports from South Africa, the costs of which are substantially higher than power from local plants. High electricity prices are driving investments in off-grid solar-plus-battery systems, even in areas where the grid is available. Just in Windhoek, the capital of Namibia, there is an estimated 20MW of off-grid capacity. While the country has done much to incentivize solar generation, which will help provide electricity at midday, the country lacks highly flexible generation sources that would minimize electricity imports during the most costly peak hours.

International donors are the primary form of financing renewables in Niger because domestic banks do not fund these projects. The EU and AFD have joined forces on two such undertakings, spending a combined 28.5 million euros ($33 million) on a 20MW solar plant at Gorou Banda and 32 million euros on a yet-to-be-developed 19MW solar-diesel plant in Agadez. Other finance to date has mainly targeted electrification efforts such as the World Banks $50 million National Solar Electricity Access Project (NESAP). Noteworthy funders in the off-grid space include the African Development Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, the West African Development Bank and the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development.

The Rural Electrification Agency (REA) is now commissioning projects under its Energizing Education Program (EEP), providing power for nine universities (seven will run on PV and two on gas) with funding for phase I ($29.7 million) coming from Nigeria's sovereign green bond issued in 2017. The REA secured a further $350 million loan through the World Bank and $200 million (from the AfDB) for the Nigeria Electrification Project (NEP), totaling $550 million. EEP phase 2 (19MW of PV) will receive $105 million of this fund. Under the NEP, $150 million is dedicated to implementing a results-based financing program through a performance-based grant (PBG) and minimum subsidy tender mechanism for helping developers finance solar hybrid mini-grids. In the commercial mini-grid segment, Rensource, a three-year-old off-grid solar energy firm, has raised $20 million in a Series A round equity funding jointly led by African venture capital fund CRE Venture Capital and impact investor Omidyar Network in December 2019. The round also saw participation from Inspired Evolution, Proparco, EDPR, I&P, Sin Capital, and Yuzura Honda. Rensources funding round follows sustained investor interest in Africa-focused off-grid and renewable energy startups seeking to plug electricity gaps. In June 2019, Arnergy, another solar mini-grid company, also raised $9 million in its Series A round equity funding.

Most of Omans renewable-energy projects have just entered the tender process or been announced, but the country is keen to invest in clean energy projects. A government-led subsidy program is in place for a residential rooftop solar PV pilot, and investment from other countries in the region has been injected to finance a utility-scale solar PV project. In addition, not only does Omans 2025 target of 3,050MW solar and wind projects require massive investment, but the Sultanates incumbent combined power-and-water-desalination plants  which were put in place 15-20 years ago  also need capital to upgrade or be replaced with more efficient gas plants, reverse osmosis water plants and solar power.

Clean energy investment into the Palestinian Territories so far has been limited, with available funds coming from international development organizations and other countries, especially in the Persian Gulf. The Palestine Investment Fund, or PIF, and the Arab Bank are financing a $20 million solar portfolio to be developed in the West Bank.

Qatar reached financial close of the 800MW Siraj-1 solar PV project with 1.7 billion Qatari riyal ($456 million) in 2020. The country welcomes foreign investment by allowing investment in renewable energy projects to come from anywhere but must not solely be from Qatari banks. Qatar also established Qatar Solar, a 100% owned holding company formed by Qatar Foundation, to specifically invest in solar technologies, new applications of solar and solar research opportunities.

Investment in clean energy in Rwanda has been volatile, despite consistent year-on-year growth in electrification. Most historical on-grid investment has been in hydro, natural gas and solar, but national utility Rwanda Energy Group (REG) has halted all permitting for future on-grid generation due to a current oversupply. Most future investment in Rwandas energy market is expected to go toward the expansion of the grid to manage this oversupply and to off-grid companies working with communities that will not have grid access in the near future. The financing matrix has been dominated by donor groups, most notably through a 200 million-euro loan from the European Union and the World Banks Scaling Up Renewable Energy Program. Since 2018, BloombergNEF has recorded no substantial new clean energy asset finance in the country.

After long remaining dormant, yearly new investment in renewables leapt to $400 million in 2018 and $600 million in 2019. That was largely the result of financial close being reached for the 300MW Sakaka PV plant and 400MW Dumat al-Jandal wind farm. Investment is expected to grow rapidly as projects auctioned through REPDO reach financial close over the years to come. Domestic renewables heavyweight ACWA Power dominates project ownership on a capacity basis with 210MW. A number of actors are present on the lender front, the ranking for which is topped by East Asian capital providers such as Sumitomo and Koreas development bank. The Public Investment Fund  the Saudi sovereign wealth fund  is expected to play a leading role in backing future renewables projects.

Recent years have seen an influx of renewables investment in Senegal, and the Scaling Solar auctions will make a further contribution to helping the sector develop. Bid prices achieved in the auctions are indicative of the sectors growing maturity, even factoring in the power price depression due to the de-risking measures applied to projects. The Taiba NDiaye wind farm, commissioned in 2020, was financed by $378 million of U.S. and Danish concessional funding. The sector will likely continue to rely on such development finance in the near term. However, in 2019 the country attract only $63 million, 14% of 2018s investment.

Grid-connected clean energy investments in Sierra Leone have only increased with the construction of several mini hydro power plants in different small distribution grids, as well as the 34 MW biomass power plant, commissioned in 2012. There are some renewable projects in the pipeline, including 6MW of PV in Freetown, currently under construction, and 143MW Bumbuna II hydro, construction of which is beginning in 2021. Financing organizations of clean-energy investments, both on-grid and off-grid, have so far been development agencies, governments or clean-energy-driven investment funds.

Somalia owes significant debt to a number of international financial institutions, making it ineligible for international development aid and concessional financing from many other sources. Most international power sector investment in Somalia comes through short- and medium-term grants. A number of international organizations are undertaking large-scale projects focused on the power sector and energy security. Somalia also receives significant remittances from its diaspora, and in some cases, power producers can fund projects directly through this kind of investment.

Clean energy investment in South Africa has risen and fallen in line with the rounds of its auction program. Periods of particularly high investment have occurred in years when winning projects reached financial close. In total, renewable energy projects attracted $19.5 billion between 2004 and 2019. The years 2014-2017 averaged just $1.4 billion each, as the auction scheme was on standby, while 2018 saw more than $3.7 billion invested after the government finally signed PPAs for rounds 3.5 to 4 of the REIPPP scheme. This boost has since subsided, with just $0.7 billion invested in 2019. More than two-thirds of the 2004-2019 total was spent on solar projects, although the share compared to wind is somewhat skewed by capex-heavy solar thermal project investment. South Africa has the most diverse mix of investor types in a region typically reliant upon concessional finance for renewables projects. Of the $19.5 billion of asset finance since 2004, some 45% has come from commercial banks and another 8% from private equity.

The growth rate of clean energy investments has been non-existent in recent years, with most funding directed to electrification projects by international aid organizations and foreign governments. Only 1% of the national population currently has access to electricity. The lack of transmission and distribution infrastructure further impedes any growth in clean energy investment. In contrast to the minimal installed capacity to date, there is a pipeline of large-scale energy infrastructure projects, most notably 2.1GW of large hydro. Yet many of these projects lack financiers.

Developers face many difficulties in securing finance in Sudan. There are no domestic banks which offer loans to developers investing in clean power, and years of international isolation, coupled with crippling debts and a dire security situation, have left international financial institutions reluctant to bankroll renewable energy projects. Difficulties in attracting donors has therefore translated into a lack of utility-scale renewables build. Several projects have been announced, including 250MW of solar PV and four utility-scale wind farms totalling 320MW, but all have struggled to secure funding and have therefore been cancelled or downsized. Investments have been limited to rural electrification schemes, with the United Nations Development Program and the government implementing separate initiatives to expand energy access through distributed renewables.

Investment in Tanzanias clean energy space is sporadic. There is a healthy presence of international donor agencies like USAID, the World Bank and the African Development Bank, along with a number of domestic and international commercial banks. However, the Tanzania Electricity Supply Company (TANESCO) is an unreliable offtaker, sometimes compensating counterparties months late, and the government continues to support fossil fuel and large hydro, such as the 2.1GW Stieglers Gorge hydro project that is under development. So long as these factors remain constant, renewables investment in Tanzania will continue to limp along.

There has been no clean energy utility-scale project in Togo yet, but existing rural electrification programs have received both international concessional finance and domestic commercial finance. The government is partnering with off-grid companies to offer solar home systems to rural customers, such as an agreement signed with BBOXX to deliver more than 500,000 PV systems to the rural population over the next five years under the so-called Cizo electrification program. Furthermore, under Cizo, select small-scale solar companies receive fixed, monthly subsidies for each system they install, allowing them to reduce costs and increase access to systems. Greenlight Planet, a U.S. company, signed an agreement to deliver more than 300,000 solar home systems under the same scheme, which has the support of local bank Union Togolaise de Banque (UTB). In 2018, the government signed an agreement with German Corporation GIZ, to accelerate rural electrification through training programs.

Tunisia has received little investment in utility-scale clean energy so far, but that is poised to change as more than 1GW of auction-winning projects are expected to be commissioned by end-2022. International development banks have been the main debt providers for Tunisia's clean-energy plants. The countrys Fond de Transition Energetique (FTE) will invest 2.13 billion Tunisian dinars ($730 million) in energy transition projects over the next decade. The budget has grown significantly, from 177 million Tunisian dinars between 2006 and 2015.

Uganda continues to develop its abundant hydro resources, pushing the power sector further down a low-carbon trajectory. The country's outlook for procuring other renewables such as wind and solar is more mixed. Uganda organized a successful feed-in tariff program that led to development of the region's largest solar projects outside of South Africa. However, government decisions to contract several massive hydro projects have raised concern about oversupply and dampened prospects for future wind and solar procurement. The 600MW Karuma hydro project is expected online by the end of 2020, and some of the country's oldest power plants have undergone retrofits in recent years. Investment and policy is expected to focus on expanding access via off-grid generation, as well as transmission and distribution infrastructure, rather than on growing renewable capacity.

As in most of the regions leading renewables markets, clean energy investment has varied considerably from year to year. New investment in renewables reached a record of $4.6 billion in 2019, and nearly all clean energy capital flows serve to finance solar projects. Local banks are playing an increasingly active role, notably by backing installations supported by Dubais net-metering program. Meanwhile, the consortia backing the countrys large-scale solar plants have drawn from a diverse capital pool. Credit providers range from local players like First Abu Dhabi Bank and the Mubadala Investment Company, to international lenders of the likes of Natixis and Mistubishi UFJ.

Investment in Zambia's clean energy sector has shown positive growth in recent years. Between 2017 and 2018, the first Scaling Solar auction round attracted some $91 million of new asset finance. In 2019, Zambia reached $176 million in investment for wind and solar projects, the highest share in a decade. The country has received both international concessional and commercial support, notably from the Export-Import Bank of China that provided $130 million of debt, although the availability of finance from local debt providers has been limited. In June 2020, Zesco and Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) have signed a contract to develop 600MW of solar projects, worth $548 million.

Solar is the most commonly funded form of renewable energy, but total investment in clean energy is negligible to date. Most of the capital for funding renewable development comes from foreign investors, but many are wary of political and regulatory risks. Renewable-energy investors have asked for policy changes, such as more relaxed licensing rules for small producers. Prior to 2018, all businesses in Zimbabwe were required to be majority-owned by a local, which dissuaded foreign participation in the renewable energy market. Overall economic stability is also a concern. The government outlawed all foreign currency in July 2019 and reintroduced the Zimbabwean dollar as the only form of legal tender. The Zimbabwe dollar was wiped out a decade ago due to hyperinflation with foreign currencies becoming legal tender in 2009. Legitimate worries remain. The Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency reported in August 2020 that annual inflation reached 838% in July.

Canada's clean energy policy is mostly addressed on a provincial level. Each province controls its own electricity generation, distribution and energy market and sets its own clean energy targets. Saskatchewan, Alberta, British Columbia, Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island have renewable energy goals. Manitoba, Ontario, and Newfoundland do not. In Manitoba and Newfoundland the majority of electricity generated comes from hydropower. Ontario had a renewable energy feed-in tariff that ended in 2017 and has the most installed wind (5GW) and solar capacity (3GW) in the country. Many Canadian provinces have vast quantities of pumped hydropower capacity, limiting the push to build out additional renewable energy or energy storage capacity.

The United States clean energy policy is driven by state-level initiatives, mainly renewable portfolio standards (or RPSs), which mandate the percentage of sales a load serving entity needs to meet with qualified, renewable facilities in a given state. In 2019, 29 states and DC had RPS mandates and multiple states had accompanying voluntary targets. States with the most aggressive mandated and voluntary renewable energy ambitions include California, which is aiming for 100% zero-carbon energy by 2045, and New York, aiming for the same by 2040. The other state-led initiative is the development and participation in carbon markets. The U.S. has two cap-and-trade programs, an economywide program in California and the power-sector-only Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) in the Northeast. On a federal level, U.S. President-elect Joe Biden has announced intentions to re-enter the Paris Agreement, which commits the nation to reducing U.S. greenhouse gas emissions to 26-28% below 2005 levels by 2025. The president-elect has also discussed ambitions to make U.S. electricity production carbon-free by 2035. Outside of these overarching goals, the United States maintains federal tax credit programs (the ITC and PTC), which allow investors in qualified renewable facilities to claim a certain percentage of those facilities capital expenditures against their tax liability.

Argentina introduced incentives and targets for renewable energy in 2015, creating the Trust Fund for the Development of Renewable Energies (FODER) and providing tax incentives such as a VAT tax rebate and accelerated depreciation. Argentina also established a 2018 target to meet 8% of its power demand with clean sources. The target increases yearly: 12% by 2019, 16% by 2021, 18% by 2023 and 20% by 2025. Argentina did not meet its targets for 2018 and 2019 and currently meets around 9% of its demand with renewable energy.

Bolivia has no comprehensive clean energy policy. Its National Development Plan 2017-2020 commits to a total installed capacity of 4.9GW by 2020, with a 1.4GW expansion in hydro capacity, 411MW of new wind, biomass, geothermal and solar and 1.1GW of new combined cycle and gas generation. At end-2019, the country had 3.6GW of total installed capacity and 249MW of renewables (excluding hydro). At November 2020, no new utility-scale projects had been commissioned and none were in the pipeline. In its Intended Nationally Determined Contribution to the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change, Bolivia commits to a goal of increasing its share of alternative energy (wind, biomass, geothermal and solar) and other sources of energy (combined cycle) to 9% in 2030, up from 7% in 2017. In 2014, the country published Decree 2048 to encourage clean energy development.

Since 2009, Brazil has implemented reverse auctions to contract new clean energy generation capacity to supply the regulated utility market. The country pioneered competitive auctions, which has led to 30GW of renewable energy contracted to date. As a result of the Covid-19 crisis, on March 30, 2020, Brazil postponed two energy auctions previously scheduled for 2020. The government says it will reassess and announce new auction timelines after the crisis. Two auction rounds scheduled for 2021 remain unchanged. Sharp competition among project developers resulted in the lowest average solar auction price ever recorded in Brazil of $17.5/MWh in July 2019. Net metering has also become a widely utilized clean energy policy. Retail electricity customers may install up to 5MW self-generation facilities, connect to the grid, deliver surplus generation and obtain compensation in the form of a subsequent billing credit. The incentive has led to a distributed solar boom, with small-scale PV capacity jumping from around zero in 2015 to over 5GW (DC) by year-end 2020. However, the boom has prompted a rethink of regulation and retail tariff design and the countrys regulator, ANEEL, is reviewing net metering rules.

Chiles exceptional natural resources make it attractive for clean energy investment. The government has set ambitious long-term goals for adding clean energy capacity. Targets include a clean energy mandate of 20% of generation for utilities by 2025 and 60% of generation by 2035. Chile generated 22% of its power from clean sources in 2019, which accounted for 25% of total installed capacity. The country postponed an auction planned for 2020 that was expected to contract 5.9TWh/year due to the impact of the pandemic on power demand projections. Auctions in Chile are technology-blind, with wind, solar, gas and other technologies competing head-to-head. In 2014, the government implemented changes to its auction program aimed at enhancing the competitiveness of clean energy. Since then, Chile has held four tenders and contracted 31TWh/year. In two of the last three tenders, renewables accounted for 100% of all generation contracted. In January 2018, the countrys coal generators signed an agreement committing to build no new coal-fired assets. In 2019, the government announced a coal retirement plan that will phase out 1.7GW by 2024, or over 30% of total coal capacity. The plan is the first step of Chiles decarbonization strategy, which aims to fully retire its coal fleet by 2040.

Colombias historically weak policy support for non-hydroelectric sources of renewable energy has resulted in limited wind and solar development. However, 2019 saw the country hold its first successful long-term power auction, in which it awarded contracts to 1.3GW of wind and solar projects.  In the same year, Colombia also introduced a mandate for electricity distributors supplying regulated markets to procure 10% of their power from clean energy sources from 2022 onwards.

In February 2019, Costa Rica launched its strategy to become the first country to achieve zero net emissions overall and specifically to reach 100% renewable power by 2030. To put that latter goal in context, in 2019, 99.8% of Costa Ricas generation came from clean sources, including large hydro. Hydropower is the countrys predominant source of capacity at 2,360MW and accounted for 69% of 2019 generation.

The Dominican Republic has set a target to get 25% of its electricity from clean sources by 2025. As of December 2019, 11% of the 5.7 TWh the country had consumed during the year was accounted for by clean generation. The Dominican Republic also has in place a net metering program, which allows retail electricity customers with rooftop solar to be compensated through credits on their bills for sending surplus generation back to the grid.

Ecuador does not have a clear target for renewables, despite claiming an interest to raise clean generation by 2025. The country did not achieve its 90% hydro target to be met by 2017, even with the addition of 2GW of hydro capacity in 2016. The government gives priority of dispatch for biomass, geothermal, small hydro, solar, tidal and wind projects. Renewable energy developers may apply for import tax exemption on clean energy equipment and a five-year waiver on income tax. Furthermore, on November 2018 the government introduced a net metering system, applicable for residential users with an installed capacity up to 300 kW of PV and industrial users with up to 500 kW. Despite that, deployment of wind and solar assets has been minimal. In 2019, the country launched a renewable auction for a 110MW wind portfolio and a solar PV project of 200MW. The Ministry of Energy received offers from Solarpack, Cobra Zero-E, Neoen and Total and intended to award concessions by year-end 2020.  The government also launched a tender for solar-plus-storage in the Galapagos Islands, aiming to reduce reliance on diesel generation. Ecuador was one of the few countries in Latin America to offer a feed-in-tariff for renewables, but it is currently not in force.

El Salvadors government is focused on diversifying its power matrix and cutting its oil dependency by adding renewable energy capacity. Since 2013 the country has held three auctions, contracting 285MW of renewable capacity. It offers income and import tax exemptions to clean energy projects and guarantees priority dispatch to clean electricity.

To incentivize renewables development, Guatemala has a net metering program which compensates self-generators for surpluses sent back to the grid. The country also has a target of generating 64% of its electricity from renewable sources by 2032. In May 2019, Guatemala launched a tender for 110MW of solar capacity. However, due to lack of feasibility studies and inconsistencies in proposals from bidders Total Eren Guatemala S.A and Corporacin Klondike S.A., the tender was canceled in August. The government intends to repeat the exercise but has set no timeline.

Improving energy access is a central announced goal of Haiti President Jovenel Mose. He has abolished import duties on wind and solar generation products as well as solar appliances as the government has adopted the Scaling-up Renewable Energy Plan (SREP) with advice from the Climate Investment Fund. In addition, the country has established a voluntary clean energy target on its Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC). It aims to increase to 47% the share of renewable energy capacity by 2030, with 24.5% to come from hydro, 9.4% wind, 7.5% solar and 5.6% biomass. Grants and projects have focused on restructuring Haitis national power company Electricit dHaiti (EDH). On a smaller scale, microgrid projects are appearing across the island. On September 13, 2019, the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) launched a tender for the construction of three microgrids in Capotille, Vallires and Mont-Organis cities, as part of its Rural Electrification and Women Empowerment project. In January 2018, Haiti announced it is opening its generation, transmission and distribution sectors to private participation in eight regions of the country by awarding concessions. As of the end of September 2019, the government had opened the pre-qualification process for companies interested in providing power services in Miragone, Les Cayes and Caracol.

The Honduras Country Vision Plan 2010-2038 set a national target of 60% renewable power by 2022. Decree 70-2007, published in June 2007, guarantees priority dispatch to electricity generated from clean sources. Renewable power is also exempt from income, import value and sales taxes.

Jamaica is seeking to cut its dependency on oil while improving energy security by diversifying its electricity mix. The countrys Ministry of Science, Energy and Technology has unveiled a 20-year Integrated Resource Plan (IRP) committing Jamaica to generating half its power from renewables by 2037 with at least 1,260MW of clean capacity .  The country has approximately 400MW of clean power under development, including 320MW of solar and wind plus 74MW of hydro, waste-to-energy or biomass. The government is expected to release details on how to respond to upcoming requests for proposals (RFP) in the first quarter of 2021. The last time Jamaica issued an RFP was in 2015. Private utility Jamaica Public Service (JPS) has responsibility for generation, transmission, and distribution on the island (the government owns 20% of the company). Other players may enter as independent power producers (IPPs) and sell electricity to JPS.

Strong support for renewable energy is embedded in the reforms that have transformed Mexicos energy sector. In 2012, Mexico established a mandate to generate 35% of power from clean sources by 2024. It authorized a Clean Energy Certificates (CEL) market in 2014. It also introduced a renewables mandate for power consumption, applying to all large consumers in the market including state-owned utility Comisin Federal de Electricidad (CFE), that began at 5% in 2018 and rises to 13.9% in 2022. Progress on market reform and support for renewable energy have, however, stalled under current President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador (AMLO). AMLO has challenged energy reform and sought to block the growth of renewables with the aim of supporting the CFE. In his first two years in office AMLO has canceled Mexicos highly successful renewables auction program, sought to dilute the CEL market, sidelined clean energy targets and eliminated legacy benefits that wind and solar plants received. Ominously, AMLO issued regulation in 2020 aimed at giving the countrys market operator expanded powers to block renewables from participating in the system, asserting that intermittent sources of generation pose a threat to the overall reliability of Mexicos power grid. Implementation of these policies was successfully challenged under Mexican laws, but the government maintains its support for such measures, casting uncertainty over the countrys energy policymaking.

The Nicaragua Ministry of Energy and Mines updated in January 2017 the countrys Plan for Electric Generation Expansion 2016-2030, with a non-binding 73% by 2030 renewables generation target (including large hydro). The plan also sets an interim renewables goal of 64% by 2023. In 2018, the country achieved 58% with wind and geothermal the biggest contributors at 17% apiece. Renewable energy developers enjoy a full range of tax breaks in Nicaragua, including exemptions on import duties, value-added taxes and income taxes. In addition, in January 2018 the government unveiled net metering rules that allow owners of PV systems up to 5MW in size to sell their surplus power back to Nicaraguas distribution companies.

Panamas efforts to promote renewable energy development include tax policies and duty exemptions but it no longer holds tenders specifically for clean energy contracts. The government exempts clean power projects from paying value-added taxes and offers income tax credits equal to 25-50% of a projects capex, depending its size. In February 2018, the Electric Transmission Company (ETESA) announced that, due to changes in the law, there will be no further tenders specifically to solicit bids from clean energy projects. Instead, all generation sources will compete with each other for contracts. However, ETESA also said technologies will be evaluated based on their environmental attributes and associated costs.

With almost all of its electricity demand met by three large hydro plants totaling 8.8GW, Paraguay has had little incentive to develop a policy framework for other energy sources. In fact, the country exports more electricity than it consumes. The only clean energy policy incentive in Paraguay is a biofuel blending mandate for gasoline and diesel.

Technology-specific auctions have been essential for renewables deployment in Peru. In 2008, under Decree No. 1002, the government established auctions to contract on-grid renewable capacity every two years. Since then, four auctions have been carried out, resulting in 71 project developments totaling 1.34GW of biomass, small hydro, solar and wind. Peru also offers priority dispatch to clean energy plants and 20% accelerated depreciation for renewables projects. Peru held an auction for off-grid solar in November 2014 to contract up to 500,000 off-grid PV systems. Ergon, the only winner, announced that will develop 150,000 to 200,000 systems by 2034, when the investment contract expires. As of July 2019, Ergon had commissioned almost 134,000 systems. Peru was among the first countries to hold off-grid energy auctions.

Uruguay has the highest rate of non-hydro clean energy penetration in Latin America and wind and solar met 32% of national power demand in 2019.  . The substantial presence of renewables reflects Uruguays strong clean energy policy regime and its longstanding National Energy Plan, which mandated 15% renewables by 2015. The plan also required that 300MW of wind and 200MW of biomass be added to the national grid by the same year. The goal was achieved a year early and in 2015 the country had 857MW of wind and 425MW of biomass installed. After reaching the 2015 goal, Uruguay clean energy activity slowed and the country has commissioned almost no new wind or solar capacity in the last three years. As of year-end 2019, Uruguay had 1,524MW of wind and 231MW of solar online. The Administracin Nacional de Usinas y Transmisiones Elctricas (UTE) raised hopes that clean energy development could return to Uruguay when in 2019 it released rules related to a potential tender for 65MW of new PV capacity. The auction was later postponed, however and as of November 2020 had still not been held.

Afghanistans renewable energy policy targets the development of 4.5GW-5GW of capacity by 2032. The policy is divided into two terms  Term 1 (2015-2020), which aims to create favorable environment for the growth of the renewables sector and Term 2 (2020-2032), which will actually achieve the capacity targets. There has been little progress on this target to date. The country has no auctions, feed-in tariffs or other incentivizing policies in place to promote renewables development. Net metering and import tax exemptions are nominally available, but there is little evidence about uptake.

Armenia is unlikely to reach an ambitious 21% renewable generation by 2020, which excludes large hydro, given the current share is 13%, but the country may approach 26% by 2025 with the growing uptake of utility-scale PV. Since 2007, Armenia has encouraged clean energy development with 15- to 20-year technology-specific feed-in tariffs. However, these tariffs are quite low, especially for wind where the tariff halved in 2019, therefore stalling discussions with developers. Renewable energy equipment is exempt from customs duties and the value-added-tax may be adjourned for up to three years following an official request. Residential and commercial customers can consume their own generation and sell it to the grid at 50% of residential prices for PV (or 100% for small hydro). This was limited to 150kW and then increased to 500kW in 2019. The uptake of self-generation has been high, totaling over 50MW PV and 374MW small hydro.

Australia has had a plethora of renewable energy policies over the years, both enforced and proposed. Its existing flagship policy, the Large-scale Renewable Energy Target (LRET), has largely run its course  driving an explosion of investment over 2017-18  , with enough capacity now secured to reach its legislated 33TWh target by 2030. A patch work of smaller programs, such as the Small-scale Renewable Energy Scheme(SRES) and state-based auctions, will continue to support new investment, but lack the muscle of a comprehensive federal policy. Combative federal politics means new supportive policy is not likely in the near term.

Azerbaijans renewables market is still in the early stages of development. The country is working toward a low 20% renewable generation target, and has awarded contracts to meet this. Feed-in tariffs are negotiated on a project-by-project basis, as rates paid by the state-owned utility for renewables generation would otherwise make investment unprofitable. The government is developing a standardized power purchase agreement (PPA) to amend this and help it meet its unofficial 30% renewable generation target by 2030. Oil and gas companies, which have long operated in Azerbaijan, may well be among the most serious contenders in the medium term. Larger utilities from abroad have been slow to show interest in investing in renewables in the country; however, the government is working hard to change this.

Bangladesh has a target of raising the share of renewables in total electricity production to 10% by 2021 from the current 2%. At present, the country has 649MW of installed renewable energy capacity out of a total 20GW. Current developments are slow and the target is unlikely to be met. Land scarcity, delays in getting project approvals and high equipment costs are deterring a faster growth. While some renewable projects have secured reasonable feed-in tariffs, they face the risk of cancellations due to delays in getting project approvals. Large-scale auctions are rare. Net metering is offered for rooftop PV, with limits on plant size. The government-owned financing institution, the Infrastructure Development Company (IDCOL), introduced the Solar Home System (SHS) program in 2003 for providing subsidized systems to remote parts of the country.  It is one of the largest off-grid solar programs in the world and as of January 2019, covered 12% of the countrys total population.

Cambodia has a limited number of clean energy policies in place today, and there are no incentives such as feed-in tariffs or net metering which could support residential or commercial solar. The Asian Development Bank has been working with Electricit Du Cambodge (EDC)  the national utility that controls most of the grid and retails power to all grid-connected consumers  to help launch a pilot solar auction to procure 100MW. On February 13, 2019, the EDC invited bids for the first leg of the auction: a 60MW project in Kampong Chhnang province. EDC has been allowing more solar projects to connect to the grid since then. The Blue Circle is working on Cambodias first-ever onshore wind project of 80MW.

The worlds largest power market is undergoing a series of changes that will impact both generation and retail. For renewable energy, generous feed-in tariffs that were the norm for much of the past decade are coming to an end. Subsidy-free capacity  and competitive auctions to allocate the remaining subsidy  will drive new build in 2020, after which subsidies are likely to be completely eliminated. Retail liberalization now allows wind and solar assets to sell power directly to large-end users in half the country, albeit for a short duration of less than a year. A prosumer (producer+consumer) reform is slowly moving ahead, which, once implemented, will allow distribution-grid-connected projects to serve neighboring loads. Chinas pledge to achieve carbon neutrality before 2060, made by President Xi Jinping on September 22, 2020 should accelerate the growth of clean energy capacity.

Renewable energy installations in Georgia are driven by winter supply constraints and energy diversification concerns rather than the need to reduce carbon emissions. The draft Renewables Law sets the national target for renewable energy at 35% of final consumption by 2030; however, this is not in force yet. Most of the countrys electricity is produced from hydro and natural gas. There are plans for 600MW of wind projects, but these are in the approval stages. The government introduced a residential net-metering program for small-scale solar, but uptake has been limited. Most policy activity in the power sector is market liberalization to align with European Union requirements. The process is under the control of the Georgian National Energy and Water Supply Regulatory Commission (GNERC), the independent energy regulator.

India has an ambitious target of 175GW of installed renewables capacity by 2022. Even though it may fall short, the country will exceed its Paris Climate Agreement target of 40% non-fossil fuel installed capacity by 2030. Auctions have become the primary mechanism for growth of renewables. India was the worlds largest renewables auction market, by cumulative capacity awarded till the end of 2019. Other incentives are also in place  accelerated depreciation, waiver on transmission charges and net metering for rooftop PV. Renewable energy policies have generally been stable but the government has had to balance competing objectives of achieving low tariffs, localization of the value chain and increasing the share of renewables.

Indonesia aims to generate 23% of its total electricity from new and renewable energy sources by 2025, up from 7% in 2019. New and renewable energy sources, however, also include technologies like nuclear, hydrogen, coal bed methane, gasified coal and liquefied coal. Nevertheless, this target is ambitious, given the low levels of finance committed to renewables in the recent past. The Electricity Supply Plan (RUPTL) 2019 sets goals to add 6.1GW of hydro, 4.6GW of geothermal, 4.1GW of solar, 3.5GW of pumped storage and 1.7GW of other renewables over 2019-28. New solar and wind projects are to be awarded through a limited tender process. Bid prices are restricted to 85% of the regional generation cost, if it exceeds the national average. If the regional cost is less than the national average, tariffs can be negotiated between the national utility Perusahaan Listrik Negara (also known as PLN) and the developer. The process to participate in the tender is not clear, and there is little clarity on the template of the power purchase agreement. These policies have increased risks and have rendered renewable energy projects less attractive to investors.

Japans renewable energy goals have not been revised since 2014. The target share of renewable energy in the 2030 generation mix is 22-24%. Since the introduction of feed-in tariffs in 2012, wind and solar generation has increased to 9% of total generation while piling up the feed-in tariff deficit.   Therefore, the competitive auction scheme was introduced, first for solar projects in 2017, then biomass in 2018 and is scheduled for onshore wind in 2021. In the next step, the government has decided to shift from a feed-in tariff to a feed-in premium from 2022 onwards. Project owners will need to manage balancing and price volatility under the new scheme. The subsidy linkage to the wholesale spot market could lower the bankability and revenue predictability of new solar projects, limiting market entry for new players. The government may no longer focus on just solar, given the high penetration of solar in renewable generation. Instead, offshore wind has been gaining momentum in terms of project announcements and development, backed by strong support from the regulator. Despite its lack of target capacity, the government has designated four offshore wind sites, and plans to increase the count to at least five sites by 2030. In July 2020, the government announced plans to phase out 100 inefficient coal power plants by 2030 without details, and did not define inefficiency. On nuclear, the safety review process has become even slower since the pandemic in 2020. The nuclear policy, which is no-new-build, has remained the same since 2014. Despite the challenges with nuclear restarts and coal phase-out policy, the government has designed market mechanisms favorable to nuclear and fossil plants under the power market reform, including baseload market and capacity market.

Kazakhstan has a goal of generating 10% of its electricity from renewable energy sources by 2030. The country initially offered feed-in tariffs to promote renewables development, but later migrated to an auction-based system under the coaching of European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), the International Renewable Energy Agency, and the United States Agency for International Development. The three institutions work closely with Kazakhstan to guide renewable energy policies and also provide financing for energy projects. While nearly 1,000MW of capacity was auctioned in 2018, the size shrunk to 255MW in 2019. Kazakhstans ambitious renewable energy targets are inconsistent with the current policy that limits future tariff increases. Without passing on the additional cost of building renewable energy projects on to tariffs, funding the subsidies will remain a challenge.

South Korea embarked on a Green Growth strategy in 2010 under President Lee Myung-bak, aimed at stimulating the economy and securing energy independence in the long-run. President Moon Jae-in came to power in 2017 and sought a more fundamental shift in the countrys energy policy to ensure environmental sustainability. Through the countrys 8th Basic Plan for Electricity Supply and Demand launched in December 2017, President Moon officially scrapped plans for a number of new nuclear and coal-fired power plants and signaled strong support for gas generation and renewable energy. In July 2020, the Moon administration announced the Korean New Deal, a $133 billion post-coronavirus spending package designed to accelerate the countrys energy transition and digitalize its social infrastructure. The plan aims to add 30GW of solar and wind capacity by 2025. Despite ongoing effort towards a cleaner power mix, electricity generation in South Korea is currently dominated by coal (40%) followed by nuclear power (26%) and gas generators (26%) with renewables contributing only 6% in 2019. The government aims to increase the share of renewables generation to 20% by 2030. Renewable portfolio standards (RPS), introduced in 2012 to replace the feed-in tariff program, are the primary driver of renewable energy deployment in Korea. The country also has an emissions trading scheme that was launched in 2015.

In September 2017, the Kyrgyz government implemented a new program called Forty Steps to a New Epoch that calls for more hydro projects by 2021 and sets a target for renewables to make up 10% of the generation mix, though it doesnt specify technologies or a target year. The program is expected to create incentives for the design, construction and operation of renewables projects, such as exemptions on import duties, expedited or removal of licensing processes, purchasing obligations from the state utility JSC National Grid and preferential feed-in tariffs. The country has no established precedent for building renewables, making these ambitions questionable.

Laos likes to pitch the country as the battery of Asia, eager to capitalize on its abundant hydroelectric resources and small population to export energy to its larger, fast-growing neighbors. Accordingly, it has focused its attention on building large hydro power plants that, in many cases, send power directly across its borders to Thailand or Vietnam. The government is targeting a 30% share for non-hydro renewables in the power mix by 2025. EDL-Gen Solar Power Company was established in 2015 with the aim of building 100MW of solar. Laos is also planning a 40MW solar tender in 2021.

Malaysia passed the Renewable Energy Act in June 2011, and followed it up with the Renewable Energy (Feed-in Approval and Feed-in Tariff Rate) Rules in the same year. Solar PV, small hydro, biomass and biogas projects were allowed to apply for feed-in tariffs. In 2016, the government announced rules for auctions of large-scale solar power projects (greater than 30MW capacity). The country has conducted three rounds of auctions to date. As part of the countrys Covid-19 economic recovery package, the government initiated a 1GW solar power auction in 2020. In 2018, Malaysia announced a target of receiving 20% of its electricity generation from renewable energy by 2025. This target is ambitious but lower than those set by other major markets across the world. Successive governments have, however, ensured continuity in the countrys push to promote renewable energy.

The government aims to reach 20% renewable energy generation share by 2023 and 30% by 2030  a significant leap from the 2018 share of 7%. The most important legal foundation was laid by the Law on Renewable Energy (2007), as well as the National Renewable Energy Program (2005-2020) that provide official targets and incentives for global investors in the sector. The principal incentive is the relatively generous feed-in tariff  (FiT): the price paid under the power-purchase agreement (PPA) signed with the National Dispatching Center. In addition, such FiTs are denominated in dollars and paid in tugriks based on actual exchange rates, helping with mitigation of currency risk. Tax exemptions are also available for importing solar panels and wind turbines to Mongolia.

Myanmars National Electrification Plan targets 50% electrification by 2020 and 100% by 2030. The country appears to be on track to meet these goals. Electrification rate crossed 50% in January 2020 and was at 54% by June 2020. Electricity demand is rising fast as a result, but power plant construction is lagging behind. During the dry season, when hydropower output is low, the grid operator is forced to resort to rolling blackouts as a result. Myanmar aims to generate 8% of electricity through non-hydro renewable energy sources by 2021, and 12% by 2025. To that end, Myanmar announced its first-ever tender for solar power in May 2020. If all of the tendered 1.06GW of solar is built on time, Myanmar has a good chance of reaching its 2021 goal.  Controversies surrounded the tender. Developers had only one month to submit their bids, which would have been insufficient even without the challenge of Covid-19. Myanmar later extended the deadline by another month, but even that was not deemed enough by many developers. Latest news reports indicate that Chinese developers accounted for more than half of all bids. If more solar tenders are floated by 2023-24, Myanmar could meet its 2025 target too. All utility-scale solar is procured via tenders. There is no countrywide feed-in tariff program.

Nepals National Rural and Renewable Energy Program of 2012 targeted 25MW of mini and micro hydro and 600,000 solar home systems. It also set goals for biogas, water pumps and solar cookers. In general the subsidies starting in 2012 were generous and ambitious, but the program has not brought about significant new-build in the renewables sector. The Renewable Energy Subsidy Policy 2016 in force today is relatively stable and clear for market entrants. Technologies that are qualified for subsidies include mini- to small-hydro and improved water mills, solar PV, solar thermal, biogas, biomass, wind, as well as solar-wind hybrid systems. It provides different levels of subsidy to those areas with national grid access or off-grid. The rates are rarely adjusted, and not cost-reflective. No auction or power market is in place. A lot of plans have been initiated to attract investments by Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA, celebrating its 35th anniversary in 2020), but progress has been slow.

New Zealand has a target of 90% renewable electricity (including large hydro) by 2025, in an average hydrological year. While this target is ambitious when compared to many of its peer countries, an abundance of hydro generation means New Zealand is already supplying around 85% of electricity from zero carbon sources. To achieve its target, the governments primary strategy is to remove any barriers to renewable energy investment and support nascent clean energy industries, such as geothermal, biomass and marine power. Due to the countrys heavy reliance on hydro, and limited amounts of dam storage, it is likely fossil fuel generators will remain in the system to provide security of supply, particularly during periods of low rainfall.

Pakistan has a renewable energy target of 60% by 2030, which is not legally binding. Wind, solar, biomass and small hydro will make up 30% of all energy while the other 30% will be met by large hydro. Large hydro already makes up some 27% of electricity generation while other renewables only make up 4.3%. The renewables target is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve as more coal and gas capacity is being added to the power mix as part of the China Pakistan Economic Corridor project. Pakistan offers upfront tariffs for wind and solar which are akin to feed-in tariffs,   and cost reflective, but have resulted in new build of only 1.5GW in the last five years. Offtaker risk, land identification and transmission bottlenecks are some challenges that stall projects.

Two major laws  the Electric Power Industry Reform Act (Epira) and the Renewable Energy Act  have incentivized growth of renewables in Philippines. However, the implementation of these laws has been slow, and the energy targets that were part of these laws were missed. The country now aims for 15.3GW of renewables capacity by 2030, and total generating capacity of about 65GW by 2040. A feed-in tariff has spurred over 1GW of renewable energy installations, and behind-the-meter policies have led to 50MW of distributed resources. In July 2019, the Department of Energy said that the implementation of Renewable Portfolio Standards would be fast-tracked, which will likely spur renewable energy adoption.

The Singapore government has set goals to reduce emissions intensity, improve energy efficiency and expand solar PV installations. It is targeting up to 2GW of installed solar capacity by 2030, of which 350MW was operational by April 2020. Much of the development is constrained to rooftop and floating solar as the city-states lack of land resources (indicated by the high population density) has proved an obstacle for ground-mounted grid-scale development

Sri Lanka approved a long-term electricity generation plan (2020-2039) last year which includes new coal plants to be commissioned starting 2023, the preferred option of the utility Ceylon Electricity Board, and also envisages new gas and renewable energy plants, which is what the regulator Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka or PUCSL favored. The new generation plan increased the proportion of renewables and decreased the proportion of coal slightly, while doubling gas capacity compared to the last plan submitted in 2018. New gas turbines are expected to come online from 2021, which indicates that gas might be what the country would settle for to balance the interests of different parties. Solar capacity installation and generation grows faster than wind in Sri Lanka, as the former benefits from the net metering policy on rooftop installations.

Taiwans feed-in tariffs helped expand wind and solar capacity to 5GW by the end of 2019. The new administration, which came to power in 2016, launched an aggressive energy transition plan to phase out nuclear by 2025 while adding 25GW of renewables. Though most of Taiwans residents were in favor of extending the life of nuclear power in a referendum at the end of 2018, the administration is keeping to its promise of phasing out nuclear by 2025. Lucrative feed-in tariffs (FiT) for offshore wind have attracted major European developers and financiers from Taiwan and overseas. Solar installations exceeded 1GW in 2018 on the back of strong rooftop solar promotion programs, though long-term challenges in land acquisition for utility-scale projects remain.

Tajikistan has little to offer in the way of clean energy policies. While no official renewables target exists, the government aims to have 103MW of small hydro installed by 2020 and, under the SE4All framework, is targeting 10% renewables generation by 2030. To support this goal, the government grants tax exemptions to renewable energy investors. While the small hydro capacity target is within reach, the SE4All remains far off as only 1% of power was generated from renewable energy sources other than large hydro in 2019.

Thailand was the first country in Southeast Asia (SEA) to implement a feed-in premium intended to spur investment and development of renewable energy projects. The generous feed-in premium and subsequent feed-in tariff programs implemented by the government successfully supported the growth of the renewables industry. By the end of 2018, cumulative installed solar capacity totaled 2.8GW and wind capacity slightly exceeded 1GW. The latest power development plan covering 2018-2037 targets an additional 18.6GW of renewable capacity in the next 20 years, with solar accounting for most of the addition, at 10GW. The countrys Alternative Energy Development Plan (AEDP) is currently under revision.

Turkmenistan offers no clean energy policy. While its 2014 national strategy on climate change stated the intention to increase the share of renewables, there has been no concrete follow-up legislation on a target, nor has it defined quantifiable targets in its Nationally Determined Contribution. To date, the power market therefore nearly exclusively consists of gas plants in addition to a 1.2MW small hydro plant.

Uzbekistan has revamped its clean energy market in the past year. In May 2020, the Ministry of Energy announced a goal to source 25% of its power from renewables by 2030, which would require an estimated 5GW of solar and 3GW of wind. In partnership with the International Finance Corporation through its Scaling Solar initiative, the country rolled out its first clean energy auction in October 2019 for a 100MW solar project. It launched a second set of tenders for two 200MW PPAs in February 2020. The targets are ambitious, and using an established framework like Scaling Solar helps, but the countrys lack of history in developing renewables makes success uncertain.

Vietnams revised Power Development Plan VII (PDP) targets 6.5% of electricity generation from renewables in 2020 from an earlier goal of 4.5%, and raised the 2030 target to 10.7% from 6%. In terms of capacity, the plan has a conservative target of 850MW of solar and 800MW of wind in 2020, but scales up to an ambitious 12GW solar and 6GW wind in 2030. To spur development in wind and solar, feed-in tariff (FiT) schemes were introduced. A wind FiT was first introduced in 2011 at $78/MWh, which failed to incentivize development. It was revised in September 2018 - the onshore wind FiT was increased to $85/MWh and an offshore wind FiT of $98/MWh was introduced, with a commissioning deadline of November 1, 2019. The Ministry of Industry and Trade (MOIT) first introduced a solar FiT of $93.5/MWh in April 2017. The scheme expired on June 30, 2019 and a second solar FiT scheme was announced in April 2020. Under the second solar FiT scheme (locally known as FIT2), ground-mounted projects receive $70.90/MWh, floating solar gets $76.90/MWh and rooftop solar receives $83.80/MWh for 20 years from the commissioning date. Solar projects are required to have received investment approval by November 23, 2019 and achieve commercial operations before December 31, 2020 to be eligible for FIT2.

Albania has set a target to meet 38% of its energy needs with renewable sources by 2020. The majority of its installed capacity is in the form of hydropower, though small amounts of solar PV have been breaking into the market. The National Renewable Energy Action Plan established in Albania emphasizes the need to diversify renewable energy toward solar and wind. In 2019, the country unveiled its net metering policy, which is available to systems with capacities up to 500kW. The foundation for this had been established in the Renewable Energy Law in 2017.

Austria wants to achieve climate neutrality by 2040. It is on track to surpass a target of achieving a 34% share for renewables in final energy consumption by 2030, including large hydro. The country is also aiming to have renewables meet 100% of electricity consumption and half of final energy consumption by 2030. The government is also aiming to install 1 million rooftop PV systems by 2030. Renewables are supported through feed-in tariffs and upfront capital grants, although the government is drafting a new energy law to transition to a premium-based auction system. Originally due by 2021, the final law is likely to be somewhat delayed.

Belarus has very limited clean energy policy in place. The 2015 Presidential Decree on renewable energy and the Energy Saving Programme foresee a modest target of 6-7% of installed clean energy capacity by 2020. The country will likely just fall short of this target, with 4% of renewable power capacity recorded in 2019. The countrys mechanism to advance clean energy build is via an annual quota system, which sets different technology thresholds. In 2019, the quota was for 15.9MW of wind power only. In 2020, the quota is for 6MW biogas, 19.8MW wind, 7MW hydro and 1.5MW wood fuel and other biomass. Small-scale industrial users can benefit from a ten-year feed-in tariff. Finally, Belarus offers custom duties and tax incentives to clean power projects that are considered official investment projects (i.e. the developers have signed an investment agreement with Belarus).

Belgian energy policy is set at a federal and regional level. National targets include a 17.5% renewables share of final energy consumption and 40% of electricity, both by 2030. Insofar as specific renewables, Belgium is targeting 4GW of offshore wind by 2030. The regions  Flanders, Wallonia and Brussels  have their own targets for technology and renewables share of consumption. Renewables are procured through green certificates issued for the production of renewable power. These are then purchased by obligated retailers before being bought by the transmission system operator. Moreover, Flanders net-metering scheme is Belgiums most successful  it is due to be replaced by new grant-based incentives for self-consumption by 2021.

Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) is split into two political entities  the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (FBiH) and Republika Srpska. The two regions have separate governments and determine their energy policy independently. Each region has a separate feed-in tariff, with Republika Srpska additionally offering a feed-in premium. These schemes have only encouraged the build-out of smaller plants so far. In 2019, Republika Srpska removed wind from the technologies eligible for receiving a feed-in tariff or premium, causing policy uncertainty. State utilities have negotiated deals for larger wind farms directly with government. In Republika Srpska, self-generation is encouraged by offering a premium for the electricity produced. The country also has a target for renewable energy share in gross final energy consumption, set through the National Renewable Energy Action Plan that has been submitted to the European Commission. The country aims to reach 40% of renewable energy in total final consumption by 2020. FBiH is planning to introduce auctions in 2021.

Bulgaria reached 20.5% renewable energy in final energy consumption in 2018, overachieving on its 2020 target of 16%. The country aims to reach a 25% share of renewables by 2030, according to its National Energy and Climate Plan submitted to the EU. At the end of 2018, the share of renewables in its power sector reached 22% for electricity, 30% for heating and 8% for transport. The rapid progress made in the power sector saw renewables double their share in less than 10 years, due to a generous feed-in tariff that fuelled a solar investment boom. Unfortunately, Bulgaria's power sector suffered from a large deficit and government-enacted retroactive cuts to renewables subsidies in 2012 that have stunted the sector's growth.
