Bulgaria aims for solar growth until 2030 to be carried out largely based on market conditions, although small-scale solar systems of less than 30kW could start to receive feed-in-tariffs.

Croatia set renewable energy targets for 2030 in its final Integrated National Energy and Climate plan for 2021-2030. The country aims to expand the share of renewables in final energy consumption to 36.4% by 2030: 63.8% in electricity, 36.6% in heat and cooling, and 13.2% in transport. The energy strategy legislation includes feed-in premiums and guaranteed power purchase prices for wind and solar, awarded via auctions. So far, no support was awarded under the scheme. However, the Croatian Market Operator for Energy (HROTE) launched the first auction for feed-in premium and guaranteed purchase price in August 2020.

The Czech Republic does not currently offer any support mechanism to new renewables projects. A short-lived renewables boom ended in 2011 when the government imposed a retroactive tax on solar projects to limit returns and lengthen the payback period. Further laws in 2012-2013 effectively put a moratorium on further deployment, with renewables additions averaging 30MW a year since then. Since 2014, only new small-scale hydro projects have been eligible for support. Nevertheless, the Czech Republic achieved its 2020 renewable energy target seven years ahead of schedule, which affirms that the original goal was not very ambitious. For 2030, the country has targeted a 22% share of renewables in final energy consumption  which is below the Commissions recommendation of at least 23%. A commission to formulate the countrys eventual move away from coal was established in March 2019, and is expected to launch a phase-out plan by the end of 2020.

Denmark is characterized by a bipartisan and almost unilateral energy policy, which has survived several changes in government and energy market trends. The country has committed to achieving 100% renewable electricity supply by 2030 and net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. Denmark has already met its legally binding 2020 renewable energy goal, with a 36% share of renewables in final energy consumption in 2018 compared to a 30% target. Denmark has two major auction schemes for renewable energy projects: a technology-neutral auction scheme (mainly for onshore wind and PV) and a separate tender scheme for offshore wind. Denmark encourages developers to offer nearby communities at least a 20% stake in onshore wind farms taller than 20 meters and has put a limit on the number of onshore wind turbines to be installed in the country by 2030.

Finlands Energy Authority tendered 4TWh of capacity through a technology-neutral auction in 2018, which awarded seven wind farms with 12 year feed-in-premium contracts. No new auctions have been announced since. Until 2017, Finland offered a feed-in premium for wind and various bioenergy technologies. Utility-scale solar has not taken off, but distributed solar capacity reached 197MW in 2019. This is set to grow as legislative changes from 2021 make solar more attractive for blocks of flats. The government submitted a bill in October 2018 to ban the use of coal for energy, with a draft deadline of May 2029 for most plants. The government has agreed on a 90 million euro investment support scheme for plants that switch away from coal before 2025. Policymakers envision that nuclear will replace at least a part of the outgoing coal capacity, and two new reactors are expected to come online by 2022 and 2028. Small modular reactors for district heating are also being investigated.

France has set itself ambitious technology-specific renewables targets through its 10-year roadmap, ratified in January 2020. This is underpinned by a net-zero target for 2050. An auction timeline extends to 2028 for most renewables technologies, and 10 or so rounds will be held each year. In addition, a feed-in tariff is now restricted to small-scale installations, although in October 2020 the government announced that it would raise the size limit for PV projects from 100kW to 500kW. France has committed to not building any additional fossil-fuel capacity, meaning renewables will dominate additions. This is especially relevant in light of the governments plans to reduce the countrys dependence on nuclear  the technologys generation share is to reach 50% by 2035, from 71% in 2019.

One of the worlds first movers in backing renewables, Germanys support programs have shifted from feed-in tariffs to auctions for most utility-scale technologies. Over 90GW of renewables capacity is to be tendered over 2020-29, a similar volume to that installed as of 2019. Onshore wind auctions are suffering from a drop in participation, largely the result of permitting and acceptance issues. Innovation auctions, launched in September 2020, reward hybrid renewables projects and storage, while feed-in tariffs continue to support small-scale installations such as rooftop PV. Europes largest renewables market will have to continue growing to achieve a net-zero goal set for 2050. Germany also has ambitious targets for emissions, renewable consumption share and renewables capacity for 2030.

Greece procures renewables capacity through an auction program that awards a feed-in premium. Since the program was launched in 2018, more than 2.5GW of wind and solar projects have been awarded. The country has met its 2020 target of 18% renewables in final energy consumption in 2018. Greece is increasing its ambition toward 2030, with a targeted share of 65% for renewables in electricity generation. The country will need to rapidly expand the policy framework to double the share of renewables in electricity generation over the next decade. An almost-total lignite phase-out by 2023 and increasing interconnection of the countrys island systems can offer growing opportunities for renewables deployment.

Hungary held its first renewables tender in 2019, supporting large-scale projects of over 1MW again, after it suspended its feed-in tariff (KAT) for new renewables projects above 0.5MW at the end of 2016. A new support program (Metar) was introduced in 2017, allowing new renewable projects of 0.5-1MW to receive a feed-in premium and sell on the wholesale market. Projects between 50kW and 0.5MW are still eligible for the KAT feed-in tariff, but PV applications for this category ended in May 2018. Wind power is not eligible for the Metar feed-in premium, and restrictions on building locations make support for wind very unlikely, although it is officially allowed to participate in tenders. The government has also introduced net metering for plants below 40kW, and has expanded its incentives for electric vehicle uptake. The country was the first EU member state to ratify the Paris Agreement, but progress on increasing renewables has been somewhat limited by its focus on nuclear. Hungary reached 16% renewables in 2013, above its 2020 EU clean-energy target of 13%, but the share has declined since. Hungarys clean-energy target for 2030 is 21%, notably below the overall EU target of 32%.

Ireland is committed to producing at least 16% of all energy consumed from renewable sources by 2020. It aims to meet this target through 40% renewable electricity, 12% renewable heat and 10% renewable transport. The country had its first round of auctions for renewable energy projects in June 2020, wherein results showed a strong turnout for solar projects. The next round will be held in 2021. Ireland has a net metering scheme, within which renewable energy is given priority grid access. It is phasing out coal plants, as well as oil and gas exploration projects.

Italys National Energy and Climate Plan (NECP) aims to achieve 26% of generation from renewables in 2020 and 55% in 2030. There is no rush to build more renewable capacity as it has achieved its 2020 target. The Italian renewable industry is looking forward to a new round of subsidies, as the European Commission granted state aid approval to the countrys auction scheme in 2019. This will revive investment in renewables, which slumped in 2013 as subsidies ended. As of September 2020, two auctions awarded a total of 964MW of contracts to wind and solar generators. The country must ramp up construction for its 2030 target of 55% renewables in electricity generation.

Lithuania achieved its 2020 target of 23% renewable energy in total electricity supply ahead of schedule  reaching 25.8% in 2017. The role for renewables is set to increase, with the target for 2030 now at 45%. The countrys first renewables auction was held in September 2019, where a 75MW wind farm was awarded a zero-subsidy contract and dispatch priority. The auction scheme will run from 2020 to 2022 with a total budget of 385 million euros ($20 million). Offshore wind auctions are planned for 2023. Lithuania has ambitious plans for what it calls 'prosumers'. These small-scale solar installations will receive a boost from a solar rebate scheme of 17 million euros, as well as from net-metering or sliding feed-in-tariffs for small-scale (up to 10kW in capacity) renewable projects. Low-emission transport has few incentives in Lithuania compared to other EU countries, although a 2020 scheme enables companies to apply for investment support for low-emission vehicles. Lithuania plans for 80-90% of heat to be produced from renewables by 2030.

Moldova in 2013 introduced National Energy Strategy targets that include the use of 20% renewables in the country's total final consumption and 10% renewables in electricity generation by 2020. While it appears that Moldova will fall short of its total final consumption target, it is on track to meet its goal for renewable electricity generation. Moldova's law on renewable energy, which took effect in March 2019, specifies the use of tenders to contract renewable energy. However, to date no auction schedule or details have been issued. Net metering is available for customers generating up to 100kW for their own consumption.

The Netherlands is falling behind on its EU target to source 14% of final energy consumption from renewables by 2020, having achieved just 7% in 2018. Its Climate Plan of June 2019 introduced a strategy to further decarbonize the economy in areas such as buildings, transport, industry and agriculture. A 2029 coal phase-out has been set, although the pace of closures has been accelerated by a landmark climate ruling  the Urgenda case  which has already moved forward the closure of a 630MW unit. This will bring emissions closer to the country's 2020 targets. The government has ramped up auction budgets in recent years with the aim of accelerating deployment. It also has one of the most ambitious offshore wind programs in the world. A roadmap for the technology published in March 2018 outlines plans to build a further 7GW between 2024 and 2030. A major turning point for the gas-reliant country came with the decision to halt extraction from the Groningen gas field by 2030 following renewed tremors in January 2018. This will fuel a more general transition away from gas-fired generation and heating in coming years. A ban on connecting new homes to the gas grid, passed in June 2018, is a step in this direction.

In 2019, North Macedonia drafted three energy scenarios in a Strategy for Energy Development. These focus on improving energy efficiency and expanding renewable energy to varying degrees with a look forward to 2040. The moderate and green transition scenarios both align with a coal phase-out by 2025. In 2017, the country revised its National Renewable Energy Action Plan to target 24% of its gross final energy consumption from renewable sources; this is down from 28% in a previous version. Feed-in tariffs for energy generated from small hydropower, wind, biomass/biogas and solar photovoltaics have been in effect for several years, and in 2019 feed-in premiums were extended to solar PV.

Renewables were supported through a joint tradable green certificate scheme with Sweden, which Norway left in 2020. There is no long-term variable renewables build-up plan as the country has almost entirely decarbonized its power sector with hydroelectricity. Norway has an overall emissions reductions target of 50-55% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels, which will require decarbonization of other sectors. The country's vast sovereign wealth fund is a key investor and has committed to divest from all coal-related investments and instead build up its clean energy portfolio.

Renewables projects in Poland are incentivized through auctions awarding award contracts for difference. The scheme was adopted into law in June 2018, with the first auction held in November 2018. The most recent round, in December 2019, was Europes largest win for onshore wind since 2017. Until July 2016 Polish clean energy projects were eligible for renewable energy credits, though prices plummeted after a regulatory change. They have since begun to recover after an increase in utilities' purchase obligations in 2018. Offshore wind has attracted investor interest, but the policy support framework has been slow to emerge. Small-scale PV has gained momentum in the last year on the back of a robust subsidy program with grants and net-metering available.

Although the Portuguese government did not retroactively cut subsidies like neighboring Spain, it disincentivized renewables by suspending its feed-in tariff for large projects projects in 2012. The government is phasing out subsidies as contracts expire, but existing plants still receive feed-in tariffs. In 2017, the first feed-in tariffs expired and switched to market prices. Another large batch of contracts expired in 2020. In 2018 the government set up a task force to simplify approvals of new solar projects that receive no subsidized support from the state and sell on the spot market. After several years of stagnant growth in new solar capacity additions, the government in 2019 held the country's first utility-scale PV auction, which awarded 1.15GW of new capacity contracts at very low tariffs.

Romania is on course to achieve its 2020 clean energy target, despite unforeseen detours. The government established a green certificate (GC) scheme in 2008 to achieve its 2020 target of 43% renewable electricity consumption. Poor design and an unexpected drop in power demand caused the scheme to be oversubscribed. To limit upward pressure on retail electricity prices, the government imposed quota reductions. Successive reforms have failed to resolve the GC oversupply. New policies have been established to support the 2030 renewable electricity target of 49.4%. In June 2018, Romanias parliament approved the introduction of a net-metering scheme for small-scale renewables up to 100kW, which allows individuals to deduct the power they produce from their electricity bill. Residential solar is also supported through the Casa Verde grant program that finally kicked off in September 2020 following administrative delays. For utility scale projects, Romania adopted regulations allowing corporate power purchase agreements for projects built after June 2020. An auction scheme starting in 2021 or 2021 is under discussion.

Russia aims to increase the share of renewable energy in power generation from under 1% currently to 2.5% by 2024. In 2013, the country launched an annual renewables auction program to support solar, wind and small hydro. The target was originally set in 2009, at a more ambitious 4.5% by 2020, but this was revised down in 2013. Though the policy is due to expire in five years, it is widely expected that support for renewables will continue beyond 2024. The auctions are accessible to all, but a local partner is required for international firms. So far, theyve attracted domestic and international players. However, much of the capacity awarded so far has not actually been built yet.

Serbia is planning to achieve 27% of renewable energy in final energy consumption by 2020. Aside the steady increase of wind generation following the recent commissioning of large-scale projects, little progress has been made so far on this target. Since 2016, Serbia has offered a feed-in tariff to support wind, solar, biomass, biogas, hydro and geothermal. The feed-in tariff has been high enough to trigger capacity additions, but there are technology caps, to curb excessive build-out and ensure a manageable subsidy budget. The country is planning to replace the feed-in tariff scheme with auctions in the near future, however, their introduction has been delayed multiple times in the past. At the outset of the Covid-19 pandemic, state utility EPS invoked the force majeure clause of its PPAs to temporarily freeze payments to privileged power producers. This freeze was only valid as long as the national state of emergency persisted and deferred, but did not annul contractual obligations.

Slovakia aims for 27.3% share of renewables in the electricity sector by 2030 and will likely reach the goal given the current policies and activities. The countrys first technology-neutral large scale renewable energy auction was launched in February 2020. However, it was cancelled on April 1 due to Covid-19. The feed-in tariff remains in place for existing installations, with rates that are administratively adjusted every year. This had created uncertainty for renewable developers and investors, particularly as the premium fell roughly 30% across technologies between 2016 and 2017. The new scheme aims to address this volatility. Slovakia also provides a bonus payment for the generation of the first 5MW (15MW for wind) of capacity, which supports mainly small-scale installations. Renewable electricity consumption is exempt from the excise duty of 1.32 euros/MWh, and such projects benefit from priority dispatch to the grid.

Slovenia aims to source 43% of its electricity from renewable energy by 2030. Based on announced policies, Slovenia will not be able to reach the target.  In March 2018, the country published its long-term energy strategy, committing to cut greenhouse gas emissions by at least 80% below 1990 levels by 2050. The results from the latest renewables and CHP auction, announced in June 2018, saw wind projects securing most of the feed-in premium support, at 109MW. This compared with 11.4MW for solar and the remaining 9MW being biomass, CHP and hydro. The auction system is meant to provide investor certainty. However, it lacks size in terms of budget and projects, procuring just 129MW with 10 million euros, limiting the renewables growth somewhat.

Spains renewable energy market has bounced back since the era of retroactive cuts to renewables subsidies in 2013, which were passed due to a ballooning tariff deficit and overcapacity. Three auctions held between 2016 and 2017 awarded 4.6GW to onshore wind, 3.9GW to solar, and 200MW to biomass. Prior to this, by 2014, the feed-in tariff and premium schemes had been replaced with a 'regulated return on investment', under which a project was guaranteed 'reasonable profitability' and its returns were adjusted for wholesale power prices. The country is legally bound to its EU target of 20% renewable energy consumption by 2020. It is on course for having reached 18% in 2018, and has also set ambitious targets for 2030, including 42% renewable energy consumption and 74% renewables in electricity.

Sweden has an ambitious long-term goal of 100% renewable energy by 2040. Renewable projects in Sweden are supported by an electricity certificate scheme, which provides producers with a revenue stream supplementing income from selling power to the grid. Norway joined the scheme in 2012. The scheme will likely exceed its 46.4TWh target next year, but has struggled with oversupply, which has led to low prices, reaching a record low of 1.9 euros/MWh in September 2020. Thus, the program will close to new entrants on January 1, 2022, and end in 2035. The quota for RECs will be slightly lowered in 2021, from 28.8% to 26.3%. Supply of RECs will also decrease, as the early projects eligible for green certificates reach the end of the 15-year compensation period.

The Swiss Federal Council announced plans for renewable energy auctions at the end of 2019, but there is not yet any clarity on timelines or technologies. Switzerland provides feed-in premiums for renewables, which is financed by a special fund raised through a consumer surcharge of up to 23 Swiss francs ($25)/MWh. Historically, this program has mostly been used for solar project support. The Swiss Energy Act includes the target of adding 5,400GWh of additional renewable electricity on an annual basis by 2030 compared to 2000. Some 2,000 of the aforementioned 5,400GWh are to come from hydropower. The government is phasing out nuclear power, leaving open a capacity gap for renewables.

Turkey has ambitious renewables targets across sectors  it aims to reach 20GW of installed wind capacity, 5GW of solar and 1GW of geothermal by 2023, as well as 34GW of hydro, for a total of 60GW of renewables. A boom in unlicensed solar development saw Turkey reach its 5GW target by the end of 2018, while the 1GW geothermal target was reached in 2017 due to a generous feed-in tariff. Wind growth has been steady, however, the 20GW target would require the installation of more than 3GW a year of additional capacity between 2020 and 2023, and policy support has been inconsistent. The site-specific 1GW Yeka auctions have yet to deliver any capacity, amid cancelations and delays. The feed-in tariff is also due to expire after 2020, with no visibility on support for renewables after that point.

Ukraine appears to be on track to reach its 2020 target of an 11% share of renewables in power generation. A generous feed-in tariff, tax incentives for the import of renewables-related equipment and a break on corporate tax for sales of electricity from renewable sources spurred a surge in build since 2017, though the market has been plagued by talks of retroactive cuts since September 2019. Ukraines Electricity Law, which came into full effect in July 2019, established an framework meant to support continued growth of renewables through a tender/auction program, but auctions have been delayed. The law also liberalizes the power market, clarifies the offtakers role and establishes a framework for standardized power purchase agreements. This boosted investor confidence, which had been undermined by political instability over the past decade and territorial conflict with Russia. More recently, subsidy cuts agreed to in July 2020 are likely to dilute that confidence.

The U.K. power policy landscape has changed significantly in the last five years, as the government has sought to minimize public spending on incentive schemes for renewables. The Renewables Obligation certificate program ended for onshore wind and PV a year earlier than planned and closed its doors to the remaining technologies in 2017. The feed-in tariff was also put on the chopping block. Now, the only substantial support available for large renewables projects is through the Contract-for-Difference (CfD) auction scheme. The government has focused the CfD scheme on delivering support for offshore wind. A sector deal for the offshore wind industry released in 2019 promises to deliver at least 30GW by 2030 - and the government has more recently promised to increase this target to 40GW. In 2019, the U.K. increased the ambition of its emissions reduction targets by legislating for a net-zero emissions reduction goal by 2050. Beyond renewables, the government also seems committed to nuclear power and has announced its sector deal in June 2018. However, it has struggled to attract investment for the substantial pipeline of new-build nuclear assets. After a costly deal was signed with EDF to complete Hinkley Point C, the government is having to rethink how it incentivizes investment to new nuclear plants.

Until recently, Algeria had an ambitious renewables target in place to add 22GW of renewables capacity by 2030. This was scaled back in February 2020, with the new target aiming for 16GW of renewables by 2035, with a mid-term goal of 4GW by 2024. This change underlines Algeria's renewed focus on building out its gas capacity. After limited success, the countrys feed-in tariff was replaced by tenders in 2018. These have been fraught with delays and cancellations, with the lack of progress in large part due to stringent local content rules, restrictions on the involvement of foreign actors and uncertainties about access to finance. While a 150MW solar tender held in early 2019 was undersubscribed, a subsequent 50MW PV tender was successful.

Much of Angola's infrastructure was destroyed during its 27-year civil war, which ended in 2002. A significant investment program has increased generation capacity from 700MW in 2002 to around 5.5GW in 2019. The country saw capacity grow 22% in 2018 as a result of the commissioning of the 750MW Soyo gas plant and additional phases of the Lauca hydroelectric dam. When fully commissioned, the $4.3 billion Lauca will become the largest hydropower plant in southern Africa, alongside Mozambiques CahoraBassa. Restructuring of the power sector has sought to strengthen the role of an independent regulator, IRSEA (Instituto Regulador do Sector Electrico). It has also sought to unbundle the power market, creating PRODEL-EP on the generation side, together with RNT and ENDE as the transmission- and distribution-system operators. Generation and distribution/retail are technically open to private participation, but private players have not entered either market yet. The power network is fragmented across three regional grids and some isolated systems, though the primary North-Central-South backbone connection - part of the Energy Sector Efficiency and Expansion Program (ESEEP) - is underway as of end-2020. In March 2020 it received a multimillion-dollar loan from the African Development Bank (AfDB).

The government of Benin is opening up the countrys electricity sector to private investors in a bid to increase supply and competition. This is being achieved by way of legislative reforms and clean energy policies. The 2020 Energy Law opened generation, transmission, distribution and retail up to private investment. It also created priority grid access for renewable energy producers, although this was limited to 50% of the authorized capacity. 2019 also saw a first competitive tender for 50MW of PV projects. These will be developed under the build-own-operate-transfer (BOOT) model and will sell power to the countrys state-owned utility Socit Beninoise dnergie Electrique (SBEE) under a 20-year PPA. In addition, the 2020 Energy Law widened the range of tax exemptions for renewable energy equipment.

Historically, Botswana has lacked the legal framework and incentives to develop its renewable energy industry, with the National Energy Policy remaining in draft form since October 2009. An ambitious tender for 100MW of solar PV capacity announced in 2017 was canceled in May 2019. The tender was reissued and redefined in late 2019 as two 50MW IPP projects. Procurement has been initiated on 12 grid-connected, solar- and diesel-powered mini-grids of total capacity up to 35 MW. Both solar PV and mini-grid tenders are expected to have contracted with developers by the end of 2020, although Covid-19 related closures have cast this timeline into doubt. Import and tax incentives apply to a wide range of manufacturing goods and there are no specific provisions for the renewables industry.

Burkina Faso has limited clean energy policy. A few tenders have been held for small-scale solar projects and the government announced 155MW of utility-scale solar capacity to be tendered in 2019, with several other small projects also in the pipeline. In addition, the country offers tax exemptions on solar panels, although the incentive is somewhat limited as it does not extend to complementary equipment. In 2019, the country revised upward its clean energy target to aim for 55% renewables capacity by 2022, up from 50% by 2025. The proportion was at 19.5% in 2019, so there needs to be faster clean energy capacity growth in order to hit this target.

Burundis Electricity Law, last updated in 2015, establishes rules for the development of new generation sites, including the possibility of public-private partnerships, and specific regulation for hydro power plants. The countrys rural electrification program is planned mainly around grid extensions and decentralized systems. The country has a specialized Rural Electrification Agency, which aims to plan and develop projects to electrify isolated areas. The only effective support for renewables developers in Burundi is import-tariff exemptions for solar and wind equipment established by the East African Community, of which Burundi is a member. There are no fiscal incentives or other policy instruments such as feed-in tariffs. There are no specific laws discouraging fossil fuels. Burundi has committed unconditionally to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 3% compared to a business-as-usual scenario for 2030, as part of its nationally determined contribution.

Cameroon has committed to securing 25% electricity generation from renewable sources by 2035, as part of its nationally determined contribution (NDC). In 2019, small hydro and solar accounted for just 5% of Cameroon's installed capacity and 1.5% of Cameroons electricity generation, so there is a long way to go to achieve the target. Also through its NDC, Cameroon targets a 32% emissions reduction from the countrys modeled business-as-usual case. The government aims to reach these goals in part through renewable energy laws, which would introduce a mandatory auction or tendering process, set renewable electricity purchase tariffs, and clarify rules around the purchase of renewable electricity. No draft has been announced as of yet. Cameroon also aims to boost energy access, in part, through grid investment and expansion, providing greater opportunity for grid-tied renewable systems. There are no existing fossil fuel phase-out policies, and one of the two largest power plants in the nations pipeline is the 265MW Limbe gas power project. The only effective support for renewables developers in Cameroon is that equipment benefits from VAT exemptions. Other fiscal incentives, such as import duty waivers, are not consistently implemented. The utility, Eneo, has begun to procure tenders for solar.

The Central African Republic has little in the way of implemented or upcoming clean energy policy. The vast majority of power generation originates from small hydro plants, but the country has no clean energy targets to supplement or maintain these penetration levels. Additionally, there are no auctions, feed-in tariffs or other incentives. Given the challenging security situation of the country, this is not surprising. Officials are keen to develop policies in order to incentivize more independent power producers to become active.

Chad has been slow to set up renewable energy incentives. As a first step, the government created the Agency for the Development of Renewable Energy (ADER) within the Ministry of Petroleum and Energy, which is accountable for renewables-based electrification, among other responsibilities. The government has not set a national target regarding renewable energy deployment or passed any further major supporting policies. The exception is the 2020 finance law, whereby any equipment relevant to the generation and promotion of renewable energy is exempt from import duties and value-added tax.

The Republic of the Congo has little to offer in terms of clean energy policy. The country has neither implemented legislation intended to incentivize the development of renewable energy projects, nor set a specific target that it seeks to achieve. The policy agenda is focused upon managing the emergence of a new state utility and maximizing the countrys large hydropower potential, while clean energy is pushed to the margins.

The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) in January 2019 had its first democratic transfer of power since independence after a controversial election held in December 2018. The countrys National Assembly, however, is still dominated by the opposition party, which was previously led by the former president Joseph Kabila. This has led to a power sharing agreement where the opposition is able to appoint some ministers and heads of government institutions. This agreement could complicate the new governments ability to implement new sweeping policies to overhaul the countrys power sector. The key focus of the government is increasing accessibility to electricity to about 30% by 2030. The country has no specific policies on renewable energy. Tax incentives for renewable energy projects are the sole area where policy directly benefits the industry.

Cte dIvoires clean energy policy consists of several targets, including 42% renewable energy generation by 2030. Some 26% is intended to come from mid- and large-scale hydro, with the remaining 16% from other renewables. Today, the country generates 67% of electricity from natural gas, with the remainder generated by hydropower. To date, it has made no progress in its non-hydro renewable energy targets, with the exception of 37MW of solar projects announced in 2018 and 60MW announced a year later. There is also controversy around a planned 700MW coal power plant by 2024  equivalent to about 30% of the countrys installed capacity today. The 2014 electricity code provides a legal framework for renewable electricity production but there are no other concrete laws or measures in place.

The government has set its sights on clean power providing 42% of electricity generation by 2035, with the target broken down according by renewable technology type. Worryingly, the target-setting strategy document has not been published, while intermediate targets for 2022 are unlikely to be met. But after some trial and error, Egypt has implemented a number of competitive renewables tenders. These include the landmark 1.4GW Benban solar project, commissioned in late 2019. However, a healthy auction pipeline has shrunk due to an oversupply of generation capacity, and there is little visibility on tenders due over coming years. Efforts are being made to encourage rooftop PV through net metering, rules for which were reissued in April 2020.

Eritrea is lacking in renewable energy policy implementation. The country aims for renewables to account for 70% of electricity generation by 2030, as part of its NDC, but does not yet have any enabling framework to help achieve this goal. As a further measure, it plans to improve power sector infrastructure to reduce transmission and distribution losses at least 50% also by 2030. However, there are a lack of incentives for renewable energy developers and very little transparency on existing regulations.

Hydro makes up 90% of the capacity of Ethiopias 4.3GW fleet, making the countrys power matrix among the cleanest and largest in Sub-Saharan Africa. The country has far greater ambitions though, setting a goal for 25GW of power capacity by 2030, of which 22GW would be hydro and 2GW wind. Despite having over 8GW of large hydro in the development pipeline, Ethiopia has a large gap to achieve its target. The roll-out of several policies in the near term should make clean energy investment more attractive. A public-private partnerships law will allow independent power producers to negotiate power purchase agreements directly with the state-owned utility, Ethiopia Electric Power. The country also expanded its Scaling Solar tender, initially for 250MW, to 750MW, indicating a desire to diversify the clean energy mix.

Ghanas government originally set a target of 10% renewable energy generation in the energy mix by 2020, but has since extended the target to 2030. The country has excess power generation capacity compared to demand, which reduces the incentive for the government to authorize IPPs to build new power projects. The current low level of renewable energy penetration is therefore unlikely to increase significantly in the near future. State-owned companies currently receive priority for building new solar projects. In theory, a feed-in tariff program exists today, but developers are unlikely to be able to access it currently.

Guinea offers no policies to incentivize clean energy development, partly as a result of its many rivers and the government focus on tapping into an estimated 6GW of hydropower potential. Promising developments include the creation of the rural electrification agency, AGER, in 2017. That was slow off the mark, however, with a board of directors only having been established in June 2019. State utility EDGs mandate must also be more clearly defined. A long-awaited reform of the 1993 Electricity Law has now been drafted, although has yet to be validated. In an effort to restructure state utility EDG, Veolia has been managing the utility since 2015, with no definite end in sight.

Iraq is slowly expanding its portfolio of clean energy policies. The country aims to generate 10% of its electricity from renewable sources by 2020 under the countrys Integrated National Energy Strategy, with a longer-term goal of 40%. However, this target is a far cry from current nearly non-existent renewables capacity. In 2019, Iraq replaced its largely unsuccessful feed-in tariff scheme with auctions, tendering 755MW of PV capacity. The Covid-19 pandemic, however, has delayed the processing of the winning bids. Learning from an unsuccessful first solar tender in 2016, the 2019 tender included a range of benefits such as improved land access, fewer customs fees and sometimes also sovereign guarantees. There are plans to float a second 750MW auction toward the end of 2020.

Israel has one-off tenders for the construction of renewable-energy projects, mostly solar parks. A feed-in tariff that ended in 2013 has been replaced with a net metering scheme. This has become popular among commercial users but as of 2017, 300MW of its 400MW cap still remained unallocated.  Israel has a target of reaching 30% renewable energy consumption by 2030. Just 4% of total energy came from renewables in 2018.

Jordans National Energy Strategy foresees the country generating 14% of its energy from renewable sources by 2030. The plan, launched earlier this year, follows on from the countrys 2020 strategy, which aimed for 10% renewables in energy by 2020. Jordan is expected to achieve the 2020 target. More than 31 renewable energy PPAs have either been signed or are in process of being signed with National Electric Power Co. (Nepco). This translates to a round of 1,531 megawatts of renewable energy projects; 619 MW of these are wind and 912 MW solar PV. By the end of 2019, the country had installed a total of 1,559MW renewable energy projects, 573MW of which were net metering or wheeling. Jordan has completed two full direct rounds of proposals, and PPAs for the third round of renewable-energy tenders are being finalized. What lies beyond the three rounds Jordans auction timeline is unclear. The government suspended the program to give time to Nepco to complete a new power-sector plan reviewing the technical feasibility of integrating a larger share of renewables. This suspension applies to all renewable-energy projects above 1MW. Jordans ambitious policies have helped it become a regional leader in renewable energy over the last five years. Still, the auction freeze, combined with the less-ambitious 14%  renewable energy target for 2030, mean the decade ahead for Jordans renewable sector could be slower than its last.

In December 2018, President Kenyatta said that Kenya planned to attain 100% green energy consumption by 2020, but there has been no legislative action to set such a target. Kenyattas non-binding target appeared to include large hydro, which accounted for more than 28% of the countrys generation in 2019. Still, Kenya is gradually increasing its non-large hydro renewables by adding solar, wind and geothermal. By end-2019, the country achieved 93% of the target. The government no longer offers a feed-in tariff for these technologies after more than 4GW of capacity applied and which the grid system cannot absorb. The country is in the process of shifting from a feed-in tariff scheme to an auction-based one, but only for wind and solar energy. In September 2020, the Energy and Petroleum Regulatory Authority (EPRA) developed draft Energy Regulations 2020 along with the associated draft Regulatory Impact Statement, which will operationalize the Energy Act 2019. The auction regulation will be available in 2021.

Kuwait's 2030 Energy Strategy sets out to secure 15% of electricity generation from renewable energy sources by 2030. Even though the power mix remains largely hydrocarbon-based, progress has been made in the past years with the deployment of solar (both PV and solar thermal) and onshore wind projects. Aside from this target, Kuwait uses tenders to support more large-scale projects. However, the major project in the pipeline, the 1.5GW Al-Dabdaba, seems to have been scrapped due to Covid-19. The development of renewable energy is in line with the countrys overall goal of freeing up fossil fuels for more value-added sectors like oil refining and petrochemicals, which makes the policy more likely to be stable and consistent.

Lebanon is aiming for a 30% share of renewables in final energy consumption by 2030. The target was proposed in 2018 and adopted by the Lebanese government in 2019. Lebanon has made some movements toward this target, guided by the countrys National Renewable Energy Action Plan, which was released in 2016. Yet, administrative bottlenecks, fiscal woes, Covid-19 challenges and a lack of government have drawn some of the focus away from Lebanons renewable-energy sector.  So far, just one 226MW wind project has signed a PPA. Two additional PV tenders are under way; one for 180MW of solar capacity and another for three 100 MW solar-plus-storage projects. A 400MW wind tender was also under instruction as of September 2020. Government support for renewables is uncertain  in August 2020 the Lebanese government stepped down in the wake for the Beirut port explosion.  Lack of investment and frequent blackouts that plague the power sector are unlikely to be addressed soon.

The Lesotho Energy Policy (2015-2025) provides a strategy for the energy sector but has not been formally adopted, creating uncertainty over the status and plan for the sector. A draft renewable energy framework policy has also been developed, including mechanisms for procuring both off-grid and on-grid renewable energy, but this has not been adopted either. There are no specific regulations for off-grid renewables deployment. The country has set an electricity-access target of 40% of the population by 2020, renewable energy being one of the main tools proposed to achieve this. According to the Lesotho Energy and Water Authority (LEWA) the country has achieved its target and in 2019 the national electrification rate was of 43%.

Liberia introduced energy targets in 2009 for 30% of electricity and 10% overall energy consumption to originate from renewable sources by 2030. This target is not overly ambitious given the countrys heavy reliance on hydropower and its large solar resource. The Rural and Renewable Energy Agency was established in 2015 and microgrid operators have since become active across several communities formerly without access to power. Draft policies and guidelines are being finalized in 2020 for independent power producers, microgrids, electricity licensing, and administration of electric sector.

Madagascar aims to reach 85% renewable generation by 2030, consisting of 75% hydro, 5% solar and 5% wind. In order to achieve this, the government plans to install around 100MW of new renewables between 2015 and 2030. A 20MW project commissioned in 2Q 2018, owned by Jirama, plus a tender for 25MW of solar with storage supported by the World Bank's Scaling Solar program, are the most tangible signs of progress toward this target. Energy project tenders are permitted in Madagascar under the 2017 Electricity Code. Further policies include a reduction in corporate income tax for renewable energy investments  equivalent to 50% of the countrys total investment so far in clean energy. Tariffs and import duties on solar PV equipment have also been reduced.

Historically, 90% of Malawis primary energy has come from burning biomass and only 3% has been met by electricity. Trees are cut down to make charcoal, leading to national concerns of deforestation and exacerbated impacts from climate change. In 2003, the government announced a goal of meeting 7% of primary energy demand with renewable generation by 2020. This was not an ambitious goal, especially given the time allotted. Thanks to Malawis buildout of hydropower dams, the country now produces about 70% of its power from renewable sources. In 2016, the generation market opened up to participation from IPPs. Since then, the central regulator has signed PPAs for roughly 200 MW of renewable energy. This year, the country reached financial close on a 70MW solar project, the first of its kind. The project is delayed due to Covid-19. ESCOM, the central utility, has consistently issued tenders and awarded PPAs, though no projects have been completed to date.

Mali has a small basket of clean energy policies in place. As part of its National Action Plan for Renewable Energy, it aims to increase the share of renewable installed capacity, including medium- and large-scale hydro, to 58.3% by 2030. Clean energy currently accounts for 29% of the countrys total installed capacity, so it has a way to go to achieve its target. Mali offers exemptions on import duties and VAT for solar equipment. A stand-alone feature in the region, the rural electrification fund subsidizes investments in off-grid projects by up to 80% for projects valued at a maximum of $500,000, which is a key factor in boosting Malis vibrant off-grid market. The subsidies should theoretically incentivize the development of capital-intensive technologies such as solar, but most operators have so far been relying on diesel. Solar-diesel hybrid projects are becoming increasingly popular.

Mauritanias government has rolled out little in the way of incentives to deploy clean energy. Nevertheless, renewable energy currently accounts for 25% of total installed capacity, so the country has comfortably overshot its 20% goal by 2020. A public procurement system is in place, with national utility, Somelec, issuing bids for renewable energy-related projects since 2013. However, there are persistent problems about the irregularity of tender announcements and procedures. A law on public-private partnerships was issued in July 2017, in an effort to promote independent power production, but its implementation remains incomplete.

Heavily dependent on fossil-fuel imports for its energy needs, Morocco has ambitious targets of 42% of its generating capacity to be renewable by 2020, and 52% by 2030. At the time these targets were announced in 2009, Morocco had only 280MW of wind capacity. By the end of 2019, renewable capacity had grown to 1,220MW of wind and 711MW of solar. Wind and solar will need to reach 2GW each by 2020 to meet the target. There is enough capacity in the pipeline for Morocco to meet its target, but most of these projects will not be commissioned until after 2020. The renewables sector is seen as key to securing energy independence, whilst reducing expensive fuel imports, and so has received strong state support. The first 400MW of hybrid solar thermal and PV of the Noor-Midelt projects was announced in 2018. The winning consortium, led by EDF, bid a price of $70/MWh, which includes five hours of storage for dispatch into the evening peak.

Mozambique has taken early steps toward development of clean energy alongside ample donor support. A lack of regulatory clarity and follow-through and competing priorities continue to restrain development. While longer-term priorities include large hydroelectric power projects such as the 1,500MW Mphanda Nkuwa dam, nearer-term efforts are focused on fossil facilities and two solar projects, one of which was commissioned in July 2019. Scatec's 40MW Mocuba PV Plant is Mozambique's first utility-scale solar project. A second, Neoen's 40MW Metoro PV Plant, remains under development. Mozambique created its renewable energy feed-in tariff in 2014, intended to apply to PV, wind, biomass and small hydro projects from 10 kW to 10MW. However, the scheme has not come into force. There are no tariffs for off-grid projects or power auctions in Mozambique currently. An effort called Proler aims to launch four pilot tenders by 2021, three for solar and one for wind, of 30-50MW each.

Solar PV is growing in Namibia, having roughly doubled its capacity each year between 2014 and 2018. Solar PV currently represents 13% of installed capacity. Solar PVs relatively low cost and high capacity factors have meant it has eclipsed investment in the wind fleet, which is now comprised of two projects. Most of the equity investment in energy projects built after 2015 has been put up by foreign companies such as Spanish IPP Alten Energias Renovables and Canadian Solar. Pipeline projects are owned by other international stakeholders such as EDF and Innosun. The government recently introduced ownership share rules that limit foreign equity ownership. For example, to qualify for Refit, each project has to allocate at least 30% ownership to disadvantaged local groups. Debt has been provided by local Namibian banks as well as a diverse set of international development banks, such as the African Development Bank, Frances Association of Fundraising Professionals, and the Green Climate Fund.

Niger is unlikely to succeed in its aim to reach a 28% share of renewable energy in installed capacity by 2030, given that its current share is just 5% and the country offers little in the way of clean energy incentives. The government also aims to connect 30% of the population to off-grid renewables by 2030. In September 2017, an import duty exemption for renewable energy components was passed, although the list of exempted equipment is subject to regular review and is inconsistently applied. Since 2016, tenders for renewables projects have been issued and these specify that projects must ultimately be transferred to state utility Nigelec.

Nigeria has a handful of clean energy policies, including an ambitious target to achieve 30 gigawatts of power generation by 2030, of which 30% is expected to come from renewables. The countrys failure to provide a stable electricity grid has created a fertile environment for the decentralized off-grid PV sector to develop. In 2017, Nigeria introduced supportive mini-grid regulation, making it easier for developers to build projects of 100kW to 1MW in size. BNEF estimates that there are 20 megawatts of distributed-PV installed to-date. Projects with capacity in excess of 1MW often require time-consuming approvals, such as a generator license. In the on-grid space, the 14 PV developers that signed utility-scale PPAs in 2016 have stalled, due to discrepancies in guarantees or risk measures that the government needs to make, with no certainty as to when or if these will actually be built.

Oman has ambitious plans to transition to a cleaner and more sustainable energy policy, with a target of 16% of electricity generation derived from renewable sources by 2025, and 30% by 2030 (starting from close to zero in 2018). To achieve these targets, the country has planned for renewable energy projects amounting to 3,050MW to be installed by 2025, including utility-scale solar and wind plus a smaller waste-to-energy plant. Over 1,600MW of solar projects have been auctioned as of September 2020. In addition, financial opportunities such as government-led subsidy for rooftop solar for residential customers and supports of foreign investment can spur renewable energy uptake in the country.

The government of the Palestinian Territories has prioritized renewable energy as a means of meeting growing demand and circumventing limitations on land use and access. However, its 2020 goal of 130MW of renewables capacity is too ambitious, as just 9MW had been installed as of 2019. While a feed-in tariff and net metering scheme are designed to incentivize rooftop solar, limited progress has been made to date. Palestine does not have any currently operational large-scale power plants and thus relies on electricity imports, mainly from Israel. The emphasis on renewables is considered a means of achieving greater energy independence.

Qatar aims to generate 2% of its electricity from renewable energy sources by 2022, and intends to increase that share to 20% by 2030. It is betting on solar projects to achieve the targets, with 800MW solar PV projects being built to support power supply for the 2022 FIFA World Cap, and an early ambition to deploy 10GW of solar power capacity in the country by 2030. The target is very ambitious, given that it is equal to the countrys 2019 installed capacity from all sources.

Rwandas 100% electrification target has been a key driver, and the country has shown unprecedented progress for Sub-Saharan Africa. By the end of 2018  the last year for which there is complete data  the country had attained an electrification rate of 51%, compared to 10% in 2010. The national strategy aims to reach the 100% target via 52% on-grid connections and 48% off-grid solutions, such as solar home systems and mini-grids. REG, the national utility, says that currently 37% of households are connected to the national grid, while 14% access electricity is via off-grid solutions.

Saudi Arabia upped its renewables targets in early 2019  the kingdom is now targeting 58.7GW of renewables capacity by 2030. The target is broken down into technology-specific chunks, the largest of which is 40GW of PV. It is unlikely that the government will meet an interim target of 27.3GW of renewables by 2023  the objective no longer features in official announcements. The countrys renewables sector has had a few false starts, but recent activity shows signs of progress. As of October 2020, some 3.4GW of solar and wind capacity have been auctioned through the countrys main auction program, REPDO. For its part, small-scale solar is likely to be buoyed by the publication of a new net-metering framework in July 2020.

Senegal has set itself a target of 15% renewable energy by 2025, which will be met as soon as 2020. The target will likely be raised to 18% by 2023. Clean energy auctions have been held, the most recent being the World Bank-backed Scaling Solar tender. The auction saw 60MW of PV awarded for the rock-bottom price of $0.038/kWh. In August 2020, the government issued a decree that exempts 22 renewable energy equipment from VAT. The technologies eligible for this incentive are wind, biogas, PV and other solar-powered technologies, such as solar pumping kits and solar water heaters. A new program will introduce a payment for all excess energy generated over 20 years for residential biogas and solar.

Sierra Leone approved its first and only clean energy policy in March 2017, setting a target for 79.7% and 84% of final energy to come from renewables by 2020 and 2030, respectively. Little progress has been made on thse targets, since the country depends on external funding to reach them. The governments Action Plan from 2014-2017 aimed to increase renewables while raising total capacity from 75MW to 1,000MW, however, no progress has been made as the state of the main grid has prevented new generation assets from being connected. Besides, the only incentive for renewable energy to grow is a reduction in import taxes on solar products, but this is rarely enforced in customs.

Somalia's power sector is severely underdeveloped due to years of conflict and political instability. Most electricity in urban areas is supplied by privately run mini-grids. Local electricity service providers typically own both power generation and power transmission infrastructure. The countrys relatively small 100MW installed base consists primarily of diesel generators and in most cases, consumers buy directly from the mini-grid at high prices. The country is divided into regions with no central administration overseeing the energy sector, while the self-declared independent Somaliland has its own energy ministry. Consolidation is occurring among many independent power producers, but there is a lack of regulation around this. Many international organizations, including the World Bank and USAID, are active in Somalia and are working to help establish a regulatory framework to incentivize additional investment in electricity infrastructure.

Once the benchmark of success, South Africa's renewables auction program has been at a standstill for five years. Some 6.4GW of renewables capacity across 102 projects won support through the scheme, but no new rounds have been announced. In April 2018, the Energy Minister at the time, Jeff Radebe, signed power-purchase agreements for the 27 outstanding renewable energy projects from rounds 3.5 to 4, after three years of delays. The 2019-updated Integrated Resource Plan (IRP) outlines the countrys planned generating capacity, and includes ambitious capacity allocations of more than 20GW of wind and solar by 2030. In March 2020, a Nersa consultation opened to begin the procurement of 2GW of emergency capacity in late 2020, as well as 6.8GW of new wind and solar between 2022 and 2024, 1.5GW of new coal between 2023 and 2027, and 3GW of new gas between 2024 and 2027.

South Sudan does not offer any specific clean energy incentives, nor has it submitted a Nationally Determined Contribution in the framework of the Paris Agreement. The country lacks a clear energy policy altogether, with the only relevant previous piece of legislation being the 2011 'South Sudan Strategic Development Plan'. This sets out electrification targets and was in force until 2016, but a new official plan has yet to succeed it. The countrys ongoing fragile security situation and unrest has diverted governmental focus away from clean energy deployment.

Sudan does not yet offer any clean energy incentives. A public-private partnership (PPP) law, renewable energy act and import-duty exemptions for solar components have been in the planning for some time, but are stuck at various stages along the legislative pipeline. Furthermore, the 2001 Electricity Law is due to be overhauled, but little progress has been made to date. Aside from Sudans plan for renewables to account for 20% of generation by 2030 as part of its nationally determined contribution, the government has not explicitly issued any further national objectives. With no utility-scale renewables commissioned to date, Sudan still has far to go in its deployment of clean energy.

Tanzanias energy policy is underpinned by three targets: 2021 goals for 4,915MW of power generating capacity and a 50% renewables generation mix, and a 75% electrification target in 2025. Since setting these targets in 2016, power capacity has increased by only 281MW (mainly due to a 240MW natural gas plant), fossil fuels still make up 60% of generating capacity and the country has a 37% electrification rate. Two tenders announced in September 2018 for 150MW of solar and 200MW of wind were canceled. The 2.1GW Stieglers Gorge hydro project, under construction, will likely remain the government priority for the near future.

Togo passed its first renewable energy development law in July 2018, which aims to reach 50% renewables in the national energy mix by 2030. The government also published a roadmap to reach 100% electrification by the same year, thanks to the addition of 108MW of renewable energy projects including solar PV (50MW), hydro, 315 mini-grids and the distribution of 550,000 solar kits. The country is setting up an open, transparent and easy-to-navigate regulatory framework. The renewable law, published in August 2018, came a year after the launch of the AT2ER (Agence Togolaise dElectrification Rurale et des Energies Renouvelables), and was followed by a series of decrees detailing the rules that renewable energy project developers should follow. In 2019, Togo joined a global solar initiative where it will jointly develop several solar parks with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) totaling 90MW and in 2020, Togo also introduced its first tender for two solar projects with capacities between 60-80MW. Togo also aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 31.14% compared to projected, business-as-usual levels by 2030.

Tunisia aims to move toward a cleaner power matrix and jump from 3% of renewables generation in 2016 to 12% in 2020, rising to 30% by 2030. Two separate auction regimes (authorization for smaller projects and concession for larger projects) are the main instruments to achieve the objectives. Under the authorization regime, the government contracted 64MW of PV capacity in 2017, 70MW in 2018, and a further 70MW in 2020. Under the concession regime, Tunisia announced in 2018 that it will contract another 500MW of wind plants, and contracted 500MW of PV in 2019. Project deadlines vary between 1H 2021 and end-2022, and the winners will secure a 20-year PPA with the state-owned utility STEG. In addition, retail electricity consumers in Tunisia that have renewable-energy facilities can connect and deliver surplus generation to the grid, in return for payment from STEG.

Uganda has achieved its renewable energy generation target and its renewable capacity target for all technologies except for large hydro (813MW against a target of 1,200MW) and geothermal (zero against a target of 45MW). The country generates more than 90% of its power from renewable sources, including large hydro and biomass, and has 1,150MW of renewables connected to the grid. Ugandas highly successful Global Energy Transfer feed-in tariff (GET FiT) program launched in 2014, becoming the first competitive auction program for renewables in East Africa. However, there is no auction program in force at the moment and none are planned, as the country has significant overcapacity.

The United Arab Emirates flagship renewables target aims to achieve an electricity generation mix composed of 44% renewables, 38% gas, 12% clean coal and 6% nuclear. A federal target for a 24% renewables share by 2021 looms in the more immediate term  this is unlikely to be met. Meanwhile, the UAEs federal structure affords emirates considerable autonomy in implementing their own renewables targets, incentives and procurement schemes. Abu Dhabi and Dubai have had considerable success in running large-scale, competitive auctions to procure solar power. However, success has been varied in certain areas. Abu Dhabi has, for instance, struggled to replicate the success of Dubais net-metering scheme even as it has proven its ability to pull off large-scale renewables auctions.

Zambia is a politically table country with a fairly light-handed regulatory framework for energy, although it has non-cost reflective retail tariffs. The country has ambitions to diversify its power mix and improve access to electricity, and its policies reflect this. In mid-2016, Zambias Scaling Solar program awarded 81MW in its first round, yielding some of the lowest solar prices in sub-Saharan Africa. Both winning PV projects, the 34MW Ngonye and 56MW Bangweulu, begun commercial operations in 2019. However, the next Scaling Solar auction round is on hold, pending the completion of a cost of service review of the state-owned utility, Zesco. Zambia also awarded 120MW of PV capacity under the first round of the GETFiT scheme. Along with the planned dissemination of 500,000 solar home systems and installation of 350,000 solar water heaters, Zambia is taking positive steps toward increasing access to modern energy services and meeting the growing demand for electricity.

Zimbabwe's target to reach over 1 gigawatt of renewables by 2025 (excluding large hydro) and over 2GW by 2030 is ambitious, given that the country is essentially starting from zero renewable generation at present and continues to face issues with unmet demand and severe load-shedding. The target is non-binding. Solar is the most promising form of renewable generation, and several IPPs have signed PPAs. In July 2019, the government announced that all new construction projects must include solar and removed import duties on solar energy-related products, from batteries to cables. This should significantly boost the solar market going forward. Zimbabwe Power Company (ZPC), the public utility, has plans for a 300MW solar project, which would be the first renewable project in its portfolio, but progress appears uncertain. In May 2020, Zimbabwe Electricity Transmission and Distribution Company (ZETDC) invited bids for the construction of 500MW of PV. Additionally, the Infrastructure Development Bank of Zimbabwe issued a request for proposal in September 2019 seeking partners for the development of seven PV plants totaling 235MW. Rural electrification efforts are mostly focused on off-grid solutions. The country is targeting universal access by 2030.

Factors such as population growth, post-Covid-19 economic expansion and increasing use of electrical appliances and equipment are expected to drive Canada's electricity demand in coming years. Conversely, economic stagnation would suppress demand growth. In the first half of 2020, Alberta power demand averaged 4.9% below BloombergNEF's "business-as-usual" model, and Ontario was 1.6% lower. Given that the country is home to a modernized power grid with an 100% electrification rate nationally, the push for mini-grid systems is subdued and focused around smaller use cases, like remote regions or those with especially volatile grid connections.

For the past 15 years, electricity demand in the U.S. has been relatively flat. However, over that same period, gas-fired and renewable energy have continually displaced increasingly uneconomic coal and nuclear plants. Both these trends are likely to continue in the short term as natural gas remains cheap, renewable power plant capital costs fall, and states and corporations continue to ramp up mandated and voluntary procurement targets. Increased renewable penetration will also lead to more opportunities for energy storage, as greater flexible capacity will be needed.

Argentinas clean energy investment has been severely affected by the countrys ongoing financial and economic crises. The financing of projects tied to the countrys third and final large-scale auction (RenovAr Round 2) remains at risk. Held in late 2017, RenovAr 2 awarded contracts to 1.8GW of wind and solar assets. The Ministry of Energy decreased considerably the amount of capacity tendered in 2019. Held in August 2019, RenovAr MiniRen 3 focused on small-scale projects and awarded only 259MW of clean energy projects due to transmission limitations. The country has seen a significant increase in corporate PPAs to procure clean energy as the renewable energy targets set in 2016 obligated large consumers to comply individually.

Bolivia's energy reform prioritizes the electrification of rural areas, aiming for universal access by 2025. By consequence, demand for electricity is rapidly growing, rising 5% annually on average since 2010. However, in 2019 peak demand was flat compared to 2018, remaining at 1,512MW. Much rural electrification takes the form of off-grid projects, mainly relying on thermoelectric generators and solar photovoltaics. Business opportunities for renewables are on the rise after the first projects were commissioned in the past year. The largest planned projects are hydroelectric dams, as the country views them as the fastest way to achieve clean energy targets and increase exports to neighbors.

After a deep recession in 2015-16, Covid-19 is pushing Brazil back into a new crisis. GDP expanded at just 1.1% per year in the period 2017-19 and the countrys economy is expected to shrink around 5% in 2020. Inflation in 2020 is expected to reach the lowest level of the decade at 3.1%, down from 3.7% in 2019. As result, Brazils benchmark Selic rate has seen steep drops, reaching a historic low of 2% in August 2020.

Chile is the worlds largest copper exporter, with the energy-intensive nature of mining creating substantial power demand. The copper industry alone accounts for nearly half of Chiles exports. In a given year, mining represents 30% of total power demand in the country. Mining operations are located in the north and are mostly served by the SING sub-system. The majority of coal assets are located in this region, which also has the greatest potential for solar generation in the country. However, the lack of interconnection between SIC and SING has historically driven the majority of solar developments to the SIC sub-system, where over 90% of the population lives and most retail demand is located. This reality may change, however, as integration of the two sub-systems continues and mining companies prioritize procurement of clean power via bilateral power purchase agreements.

The government introduced tax incentives for investment in renewables in 2014, providing for accelerated depreciation of up to 20% per year for renewable energy investments; 50% income tax deduction on the value of investments up to 50% of taxable income for up to five years; VAT exemption for renewable energy equipment and services; and import duty exemption for renewable energy equipment. Policies introduced in 2019 have added momentum to the renewables market. Colombias first successful renewable auction awarded long term PPAs, paid in local currency, to 1.3GW of wind and solar projects. The presence of large global companies in the auction underlined the attractiveness of Colombia as an emerging clean energy market. With the exception of domestic player Celsia, all winners were large, global firms aiming to secure early market entry.

Costa Ricas government has demonstrated strong commitment to clean energy and climate-related incentives. However, high hydro penetration and slow demand growth have curtailed opportunities for new entrants. With typically around 70% of the countrys power coming from hydro, the need to add other clean generation to achieve the national 100% renewable energy goal is limited.

In 2019, the Dominican Republics electrification rate was 97.8% and demand for power in the country has grown briskly over a decade. Specifically, peak power demand jumped 38%, from 1,810MW in 2010 to 2,506MW in 2019, while average annual generation grew 42% over the same period. In January, 2019, the countrys National Energy Commission (CNE) published some details on how it plans for clean energy auctions to be executed. While national and international companies are allowed to participate, further details on how they will do so are not yet available. In May 2019, CNE authorized 12 provisional concessions for potentially 874MW capacity. The government also announced that month that it will invest $900 million in clean energy projects. However, as of November 2020, no further details on how those funds would be disbursed had been published.

On October 13, 2015, Ecuador submitted its unconditional Intended Nationally Determined Contribution (INDC) to the United Nations, committing to cut greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the energy sector by 20.4%-25% below the business as usual (BAU) scenario by 2025. Ecuador also committed to a further reduction of GHG emissions in the energy sector to a level between 37.5% and 45.8% below the BAU scenario by 2025. This additional reduction is conditioned upon availability of resources and international support.

El Salvadors renewables boom is set to continue with more project completions in the next two years. Still, the country remains highly dependent on fossil fuels and hydro, exposing its market to price spikes during droughts and periods of high oil prices. Investment in renewables is seen as a path to reducing these impacts.

Guatemalas national energy plan calls for 64% of the countrys energy to come from renewables by 2032. As of December 2019, the country was at 32%, suggesting additional investment will be required. Guatemala's level of electrification was 92% in 2019.

Haiti has limited energy-related policies. The 2017-2018 Finance Act abolished all import duty taxes on PV generation equipment, wind generation equipment, and solar powered off-grid home appliances such as refrigerators, lamps and chargers. Only a quarter of the population has access to on-grid electricity. The national grid shortfalls have created opportunities for distributed clean energy generation solutions and the implementation of microgrids. With the help of a grant from USAID, EarthSpark was responsible for developing Haitis first microgrid, which started operation in the south of the country in 2015, providing solar power to around 450 households in the city of Les Anglais. The system relies on batteries to ensure reliability and smart meters for system stability and to facilitate pre-pay capability for its customers.

Market conditions for renewables developers in Honduras are not easy. ENEE has failed to pay a feed-in premium promised to solar plants commissioned by July 31, 2015 and this has undermined confidence. The utility says energy demand is growing and will rise 4% per year through 2030. The national electrification rate in 2019 stood at 82%.

Jamaicas national electrification rate in 2019 was 98%, according to the Ministry of Science, Energy and Technology. The countrys peak demand rose slightly from 2018 to 2019 to 660MW. Hoping to achieve its longer-term clean energy target, the government is developing new frameworks for the power sector, including technical parameters developers can use in responding to planned RFPs.

After improving under the previous administration, business opportunities for renewable energy in Mexico have soured under the AMLO administration, which has proven hostile towards private investment in the energy sector. Since taking office in late 2018, AMLO has advanced a number of policies aimed at strengthening the CFE, generally at the expense of privately operated companies. Given that Mexicos wind and solar industry is dominated by private firms, including business units or wholly owned subsidiaries of international utilities, this has been consistently bad for clean energy. AMLO has sought to dismantle the pro clean energy policy frameworks established by his predecessors. Since assuming the presidency, he has made it his explicit goal to revitalize public sector involvement in energy. Nevertheless, several fundamentals remain strong. Total generation has expanded by an average of 2.6% per year over the past five years. In June 2018, Mexico announced the end of the 15% customs duty on solar PV module imports, introduced in 2015, removing a barrier to renewables development. Mexico is also a potentially strong market for distributed generation. Though the market remains small, with just over 1GW of installed capacity, residential PV has continued to grow in recent years, driven by excellent solar resources, high electricity prices for high-consumption residential and commercial users and a national net metering scheme in place since 2010.

Peak demand for power in Nicaragua jumped 28% from 2010-18. Growth then decelerated to just 1% per year from 2015-2018 due to slower economic growth. In 2019, however, peak demand set a new record at 718MW. The governments National Expansion Plan 2017-2030 projects demand to grow 4.5% per year through the end of this decade.

The business environment for renewables development is generally positive in Panama. While hydro still represents the largest single source of clean power, solar and wind have been increasing their shares since 2014. Peak  demand rose 17% year-on-year to 1,961MW in 2019.

Paraguays electrification rate in 2019 was 99%. The countrys peak demand jumped 70% over the past nine years, from 1,892MW in 2010 to 3,226MW in 2018. However, in 2019, peak demand fell slightly as energy consumption dropped 1.2%.

Ministerio de Energa y Minas (MINEM) is responsible for evaluating the need for auctions, and Organismo Supervisor de la Inversin en Energa y Minera (OSINERGMIN), the power sector regulator, conducts the tenders. A renewable auction expected to be held in 2018 was canceled in April 2017, and no new tender has been announced. MINEMs explanation for the cancellation is that not all projects selected in the previous auction are being developed. In 10 years, Peru saw its electrification rate spike from 74% to 97%, the biggest increase in Latin America. The progress is due to a rural electrification program, which included an off-grid auction aiming to contract PV systems for isolated regions in the country.

Uruguays clean energy sector boomed 2011-2015. However, the spike in power generation from intermittent sources saturated the market. As a result, investment has declined and the country appears unlikely to hold major auctions again soon.

Power demand for Afghanistan is largely met by imports. Demand is expected to rise in future, yet imports are not a reliable source to meet the countrys electricity needs, mainly due to the political instability of the exporters. Despite nearly all segments of the population formally having access to power, supply is patchy and blackouts are common. There is strong potential for distributed power generation due to Afghanistans significant solar resources.

Armenia is 100% electrified. Although it imports gas and nuclear fuel, it is a net exporter of electricity. Peak operational demand has been decreasing slightly as more energy efficiency and behind-the-meter projects are installed. A focus on energy efficiency, particularly in buildings, could further decrease electricity demand. Slashed wind tariffs have dissuaded wind project development for now. There are plans to extend the life of hydro plants, and while the government is considering refurbishing the remaining nuclear plant, this would be extremely expensive.

Electricity demand in Australia remains substantially flat, following a period of softening demand around 2010. The rapid and seemingly unstoppable influx of behind-the-meter solar generation continues to put downward price pressure   on grid served electricity, particularly in the middle of the day. In more remote areas of the country, falling renewable energy costs are spurring a re-think of remote electricity infrastructure, with rising interest in the role of micro-grids in certain locations. But demand for these services are dwarfed by the main networks, which already service roughly 90-95% of power consumption in the country.

Power demand decreased significantly in Azerbaijan and many other Soviet republics as industrial production fell after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Power demand has been rising in recent years as the economy has grown, although the relationship will ultimately decouple with economic growth expected to outstrip growth in power demand. Economic growth depends largely on oil and gas exports, and increased efficiency in energy use will further disconnect the two. The country is reforming legislation to strengthen the current power system and market. The electrification rate is 100%, so off-grid and mini-grid potential would appear to be limited.
