The potential for mini-grid development to increase energy security and stability of the system is not yet under consideration.

Bangladesh is a power-starved nation and demand will only go up as the country grows in population and GDP. Load shedding is prevalent, particularly in rural areas. The government adopted a Vision 2021 plan which aims at electricity for all by 2021. The country has two types of rural electrification programs: extension of the conventional grid to remote areas and installation of solar irrigation pumps, solar mini grids and improved cook stoves. Apart from these, IDCOL started a solar home system program in 2003 to supply electricity to areas where grid expansion is challenging. Increases in the countrys power requirements will be met through a combination of new power generation projects and electricity imports from India.

The governments aggressive electrification program has raised the share of households with access to electricity from 22% in 2010 to a reported 75% in 2019, boosting demand for power five-fold. The quality of electricity supply remains an issue in remote areas, but opportunities for off-grid companies are thin: the government is not transparent about grid extension plans, and off-grid systems are unable to feed into the grid once it arrives, effectively stranding these assets. The country is making an effort to expand renewable energy projects by floating tenders. There is steady progress in  solar installations despite a lack of financial incentives.

China's power demand grew 4.5% year-on-year in 2019, to 7,226TWh. Growth contracted by 1.3% in 1H 2020 due to Covid-19. Despite the blip, the energy transition and electrification of transport, heating, industrial processes, etc. are long-term policy goals that will continue to bolster demand. Investing in renewable energy will be subject to new rules for managing subsidy-free build as well as growing power price risks brought by market deregulation. Policymakers are mulling solutions to the estimated $66 billion current deficit in the funding pool for renewable energy subsidies. Asset owners balance sheets will benefit should they implement an effective solution.

Power demand in Georgia rose by 30% between 2010 and 2019 but has started to level off. The majority of the growth comes from rural areas in the north of the country, where service is complicated by the presence of Russia-occupied territories. There are plans to upgrade the grid and add new high-voltage lines in order to accommodate new renewable energy. Aging hydropower plants are being refurbished to extend their lifetimes. The country is completely electrified, and there is little interest in off-grid developments.

Indias annual power demand grew by 50% from 2010 to 2019, and it is now the worlds third-largest power consumer, behind China and the U.S. At the same time, the supply deficit narrowed from 79TWh in 2010 to 6TWh in 2019. This was the result of rapid expansion of generation capacity as well as fast rollout of transmission and distribution infrastructure. The Central Electricity Authority expects electricity use to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 6% for the next 10 years. This will be driven by population growth, the governments focus on ensuring 24x7 power for all, economic growth and the electrification of sectors such as transport.

Power demand in Indonesia is not increasing as expected by the countrys policy planners. Economic growth rates were high during 2010-12, and electricity demand increased at an annual rate of 8-9%. Annual demand growth has slowed since 2014 to 4-5% due to lower-than-expected GDP growth, forcing the government to cut its power capacity expansion plans. The government reported 99% of all households as electrified in 2019, up from about 64% in 2010. In the medium term, there is a huge potential to develop clean-energy microgrids in Indonesia as the country has about 5GW of oil and diesel power generators providing electricity in the remote regions. Replacing diesel power with a combination of solar and battery storage could decrease generation costs as well as emissions. Indonesia receives relatively good sunshine throughout the year, and therefore offers significant opportunities for large- and small-scale solar power projects in the long term. The country does not currently have any official power plant fleet modernization programs.
Power demand is expected to fall due to the shrinking population, high energy efficiency and slowdown in economy.

Electricity generation grew by over 30% between 2010 and 2019 fueled by a growing economy and population. Electricity is predominantly generated in the northern region by inefficient Soviet-era coal plants, while demand is greatest in the south, surrounding Almaty  the countrys largest city. The grid connecting the two regions does not extend westward to the oil producing regions adjacent the Caspian Sea. There is a potential for robust wind and solar development as the country aims to raise the share of renewable generation to 10% by 2030 from 3% today. The governments reversals of regulation and power market reform as well as currency risk associated with Kazakhstani tengi remain as challenges.

Koreas electricity demand will likely rise until mid-2030s, driven by the countrys energy-intensive manufacturing sectors such as steel making, automotive and electronics. The novel coronavirus in 2020 will likely apply downward pressure on electricity demand in the near term but economic recovery, coupled with modest population growth, will likely push up demand in the long term. Demand for renewable energy will continue to rise as the government aims to achieve 20% renewable generation by 2030 from just 7% in 2020. The government also plans to launch various procurement mechanisms of renewable energy in 2021 including third party power purchase agreement or PPA, green tariff, and direct investment in renewable energy.

Despite an aging power fleet and transmission and distribution grid, almost 100% of Kyrgyzstan's population has access to electricity and the country hasn't established any energy access targets. This is one reason the country has invested little in upgrading this infrastructure or diversifying its power mix, and has allocated minimal to no resources into grid expansion, mini-grids or solar home systems. A government program in 2018 to install PV systems in remote villages is the only residential solar initiative to date in the country, indicating there is little support for such technology at the government level.

Power demand has surged as Laos has extended its electric grid to the countryside, with peak load doubling between 2010-2018 and overall generation (much of which is exported) almost quadrupling over the same time frame. Laos aims to reach 98% household electrification by 2020. It is well on its way, according to official statistics, with 94% electrification in 2018, compared to only 15% in 1995. Concerns remain, however, on the quality of the power supply to rural areas, and many speculate that the true electrification rate remains around 70-80%. Off-grid systems are an option for the remaining households, but the remoteness of these homes means that income-generating opportunities  and therefore, the ability to pay for solar home systems  remain limited. Most solar home systems to date have effectively been financed through grants.

Average power demand in Malaysia has increased at a compound annual growth rate of 4% since 2010. The country achieved 100% electrification in 2015. The long-term economic growth prospects of the country offers further potential for power demand growth, and the government targets to ramp up solar power capacity to meet this demand at least partially. The country has a potential for 42GW of rooftop solar power capacity, and 16.5GW of solar on water bodies. Malaysia is also the third-largest PV cell producer in the world. The average age of power generation assets in the country is still low, therefore Malaysia does not have a program to modernize power plants.

Power demand has increased gradually  a trend expected to continue in the coming decade. This is because GDP growth in Mongolia peaked at 17% in 2011 and has been slower since  it was as low as 1.2% in 2016. A rebound of GDP growth was observed in 2018 at 7.2% and 5.1% in 2019, meaning more potential for business in the country. In addition, national electrification is 88% (rural areas only 60%), so access to power has significant room to grow. The country has good land supply and weather conditions to build wind and solar, while mini- and off-grid systems operate decently in remote areas. Last but not least, it needs to modernize its coal-power fleet as it was built some 30 years ago.

Myanmar's power demand is rising sharply, with the World Bank expecting an 11% annual increase to 2030. The country will need to increase its power capacity four-fold by 2030 from the 2017 level to meet its demand, partly arising from the target of 100% electrification. In addition to developing utility scale gas plants and renewables, the government has ambitious plan to build microgrid and offgrid projects across the country, with funding from multilateral development agencies.

Nepalese power generation has grown by close to 10% in fiscal 2018-19 and 19% in 2019-20. Both rates are impressive. Power consumption also recorded a 3% increase. The shortage of power has become one of the barriers to better economic growth. The electrification rate stands at less than 90% now, but the target is for 100% by 2030. As the country recovers from the Covid-19 hit, it will need more power and provide opportunities for related businesses. Nowadays, only 2% of the total estimated 42GW of hydro resource is tapped. At this level of availability, and with the regular speed of development, the expected consumption of 17,400GWh by 2027 may not be met. Nepal adopts the Common Law system and has satisfactory data transparency in the field of electricity.

Electricity demand in New Zealand has been largely flat over the past decade, despite economic growth and increasing electrification in various sectors of the economy. However, in order to keep carbon emissions within its current Paris Agreement commitments and net-zero by 2050 targets, greater electrification of transport, heating and industry is expected to drive up electricity demand over the longer term. Its relatively small land mass and extensive network infrastructure mean there is little need for substantial electrification, or micro-grid programs, although the falling costs of decentralized energy may see a rise in these type of projects in the future.

A spate of new power plants commissioned in the last few years means that the gap between demand and supply has narrowed, reducing the frequency and severity of blackouts. Planners are getting ready for an era of surplus electricity on the government-owned networks, with K-Electric following in the next few years. This puts brakes on the expansion of renewables, even though they present the most cost-competitive option to generate power. Despite this surplus, transmission and distribution losses of between 20-30% mean that the market will remain highly inefficient and indebted.

Over the past two decades, the Philippines went through significant energy reforms, and opened up its power industry to the private sector. However, the relationship between developers and regulators has been strained, with the former complaining about red tape and bureaucracy. While the government has created policies that allow more private participation, the failure to meet installation targets suggests a lack of follow-through. Unpermitted rooftop solar is widespread. One of the largest solar vendors widely advertises a solar-diesel-storage microgrid that is often deployed without the required permits. While policy implementation lags, both population and economic growth are expected to increase demand significantly and open up more opportunities for power development.

Singapore is a developed economy with strong legal and institutional frameworks in place to support business transactions and financing arrangements. The country has world-class infrastructure and office space, and a highly educated English speaking workforce. The government is also keen to attract foreign investment and developers into the market and is likely to attract more foreign players for subsequent tender rounds for SolarNova and floating PV projects.

Power demand growth in last five years averaged 5%. Looking forward, CEB expects the demand will continue to grow at a five-year average growth of 6%. Unlike any other country in South Asia, Sri Lanka already achieved 100% electrification. New power plants are required to meet growing demand, and also to balance retirements. Rooftop solar is a bright spark in renewable energy in the country. The availability of a net metering scheme coupled with high tariffs means that more and more rooftops are aiming for solar installations. Import of equipment for renewable energy including solar panels and storage batteries, etc. is exempt from the national building tax (NBT) as well as the ports and airport levy (PAL).

Taiwans power demand is only expected to grow modestly at 1.6% in the next two decades, according to Taiwan Research Institute. Yet the governments intention to take all the 5.1GW nuclear power capacity offline by 2025 creates opportunities for renewable energy. The island has been receptive to foreign players, granting three-quarters of the 3.8GW offshore wind capacity announced in April 2018 to overseas developers. The government is also working with global supply chain companies to establish a local offshore wind manufacturing hub. Overseas banks have also participated in project financing.

Peak power demand has increased moderately in recent years. Despite its near 100% electrification rate, Tajikistan suffers from power reliability issues due to its dependence on large hydropower plants, most of which are operating beyond their intended operating life.

Thailand has achieved 100% electrification. In the 2018 PDP, total electricity demand is forecast to increase at an average growth rate of 3.2% over 2018-36. Year-on-year percentage growth is expected to decrease. Average growth is estimated to be 3.9% over the period 2019-22, and drop to 3% for 2023-37. This is partly due to an expected increase in energy efficiency. To boost the development of the renewable energy industry, Thailand's Board of Investment has exempted such projects from import tariffs. The investment climate in Thailand is stable. There are no known defaults by the single offtaker, EGAT. The grid in Thailand is also relatively robust, with a few instances of supply interruptions and no known curtailment. There are no barriers to entry in the form of foreign ownership restrictions or local content requirements.

The country and its economy are effectively closed to the outside world. Independent offtake, contracts, and investments are extremely difficult, if not impossible, to secure. Any potential for the situation to improve is linked to global gas pricing as well as power sector regulation and incentivizing policies.

Uzbekistan's electrification rate has remained at or close to 100% for many years, but is expected to decrease. In a concept note published in May 2020, the countrys Ministry of Energy is forecasting peak power demand to more than double, from 10.4GW in 2019 to 20.9GW in 2030. It anticipates it will need 29.2GW of power generating capacity to meet this demand, or 120.8TWh -- 176% greater than 2020 levels. As demand goes up, the country will need to upgrade its generation capacity to maintain this electrification rate. Utility-scale renewables projects appear to be the country's main priority for the time being, and there is no rural electrification program.

Power demand grew at an average rate of 11% annually between 2014 and 2018 on the back of a growing manufacturing industry. This rapid growth resulted in a tripling of electricity generation from coal in the same period. Vietnam plans to more than triple coal capacity again, from 17GW in 2017 to 55GW by 2030. The country has an electrification rate of 99.2% with the urban population fully electrified. Most of the solar and wind potential areas lie in the low power demand regions of the country.

All Albanians have access to electricity, and the policy focus is on ensuring the ability to meet demand in the future should it rise as hydrologic supply remains static. Albania is seeking admission to the European Union, which has provided an impetus to expand its renewable energy portfolio, both in amount and in diversity from hydropower. The World Bank is supporting a 'Dam Safety Project' for hydropower facilities that aims to improve performance in addition to safety. In 2019, German development bank KfW set forth to finance digitalizing and modernizing the power distribution network. The country also plans to expand its natural gas network.

Demand is rising gradually, but growth is unlikely to accelerate in the absence of widespread electrification across the heating, industry and transport sectors, a longer-term prospect. The countrys power fleet is well maintained, and no phase-out looms over the coming years. A turning point was reached in April 2020, when the last of the countrys coal plants was shuttered. In the more distant future, the closure of the countrys 4GW of gas generation may be on the cards, if the country is to achieve climate neutrality by 2040. The country is not particularly well endowed when it comes to wind speeds or irradiation levels.

As a fully electrified country overseen by a state utility, immediate investment opportunities may be more challenging than in other emerging markets. However, there is potential to reduce dependency on imported gas and enhance energy security via renewables. Should the country apply to become a contracting party of the Energy Community, this could also bring stringent rules on further unbundling the power sector, which could open up new opportunities. Belarus scores well in the World Banks 2020 Ease of Doing Business report, ranked in place 49 out of 190.

As in most of Western Europe, a pick up in stagnant demand in the long term will hinge on the extent to which transport, industry and heat are electrified. That said, replacing the nuclear reactor fleet clears the way for new investments in generation assets  during the latest power crisis, the government was reportedly considering procuring emergency electricity from Turkish power barges. Continued growth of residential solar is expected, while space constraints and acceptance issues could hinder growth in utility-scale onshore wind and PV. Cumulative offshore wind additions are expected to reach 4.1GW by 2030, from 1.5GW in 2019.

Over half of the countrys thermal capacity was commissioned in the 1960s and 1970s  the list of thermal power plants to be closed encompasses 30% of the countrys total. However, there are several new coal plants in the pipeline. While power generation has increased in the past decade, domestic demand has remained more or less constant since the early 2000s. BiH is currently a net power exporter.

Bulgaria has recorded almost 4% growth in every year between 2015-2019, with growth rates in excess of 6% in the years preceding the 2009 financial crisis. However, the country has also entered a phase where economic growth is not as energy-intensive and demand is expected to stay relatively flat in the future. Electricity consumption increased by 2% from 2018 to 2019. Construction of the 2GW new nuclear power plant facility at Belene will be a significant investment opportunity, and so far, four investors have expressed interested in acting as the strategic partner for the plant. Confidence in the renewables space remains shaken by the retroactive policy intervention rolled out in 2012.

Croatias electricity consumption had dropped in recent years from an all-time high of 18.61TWh in 2009 to 16.97TWh in 2017, but has recovered in 2018. This drop has taken place against a backdrop of economic slowdown that has seen Croatias GDP drop from $70.5 billion in 2008 to $50.4 billion in 2016. The main investment opportunities in the power sector arise from renewables buildouts and revitalization of existing power stations (especially hydropower plants), which should ensure that Croatia meets its 2030 decarbonization targets. In July 2018, HEP secured 140 million euros from the European Investment Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to build a 150MW gas-based combined heat and power plant. The plant will supply the city of Zagreb and replace existing highly polluting heat-only oil and gas plants.

Electricity demand growth has been sluggish since 2000, rising by a compound annual rate of less than 1%  and it is not due to accelerate over the next decade. Onshore wind potential is limited by land availability and public acceptance issues. The 2030 strategy prioritizes biomass and energy-from-waste, and so these technologies may offer more opportunity for both electricity and heat. As such, the State Energy Policy prioritizes biomass (subject to food-security limits) alongside wind and solar (for small-scale systems). The role of gas is focused around CHP plants and offering flexibility services in the electricity sector.

The business environment for renewables is positive in Denmark as the country is actively pushing to increase clean generation. A bipartisan agreement on energy policy has ensured policy certainty for decades. There have only been a few PPAs signed with corporate offtakers, as developers instead opt for the feed-in-premium scheme for onshore wind with little scope to develop offshore outside of auctions. Nonetheless, deals are slowly growing in size, with around 120MW of wind having received a corporate PPA in 2018, while 250MW of solar secured a corporate PPA in 2019. The power market is decentralized with a strong coupling to the heat sector. More than half of the country's heat supply comes from district heating, of which more than 80% is co-produced with power.

The clean energy business environment is relatively positive, as the country is pushing to increase its renewables output. Finland achieved its 2020 target for 38% renewable energy consumption six years early and is planning on further tripling wind output and increasing solar output more than tenfold by 2030. Its coalition government pledged to carbon neutrality by 2035 in June 2019. As wholesale prices are low, corporate power-purchase-agreements have offered an opportunity for subsidy-free wind-projects in Finland. Despite the administrative burden of permits for wind farms, in January 2020 the permitting process had reached its final stages for onshore wind sites with potential for up to 7,500 MW additional capacity.

Opportunities revolve around the future of Frances nuclear fleet. As baseload power is reduced, renewables will be added in increasing volumes to fill the gaps. Security of supply might also be threatened as increasingly frequent heat waves make it harder to cool nuclear reactors. The government has planned to phase out its remaining 3GW of coal capacity by the end of 2022, and has pledged not to add any new gas capacity. As in other European markets, there is considerable uncertainty surrounding how the electrification of hard-to-abate sectors will impact demand. That said, France is one of the few countries where electricity, at over a third, accounts for a larger share of residential heat that any other technology.

Power demand has remained flat over recent years. Yet much uncertainty surrounds future electricity consumption, which could rise as a result of sectoral electrification. This is particularly relevant to such areas as green hydrogen production  in June 2020, the government set its sights on 5GW of renewable-powered electrolyzers by 2030. The closure of Germanys coal plants by 2038 will offer additional opportunities for renewables as well as coal-to-gas conversions. That is especially relevant due to the governments reluctance to subsidize new combined-cycle gas plants. Although strong winds benefit wind farms located in the north, they are often subject to curtailment. That is partly the result of congested transmission lines, although new cables being laid should alleviate this issue in the years to come.

Robust wind and solar resources have driven interest in Greek renewables, though electricity demand has fallen due to the economic crisis and now Covid-19. The transmission system operator is working to extend the grid to the islands, which host some of the best wind and solar sites, with capacity factors for the former reaching 30% in some locations. But highly seasonal power demand on the islands means that development of these sites makes economic sense only if the power can be transported to the mainland. Other islands have also been selected for the development of pilot hybrid mini-grid systems.

Solar PV is expected to continue its recent growth supported by the Metar tenders, as Hungary aims to increase its share of renewable electricity from 8% in 2018 to 21% in 2030. An increasing amount of electricity is traded according to market principles, and the volume of electricity sold on the wholesale market grew 12% from 2018 to 2019. Electricity demand in Hungary (a former Soviet republic) fell substantially since the 1990s owing to the collapse of heavy industry. Demand has yet to recover fully, and it experienced another fall after 2008 in the wake of the global financial crisis. From 2015 to 2019, demand slowly recovered, growing 1-2% per year. The government has somewhat reversed the liberalization of the country's power market. In 2016, it took steps to renationalize the sector, with the national utility company ENKSZ acquiring stakes in EDF Demazs as well as regional electricity distributors owned by RWE. ENKSZ was renamed NKM in 2017 and is owned by the MVM group. However, not only government-owned players have increased market concentration -- in 2019, E.On acquired two of the countrys distribution networks and reached a distribution market share of 79%.

Peak demand has remained relatively stable over the last ten years, with year-on-year change not fluctuating by more than 2% in any given year. Ireland is expected to be a key market for corporate power-purchase agreements (PPAs) in Europe.

The Italian government is looking to stimulate the wind and solar industry. It has re-introduced auctions and is looking to cut red tape around permitting. As part of an EU-wide effort, it is in the process of finalizing its 2030 renewable electricity generation target. All of these should help investors get the clarity and confidence to finance new projects. Italian demand has been growing at an average 1% per year since 2014, complementing government efforts. We expect this trend to continue at an average of 0.5% per year until 2040. Enel, the largest generator in Italy, has also been investing in digitalization. It plans to have 90% of its power generation fleet automated by 2020, with 60% enabled by internet-of-things connectivity, to boost plant performance and reduce operations and maintenance costs.

Lithuania's renewable energy market continues to be driven by the EU Renewables Directives' 2020 targets, as the country seeks to help other member states meet their shortfall with its excess renewables. A statistical transfer agreement was signed in October 2017 whereby Lithuania will transfer its renewable energy surplus from 2018-2020 to Luxembourg. The deal will bring it 10 million euros, which will be invested in new renewables projects and research, according to the Ministry of Energy. Lithuania is looking to set up a capacity market by 2025 and so submitted draft regulation for capacity auction procedures for public consultation in July 2020. Renewables capacity, generating a total of 21TWh annually, can be awarded feed-in-premiums through auctions in 2020-2022. The 2020 auctions for premiums up to 3.02 euros was undersubscribed and the quota was instead moved to later auctions.

It is legally possible to set up residential and commercial PV in Moldova, and the countrys feed-in tariff allows system owners to sell their surplus generation. Overall power demand is growing slowly, as Moldova remains predominantly agricultural and its economic system contends with the breakaway region of Transnistria, which receives economic support from Russia. The post-Soviet Moldovan energy system requires investment as the grid is outdated technologically and remains unconnected with Western Europes. Plans to synchronize the Moldovan grid with the European system are moving forward fitfully. Moldovas electrification rate, which approaches 100%, obviates the typical case for minigrids, paygo power systems or other investments needed for energy access.

Electricity demand declined by 11% in the 10 years ending 2017 and tumbled further in 2020 due to lockdown measures. It is not expected to ramp up significantly in the next few decades, despite a slight uptick due to increased electric vehicle usage. The Netherlands will maintain its ambition with regards renewable energy over forthcoming decades. This includes a target to ramp up renewables generation by almost 400% between 2018 and 2030, while the SDE+ program is set to be replaced from 2020 by the SDE++. The new scheme will aim to deliver 985 million euros in funding to sectors including renewable power, biofuels and clean heating by 2030. The Netherlands is also a leading market in Europe for corporate PPAs, benefiting from good resources, stable renewables incentives, national green energy commitments, and domestically located companies with high demand for electricity and sustainability objectives. BNEF has tracked some 642MW in corporate PPAs between 2014 and 2019 in the Netherlands for renewable energy projects.

Evaluation of gas network development and expansion is underway in North Macedonia; at this time Macedonia only receives gas imports via an inlet from Bulgaria and the proposed network would connect to Greece and other neighbors. Despite network constraints, North Macedonia still has 100% access to electricity. Emphasis on expanding renewable energy is focused on increasing the amount of solar and wind energy developed and connected to the grid, as opposed to storage or other technologies. Policymakers are focusing on energy alternatives and environmental impact assessments as environmental concerns mount regarding hydropower.

The business environment for renewables is positive in Norway as the country is actively pushing to increase clean generation. It is already almost entirely reliant on renewables for power generation, only using natural gas for back-up. It has therefore expanded its green focus to other sectors, such as transport, and implemented an array of tax reductions and other incentives for the purchase and ownership of electric vehicles. This helped make it the leading country for electric vehicles in Europe by absolute numbers and in the world on a per-capita basis. Power demand has been flat in recent years. As a result, there are several initiatives to attract major data centers to regions with abundant hydro resources.

Increased power demand and higher costs for the aging coal fleet are providing opportunities for renewables. The Polish government has announced that nuclear capacity is to allow the country to move away from coal, but there is not enough time to build a nuclear power plant to cover the short-term gap left by coal retirements up to 2025. In the meantime, coal closures are accelerating due to increasingly strict emissions limits and higher operational costs. As the coal mining sector seeks restructuring, Poland may be moving toward a coal phase-out, but 90% of the country's coal-fired capacity is held by state-controlled interests.

Renewables have dominated new capacity additions in Portugal since 2000, but reduced government support since 2012 has led to some big players to leave the market. Enel Green Power sold its $1 billion portfolio of Portuguese renewable assets in 2016. Fears of retroactive cuts to the country's feed-in tariff program have not come to fruition; the government has said it would wait until contracts expire and for the scheme to phase out in order to guarantee stable returns on renewables investments. BloombergNEF forecasts that power demand in the Iberian Peninsula is likely to continue steadily on its growth trajectory through 2030.

In 2015, the government announced a new energy strategy for 2016-2030, calling for 1 trillion euros of investment to make Romania an eastern European energy crossroads. Energy regulator ANRE approved a 1.1-billion-euro plan to enhance the national transmission network through 2016-25. In 2020, Romania launched a post Covid-19 economic recovery plan of which approximately $14 billion will go to the energy industry, including support for Hidroelectricas wind projects, Complexul Energetic Oltenias decarbonization plan and expansion of the power grid. It also calls for two new nuclear reactors in collaboration with China, interconnectors and developing new gas finds in the Black Sea. These may leave little room for expansion of renewables in the country, though the country's aging thermal fleet will likely create a capacity gap from mid-2020s. Romania expects electricity demand to grow around 1% per year, according to estimates from the grid operator.

Russias climate and extensive land means it has significant resource potential for wind and solar, but meaningful development has been held back by a number of barriers including volatile exchange rates, high local-content requirements and international sanctions. Russia has a good grid and road network to support industry, and it has a 100% electrification rate. Electricity demand in Russia has remained fairly flat and is expected to continue to do so, as a result of sluggish economic growth. Though electricity generation has increased by roughly 25% since 2000, it has only recently reached pre-1990 levels, prior to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the economic shock that ensued.

To meet the EU's accession requirements, specifically, adhering to the 'Large Combustion Plants Directive', at least eight coal power plants need to be shut down by 2024. The generation gap is to be replaced by two new coal power plants, a combined heat and power plant, and at least 500MW of wind capacity. Should the pressure to abandon new coal plants increase, this could offer up further potential for renewables. Since 2010, peak power demand has been more or less constant.

The most controversial topic around Slovakias power sector has been the ongoing dispute over Enels intended sale of its 66% stake in the national utility Slovenske Elektrarne. The government was determined to force Enel to complete the two new reactors at Mochovce. In July 2016, Enel sold half of its stake to privately held Czech-Slovak energy investment group EPH for 375 million euros. The sale of Enel's remaining 33% stake for the same amount will happen once it completes its Mochove nuclear plant, and is still planned for 2020 or 2021.

Unlike many European countries, Slovenia has seen power demand rising slowly in the last few years, providing the impetus for further build-out of generating capacity and/or interconnection with neighboring countries. Much of the country's hydro resources have already been exploited and, with high costs of new nuclear power plants, it is renewables that will likely benefit from this growth in demand. While the renewables subsidy program remains limited to small projects, developers may explore other revenue streams such as corporate power purchase agreements or PPAs.

The three auctions held between 2016 and 2017 have demonstrated a resurgence in investor interest for Spain's abundant wind and solar resources. The business environment for renewable energy is positive in Spain as the market swings through its second boom. Much of the capacity secured in the auctions is exposed to merchant risk, having effectively bid for zero subsidy on the regulated return on investment. In 2017, the first corporate power purchase agreement was signed by a wind farm owned by EDP Renovaveis, a further example of Spain's merchant renewables market activity. Since then, BNEF has tracked a steady flow of corporate PPAs in Spain, with more than 1GW of wind and solar projects securing contracts between 2018 and 2020.

Sweden is one of Europe's leading markets for corporate PPAs, which provide an additional incentive for renewables growth. Strong natural resources, a stable and credible incentive program and a national renewables commitment have all contributed to Sweden's dominant role in the European market. Corporate PPAs also hedge against the potential for higher wholesale power prices, which may increase in Sweden if the capacity gap created by nuclear decommissioning is not addressed.

Power demand in Switzerland is increasingly gradually. Peak demand was 5% higher in 2019 compared to 2018. Demand is increasing, yet power consumption has not varied significantly as improved efficiency has been enough to offset higher demand.

Since 2018, Turkey bucked its longer-term trend of adding capacity across all technologies based on the assumption of long-term economic growth and increasing power demand. The last two years have seen peak power demand drop from 47,660MW in 2017 to 45,324MW in 2019. The government's prioritization of lignite and emphasis on domestic resources means it is focusing on adding capacity based on energy independence and security of supply rather than just the economics of different technologies. To take advantage of domestic resources, Turkey plans to refit existing coal assets to run off lower-quality domestic lignite rather than imported hard coal  this should help keep costs down and reduce reliance on imported fuel.

Power demand in Ukraine fell after the 2014 Russian annexation of Ukrainian Crimea, and ongoing militarization of eastern Ukraine has led to major economic volatility and a longer term slowdown. Demand has revived somewhat since 2016, as parts of the country have stabilized and returned to growth. The current generation fleet has been adequate to serve the national market, but Soviet-era nuclear assets must either be upgraded or replaced. The governments drive to improve the energy efficiency of housing and public buildings is expected to limit increases in demand while renewables are developed. The aim is to reduce Ukraines dependence on Russian gas for its power and heating needs. Wind and solar resources are attractive, but the distribution and transmission system will require major investment to integrate growing renewables capacity.

Government focus is on offshore wind out of all the renewables technologies on offer, due to the good resource potential for the technology in the U.K. In 2019, the government put forward a 'sector deal' to achieve 30GW of installed offshore wind capacity by 2030, which requires an additional 10GW of new capacity. The government has since tentatively pledged that it will increase this target to 40GW by 2030. Meanwhile, U.K. power demand declined 6.8% from 2010-2019. BNEF expects a small average rise in power demand of 0.1% each year between 2020 and 2050, as efficiency gains are offset by the ramp-up in demand from electric vehicles. However, meeting net-zero emissions by 2050 could require further reliance on the electrification of other sectors like heating for buildings.

An administratively burdensome bureaucracy and high taxes do little to attract investment. Sonelgaz is the offtaker for utility-scale projects. However, the utilitys financials have been strained over recent years as it suffers from low commodity prices, widespread fraud and structural inefficiencies. In addition to the company running up debts, many of Sonelgazs customers are behind on payments. The group launched legal proceedings against over 50 companies it claims owe it money in August 2019. Despite the possibility of arrears on payments, the risk of the offtaker defaulting is held in check by Sonelgaz being backed by the government and domestic banks.

Angolas economy contracted in 2019 for the fourth straight year, as a slower-than-expected economic recovery unfolds for its large petroleum sector. Declining crude production, falling oil exports and high inflation create a challenging outlook for a return to economic growth. Investments in generating capacity in the form of new large hydro facilities have improved reliability of power supply in the capital region in recent years, though soaring demand and population growth means progress on electrification will be challenging. Angolas electrification rate was 42% in 2019, with much lower rates of access in rural areas. Angola has ambitious, if unsupported, near-term plans to develop renewable energy. It plans to connect over 500MW to the grid by 2022, and 800MW by 2025. The mapping of resources has been carried out to some extent across all technologies and several solar hybridization projects are underway, but no concrete steps have yet been taken to advance a planned solar auction program or to develop the country's wind resources.

Benin has significant off-grid electrification potential, with only 34% percent of the national population currently having access to power. Urban and rural electrification rates have improved in recent years, although only two-thirds of citizens in towns and a mere 16% of the rural population have access to power. Peak demand has been rising steadily in recent years.

Botswana boasts an impressive electrification rate of 67%. Botswana's power demand has plateaued in recent years, sitting at 610MW for the last three years. Demand has peaked due to a slowdown in mining as a result of the commodities price slump, whereby the largest state mine in the country filed for liquidation in 2016 and halted all operations. BPC has an aging power plant fleet with the oldest plant commissioned in the late 1980s. Refurbishment of the Morupule A coal plant has experienced numerous delays while Morupule B has proved prone to breakdowns.

Power demand has been rising rapidly in Burkina Faso, with peak demand increasing on average by 9% a year since 2015. Electrification has barely kept up with this growing demand. The national electrification rate is 21%, yet only 3% of the rural population has access to electricity. Burkina Faso has great solar and hydro resources, but limited wind potential. The low rural electrification rate and high solar resources offer a significant opportunity for off-grid project development. Mini-grids can be owned and operated by private actors, but require an authorization or license if exceeding 250kW or 1MW respectively.

Burundi is one of the poorest countries in the world and relies on foreign aid. The country has been facing civil wars and political tension for decades. Burundi is ranked 168 among 190 countries in the Worlds Bank Doing Business index for 2019. Bureaucracy, poor infrastructure, trade challenges, high taxes and low access to credit are among the challenges for businesses. On the positive side, Burundi joined the East African CommCommunity in 2007 and started the implementation of a common external tariff in 2009. Burundi also made major reforms to improve the procedure for creating a new business. The relationship with the East African Community could be a good opportunity for Burundi to proceed with the country's participation in regional infrastructure projects, such as interconnection and shared hydro power plants with neighboring countries.

Cameroon has seen average economic growth of 3.9% a year over the last decade and growth has picked up recently owing to rising revenue from oil, rubber and coffee production. The country has a relatively weak electrification rate of 68%, with 21% in rural areas. The government aims to reach 3GW of power capacity by 2020, mainly through new hydropower plants, and off-grid solar in rural areas. The Rural Electrification Master Plan, in its second phase, aims to electrify 10,000 locations by 2035, securing 50,000 connections annually over 20 years. The government is also preparing a new framework to regulate private off-grid renewables projects, although the policys legal status is still unclear.

Electricity demand in the Central African Republic has been relatively flat over the past decade. Very little progress has been made in terms of national, urban and rural electrification rates. As distribution grids and electrification rates improve, demand is expected to rise. There are programs to modernize the energy infrastructure, funded primarily by international development banks, yet these are insufficient to enable wider electrification of the population. There is therefore a high potential for mini-grids.

Electrification rates remain low in Chad, with only a tenth of the population having access to power. Urban access has been steadily improving, while rural rates linger around 2%. This contrasts with the governments goal of a 53% national and 20% rural electrification rate by 2030. Microgrid projects are few and far between, but offer great potential, particularly given the large distances in the country. There are persistent concerns about the lack of investment in transmission and distribution, with grid congestion a particular issue for projects in and around the capital Ndjamena.

The Republic of Congo has been teetering on the brink of insolvency since 2016 in the context of an economic crisis sparked by plummeting oil prices. The countrys business environment has been detrimentally impacted and has also contributed to reducing the markets attractiveness. Moreover, finance to date has been directed toward large hydro projects rather than other renewables. The National Agency for Rural Electrification and the Fund for the Development of the Power Sector lack the financial means necessary to abate low electrification rates. Investment in the countrys decrepit dams is lacking, with no concerted modernization plan in place to date.

Mining activity will drive near-term growth in power demand in the DRC, in part due to the increase in global demand for specialty metals such as copper and cobalt, which the country has in abundant supply. Copperbelt Energys plans to build two grid-connected solar PV projects for the mining sector are evidence of this. The government plans to triple the current national electrification rate to 32% by 2030 and this is likely to mean favorable policies will be introduced for mini-grids or off-grid solar. Most DRC power plants are hydroelectric stations that do not require near-term upgrades. Once the liberalization of the energy sector is completed, mining companies can independently produce or procure, which could force SNEL to operate competitively. However, mini-grid and off-grid are also expected to grow in the coming years as household demand increases.

Cte dIvoires electricity sector is growing. Peak power increased from 912MW in 2010 to 1,443MW in 2019, and electricity exports from 470GWh in 2010 to 1,255GWh in 2019.  Its power network is one of the largest in West Africa, with more than 54,000km of network in total. Today, 70% of its population have access to electricity and 69% of municipalities have been electrified. The 2014 Electricity Code provides a framework for the distribution of renewable energy by independent producers, although this is currently forbidden because of the concession contract between CIE and the state, in place until 2020.

Peak electricity demand has increased by almost 50% over 2010-19 to reach 31.4GW. The pandemic has slashed power consumption, but demand is expected to resume strong growth. Moreover, favorable wind and especially solar resources align with the governments ambitions regarding renewables. Egypt has its sights on boosting gas extraction, but plummeting renewables costs will render future combined-cycle gas plant additions unlikely. And while the country enjoys an overabundance of generation capacity at the moment, much of Egypts power fleet is composed of old, highly inefficient diesel plants which will be replaced over coming years. For its part, a 6.6GW coal plant postponed in April 2020 is unlikely ever to be built.

The prerequisites for doing business in Eritrea are likely to improve following the political rapprochement with Ethiopia. The combination of low electrification rates, good solar and wind potential and the expense of fuel imports offers opportunities for mini-grid developers in particular. However, the poorly maintained or, in parts, non-existent transmission and distribution infrastructure impacts the viability of larger projects. The lack of transparent, clear regulatory framework and incentives further thwart clean energy project development.

Most private sector opportunity in Ethiopias clean energy space exists within the on-grid sector. The Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Energy has plans for 100% energy access by 2025. Ethiopia has ambitions to be a middle-income economy in 2025, and power demand is growing fast across the country (estimated at 30% annually), meaning mini grids and off grid products will still factor into meeting this demand. The country has a separate goal of distributing 3.6 million solar lanterns and 400,000 solar home systems by 2025.

Power demand in Ghana has been growing, with peak demand reaching 2,783MW in 2019, up 10% from 2018. The heaviest power consumers are the 51 companies registered as bulk customers (as of August 29, 2019). These entities have a peak demand of at least 500 KVA for a consecutive period of three months or a minimum annual energy consumption of 1GWh. Many of these are concentrated in the Tema Export Processing Zones, which is authorized by the government to promote industrial activities. The extractive industry is also a heavy power consumer, accounting for about 10% of total power demand in Ghana. The national electrification rate reached 84% in 2018, which is one of the highest in Sub-Saharan Africa. However, electrification rates as reported by government are not always accurate because many households may not have electricity access even if the grid extends to their area. Political focus is on extending the grid as opposed to electrification via other means such as solar home systems.

Power demand has been steadily increasing in Guinea, with an average growth rate of 9.5% over the past three years. Electrification will continue to increased demand, with more than 60% of the population remaining unconnected despite a 22%-point increase in national electricity access rates since 2010. While urban electrification rates have been improving quickly, progress in raising the rural populations access to power has been slow, with less than a fifth connected to the grid. There is therefore significant potential for off-grid project development given the countys ample hydro and solar resources. Existing thermal plants have been modernized, and a program funded by the European Investment Bank is doing the same for the countrys large hydro assets.

International industrials such as General Electric, Siemens and ABB are working with the Iraqi government to repair and upgrade power plants in an attempt to sustain current plant production and rehabilitate capacity damaged during years of conflict. The government also aims to strengthen the grid and reconnect areas in the north and west with the rest of the country. With demand growing 7% on average each year, further capacity will be necessary to avoid continued shortages.
80 to 120 words

The government continues to foresee a considerable increase in power demand despite a slowdown over 2016-2018 linked to slower economic growth. The government expects high population growth combined with an expanding commercial and industrial sector to boost power demand to 19,701GWh in 2030, from about 17,672GWh in 2020. The majority of Jordanians live in the north of the country, around the capital Amman, and 99.9% of the population have access to power. Further renewables growth will be challenged by the financial commitments Nepco has with fossil fuel generators. Whilst growing renewables generation is reducing fossil fuel power plant run hours, Nepco is still bound to pay fossil fuel generators in full through take-or-pay PPAs.

Kenyas peak power demand saw 5.6% growth from 2018 to 2019, reaching 1,900MW. It was driven by growing demand from residential customers that could benefit from a subsidized grid connection cost, and from commercial as well as industrial customers. Kenya Power introduced a night-time discounted tariff for commercial and industrial customers in December 2017. But, it has not stimulated consumers to increase power demand as intended, likely because of strict criteria for eligibility. Kenya has the largest off-grid solar market in Sub-Saharan Africa, and is poised to grow further under its National Electrification Strategy launched in December 2018, which aims to attain universal access by 2022.

Power demand has steadily grown at 3% per year on average since 2015, with power consumption per capita among the highest in the world. This is the result of several factors, namely wasteful resource consumption on the back of heavily subsidized energy prices, population growth, and a nascent petrochemical industry. Kuwaits abundant solar and wind resources offer the potential for a quick ramp up of renewable power. Although no explicit fleet modernization program has been announced, Kuwait is building capacity in response to the forecasted growth in electricity demand.

Lebanons power demand is difficult to estimate because much of it is unmet or provided by the fleet of black-market diesel generators. In recent years, an estimated 500MW of additional demand has come from the 1.5 million Syrian refugees present in the country. Forecast demand growth is modest. However, significant investment is required before current demand can be met. Lebanon enjoys high electrification rates and has few off-grid developments, although this sector represents opportunities to reduce dependence on the chronically unreliable grid. In terms of natural resources, Lebanon has abundant solar potential, which IRENA estimates to be around 182GW. Studies have also suggested wind potential between 1.5GW to 6GW of capacity.

Data indicates that Lesotho's electrification rate has advanced from 17% in 2015 to almost 43% in 2019. Lesotho's energy-access goals stipulate continued growth toward 50% by 2020, and 80% by 2030. This would provide a substantial opportunity for investment in the power sector.

The refurbishment of the Mount Coffee Hydropower Plant was a game-changer for the Liberian energy system. Power quality and reliability has since improved, and retail rates have dropped. However, demand for electricity far exceeds supply and significant grid investment is required. Outside of Monrovia, microgrid development has commenced despite the lack of a dedicated policy framework and regulatory oversight. There is significant potential for new solar and hydro projects, especially as the regulatory and policy framework continues to improve.

Madagascar is among the most difficult countries to do business with, according to the World Bank Ease of Doing Business report. The country ranked 161 out of 190 in 2020. The report cited difficulty in obtaining construction permits, registering a property and obtaining credit to finance a project. Madagascars tax structure is also complicated. These factors make it difficult to start a renewable energy project in the country. With electrification rates encompassing only one quarter of total inhabitants and less than one tenth of the rural population, Madagascar offers significant off-grid clean energy development opportunities, particularly given its ample solar resources. Putting in place the right policies to attract business into the countrys electricity sector could drive new investment.

Malawi is one of the least electrified countries globally, with an overall electrification rate of roughly 10%. In rural areas, this reduces to 1%, although many live within 10 km of electrical infrastructure. The country's rural electrification fund has an aim of extending the existing grid, not building off-grid, but has not been able to increase electrification significantly according to reported results. Resource potential for solar and mini grid solutions is high. Though Escom, the central utility, has no plans to build solar assets of its own, it has awarded solar PPAs to a number of foreign developers.

Power demand increased annually by 10% on average between 2015 and 2019 in Mali. Electrification has slowly but surely been improving over past years. In 2015, only 36% of the national and 17% of the rural population had access to power, but rates reached 50% and 21% respectively in 2019. Opportunities for mini-grid developers remain high. Solar/diesel hybrid plants are also growing in popularity due to the countrys high potential for solar irradiation and its rural electrification fund. The rural electrification agency is responsible for authorizing such operators, making the process of setting up a mini-grid more efficient than in neighboring countries.

Power demand has been increasing slowly but surely since 2010. Officials foresee that coming years could see a tripling of demand with the completion of three large transmission projects connecting large urban centers. There is strong potential for clean energy development, due to ample solar and wind resources in addition to single-digit rural electrification rates. Investment in renewables is set to continue despite imported hydropower and the attraction of offshore gas.

Moroccos electricity demand has grown at an average rate of 5.1% since 2010, slightly outpacing average economic growth of 3.5%. Of particular importance to the energy sector, peak electrical demand has also grown at a similar rate to total demand. Morocco has had great success in the electrification of rural areas, with the ONEE connecting more than 99% of the Moroccan rural population to the grid by 2014. The law that provides the framework for renewables projects, law 13-09, only permits the sale of electricity over the medium- and high-voltage networks. In 2015, the publication of act 58-15 opened up the possibility of access to the low-voltage networks, seen as key to the growth of the small-scale PV sector. However, as of 2019, this act is not yet implemented and therefore any sale of electricity back to the grid by small enterprises or private individuals is not yet possible. The intention is for this obstacle to be removed in the short to medium term. Estimates of total wind-resource potential for Morocco are as high as 25GW.

Mozambique's power fleet is in need of investment as the country seeks to expand generation capacity to meet growing load and ambitious electrification targets. The Ministry of Energy has published a long-term development plan, the Integrated Electricity Infrastructure Master Plan, which encompasses the southern system and central and northern systems for 2018-2028 and the integrated system through 2029-2043. The Plan envisions new power generation projects totaling 530 MW solar and 150 MW wind, in addition to 4,300 MW of hydro, 1,350 MW of coal and 8,500 MW of gas. Mozambiques electrification rate remains very low at just 32% in 2019, and progress in extending access to the wider population has been slow. Power demand continues to grow quickly, with peak consumption nearly doubling since 2010. For on-grid projects, developers can negotiate prices that enable the project to be profitable, but PPAs are negotiated on a case-by-case basis and there is no standardized duration for either on- or off-grid projects.

Namibia experienced an economic recession between 2016 and 1Q 2019. As of the second quarter of 2019, the economy showed some signs of growth. Fitch ratings agency expects 1.1% real GDP growth in 2019. In spite of the weak economic backdrop, power demand in Namibia has increased year on year at an average rate of 4% since 2006. The main factor propping up demand growth is a rapidly increasing electrification rate, which now sits at 54%. Rural electricity access still lags significantly, and is over 20% below the national average. The country has an ambitious rural electrification target, aiming for 50% electricity access by 2020. Large investments in off-grid systems and mini-grids will be necessary to meet that goal. Providing access to the rural population has historically been a challenge in Namibia, as it is the least densely populated country in Africa and the rural population is extremely dispersed. In some areas, grid extensions are not financially feasible. So far, minigrids have been developed top-down by the government, but they are keen to discuss public-private partnership arrangements with investors.

Demand has steadily increased in the past decade, with future demand likely driven by ongoing electrification. Alongside similar initiatives, the World Banks NESAP is expected to make considerable progress in the off-grid space, given that only 1% of the Nigerien rural population currently has access to power. The historically slow rate of progress in electrification and Nigers ample solar resources provide ample opportunity for off-grid project development.

Nigeria has a very strong solar resource, followed by up to 3.5GW of small hydro. There is little wind resource. In 2016 alone, Nigerians spent a massive $16 billion to power privately-owned diesel/gasoline generators. More than 60% of companies in Nigeria have access to, or rely heavily on, diesel generators, compared to less than 20% in South Africa. The potential for minigrids in Nigeria is therefore substantial. The on-grid peak demand reported by the government was 26GW in 2019, but actual demand, accounting for off-grid consumption, is likely to be well over 50GW. In 2016, Nigeria announced the Power Sector Recovery Program (PSRP), a series of policy actions, operational, governance and financial interventions to be implemented by the Federal Government of Nigeria between 2017 and 2022, in order to reset the Nigerian Electricity Supply Industry (NESI) for future growth. The World Bank Group expressed its willingness to assist the PSRP with a $2.6 billion loan in 2019 and as of June 2020, $750 million had been approved.

Peak power demand in Oman increased at a compound annual growth of about 8% from 2007 to 2017, primarily driven by a growing economy, rising population and the governments focus on non-oil sectors. From 2018, the peak-demand growth rate declined to around 5% due to the introduction of the Cost Reflective Tariff for large industrial, commercial and government consumers in 2017. Commissioned renewables projects only accounted for less than 1% of installed capacity as of 2019, but Omans fuel diversification plan and support of finance could spur rollout.

Power demand has remained stable in the past few years. The unreliability of the electricity supply in the Gaza Strip, where most consumers rely on diesel generators, offers opportunities  still, doing business is difficult as imports and entry are controlled by Israel. In the West Bank, the potential for PV uptake is significant but in practice it is limited as the most promising area for development is under the control of the Israeli military.

Qatars peak power demand is growing at approximately 7%. The rate varies year-to-year with a range of 1-11%. Generation capacity continues to increase as load grows at 6.5% per year, which leads to expansion of transmission and distribution networks. This demand growth is primarily driven by growth of the countrys industrial sector and increasing infrastructure development for FIFA World Cap 2022. Abundant sunlight means solar PV projects have the greatest potential to help Qatar reduce its dependence on natural gas.

Rwanda prides itself on being one of the best markets to do business in among Sub-Saharan African countries and has an appetite for domestic and foreign investment to serve its fast-growing economy. The Rwanda Development Board has been created to support private sector players entering the country, complementing the strong presence of commercial and donor-backed lenders on the ground. Most of the growth in the energy space has been off-grid, as Rwanda has reached critical mass in its on-grid sector with an oversupply of generation. On the negative side, in 2018 Rwanda implemented new solar-equipment import standards overnight, which raised uncertainty for foreign investors and harmed the business model for some off-grid companies. Moreover, the country is reviewing its National Electrification Plan to divide off-grid areas between solar home systems and mini-grid systems.

Peak electricity demand has grown steadily, rising from 46GW to 62GW over 2010-19. Growth is likely to resume despite the economic impact of the pandemic. Besides the conversion of western oil plants to gas, policymakers are mulling the relative benefits of using domestic gas resources versus liquefied natural gas, terminals for which have yet to be built. In the long run, world-beating renewables resources are likely to undercut such investments. Moreover, the amount of power used by desalinification processes is likely to reduce as the country switches from existing thermal plants to installations employing reverse osmosis.

Senegals electrification scheme has fallen short of expectations, since being initially hailed as revolutionary upon its launch in 2008. The private concessionary framework assigned 10 rural districts to operators, setting out yearly electrification targets in the process. But operators have fallen behind on their goals while charging prohibitive fees. With national electrification at 67%, the 2025 universal access target seems ambitious. More generally, Senegal is a dynamic market  demand is growing fast and the economy is buoyed by a young, skilled workforce.

According to the 2018 Integrated Household Survey, grid electricity customers in Sierra Leone received around 15 hours of electricity a week. Several sites for large hydro have been identified and announced, however, the grid needs improving to ensure efficient power transmission as well as to connect additional capacity. On the other hand, there is potential for mini-grids and off-grid solar in rural areas. Today, there are 60 operating mini-grids that are part of a project funded by the U.K.s DFID that identified 94 sites for development and within which customers can buy electricity tokens using pay-as-you-go services. Off-grid solar is also financed with pay-as-you-go, although mobile has limited penetration.

The absence of reliable electricity supply is a significant barrier to doing business. Even consumers that have a grid connection are dissatisfied with the quality of the service they receive. Were the generation capacity and transmission and distribution infrastructure to improve, power demand could grow significantly. The grid in Somalia is very decentralized, so off-grid and mini-grid development offers the potential for electrification even in the most remote areas. Somalia's rich solar resources make PV mini-grid systems an attractive option, and its long coastline also offers good resource potential for wind.

Electricity consumption in South Africa has stagnated in recent years, declining on average 0.5% per year since 2006. The reduction has been mostly caused by heavy power users, due to factors such as economic slowdown, volatility in commodity markets and rising electricity costs. This trend has been reflected in peak demand, which fell for a second consecutive year in 2019. The main opportunity for off- or mini-grid projects in South Africa is in rural areas where electrification was at 66% in 2018, compared to 93% in urban areas. The Integrated National Electrification Plan includes initiatives to boost electricity access in rural areas  aiming to fund an estimated 723,000 grid and 49,650 non-grid connections to households by 2019/20.

Power demand in the country is growing and expected to increase. This is due to the combination of population growth, very low electrification rates and little installed capacity to date. Taking into account the abundant solar resources, the case for off-grid solar development is particularly strong. On-grid growth is, however, limited by a lack of transmission and distribution infrastructure. The fragile economic and security situation in South Sudan will also continue to make it hard to attract utility-scale clean energy developers.

Optimism abounded following the removal of the majority of U.S. sanctions in October 2017, but Sudans economic situation has improved little since then. Inflation has surged, widening the chasm between production costs and rock-bottom power prices, and economic hardship will persist in the wake of a sharp ongoing currency devaluation. The reliance on costly imported fuel underlines the attractiveness of renewables, to which Sudans geography is well suited, with its high solar irradiation and strong winds. Power demand has increased by 9% per year on average since 2015, but 32% of the national population remain without access to power.

Doing business in Tanzanias clean energy sector presents risk. The countrys power demand has failed to grow with the countrys population, and the regulator published data showing that power demand actually fell between 2017 and 2018. Additionally, there are questions surrounding the validity of economic growth figures the country has published, which is expected to fuel more investor uncertainty. The country has significant potential for solar and hydro, but neither technology has been fully realized. There is a strong market for off-grid energy in Tanzania, and while the government continues its grid extension plans, in practice many households remain without access to energy in connected areas. In the mini-grid market, no company has succeeded in developing larger sites, with most mini-grids sizing around or below 100kW.

Togo has a low electrification rate of just 11% in rural areas and 45% nationally. The country has developed a roadmap for electrification to reach 100% of the population by 2030. The program combines the distribution of 550,000 solar kits, notably with partners such as BBOXX, developing 315 microgrids, and extending the distribution grid to remote areas. The level of demand for electricity largely exceeds supply, and increased at a compound annual growth rate of 6.1% from 2013 to 2017. The construction of the utility-scale PV project (5MW by Eiffage and Neoen) has been proposed several times since 2015, but has been held back by the government wanting to benefit from the steep cost reductions of PV, and the required engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) price renegotiations. In 2019, the UAE-based Amea signed the first solar PPA with CEET (Compagnie Energie Electrique du Togo) as it announced the development of its subsidiary Amea Togo Solar, which will finance, build and operate a 50MW solar plant in Togo.

The country is slowly recovering from an economic crisis. Growth in GDP fell to 1% in 2019, down from 2.6% in 2018, and 2% in 2017. The economy was forecasted to continue its growth trajectory in 2020, before the global pandemic hit. Tunisias peak power demand is recovering, after a 6% drop from 2015 to 2016, and recorded a spike of 18% year-on-year to 4,025MW in 2017. This represented the greatest increase since at least 2011. It is one of few countries in Africa with nearly 100% electrification rates.

An oversupplied market and lagging transmission and distribution infrastructure are reducing activity in Ugandas power-generation sector. The most promising on-grid investment opportunities today involve building wires to transmit power to where it is needed most. Offtakers are generally secure in receiving payments for contracted power. The transmission system operator, UETCL, is the sole offtaker for all grid-connected power in the country. Grid-connected projects to date have signed 'deemed energy' (take-or-pay) contracts, and UETCL's commitments are understood to be backstopped by the Ministry of Finance. As long as projects are delivering to UETCL at the designated delivery point, they are paid whether or not UETCL is able to evacuate the power. This has increased the ability of projects to secure finance and increased their profitability. Rural electrification and distributed energy are also booming. Uganda has a thriving off-grid solar industry, with many companies using pay-as-you-go and mobile money applications to power explosive growth. Most of Uganda's energy access initiatives are focused on rural electrification, as a large portion of the country's capital, Kampala, already has grid access. The national electrification rate is low at 28%, while the rural electrification rate stands at just 8%. The country has introduced various strategies and plans with universal access targets that range from 2030 to 2040.

Power demand has risen rapidly in recent decades, growing by nearly 10GW over 2010-19 to reach 25GW. The long-term impact of Covid-19 on demand will hinge on whether fears of a pandemic-induced expat exodus are borne out  foreign workers account for some 90% of the population. Regardless, favorable geography likely see more solar additions in the year to come, although there is a lack of visibility on tenders going forward. Yet much of the power fleet is relatively young. A high number of power purchase agreements for combined-cycle gas plants will come to an end in 2030  many could be extended. Meanwhile, a transition toward less power-hungry reverse osmosis plants will contribute to decoupling the water and electricity sectors.

Electricity demand has risen on robust GDP growth, due to the expansion of copper mining and agriculture. Peak demand grew from 1.5GW in 2010 to a record 2.2GW in 2018. However, in 2019 peak demand hit the lowest level since 2014, of 1.9GW. Zambia's mining sector has seen copper production almost double following the commissioning of the country's first coal-fired power plant, Maamba, in July 2016. However, Zambia's hydro-dominated power sector has failed to meet growing demand during times of drought: the deficit of power output relative to demand reached around 1,000MW in 2015 and 526MW in 2016, and resulted in load shedding. This had a devastating effect on the Zambian economy, bringing annual GDP growth downwards from a mean 7%, between 2002 and 2014, to 2.92% in 2015, which was the lowest since 1998. In 2019, drought conditions have again caused power shortages, with a peak deficit reported at 273MW. However, the country has made significant steps to improving load management with scheduled 4-hour periods of outages per day and exemptions for critical consumers. The national electrification rate is 31% (67% in urban and 4% in rural areas). The governments plan of 66% national access (90% urban and 51% rural) will likely require mini-grids or off-grid solar, as low population density and affordability can limit the case for major grid extensions to all areas.

On average, the country produces around 969MW daily against a peak demand of 2,100MW, resulting in severe load shedding of up to 18 hours per day. Businesses in the country struggle to maintain operations without stable electricity. Due to unreliable generation in the country's own fleet, Zimbabwe imports approximately 400MW from Eskom (South Africa) and EDM (Mozambique) in order to meet demand. This is not sustainable long-term. All of the country's five main generation plants have surpassed their 25-year general lifespan and are in need of modernization. However, funding for this is limited. Despite contending with severe load shedding, Zimbabwe exports 80MW to Namibia via a 15-year agreement signed in 2015. The countries discussed expanding the arrangement in 2019. Renewable energy development can benefit from a 10-year income tax holiday and solar equipment is exempt from import duty as well as VAT, effective July 2019.

On a country-wide basis, hydropower supplies about 60% of total generation in Canada. As the country has not recently experienced the effects of droughts or other climate change-related natural disasters that could impact the output of hydropower resources, the dominance of hydro as a share of Canada's power mix is unlikely to change in the near term. Pumped hydropower resources provide necessary flexibility to provincial liberalized power markets, and about 35% of the country's power generation comes from inflexible thermal generating sources. There is little pressure to begin building significant battery resources. The biggest players in Canada's power markets are public utilities like Hydro-Quebec, Ontario Power Generation, and BC Hydro.

The U.S. power markets consist of 11 primary regions, the three largest of which from a generation standpoint are PJM, MISO and the Southeast. Other frequently discussed regions are California and Ercot (Texas). Broadly, regions in the U.S. are either regulated (where vertically integrated utilities control the generation, transmission and distribution of energy) or deregulated (where utility ownership of power plants is less common and IPPs own a greater share of generating assets). Across all regions, the asset owners with the largest portfolios are Duke Energy, Southern Co. and NextEra. Within these regions, there are individual markets that maintain individual wholesale power pricing mechanisms; power exporting/importing occurs between and within markets.

Argentinas power matrix remains largely reliant on thermal and large hydro assets. Currently, 50% of installed capacity is gas power plants, with hydro representing 27%. The country has a considerable amount of oil and diesel in the mix at 10%. The share of renewables increased from 2.5% in 2017 to 7% through 2019 thanks to the commissioning of projects awarded in RenovAr. Total wind and solar capacity, less than 300MW in 2017, passed 2GW in 2019. For the first time, wind became the largest source of renewable generation. Despite the dramatic increase, Argentina still fell far short of its goal of 12% renewables in 2019. Around 6% of generation came from small hydro, wind, solar and biomass last year.

Despite the 800MW of new combined cycle gas turbines added in 2019, the share of natural gas generation in Bolivias power matrix has been declining. Government-subsidized pricing limits the competitiveness of renewables. However, Bolivia is seeking to expand its hydroelectric capability to 74% of capacity by 2025 (up from 30% in 2018) and allow the country to export electricity. Despite the subsidized competition from fossil fuel, renewable generation, such as from the Uyuni and Oruro solar plants, now accounts for 3% of total capacity. ENDE is responsible for most generation, transmission and distribution.

Brazil has the largest power market in Latin America, with total installed capacity of 171GW in 2019, up from 162GW in 2018. The countrys size, plentiful resources and conducive policies have made it the regions main renewable energy market and one of the top 10 in the world.
