Its matrix remains highly reliant on hydropower, which accounted for roughly 64% of the countrys generation in 2019. The heavy reliance on one source came at a high cost in 2014: a prolonged drought caused significant stress for Brazils water supply and energy matrix, exposing the market to costly fossil-fuel generation. The crisis emphasized the countrys need for power sector diversification. Auctions and net metering will continue to be crucial policies to develop Brazils power sector. In terms of structure, the power market is fully unbundled and fairly evenly split between state-owned and private-sector players.

Chile has a National Electric System (Sistema Elctrico Nacional, or SEN) as well as two smaller isolated systems in the south of the country, the Sistema Elctrico de Aysn (SEA) and Sistema Elctrico de Magallanes (SEM). The SEN was created with the interconnection of the countrys two primary power systems, the Sistema Interconectado del Norte Grande (SING) and the Sistema Interconectado Central (SIC), at the end of 2017. The process of interconnection continued with the commissioning of a second line connecting the two systems in June 2019. The SIC and SING sub-systems together account for 99% of Chiles total installed capacity, at 18GW and 7GW, respectively. In 2019, Chile had 2.7GW of solar and 1.6GW of wind capacity, representing 18% of the countrys total installed capacity. Wind and solar alone represented 14% of the countrys total power generation in 2019, up from virtually nothing five years ago.

Of Colombias total installed capacity of 17.6GW at year-end 2019, large hydro represented 62% and provided 71% of the 70TWh of total electricity generated that year, followed by natural gas and coal at 10% of generation each. Other renewables accounted for 8% of generation, with most coming from small hydro. Capacity additions since 2010 have been dominated by hydro, oil and diesel. Among renewables, Colombia had 941MW of small hydro, only 130MW solar and a single 18MW wind plant. Colombias power market has numerous private and state-owned players across segments, but remains concentrated. Government-operated Empresas Publicas Medelln (EPM), together with privately owned Emgesa and Isagen, accounted for 65% of generation in 2019.

The power market in Costa Rica is regulated and dominated by vertically-integrated Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad (ICE), the countrys major generator and sole power purchaser. However, the Costa Rican market allows private participation in the form of cooperatives and independent power producers. These entities can be involved with generation and distribution in some parts of the country. In 2019, Costa Rica had an installed capacity of 3,637MW, with hydropower representing almost 65% (2,360MW) of the total. Oil-fired capacity slipped to 474MW, or 13% of capacity, from 572MW, or 16% of capacity in 2018. Wind represents 11% (411MW) of current capacity. More geothermal capacity was added in 2019 than any other technology with 50MW brought online. Geothermal now accounts for 7% of Costa Ricas total capacity.  Generation in 2019 totaled 11,313GWh, thanks primarily to hydropower with 69% (7,827GWh), followed by wind with 16% (1,796GWh) and geothermal with 13% (1,513GWh).

The Dominican Republic had 7.4GW of installed capacity in 2019, compared to 6.4GW in 2018. Oil, diesel and coal are the main sources of electricity, accounting for 5.2GW, or approximately 71% of total capacity. Small hydro, wind, solar and biomass together account for 12%. Although generation is open to private players, it remains dominated by state-owned entities. The distribution segment is divided into three public companies: Edeeste, Edenorte and Edesur. All state-owned companies are managed by the Corporacin Dominicana de Empresas Elctricas Estatales (CDEEE).

In Ecuador, the Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy (MEER) oversees renewable energy policy and planning. In 2015, the Act Establishing the Public Electric Power Service (LOSPEE) was published, overseeing the power sector in Ecuador. Under this law, the National Electricity Board (CONELEC) becomes the Agency for Regulation and Control of Electricity (ARCONEL). While generation is open to private players in Ecuador, transmission is under the responsibility of state-owned utility Corporacin Elctrica del Ecuador (CELEC EP Transelectric). Distribution is divided between 11 majority-public companies, in which MEER is the majority shareholder. In 2019, Ecuador had a total of 8.6GW of installed capacity, with hydro representing 51% and thermal power accounting for 39% of its mix. Clean energy, encompassing small hydro, biomass, wind and solar plants, represents 9% of total capacity.

El Salvador had 2.1GW of installed capacity in 2019. Oil and diesel constitute the single largest source, with 35% of the total, followed by large hydro with 25%. Among renewables, biomass and geothermal dominate, with 13% (294MW) and 9% (204MW), respectively. PV capacity reached 269MW in 2019, compared to 104MW in 2017. El Salvadors power market has been unbundled and generation is open to private operators. The country is part of the Central American Electrical Interconnected System and is connected to Guatemala and Honduras by 286km of transmission lines. From January through September 2019, El Salvador added 84MW to its grid with two PV projects commissioned. In March 2019, Real Infrastructure Capital Partners completed a portfolio of three PV plants with a combined capacity of 44MW in the city of Acajutla. In July 2019, AES El Salvador and the Guatemalan Corporacin Multi Inversiones (CMI) installed 40MW of the 100MW Bosforo PV portfolio. Those plants are located in the cities of Santa Ana, San Sebastin Salitrillo, Sonsonate and Jiquilisco. With these new additions, El Salvadors solar capacity jumped 58% in less than a year.

The power market in Guatemala is unbundled. The country has 50 private and state-owned companies providing generation, distribution and transmission services. Guatemala is connected via the Central American Electrical Integration System (SIEPAC) to Honduras and El Salvador. Northern Guatemala is also connected to Mexicos transmission system. Guatemala has a total of 3,892MW of installed generating capacity. Wind capacity grew by 40%, from 76MW in 2017 to 107MW in 2018. However, there were no solar and wind additions in 2019. Biomass and hydropower (small and large) account for 60% of installed renewables capacity. In 2019, 68% (8.4TWh) of the electricity generation in Guatemala came from renewable sources.

Haiti has 284MW of installed capacity, with the bulk (80%) represented by fossil fuels. The remaining 20% comes from the Pligre hydro plant, which is undergoing restoration, and other small hydro plants. EDH owns 44% of capacity in Haiti and operates Haitis 1,500 km of distribution lines. EDH is able to power Haitis capital Port-au-Prince and a few cities nearby, but only intermittently due to insufficient infrastructure. Meanwhile, the use of diesel generators, kerosene lamps and other forms of off-grid technologies is commonplace. EDH has received grants from the World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) and other international organizations to help the country improve its infrastructure.

Honduras has total installed capacity of 2.8GW. In 2019, just under a third of the countrys power came from oil- and diesel-fired plants. Hydro accounted for 25% of generation, while renewables (biomass, solar and wind) were a combined 39.5%. Solar capacity has grown by 21% since 2015 to over 640MW in 2019. The Honduras wholesale market started operations in June 2019 and the country is part of the Central American Electrical Interconnected System (SIEPAC) meaning it is connected to El Salvador, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Panama and Nicaragua via transmission lines. Honduras is a net importer in the regional market.

In 2019, Jamaica consumed 4.4GWh of power, with just 12% generated by renewables. The country also commissioned the 37MW Paradise Solar (PV) project. JPS now controls 60% of generation and 100% of transmission and distribution services on the island.

Mexicos energy reform unbundled the state-owned, vertically integrated utility CFE, established the independent market operator and created a wholesale market. The CFE continues to hold the majority of generation assets and a monopoly on transmission and distribution. Deregulation of generation in 2016 created Mexicos wholesale market, which has operated on a day-ahead basis since January 2016. Power in Mexico remains heavily weighted toward fossil fuels, with natural gas, oil and coal together accounting for 69% of total capacity and 80% of generation in 2019. Hydro accounted for 9% of generation and renewables met 8%. At year-end 2019, Mexico had nearly 6GW of wind capacity while rapid growth in solar has seen commissioned utility-scale PV capacity grow to 4.7GW. Policy changes introduced by the Ministry of Energy in 2020, and since suspended, sought to reverse a core achievement of prior reforms: a competitive, cost-based power market. The new regulations would have given priority to CFE power plants by endowing market operator Cenace with permanent authority to prioritize dispatch based on reliability rather than cost. The step would have ensured that zero marginal cost renewables do not undercut and eventually displace CFE plants, many of which are aging, thermal generators. Prioritizing these costly units would essentially mark a return to Mexicos pre-reform power market. The ministry has said it will challenge the suspension of the policy in court.

Renewables accounted for 56% of the 4.5TWh of power produced in Nicaragua in 2019. Fossil-fueled plants still play an important, albeit somewhat diminished, role in the countrys power sector at 43% of 2019 generation. Nicaragua's power sector is unbundled and distinct actors (both state- and privately owned) participate in the generation and distribution sectors. At least 18 companies hold active generation contracts today for projects they own. Nicaragua is part of the Central American Electrical Interconnected System (SIEPAC) and is connected to El Salvador, Guatemala, Panama, Costa Rica and Honduras by transmission lines.

Panama had 3.86 GW of installed capacity in 2019 with oil and large hydro serving as the main sources. Renewables, excluding large hydro, accounted for 827MW in 2019, with solar and wind at 472MW. Panamas power market was unbundled in 1997, with generation and distribution opened to private operators. Panama is part of the Central American Electrical Interconnected System (SIEPAC) and is connected to Costa Rica via 150 km of transmission lines.

Paraguays electricity market is overseen by the Department of Mines and Energy, which is under the Ministry of Public Works and Communications (Ministerio de Obras Pblicas y Comunicaciones) and controlled by state-owned vertically integrated utility Administracin Nacional de Electricidad (ANDE). ANDE allows the participation of independent power producers (IPPs); however, as of 2019, there were no IPPs registered in the country.

In 2018, Peru generated 62% of its total 52TWh from renewable sources including large hydro. That source accounted for 57% in 2019, up from 40% in 2016, despite no significant capacity additions. Regarding non-renewable sources, coal and oil saw shrinkage in generation. Coal generated only 36GWh in 2019 compared to 674GWh in 2017; oil declined 92% in the same period. Perus installed hydro (small and large), solar, wind and biomass accounts for 45% of the countrys 13.2GW of generating capacity. In 2019, renewables installed capacity added accounted just for 167MW of hydro and 35MW of biomass, while wind and solar saw no increase.

Uruguays electricity market is overseen by the Ministry of Industry, Energy and Mines. Vertically-integrated state-owned utility UTE controls parts of generation and all transmission and distribution. UTE allows the participation of independent power producers through auctions, usually through 20-year power purchase agreements (PPA).

Da Afghaninstan Breshna Sherkat (DABS) is a government-owned utility that controls all segments of the power market, with little participation from the private sector. Private sector participation is not unwelcome, however, and independent power producers can request to take part in the market. Due to this, there is no standard offtake procedure in place so far. On-site power generation to exclusively meet the demands of a specific site is permitted.

Gas plants provide 40% of generation, nuclear 28% and large hydro 19%. Small hydro, solar and wind make up the remaining 13%. The countrys aging nuclear plant will eventually need an expensive life extension or replacement. Armenia aims to reduce its heavy reliance on gas imports and increase its diversity of resources. Aside from large hydro, renewables play a small but growing role. The power market is still fully regulated, although reforms are underway to shift to a deregulated wholesale market. The generation market is fully liberalized with a range of local and international owners. Transmission is controlled by the state-owned High Voltage Electric Network (HVEN). For now, only Electric Networks Armenia (ENA) is the only buyer and supplier of power for residential and industrial customers.

Despite a rapid influx of new renewable energy generators, coal generation still makes up the backbone of Australian electricity. But, the share of coal is dwindling as assets age, or are squeezed out of the market by cheaper renewable energy projects. Increasing intra-day volatility in spot electricity prices, and a greater need for improved system strength, are signalling the need for more flexible capacity to enter the market. Policy makers and regulators have put forward a series of packages that would support additional investment in dispatchable technologies like gas, batteries or pumped hydro. However, many market participants remain wary of a lurch back to direct government intervention in a market which has become highly liberalized and privatized.

Gas accounts for the largest share of generation in Azerbaijan, with hydropower a distant second and renewables having only a small impact. The country is self-sufficient in energy, although the interconnectors with neighboring countries allow for some imports and exports. Renewables projects do not benefit from priority dispatch, although the state-owned power company does have some obligations in the purchase of power. The power market is not unbundled but is controlled by the central government. Efforts are under way to reform this, with DNV-GL acting as a consultant to the government, and with support from development institutions. There is no market for PPAs (power purchase agreements); however, the government is working alongside the EBRD to develop a standard framework.

As much as 76% of electricity generated in Bangladesh comes from natural gas power plants. However, the countrys gas supplies are dwindling and reliance on imported fuel - chiefly LNG and coal - is set to rise. Coal power plants are under development with tie-ups from countries like China and India. Bangladesh is also building a 2GW nuclear plant with support from Russia. While private independent power producers or IPPs are involved in power generation, a large proportion of that share is short-term emergency rental plants. Transmission and retail businesses are dominated by government companies. Bangladesh Power Development Board acts as a single wholesale-buyer of all electricity. Third-party power purchases are not permitted unless it is a captive plant. Renewables, including large hydro, produce only 2% of electricity. This share may hold steady as rooftop solar projects increase in the coming years.

Cambodias power market is dominated by EDC. Nearly all of the generators are owned by independent power producers, which can sell to EDC only via a special license. In remote areas of the country, electricity is supplied by hundreds of private operators that generate, deliver and sell power. These operators however lose their licenses to generate power as soon as the national grid arrives. In 2019, 25% of Cambodia's electricity was imported from Thailand, Vietnam, and Laos. Large hydro and coal-fired plants account for about 90% of the domestic power generation. Most of these units have been built since 2012 to support its growing demand.

Coal still dominates Chinas power system, accounting for 52% of capacity and 62% of generation in 2019. Wind and solar together now account for 21% of capacity and almost 9% of generation. Generation from renewables continues to grow, not only due to growth in capacity, but also due to reduction in curtailment. China's grid companies have deployed multiple approaches to incorporate more renewables, including mandates for minimum dispatch hours, expanded inter-regional power transfer capacity and thermal generator flexibility retrofits. The result is historically low national average curtailment rates of below 3% for both wind and solar, despite the depressed power demand due to Covid-19. The share of wind and solar in overall power generation topped 11% in 1H 2020.

Georgias power market is unbundled and open for privatization in all segments. There are 21 qualified generators in total. The main generators are the state, which owns the 1,300MW Enguri Hydro Plant, and the Czech private company Energo-Pro Georgia. In 2019, Enguri was responsible for 28.5% of generation. The vast majority of power is transacted through contracts, but a wholesale spot market has been growing slowly. In 2019, 10,367GWh was sold through direct contracts while 2,879 was transacted on the spot market. There is little market for corporate PPAs, though rising commercial and industrial power prices could increase demand.

Coal remains the dominant fuel for electricity generation, with a 70% share in 2019. However, renewables have overtaken coal in terms of new capacity built each year since 2017. Renewables have benefited from supportive policies such as priority dispatch and waiver on transmission charges. Commercial and industrial users have also recognized the economic advantage of procuring renewables and are doing it through captive plants and power purchase agreements or PPAs. Power market reforms are in the pipeline, with a focus on improving financial and operational performance of the electricity distribution companies.

The power market in Indonesia is semi-unbundled: private players can participate only in generation, and accounted for 37% of the installed capacity in 2019. System operation, transmission and distribution are controlled by PLN, which is the sole offtaker. Private developers are not allowed to sign direct power purchase agreements with consumers. Corporate users may procure renewable power only through on-site PV systems, which can be purchased upfront or leased. Indonesias power mix is dominated by fossil fuels, which accounted for 85% of the installed capacity in 2019. The share of coal has increased from 36% to 50% of the installed capacity during 2010-19 to meet the rapid rise in electricity demand. Renewables share has grown only marginally due to lack of support from the government.

The vast majority of generation assets  which could be higher than 85%  are owned by the incumbent utilities, which makes it difficult for new entrants to compete in retail markets. As power demand is expected to fall amid the shrinking population and slowdown in economy, opportunities for new capacity additions are very limited except for the replacement of retired old capacity. Coal and gas account for 68% of generation. The growth in solar capacity is expected to be the largest in 2020 - we expect 7GW of capacity to be added. Japan has 10 different power markets and each region is poorly connected, resulting in price distortion between east and west regions in the wholesale market.

Power generated in Kazakhstan comes predominantly from Soviet-era plants that are old and inefficient and burn high ash coal of which the country has a 300-year supply.  As a result, fossil fuel generation account for nearly 90% of the power mix. Kazakhstans abundant coal resource and well-developed transmission infrastructure have positioned the country as a net energy exporter in recent years. Despite the favorable policies to expand renewable energy, such as auctions and tax exemptions, Kazakhstans heavily regulated retail tariff and the entrenchment of fossil fuel resources in terms of employment and infrastructure will likely slow the countrys energy transition.

The wholesale power market operates on a day-ahead, cost-based pool, in which the hourly price of electricity is determined by the variable cost of the marginal power plant. While the wholesale market is open to competition, Korea Electric Power Corp. monopolizes grid operation and retail market. Renewable energy power plants receive revenue from the sale of electricity on the wholesale power market as well as through the sale of renewable energy certificates. Korea Energy Agency issues 1 REC per every 1 MWh of electricity generated from renewable sources. Large-scale utilities purchase RECs to meet their annual RPS requirement set by the government. The requirement obligates utilities to procure a set share of their total generation from renewable sources: 7% (2020), 9% (2021), 10% (2022).

Kyrgyzstan's power sector was privatized in 1999, disbanding the state energy company Kyrgyzenergo and unbundling generation, transmission and distribution. JSC Electric Power Plants oversees generation and owns and operates nearly all of the country's existing power generation, which is mostly hydro and hasnt increased in recent years. No private players have entered the country's generation market, though it is technically privatized. JSC National Grid operates the transmission grid and is entirely independent of JSC Electric Power Plants. SeverElectro, VostokElectro, OshElectro and Jalal-AbadElectro are the four public distribution companies. There are also 21 private companies that operate portions of the distribution network around the country's capital, Bishkek. While the energy market is technically unbundled, government dominance leaves very little wiggle room for private players.

The domestic power market in Laos has a single-buyer structure, with lectricit du Laos (EDL) the sole buyer and retailer as well as the grid operator. Power generation was partially liberalized in 2010, when EDL spun off its large hydro assets under EDL-Gen, in which it owns a stake of about 75%. Independent power producers are also active in the market. They have been responsible for roughly 90% of the capacity addition since 2015. The pace of capacity addition picked up rapidly from 2013 onwards, due to external demands: Thailands EGAT financed, contracted and now dispatches power from several new large hydro projects and a 2GW coal plant. External demands will keep on driving new capacity addition as Laos is planning to double its transmission capacity with neighbors Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, Cambodia and Myanmar, over the next few years.

Coal and gas dominate power generation in Malaysia, and accounted for 75% of the installed capacity and 83% of electricity generation in 2019. This share has largely remained stagnant despite the governments efforts to promote renewable energy. A number of projects awarded under the three large-scale auctions completed during 2016-19 are expected to be commissioned in the next two years. The government is also awarding an additional 1GW of new projects in the fourth round of auctions. These projects will help increase the share of solar in installed generation capacity, and power generation, in the next three to four years. The electricity sector is partially unbundled, with private participation allowed in electricity generation. Independent power producers account for about 70% of all power generation assets in Malaysia. The three state-owned utilities  TNB, Serawak Energy and Sabah Electricity  are the only entities allowed to participate in electricity transmission and distribution.

Fossil fuels accounted for 93% of generation in 2018, although this may change as the high-polluting Soviet-funded coal plants age, and as renewables investment rises. Grid-connected generation capacity is expanding, which should reduce Mongolias reliance on electricity imports from Russia in the western grid and from China in its south (Mongolia has four grids). So far, almost 100% dispatch and purchase is secured for wind and solar. In addition, Mongolia has approximately 1MW of off-grid solar and 0.9MW of solar-wind hybrids, which typically supply  to Mongolian towns or soums and living tents or gers distributed in remote villages. The power market is generally state-owned and the grid is regulated, without near-term plans for liberalization. The state is the biggest player in both generation and distribution, and the National Dispatching Center is the only offtaker.

Natural gas and large-scale hydro are two dominant sources of energy for Myanmar, accounting for over 90% of the country's installed capacity. Renewable energy is getting traction, with the country's first utility-scale solar plant of 40MW coming online in May 2019, and a tender for 1.06GW of solar completed in July 2020. Although the country's power market is still dominated by a few state owned players, it is starting to open up power generation to foreign players. Sembcorp Power, a Singaporean utility, became the first foreign independent power producer in Myanmar in 2019. Chinese players are very active in the market. Japan's Marubeni Corporation won a $2 billion tender to build a 1.25GW gas power plant in July 2020.

Hydro is the main (99%) power generating source in Nepal. No fossil fuel is used for the purpose of powering the Himalayan country, except diesel, which is used for back-up generators widely adopted in facilities and at home. While hydro has zero emissions, Nepal experiences serious shortage of power: many people remain with restricted access to electricity, and those with access have regular or irregular blackouts. This is likely to change, as the country intends to build more hydro and introduce solar PV. Its power generation and transmission is largely bundled and dominated by a single state-owned entity - Nepal Electricity Authority or NEA. Although some independent power producers exist, the country wishes to introduce more in order to increase supply. So far Nepal imports power regularly from India, especially during the dry season. It does not have a domestic power market yet.

Wholesale spot prices in New Zealand are relatively volatile, largely depending on local rainfall levels - periods of drought lead to highly elevated spot prices. Increased transmission and distribution costs have also placed upwards pressure on retail power prices around the country over the past two decades, although final retail rates are still on the lower end of comparable OECD countries.

Closing the power supply gap is a policy priority. In the past three years, the government has attracted over 8.7GW of new coal and gas capacity under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor project, compared to 1.2GW of non-hydro renewables in the same timeframe. Growing public debt means that generators often are not paid due subsidies, and power distribution companies cannot claim their heavy transmission and distribution losses from consumers. Captive power plants are common among industrial users. The behind-the-meter solar market is significant, importing over $300 million in PV modules from China per year. Power plants currently receive a fixed cost-plus based tariff from the single buyer. Reforms to transition to a competitive wholesale spot market are underway and to be completed by 2026.

Historically, geothermal, oil/diesel and hydropower were the Philippines largest sources of generation. In 2019, coal was the largest power generation source, at 58GWh (55%), while the share of renewables decreased to 21%. After Epira liberalized the power market in 2001, Aboitiz Power, San Miguel Global Power and Trans Asia acquired the majority of assets and currently own about 62% of the total capacity. Epira also institutionalized the Wholesale Electricity Spot Market for Luzon and Visayas regions, and plans to do the same in Mindanao by December 2020. The government supports the signing of power supply agreements between large-demand consumers and developers, and has mandated utilities to facilitate customers wanting renewable power through a Green Energy Option program.

Tuas Power Generation, Senoko Energy, YTLPowerSeraya, Keppel Merlimau Cogen, Sembcorp Cogen, PacificLight and Tuaspring account for more than 90% of the generation capacity in Singapore. Half-hourly price-quantity bid offers are submitted to the wholesale market operated by the Energy Market Company  a subsidiary of Singapore Exchange. Prior to the inception of the OEM, only consumers whose monthly consumption exceeded 2MWh (contestable consumers) were allowed to purchase electricity from licensed private retailers. Those who did not meet this consumption threshold (non-contestable consumers) had to purchase electricity at the regulated tariff from state-owned utility SP Group. Under the OEM regime, which was rolled-out island wide in May 2019, all consumers, regardless of their monthly consumption, are allowed to purchase electricity from a licensed retailer. The retail market is highly competitive, with 29 licensed firms, out of which 12 are competing in the residential segment.

Sri Lankans power market is still a long way away from liberalization. Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB), the dominant utility, is yet to be unbundled, and seems to hold views contrary to the regulator PUCSL on the long-term generation expansion plan. CEB is the biggest player in the generation market and the only transmission licensee, which makes it hard to proceed with the reform in power supply. In the current energy mix, thermal oil accounts for the second largest share of installed capacity, and coal most likely became the first in generation in 2019. The PUCSL has not announced any retail tariff revisions since 2014. CEB has not been able to make a convincing case for tariff revision, transparently laying out its power procurement and power sales. The country hasnt implemented any battery storage into the grid system but has an ambitious goal. Sri Lanka's grid is isolated  having no connections with any of its neighbors yet  which also impacts future planning.

Coal accounted for 47% of Taiwans power generation in 2019. This position is likely to change with the governments energy transition set to increase the share of gas power to 50% and renewables to 20% of total generation by 2025, while phasing out nuclear power, which accounted for 12% of generation in 2019. To spur accelerated growth, policies have been introduced to give renewable energy priority dispatch and permission to be sold directly to end-users on the unregulated market. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company signing the world's largest corporate PPA with Orsted's offshore wind farms in Taiwan in July 2020. Fossil fuel generators can only sell power to Taipower. Liberalization for thermal generators is due to take effect in 5-8 years.

Barqi Tojik, a vertically integrated state-owned utility, dominates Tajikistans power sector. Despite its strong market position, the utility is in poor financial health due to low subsidized tariffs, losses on transmission and distribution services, and mediocre collection rates. The government has granted Pamir Energy the authority to generate power, provide transmission and distribution infrastructure and sell to retail consumers in one remote region, but Barqi Tojik acts as the utility for over 95% of the countrys population. Industrial players consume most of Tajikistans power.

Thailand's power market is partially liberalized, with the generation sector opened up to the participation from private players. State-owned utility EGAT is the sole offtaker of all generated electricity. The introduction of Small Power Producers (SPPs) and Very Small Power Producers (VSPPs) promoted the decentralization of power generation utilizing renewable energy. In 2018, renewables, including large hydro, accounted for 18% of total domestic electricity generation. Natural gas is still the backbone of Thailands power system, accounting for 60% of 2018 electricity generation. The latest power development plan of Thailand shows a further step back from coal and an increased role for gas in the power mix.

Turkmenistan relies almost exclusively on natural gas for its electricity needs. The state-owned utility, Turkmenenergo, controls all segments of the power market. There are no incentives to attract the involvement of IPPs.

In May 2019, Uzbekistan's electricity grid and its national utility JSC Uzbekenergo were split into three independent joint-stock companies. JSC Thermal Power Plants manages and develops the country's coal, gas and large hydro projects, but the generation segment of Uzbekistan's power market is partially liberalized and private-sector players are free to build renewables projects. The countrys transmission and distribution segments are managed by JSC National Electric Networks and JSC Regional Electric Networks, respectively, and neither are privatized. Coal and gas make up most of the countrys current generation mix. Renewables are expected to make up a majority of future build, however, with a national goal of being 25% renewable by 2030.

Vietnams power system is predominantly fossil fuel based with coal, gas and oil supplying 60% of generated electricity in 2018. Hydros potential has been largely harnessed in Vietnam and accounts for 38% of supply. Renewable energy (excluding hydro) has a limited role in the current generation mix, with less than 1% of total supply. Vietnams power market is partially liberalized, with the generation sector open for private participation. EVN and its subsidiaries monopolize transmission, distribution and retailing of power. Vietnam operates on a single buyer model with EVN as the sole off-taker of all generated electricity. A power sector reform roadmap is in place. In 2012, the competitive generation market was established and unbundled EVNs power generation function. In the second phase of liberalization, Vietnam introduced the competitive wholesale market in 2019. A competitive retail market is targeted after 2021. A mechanism for direct purchase of power by corporates is also under development.

In an 2020 update to the Law for the Electricity Sector, the Albanian government indicated that the establishment of a wholesale market is critical. However, this process has yet to be completed. Similarly, the liberalized power market has been delayed; certain customers are eligible to choose suppliers and sign bilateral contacts, while others are supplied by the distribution system operator OSHEE. With so much of its electricity supplied by hydro, the Albanian market has an outsized dependence on imports. To date no concrete steps toward establishing energy storage assets have been taken. Unbundling the market has been a long process, which has more recently been named a top priority.

Various hydroelectric technologies provides the bulk of generation and flexibility services  pumped, small and large hydro installations represent over half of a total 25GW of installed capacity in 2019. The countrys installed capacity has decreased in recent years. However, renewables  mainly rooftop PV and onshore wind  have grown from a low base over the last decade to reach over 4.5GW. The power sector has been partly unbundled and liberalized, but the state retains a central role: majority state-owned Verbund owns the sole transmission system operator and dominates the generation market, operating 46% of capacity as of August 2019. Corporate power purchase agreements have yet to take off, part of which is due to the ready availability of cheap hydropower.

The main source of power in Belarus is gas, accounting for 98% of power generation in 2019. Biomass, biogas and small hydro have been installed piecemeal in the past decade, but only made up 1% of installed capacity in 2019. Small- and utility-scale solar installations have been picking up since 2015, totaling around 150MW by 2019. There is around 100MW of onshore wind installed. The state utility Belenergo is vertically integrated and oversees all segments of the power sector. Rules have been relaxed slightly for power generation, so that IPPs have been able to enter the market. They can, however, only sell power to Belenergo, as bilateral contracts are currently not possible.

The Belgian power system has been coal-free since 2016, when the country became the first EU member state to phase out the technology. The countrys 6GW nuclear reactor fleet  to be phased out by 2025  is the source of much disruption, with outages representing a severe threat to security of supply over the winter of 2018. Private players can participate across the power sector, which has been unbundled and liberalized. However, Engies subsidiary Electrabel owned some 69% of generation capacity in 2019. Renewables growth has been steady across all main generating technologies, with the penetration of rooftop solar at 10%, the highest in all of Europe.

BiHs power fleet is roughly split between just over 2GW of lignite capacity and about 1.7GW of large hydro. Renewable energy capacity is minimal, but includes wind, solar, biomass and small hydro. While the electricity sector is open to private participation, the overwhelming share of generation and distribution is overseen by three vertically integrated public utilities whose remit is geographically distributed. NOSBiH operates and balances the grid. The wholesale market does not yet operate transparently and dispatch is not determined on purely economic terms.

Ageing coal power stations and a single nuclear power plant dominate Bulgarias energy mix, accounting for 42% and 38% of 2019 generation respectively. The operators of those plants, which are state-owned Bulgaria Energy Holdings for coal and Kozloduy for nuclear, hold a dominant position in the countrys power market. However, liberalization and unbundling reforms rolled out since 2010 have opened up the retail sector to competition. This has put pressure on retail prices and attracted international investors such as CEZ from Czechia or Energo-Pro. CEZ plans to divest its Bulgarian assets but sales have so far been blocked by anti-trust authorities. Bulgaria Energy Holdings remains the only entity that can sell electricity directly to customers at below-market prices and without going through the power exchange. The government is continuing to take slow steps toward the full liberalization of the power markets, with the support of the EU Commission and development banks.

An aging hydro (45-55%) and fossil-fuel (40%) generation fleet supplies the bulk of Croatias domestically produced electricity. Croatia relies on imports from neighboring countries to meet its electricity consumption. In 2018, Croatia covered some 34% of its electricity consumption with imports. The power market has gone through an unbundling reform to bring it in line with the EUs energy packages. The generation and retail markets are fully liberalized. The transmission system operator, whilst still being owned by the national utility, has been spun out as independent entity, similar to the set-up in France.

The electricity sector was liberalized in 2006 but remains fairly concentrated, with CEZ accounting for more than two thirds of generation. Both CEZ and CEPS (the transmission system operator) are likely to remain state-owned for the foreseeable future. CEZ owns and operates the two nuclear power plants, which account for around a third of generation. This share is due to expand over the coming decades due to strong government and public support, a wish to boost energy independence (away from reliance on Russian gas) and a need to replace lost capacity through phase-out of its aging coal fleet. Potential challenges will be deciding how to finance new reactors and mitigating anti-nuclear pressure from some of its EU neighbors. The generation mix is likely to remain diversified as the national strategy does not allow any one technology to provide more than 65% of generation.

Denmark shares a wholesale power market with Norway, Sweden and Finland, but has a separate and sovereign energy policy. The country is split into two power price zones. Wind power is the dominant source for electricity, accounting for 49% of generation in 2019. The country has been committed to build out wind capacity for decades and now aims to reach 100% renewable electricity by 2030, which will include launching two 2GW offshore wind 'islands'. Increasing renewables penetration has led to concerns over security of supply, particularly in east Denmark. There was a plan to implement a strategic reserve to combat this, but this was postponed when it became clear that the European Commission would reject it as it was likely to be in breach of state aid rules. More recent reviews conducted by the system operator from 2019-2020 suggest that there is no longer a need for a strategic reserve so the plans are shelved until 2030. Instead, the country has decided to put more focus on flexibility and interconnection capacity.

Nuclear remains the largest source of generation with a 35% share, with hydro at 19%. Finland is a part of Nord Pool and benefits from low-cost electricity imports from Sweden. It also imports cheap power from Russia and recently reduced tariffs on Russian electricity imports, which paves the way for increased imports. In 2019, Finland imported around 23% of its total electricity consumption. Low power prices have slowed down wind projects in neighboring Sweden, but Finnish projects have been protected by the above-market feed-in-premium. In addition, Finnish wholesale prices in 2019 were on average 15% higher than in Sweden. Finland has implemented a strategic reserve to guarantee security of supply with 611MW capacity for July 2020 through June 2022.

Frances power market is dominated by one of the worlds largest nuclear fleets  EDFs 56 reactors accounted for more than two thirds of generation in 2019. The presence of an amortized nuclear fleet with low running costs has reduced the impetus for renewables. French reactors produce enough power to sell large volumes abroad, although it is expected to increasingly rely on imports as the nuclear fleet shrinks. Already, winter peaks cannot be met without importing power from abroad. The government is poised to restructure EDF to increase the utilitys financing capacity, potentially separating its nuclear arm from more profitable divisions. Meanwhile, it will decide whether to embark of a new wave of reactor building by mid-2023  an unlikely prospect given the technologys high cost.

Despite commissioning vast volumes of renewables, Germany continues to host Europes largest fossil fuel fleet. Renewables additions are set to rise with ambitious targets and a long-term auction timetable stretching out to 2030. However, difficulties commissioning onshore wind farms means that offshore wind and solar will have to pick up the slack. Over 40GW of coal and 30GW of gas was online in 2019  a sizeable chunk of a 256GW power system. The electricity sector is fully unbundled and liberalized. Yet a handful of utilities such as RWE, Uniper and EnBW own a majority of generation assets. After remaining quiet over recent years, a handful of corporate deals indicates that the market for corporate power purchase agreements is heating up.

The Greek power system is still dominated by Public Power Corp (PPC), the former state monopoly that owns the countrys lignite and hydro assets. As part of Greeces bailout deal with its European creditors, PPC was to sell off 40% of its lignite capacity, but no buyers were found and in September 2019 the prime minister announced Greece would phase out all lignite production by 2028, with all but one plant to close by 2023. A flexibility mechanism to reward ramping capacity is under discussion, and at least two new combined-cycle gas turbine plants of around 800MW each are in the works to ensure security of supply as lignite  which made up almost a third of generation in 2018  leaves the system.

Nuclear plants generate one-half of Hungary's electricity, gas and coal combine to provide one-third. Renewables, mainly biomass and wind, deliver the rest. Hungary is highly dependent on energy imports, mainly from Russia  a trend that the EU wants to limit. As a result, the European Commission gave approval for two new nuclear reactors at the Paks site, with a total capacity of 1.2GW, potentially limiting the opportunity for renewables. Both generation and retail markets are highly concentrated. State-owned MVMs market share in generation grew from about 40% in 2010 to almost 60% in 2019, and Hungary has among the lowest number of electricity suppliers in the EU  only three, despite a population of almost 10 million.

Ireland may still rely on fossil fuels (in particular gas) for more than two thirds of its power generation. But intermittent renewable technologies have one of the biggest shares of the generation mix in Europe, thanks to an influx of onshore wind capacity in the last decade. Its reliance on gas imports is set to rise to 85% by 2025. Its power market was liberalized in 2005, although it remains dominated by the former monopoly (ESB) and its many subsidiaries.

Italian gas plants supplied 41% of electricity generated in 2019, followed by hydro at 18%, and wind and solar at a combined 20%. Despite gas plants making up the biggest generation share, their utilization rate in 2019 was a lowly 28%. As a result, many Italian gas plants struggle to make a profit and are at risk of closure. However, the most efficient ones run often and enjoy some of the biggest margins in Europe. The 2025 coal phase-out would reduce some of the overcapacity in the Italian market, although it is part of a non-binding energy plan. The recently approved capacity market has given marginal generators a boost. It held its first auction in 2019 and awarded 30GW of capacity contracts to existing gas generators and 5GW for new build.

In 2019, the share of renewable electricity reached 21% and some 62% of renewable electricity was generated by wind power plants. The share of gas in the generation mix increased slightly to 13% from 10% in 2018, but significantly decreased from 42% five years earlier. Lithuanias wind and biomass & waste sectors have expanded. The country has met its 2020 capacity targets of 500MW of wind capacity, 224MW of biofuels and 10MW of solar. Renewable electricity should account for 45% of consumption, according to Lithuanias 2030 target. Distributed solar is available to residents of apartment blocks through a remote purchasing scheme, made possible by way of the Solar Community online platform in March 2020. Plans for offshore wind are progressing in 2020, with a site in the Baltic Sea, supporting 700MW of capacity, having been selected. In 2018, the Baltic States and Poland signed an agreement to decouple their electricity systems from the Russian power grid, and to instead synchronize with the EU by 2025. This should help them to balance and integrate an increasing proportion of intermittent renewables.

Until Moldovas desired power auctions actually begin, the country will continue to obtain roughly three-quarters of its domestic power from the fossil-fueled Kuchurgan power plant. Power from Kuchurgan or imported from Ukraine constitutes more than 90% of Moldovas supply. Electricity supplied by Ukraines DTEK is sourced from thermal plants that burn coal and could include some power from wind and solar sources. Renewables generated in Moldova itself contribute a negligible amount to the countrys power supply. While distribution has been privatized, the rest of the power market is state-controlled and prices are regulated. There are plans to reform the system, which has six licensed power producers that operate in part under regulated tariffs.

With an emission intensity rating of 482.5MtCO2e/MWh in 2017, the domestic power fleet is Western Europes most polluting. The Dutch capacity mix remains dominated by fossil fuels, with gas accounting for 56.8% and coal 14.3% in 2017. This breakdown is due to change over forthcoming decades as the Netherlands implements its 2030 coal phase-out and moves away from burning gas. The country's ambitious auction program will ramp up the offshore wind capacity. The question will be how the government compensates coal plant owners (Nuon Vattenfall, Uniper, RWE and Engie) given that three of the power stations came online in 2015. Forthcoming compensation payments to Nuon for the accelerated closure of one of its coal plants as a result of the Urgenda case could set a precedent. Wholesale power prices in the Netherlands are close to the EU average, and have also declined gradually in recent years as more no-marginal-cost renewables have entered the generation mix. More broadly, the Netherlands' electricity market has been fully open to competition since 2004, but generation remains dominated by a handful of companies.

The electricity market in North Macedonia was fully liberalized in 2019. Beginning in 2019, as well, all electricity consumers have the right to choose from which supplier and at what terms they obtain their power. North Macedonia has regulated and unregulated energy markets and is in the process of establishing its day-ahead market and coupling this market with neighbor Bulgarias. The electricity transmission authority in North Macedonia, MEPSO, is still state-owned, but generation and retail have been privatized. Renewable energy generation sources are classified as preferential producers, and the market operator is obligated to purchase all electricity from preferential producers.

Hydroelectric power is the dominant source of generation, accounting for 95% of capacity and 95% of generation in 2019. Wind and gas assets accounted for 3% and 2%, respectively. Norway, which is not a part of the European Union, has agreed to implement the EUs third energy package and to join the blocs Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER). That allows the country to stay as an equal partner in the EUs energy markets, but does take away some of its sovereignty over energy policy. The move to join ACER happened because the Norwegian wholesale power market is shared with Denmark, Sweden and Finland. Norway is not a member of the EU, and would lose equal access to the European energy market if it did not join ACER. That could put the common electricity market at risk.

Poland's power sector is dominated by coal, which accounted for 75% of electricity generation in 2019. The share of coal is on a steady downward trajectory, from 87% in 2012, but the country is still one of Europe's main laggards in the transition away from coal power. Its priorities remain centered on energy independence and diversification of supply. Poland introduced a capacity market to address security-of-supply concerns and provide a revenue stream for coal plant modernization. Onshore wind accounted for 10% of Polands total generation in 2019, and is by far the largest source of renewable power  hydro and biomass account for less than 2% each.

Renewables enjoy a dominant share of capacity in Portugal, particularly onshore wind and hydro. Meanwhile, fossil fuels contribute just under half of generation. Onshore wind was the largest beneficiary of the feed-in tariff scheme, with capacity increasing tenfold between 2004 and 2014. However, the scheme's suspension ended growth. The government's support program for under-developed technologies has a maximum award of 5 million euros per developer  too small for offshore wind projects. However, the government is helping to provide a grid connection for a floating offshore wind platform. Electricity generation and retail are fragmented in Portugal. Energias de Portugal (EDP) holds the greatest market share in both segments, but a number of players with a 1% share or less are active.

Half of Romania's installed generating capacity is coal, gas, and nuclear. These three technologies account for approximately two-thirds of the annual electricity generation. In renewables, hydro dominates, followed by wind, solar and biomass, which collectively generate a third of the country's electricity. Romania has gradually shifted toward a liberalized energy sector. Consumers have been eligible to switch electricity suppliers since 2007, and price liberalization was finalized for non-household consumers in 2014 and household consumers in 2018. The distribution and retail divisions have transitioned to being predominantly privately owned. Key asset owners include CEZ, Energias de Portugal (EDP) and Enel. However, CEZ has announced that it will divest all its Romania assets. Enel, which in 2015 also considered exiting the Romanian market, has since announced it will instead sell off minority stakes in its Romanian subsidiaries.

At the end of 2019, Russia had an installed capacity of 248GW. Though generation, system operation, transmission and distribution are managed by separate entities, much of them are state owned. Fossil fuels account for around 60% of Russias power generation, and abundant oil and gas resources mean renewables are unlikely to meaningfully displace fossil fuels in the near future, in particular, natural gas generation. However, renewables are being used to improve domestic power supply to remote regions that are not connected to the grid. These regions traditionally relied on power generation from oil. So, while natural gas is likely to remain the dominant generation technology, generation from oil has fallen by more than two thirds since 2000.

In 2019, some 70% of Serbia's generation came from coal, while a quarter came from large hydro. Generation from renewable sources of powe, however, has been picking up in recent years. While in 2017, only 2% of generation came from clean energy, it was 5% two years later, in 2019. Serbia has struggled to meet the unbundling requirement under the EU's so-called third energy package. The state-owned TSO, Elektromrea Srbija (EMS), has gained its license to operate and transmit electricity on the transmission system. To satisfy concerns over independent operationsince the government also runs the state utility, Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS)  EPS and EMS are operated by different ministries. But generation, retail and distribution fall under the control of the state-owned utility EPS, meaning the EU Secretariat still deems Serbia non-compliant. Serbia's import and export balances are sensitive to the country's hydrology for hydro generation, the condition of its aging fossil fuel plants, and demand dynamics from its seven interconnected neighboring countries.

The installed capacity is fairly evenly distributed among nuclear, coal- and gas-fired generation, and renewables (80% of which is hydro). The largest producer is Slovenske Elektrarne (Enel), which generates over two-thirds of the country's electricity. In 2017, retirement of 1.61GW of large hydro and oil capacity caused a drop in generating capacity by 18%, which increases Slovakia's dependency on import. The government aims to reduce import dependence. However, its main tool to achieve that is through an 880MW extension of the Mochovce nuclear power plant  an extension that was started in 1985 but has been subject to delays. The government has also sought to improve power market integration, with short-term trading with the Czech Republic and Hungary starting in 2012, and the day-ahead market coupled with the Czech Republic, Hungary and Romania, opening in late 2014.

Slovenia's capacity mix is dominated by nuclear and hydro plants, which together provide nearly three-quarters of the electricity consumed. And, according to the government's long-term strategy (known as the 'Energy Concept'), the reliance on nuclear will continue with a 20-year life extension for its Krsko plant to 2043. In addition, growth in renewables is expected to continue, thanks to the support system and priority dispatch for these generators. Slovenia relies heavily on energy imports from its neighbors, having met 56% of its energy needs from domestic resources in 2018. The electricity market has been open to competition since 2007, with a variety of generators and retailers available to consumers. However, much of the market remains in the hands of state-owned players.

Spain's generating capacity has doubled since 2003 to reach 108GW in 2019, and is set to continue increasing in line with its renewables auctions. Today, more than half of the country's power generation is produced by nuclear and gas. But capacity additions over the last 10 years have been dominated by wind, hydro and solar - with renewables reaching 40% of generation in 2019. Spain's onshore wind market is more mature than solar, but BNEF forecasts indicate that more than half of new installed capacity in the country between 2020 and 2022 will be solar. Spain's regulation for balancing requirements is one of the most favorable to renewables in Europe. It has strict grid codes ensuring that generators meet technical standards and compensation (at 15% of wholesale prices) is available for any curtailment incurred in the spot market. In 2020, more than half of Spain's remaining coal capacity closed due to worsening economics and the unwillingness of generators to upgrade their power plants to meet emissions requirements.

Sweden has the highest share of zero-carbon energy in the EU, mainly thanks to its 16.2GW of installed hydropower, and has already achieved its 2020 renewable energy target of 49%. The government has an ambitious long-term goal of 100% renewable energy by 2040, so it will continue to add clean energy capacity while it has pushed the state-owned utility Vattenfall to abandon any activity in the coal sector. Sweden's parliament voted in 2020 against restarting the Ringhals 2 reactor, and Ringhals 1 is set to close at the end of 2020. This leaves six nuclear reactors with a combined 6.9GW of capacity that are set to operate until the end of their lifetimes. Sweden is divided into four areas with different power prices that reflect local supply and demand balances. Prices can vary significantly across areas due to grid congestion.

Hydro accounts for more than 60% of Switzerland's installed capacity, with nuclear accounting for the next biggest slice, followed by solar.  The shift away from nuclear, which makes up a third of total generation, will create a substantial gap in the mix, although the transition will not happen immediately. In 2017, voters rejected a scenario that would have had three of the country's five nuclear power plants close from 2017-2018. Instead, the Swiss Federal Nuclear Safety Inspectorate will determine how long the plants can operate safely and no new plants may be built.

Turkey has undertaken ambitious power-market reforms to privatize and liberalize the sector, and to exploit domestic energy resources. This has primarily meant an emphasis on lignite and hydro, as well as renewables. The government has dialed back its nuclear ambitions, but still plans one 4.8GW Russian-backed plant. Commissioning is unlikely before 2026. The historic dominance of coal generation is likely to continue in the short term, though gas has struggled as the economy slows down. In the 2019 generation mix, coal accounted for 37% and gas 19%. Renewables additions, mainly wind and solar but also geothermal and biomass, are all growing, but face an uncertain future due to a lack of clarity on the feed-in tariff and delayed auctions.

Nuclear plants supplied more than half the electricity generated in Ukraine in 2019  a proportion that has increased in recent years. Non-hydro renewables accounted for just over 3% of generation in 2019, and this share has continued to increase in 2020 as the renewables pipeline is built out. The upcoming power auctions appear likely to slow that growth rate, however, due to delays in implementation. The quota of capacity on offer could also limit new additions. The new power market structure will require further price liberalization to incentivize independent power producers to enter the market. Generation is only partially privatized, and DTEK is by far the largest single player.

The U.K. has two electricity markets: one for England, Wales and Scotland; and the Integrated Single Electricity Market (I-SEM) covering the whole island of Ireland. In Great Britain, the 'Big Six' (British Gas, EDF, Eon, RWE npower, Scottish Power and SSE) hold a majority share of the generation and retail segments of the market, but this picture is rapidly changing as new entrants arrive to compete. Security-of-supply concerns in the 2010s prompted the government to implement a capacity market. This guarantees a sufficient reserve margin, but is costly compared to reserves. It could also discourage decarbonization and lead to lock-in of existing generators. More than half of U.K. power generation is fueled by fossil fuels and nuclear, but this is rapidly changing. The country's carbon price floor has been effective in reducing coal generation, and the government plans to close all remaining coal-fired power stations by October 2024. By 2050, BNEF expects just over half of U.K. electricity to be generated by wind farms, and another third by PV, driven by declining renewables costs.

Algeria opened up generation to competition in 2002, but the sector has remained dominated by Sonelgaz. The state-owned utilitys dominance is ensured by its access to the countrys abundant gas reserves, whose cheap procurement has prevented the emergence of competitive independent power producers (IPP). The Sonelgaz group is the sole authorized retailer of power on the countrys three grids. However, consumers are free to procure their own electricity through self-generation or power purchase agreements (PPA). Increasingly cheap solar technology, the high cost of diesel generation and unreliable grid power have created a favorable environment for small-scale renewables.

In 2019, Angolas electricity prices changed for the first time since 2013. The increase of retail tariffs for electricity was already expected and was a consequence of the electricity sector reform started in 2014. Commercial prices almost doubled, from $12/MWh in 2018 to $23/MWh in 2019. Residential prices boosted 61%, reaching the high of $21/MWh in 2019. Extensive fossil-fuel subsidies significantly affect the price at which electricity is offered by the state generation company, reducing the potential incentive for consumers to install small-scale PV. ENDE cannot charge cost-reflective tariffs and is dependent on government subsidy. Higher rates are expected to increase the financial viability of the utility and potentially attract independent producers.

Benin relies on thermal generation and has a heavy dependence on neighboring countries. In March 2019, the 120MW Maria Gleta II Heavy Fuel Oil and Gas plant began operating, and the country still has virtually no renewable energy projects to date aside from a 500-kilowatt hydro project. The planned PV projects should help Benin to reduce its energy dependence by improving local energy capacity. Finally, the country also plans additional electricity transmission interconnections within the regional market. So far, the grid has mostly served the south of the country, whereas the northern part of Benin is relatively isolated and has limited access to cost-efficient sources of energy.

Coal dominates Botswanas power sector, accounting for 82% of the current installed capacity. By contrast, solar PV accounts for just 0.1%, although this is expected to change with the development of a 100MW solar project that was reissued in May 2019. Botswana has gradually weaned itself off dependency on imports from the SAAP, and it now imports only 23% of the distributed power nationally. There is only one operational 1.3MW solar plant in the country, and renewables do not benefit from purchase obligation as BPC buys all the power available regardless of sector. Currently, the Botswana Power Corporation is the sole provider of generation, transmission, distribution and retail services. However, BPC is looking to transform itself into a transmission and distribution utility, and move away from being a fully integrated utility. Independent power producers (IPP) have been allowed to enter the market since 2007 but have only began to expand into the generation market in the last three years with the signing of two PPAs for the Morupule B Coal plant and a 1MW solar plant in 2017.

Power generation in Burkina Faso is dominated by thermal plants that run on expensive imported fuel. Sonabel has tried to keep up with rising demand by ramping up generation and by importing electricity. The power sector is partially liberalized and divided into two segments, of which the first covers urban areas, where Sonabel has a de facto monopoly, despite generation and distribution being open to private investment. The second segment covers rural areas, where local cooperatives (COOPELs) are responsible and are overseen by the rural electrification agency ABER. In this segment, the private sector may operate generation and off-grid distribution projects. The offtaker can be commercial, as in the case of the Essakane PV plant.

Renewable energy installed capacity is dominated by small hydro power plants (55%), followed by natural gas (34%) solar PV (6%) and biomass (5%). The capital Bujumbura accounts for 95% of electricity consumed. Besides its national generation, Burundi also imports electricity from neighboring countries Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Rwanda, through a cross-border hydropower complex. The power sector continues to be dominated by Regideso, which has a monopoly on electricity transmission, distribution and supply. Transmission, distribution and generation infrastructure is old and needs further modernization and investment.

Large hydro dominates the capacity mix, followed by fossil fuels. Cameroon was one of the first countries in Africa to open its electricity sector to private-sector participation, and in 2001, AES became majority shareholder of the utility (then called Sonel). A new reform phase began in 2011 with the unbundling of generation, transmission and distribution. Sonel was acquired by Actis in 2014, and rebranded as Eneo. A 2015 decree split the transmission and system operation components to create the state-owned Sonatrel, which decides on dispatch and is a single buyer for grid-connected generation. Eneo dominates generation, but two IPPs operate the two main thermal plants. The legal framework for electricity needs significant review, which has now begun following the October 2018 elections.

Most electricity generation comes from dated small hydro systems, the oldest of which has been operating since the mid-1950s. These systems are poorly maintained and break down often. The national grid only extends to the capital Bangui. There are supplementary diesel-powered generation units, but these are small and only account for a fraction of total power generation. There is an interconnection with the Democratic Republic of Congo, but this is inactive due to degradation. State-owned utility Enerca dominates the generation, distribution and retail of electricity, despite all three segments being liberalized for competition. So far, however, no independent power producers have emerged, likely due to the desperate security situation in the country. There are plans to introduce further laws to facilitate competition, but none have yet been made public.

Chads current generation fleet is exclusively powered by fossil fuels. Generation is open to private investment, with the 2019 energy law also opening up distribution. Transmission remains the state utility SNEs prerogative, yet it may delegate management to private companies should it so wish. SNE remains the countrys offtaker, purchasing electricity from a 20MW thermal plant owned and operated by VPower, as well as the NRC 20MW thermal plant. Vergnets aforementioned wind plant does not seem to be generating power so far. A further IPP, Aggreko, entered the market in mid-2019 with a 24MW heavy fuel oil plant. A law setting out more detailed regulations for IPPs, which clarifies the procedures and penalties, remains stuck in the National Assembly.

Thermal power constitutes just over half of installed capacity in Congo, primarily provided by a 300MW gas plant in Pointe Noire owned by Italian developer Eni and the Congolese state. Large hydro also accounts for a sizeable slice of generation through the Imboulou (120MW) and Moukoukoulou (74MW) dams. No non-hydro renewables capacity has been installed to date, with new projects in the pipeline exclusively comprising large hydro projects or the expansion of the Pointe Noire gas plant. The four segments of the power sector are dominated by private utility E2C (Energie Electrique du Congo), which was a public enterprise operating by the name of Societe Nationale d'Electricite until June 2018. Power generation was opened up to private power producers in 2003, but regulations concerning private generation still remain unclear, with the only semi-independent power producer to date being Enis gas plant.

There has been much discussion about constructing Inga III. The government selected two consortia for the task: one including Spains Actividades de Construccion Servicios and AEE Power, and the other led by Three Gorges Corporation. In 2017 the government requested that the two consortia merge their proposals. They did so, and have since proposed building a much bigger version of Inga III, capable of generating 11,000MW, for $13.9 billion. It remains to be seen if this project will be developed. As yet, there are no utility-scale wind and solar projects, although there is some evidence this could change: Nuru deployed Congo's first solar-based mini-grid in 2017 and is currently constructing a 1.3MW solar hybrid site in Goma, the largest off-grid mini-grid in sub-Saharan Africa. Power generation still largely rests in the hands of state-controlled utility SNEL.

Cte dIvoires power market is only open to private participation for generation. CIE has a government concession to run the state-owned generation assets and the transmission and distribution assets until 2020. The CIE also has single buyer status, which makes bilateral electricity contracts and independent mini-grids illegal, and forces independent power producers to sell electricity back to it. Almost 60% of the 2,229MW of installed capacity is provided by independent gas power plants, with the remainder from hydro. The government has identified 30 sites with a total hydro capacity of 1,684MW to be developed in the coming years. Potential increases in capacity could come from around 100MW of solar projects, agreed in 2018 and 2019, and a 700MW coal power plant to be commissioned by 2024.

Egypts power mix is dominated by the addition of 14.4GW of Siemens combined-cycle gas turbines, invested in after a power crisis in late 2014. Together, these additions have provided a substantial reserve margin. Despite recent additions, renewables made up only 1% of the power fleet in 2019, and the oversupply could crimp growth in the short term. What renewables have been commissioned are contracted on a take-or-pay basis, guaranteeing tariff payments regardless of demand. Despite the growing role of independent power producers, state utility and its subsidiaries own and operate some 80% of installed capacity. Moreover, private-to-private power deals can be signed, but a robust framework governing such contracts has yet to be finalized.

To date, the vast majority of installed capacity in Eritrea runs on imported fossil fuels. State-utility EEC dominates all segments of the power market and there is little transparency on the regulatory framework governing the energy sector in the country. A handful of independent power producers are active, with little transparency on their arrangements with EEC. Eritrea has no interconnection with its neighbors, although this could change in coming years, due to its improving relations with Ethiopia.

Ethiopia Electric Power (EEP) currently owns all generation and transmission in the country and Ethiopia Electric Utility (EEU) is responsible for distribution. The roll-out of a public-private partnerships law will allow independent power producers to negotiate PPAs directly with EEP. Along with plans to tender out renewable generation, such as the Scaling Solar Initiative, these policies will go a long way in diversifying Ethiopias power mix. Nearly 90% of generation capacity in Ethiopia is hydro, and the country has suffered from load shedding due to drought. A diversified power mix will be essential in ensuring reliability for the countrys growing commercial and industrial sector: 13 industrial parks are under development in Ethiopia and are expected to grow power demand by 1.5-2GW.

The generation sector has several independent power producers operating plants together with state-owned companies such as Volta River Authority (VRA). State-owned Ghana Grid Co. (Gridco) is the sole company that owns and operates the transmission system. Distribution is carried out by the Electricity Company of Ghana (ECG), the Northern Electricity Distribution Co. (Nedco) and Enclave Power Co. In 2019, some 68% of generation was sourced from oil and gas, and 30% was from hydro. The small remaining proportion came from two utility-scale PV plants, and there is little prospect of new projects in the near future due to the oversupply in generation. The market for commercial offtake is developing, however, with a couple of recent PPAs signed, such as one for the 225MW Ayitepa wind farm that is being developed by Lekela.

Around two-thirds of generating capacity is derived from small and large hydropower, with the completion of the aforementioned Kalta project in 2015 effectively quadrupling the countrys installed large hydro capacity. Hydropower capacity is set to scale up with a series of dams in the pipeline, including the 450MW Souapiti project. The remainder of Guineas electricity fleet is oil- and diesel-fired. There are plans to develop offshore gas fields, but reserves remain unproven. Efforts to liberalize the power market are driven by the prospect of trading competitively within the West African Power Pool and the first two of four planned interconnection lines should be completed by 2021. To date, generation is the only segment of the power market open to private players, with state utility EDG generating 90% of all electricity.

The Ministry of Electricity oversees all segments of the power sector via distinct entities. Over half of Iraqi power capacity is gas, with oil plants making up around a third of capacity. Despite over 2GW of large hydro capacity, just over half is available to generate due to damages and aging infrastructure. Electricity and gas imports from Iran help meet demand. Due to age, lack of maintenance and terrorist attacks, transmission and especially distribution are severely dilapidated, causing around three-quarters of generated electricity to be lost.

Solar accounts for almost all (96%) of Israel's current renewables capacity. State-owned Israeli Electric Corp. owns all transmission, distribution, retail, and 79% of generation. The government is promoting competition in the power sector, and it has already reached its goal of increasing the share of private power production to 20% by 2020, up from 4% in 2002. A structural reform to the power market was approved in 2018, with plans to liberalize the market. Israel's grid is not connected to those of neighboring countries for political reasons, though in January 2017, it began exporting small volumes of gas to Jordan and a $10 billion deal signed in September 2016 will see exports ramp up from 2019.

The share of renewables in power increased rapidly from less than 1% in 2014 to around 10% in 2018. It is expected to reach over 20% by the end of 2020.  Jordans National Energy Strategy calls for the power mix to include 31% of renewables by 2030. To reach this, Jordan wants to increase its renewable energy capacity to 3,200 MW by 2030, up from 1,559MW at the end of 2019. Capacity additions will slow down in the coming years as the government has suspended auctions until state-owned Nepco completes a new energy-sector development plan. Distinct bodies exist in the sector for production, transmission and distribution. There are separate companies for generation and distribution, while transmission is the responsibility of Nepco. There is no wholesale generation market, and Nepco purchases all generated electricity. Nepco has a template wind and solar PPA that currently exposes them to energy compensation. Jordanian power prices are not market-driven as generators cannot sell directly to the distributors and the government subsidizes tariffs.

The liberalization of the generation market has seen more than 10 independent power producers cut into KenGens market share. The government has also mandated Ketraco to compete with Kenya Power on transmission. In March 2019, the president signed Energy Bill 2017, which liberalized the electricity retail market on paper. But the market has been so far monopolized by Kenya Power in practice and it would take another year or more to set up detailed regulations. Large hydro and geothermal are the two main sources of Kenyas generation mix. The share of non-large hydro renewables generation reached 60% in 2019 from 52.3% in 2018.

Fossil fuels account for the vast majority of Kuwaits power generating capacity. The country has increased the share taken by gas-fired power plants in the past years, and will continue to do so in the future. Despite the commissioning on PV, solar thermal and onshore wind projects in recent years, renewable energy still accounts for less than 1% of total capacity. All segments of the power sector remain under the governance of the Ministry of Electricity and Water.

EDL has a monopoly on transmission and distribution as well as retail of electricity. Any reforms to EDL or the power market are unlikely in the current political situation. Diesel and heavy-fuel generation dominate Lebanons power mix in the form of ageing plants, leased power ships, or illegal private generators. The country imports some electricity from the Syrian interconnector. The law authorizing IPPs is still pending implementation; however, an exceptional decree granting the executive temporary powers to license new projects, which was introduced in 2014 and extended for three years in April 2019, has made the current pipeline of projects possible.

Lesotho's current installed capacity features 76MW of hydro. In 2018, Lesotho imported 30% of its power from neighboring South Africa. While its domestic fleet is composed entirely of hydro, South Africa's grid is composed of 90% coal power. Between its domestic production and imports, Lesotho's average carbon intensity is about 0.218 CO2 kg/KWh.
