Expansion of its domestic fleet with renewable energy will reduce import volumes and lower the carbon footprint of the power sector. The country has a strong financial incentive to do so, as imported electricity costs 10 times as much as domestically produced power.

LEC is a state-owned monopoly responsible for generation, transmission, distribution, retail and system operation in Liberia. The utility owns and operates a small fleet of mostly hydroelectric generators, including the 88MW Mount Coffee Hydropower Plant, which was returned to service in December 2016 after being offline for 26 years through civil turmoil and the ebola outbreak. LEC also procures power from independent producers  mostly embedded diesel generators. The LEC grid is concentrated around Monrovia and expansion of the grid to more rural areas is currently under way. Liberia receives 8MW of power from neighboring Cote dIvoire and will receive an additional 27MW once the West Africa Power Pool is complete.

More than three-quarters of Madagascars installed capacity is powered by fossil fuels, with the remainder accounted for by small hydro and solar, at 2% of installed capacity. Renewable energy additions have stagnated in the past few years, compared to the growth rate of new thermal capacity. For more than a decade, the generation sector has been opened up to independent power producers and there is a clear intention to attract more private and international investment to the industry. Independent companies can also sell power through direct sales or within rural electrification concessions, although experience in this segment remains limited. The typical PPA guarantees a volume and number of run hours to the generator for up to 20 years.

Essentially 100% of Malawi's electricity generation comes from hydropower plants situated on the Shire River. In recent years, low water levels and debris in the river have significantly reduced electricity output and caused severe load shedding. Malawi has no significant interconnection to neighboring countries. In 2016, the generation market was opened to participation by IPPs. Since then, PPAs have been signed for some 200 MW of new renewable generation. However, nothing has been built yet. With no IPP assets yet operational, Malawi's central utility ESCOM owns all generation, transmission, and distribution assets. MERA, the central regulatory agency, is the single offtaker.

Just under half of Malis power generation runs on fossil fuels and the remainder is supplied by hydropower. All segments of the power market have been liberalized since 2000, yet EDM dominates generation, transmission, distribution and retail. In rural areas, authorized mini-grid operators can sell power. Most of this capacity is dominated by fossil fuels, although there are an increasing number of hybrid projects. Tendering processes are yet to be standardized, yet the first clean energy projects have been awarded successfully. In 2015, the government issued two PV tenders for the development of a 25MW project in Koutiala and a 50MW in Sikasso. In August 2019, the rural electrification agency announced a tender for two solar PV plants totaling 1.3MW, in addition to a 1.5MW energy storage system.

Thermal plants account for the majority of Mauritanias installed capacity. Since 2013, however, clean energy capacity has steadily increased, with a handful of solar PV and wind plants in the pipeline. The power sector is not yet liberalized, with all segments remaining under Somelec control. In rural areas, operators with a concession may participate in power generation, distribution and retail. Solar PV-diesel hybrid projects are increasing in popularity, with a number of 2-6MW projects having been brought online, most recently at Kiffa and Nma. The expansion of renewable energy capacity and the discovery of offshore gas have made the government eager to begin selling energy to its neighbors.

Coal is the largest sector in Moroccos power mix, accounting for 40% of capacity and more than 67% of generation as of 2019. The coal sector has added more than 2.4GW of capacity since 2011, with 1.3GW added in 2018. In the context of total capacity growth of 35%, renewables capacity has remained constant at around 34% for the last five years. Wind and solar capacity has more than tripled from 5% to 18% since 2011, and additions of a further 2GW of renewable capacity in the coming years will push this to the 2020 target of 42%. Recent years have been poor for hydroelectric generation, and total renewables generation has been flat at around 16% but grew to 20% in 2019. This has hidden an underlying growth in solar and wind generation from only 3% in 2010 to 16% in 2019. The Moroccan state utility, ONEE, still holds a monopoly over the transmission network and is involved in all sales of electricity in Morocco. ONEE also accounts for around a third of total generation, and more than half of the distribution and retail sectors of the power market.

Mozambiques power market is structured around Electricidade de Moambique (EDM), a state-owned and vertically integrated utility responsible for the transmission, distribution and sale of electricity. All power consumers in Mozambique must buy electricity from EDM, which oversees 20% of the countrys generating capacity and purchases power from IPPs and the 2.1GW Cahora Bassa Hydro (HCB) facility. The latter is majority owned by the Mozambican state (92.5%). Some 90% of the plants generation is exported, mostly to South Africa. Cahora Bassas vast size means that hydroelectric generation dominates Mozambiques power sector, representing 70% of the capacity mix in 2019. A new draft electricity law is expected to overhaul the sector, streamlining the legal framework and clarifying licensing for generation, transmission and distribution. A new regulator, Arene, was stood up in 2017 but is not yet fully operational and will require support to become a strong and independent regulatory body.

In 2015, Namibia introduced its feed-in tariff program (Refit), which opened up its previously vertically integrated power sector to privately owned renewables projects. Under Refit, Nampower (Namibias state-owned utility) has signed contracts for 70MW of solar capacity between 14 counterparties. As of 2020, 45MW of the 70MW contracted have been commissioned. Namibias power sector regulator has suggested that it would stop awarding Refit contracts, and instead switch to tenders to procure additional capacity. Two renewable projects totaling 41MW have been awarded so far through tenders. Five unsolicited independent power producers (IPPs) have signed PPAs with Nampower. In its 2019-2023 business plan, Nampower pledged to spend an additional $338 million to add 220MW of renewable power to the grid, and another 70MW that will be procured from IPPs. This would represent a 50% increase in Namibias installed capacity.

Nigers power demand is predominantly met through energy imports from Nigeria, while the market is dominated by state utility Nigelec. The Electricity Act of 2016 opened up power generation to the private sector, with IPPs also being able to enter transmission and distribution if granted a concession. The only independent producer to date is Sonichar, which supplies the northern zone of Niger through a 32MW coal-fired power plant. Several solar projects are either under construction or remain in the pipeline, and investment in non-renewable generation is set to continue. After repeated delays, the 130MW hydroelectric Kandadji dam began construction in early 2019, with the 600MW Sakaldamna coal plant facing similar uncertainties.

Nigeria has no non-hydro renewable energy installed on-grid. Of the 13.5GW total capacity, 84.6% is accounted for by natural gas, 14.5% large hydro, 0.7% off-grid small hydro and 0.2% off-grid distributed PV. Only 7.5GW of the installed capacity is actually available, of which Nigeria generates an annual average of around 3.5 to 4.5GW of electricity. Generation is fully privatized, transmission is government-owned, and distribution is private but with only 11 regional players. Nigeria aims to create an enabling environment for increasing grid capacity. As of April 2018, distributors must provide metered billing as opposed to the estimated billing system previously in place, in accordance with new Meter Asset Provider (MAP) regulation. The regulation states that a minimum of 30% of contracted meters must come from local manufacturers. As a results, President Buhari imposed a 35% import levy on Fully Built Unit meters. This has been waived as of August 2020 since it makes it difficult for the MAP to be carried out effectively due to lack of local manufacturers.

Natural gas is the primary resource for power generation in Oman, accounting for over 97% of power output in 2019. The power mix will change dramatically in the next decade. Omans strategic plan for energy and economics aims for renewable energy sources to account for 30% of power generation. The countrys electricity and water procurement company (OPWP) aims to diversify fuels by introducing 3,050MW of renewable-energy projects by 2025 and 3,000MW of coal-power capacity by 2030. While little planned capacity has been installed, the implementation of the rest should move more quickly as Oman has finished financing a utility-scale solar PV project and initiated an auction for another two. Oman has passed laws to push for the privatization of power sector. The country has become the first in the region to privatize its transmission utility, Oman Electricity Transmission Company (OETC), by selling a 49% of stake to Chinese transmission and distribution operator State Grid Corp. of China (SGCC) in 2019. Oman is a part of the Gulf Cooperation Council's (GCC) grid interconnection system, which allows for electricity transfers between the six connected countries (Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, the UAE and Oman). A 0.22 MW (220 kV) interconnection between the Oman (MIS) and UAE (Abu Dhabi) power systems has been commercially operational since 2012. While not used consistently, the link has provided emergency reserves on a number of occasions, preventing power failures in the MIS.

Installed generating capacity in Palestine is concentrated in one large-scale diesel-fired plant in the Gaza Strip, and some small-scale solar projects. The Gaza Power Plant has not been operational for long periods due to fuel shortages, although fuel supplied by Qatar began powering the plant from October 2018. The country still relies heavily on electricity imports, mostly from Israel and also from Egypt and Jordan. There are plans to add more domestic generation capacity, including a 455MW CCGT plant. Renewables uptake is also meant to reduce reliance on imports.

Natural gas accounts for over 99% of Qatars power generation. The installed generation capacity continues to increase as load grows at 6.5% per year. Renewables  primarily solar projects  are set to replace some generation to save gas from being burned for power, as exporting the gas as LNG has more value. Only power generation is liberalized in Qatar, and only Strategic National Investors can participate. Transmission and distribution are completely controlled by the national utility Kahramaa, which does not own generation assets.

Rwandas power mix is based heavily on hydro, at just under 47% as of December 2019, but other technologies, such as solar, natural gas and diesel, are also represented. Since 2010, the country saw installed capacity grow 180%, reaching 217MW in 2019. State-owned Energy Development Corp. has been the most prominent developer, but there are multiple private players involved in Rwandas generation sector. The country has an oversupply of on-grid generation, as well as a backlog of contracted projects. As a result, new developers will not be able to secure permitting until the roughly 200MW of generation projects with existing contracts are commissioned. The country is instead focusing near-term investment into transmission and distribution, both of which are fully controlled by REG.

Gas generation plays an important role in the countrys east, while western regions rely on burning oil for power. Plans exist to convert western oil plants to gas, although progress in this area is lagging. Renewables additions have increased substantially in recent years from a low base  capacity awarded through Rounds 2 and 3 of the REPDO auction program suggest that this will continue. However, investors could be deterred by a lack of visibility on future procurement schemes. The countrys partially unbundled power sector remains dominated by the state utility, and private-to-private power purchase agreements are not yet explicitly allowed. Contracts signed with renewables developers are take-or-pay, guaranteeing that power be purchased regardless of demand.

Power prices in Senegal have not changed a great deal over past years but are on a downward trajectory as the government tries to reduce rates. The trend should continue as new renewables projects and domestic gas discoveries drive down production costs, which are higher than elsewhere in the region due to a reliance on costly diesel generation. Early 2019 saw the beginning of a long-awaited harmonization program, through which the private holders of electrification concessions will be compensated so that they can reduce retail rates charged to rural customers, which are higher than those levied by Senelec.

In Sierra Leones power market, only generation is open to private participation. Grid-connected independent power producers, or IPPs, must sell their electricity to EDSA, the state-owned main utility. However, the regulatory commission can provide retail licenses to other suppliers in areas where the grid is not available. Sierra Leones grid system is composed of several isolated distribution grids, of which Bumbuna-Freetown and Bo-Kenema are the main ones. Grid-connected generation capacity is around 30% hydro and 70% oil-fired power plants, plus one 15MW biomass plant. There are some hydro and other renewables projects in the pipeline, as well as oil projects. However, the current grid status is preventing the allocation of additional capacity.

Much of the population of Somalia relies on traditional biomass for its basic energy needs due to an unreliable power supply. Operating electricity suppliers mostly run diesel generators, although PV systems are starting to penetrate the market, mainly in Somaliland. The initial investment required for a diesel generator is still lower in some cases than a PV system, so adding PV to an existing diesel system is proving popular among small IPPs. Many electricity service providers operating in Somaliland have plans to add renewables to their existing diesel infrastructure.

Eskom, the state-owned utility, dominates South Africas power sector. Independent generators have started to capture generation market share, mostly renewables, and municipalities are responsible for retail of electricity in some areas - although the customer still has no choice of supplier. The country regularly exports electricity to its neighbors through the Southern African Power Pool. However, meeting peak demand is a major challenge as the supply crisis worsens. South Africa has seen regular short-term load shedding (scheduled power cuts) return over 2019 and 2020 at rates worse than the previous height of load shedding in 2014-2015. Coal dominates South Africa's electricity mix, accounting for 73% of capacity in 2018. This share is likely to be maintained once the Medupi and Kusile coal plants (at 4.8GW each) come online with the government's IPP program.

Fossil fuels dominate on-grid energy generation in South Sudan, with power plants consisting of a mix of oil or diesel-fueled facilities, with the exception of one small hydro facility in the capital, Juba. As much as 99% of the population is off-grid and relies on diesel generators for power. In terms of renewable energy, 15MW of distributed off-grid solar PV is progressively coming online, developed by Depo Energy. In 2019, there were some very small-scale solar-plus-storage projects from developers such as Equator Energy, Solar23 or Aptech Africa that came online. To support power market development, there are plans to create new transmission lines to Ethiopia, Sudan and Uganda.

The structure of Sudans power sector has evolved in recent years. Following the unbundling of the sector at the turn of the millennium, 2016 saw the creation of the Sudanese Electricity Holding Co. This has an effective monopoly on procurement, with the holding company overseeing two generation utilities  the Sudanese Thermal Power Generating company and its hydro-focused counterpart  as well as two companies whose respective remits cover distribution and transmission. These companies remain state-owned, despite the 2001 Electricity Law to open up private participation in the energy sector. There are no real independent power producers to date, although there is one company that owns and operates thermal plants in a handful of regional capitals, although the fuel is supplied through the Sudanese Electricity Holding Co. free of charge. In terms of technology, the country is still predominantly dependent on oil- and hydro-based power generation, with hydropower accounting for more than half of installed capacity.

On-grid, Tanzania has a diverse power generation portfolio, consisting of thermal generation like natural gas (880MW) and diesel (271MW), large hydro (532MW), small hydro (42MW) and biomass (11MW). Despite promising tenders announced in 2018 for solar and wind, the only utility-scale project under construction to date is a small 2.4MW wind farm. A number of independent power producers sell power to TANESCO under power purchase agreements, but TANESCO still owns over 50% of the countrys generation. The countrys Ministry of Energy has plans to establish a competitive wholesale and retail electricity market in 2025, but this remains little more than ambition at this stage.

Togos generation is mainly thermal. The country relies on a 100MW Contour Global fossil fuel power plant and a 65MW large-hydro plant, and it imports significant gas generation from Ghana and Nigeria. The country aims to reach electricity independence and 100% electrification by 2030. There has been no large-scale renewable project fully developed in Togo to date, although the national electrification and energy independence plan relies heavily on renewable energy build. Under the new renewable energy sector law, renewables benefit from priority dispatch and purchase obligation from the offtaker. Although the power sector is officially open to all players, the CEB (Communaut Electrique du Bnin) still owns most generation capacity in the country, as well as transmission assets. The CEET (Compagnie Energie Electrique du Togo) is responsible for retail.

Over 94% of Tunisias 5.5GW of installed capacity and more than 95% of the power produced in 2018 came from gas-fired plants. As of end-2019, only 240MW of wind plants, and around 60MW of small-scale PV were commissioned. However, the power mix is due to become more diversified over the next few years as auctions are due to increase the clean-energy capacity. The state-owned utility Tunisia Company of Electricity and Gas (STEG) controls over 80% of power generation and has a monopoly over transmission and distribution of electricity and natural gas. IPPs are allowed in the market under the concession and authorization programs and can rely on a 20-year standardized PPA with STEG. According to law 2015-12 that regulates renewable-energy generation, STEG is mandated to buy all power produced by clean energy plants.

Uganda began unbundling its power market at the turn of the century, splitting up the utilitys generation, distribution and transmission arms. To date, more than ten different independent power producers (IPPs) have commissioned projects on the grid. They compete alongside the state developer, Uganda Electricity Generation Company Limited (UEGCL). The country's transmission remains under state monopoly, with the Uganda Electricity Transmission Company Limited (UETCL) being the sole operator of the system. Distribution is liberalized, with Uganda Electricity Distribution Company Limited (UEDCL) licensing eight different electricity distribution companies; however, Umeme Limited controls almost all of the retail electricity sales on the grid via a concession with UEDCL. Concessions are granted to other distributors in areas of the country outside of Umemes concession as sole providers of electricity in these regions. Customers cannot choose from whom to purchase electricity. The Electricity Regulatory Authority (ERA) oversees all three segments of the power sector.

The UAEs grid is fragmented among the various emirates, but gas remains the dominant form of power generation across the board. Representing 6% of installed capacity in 2019, renewables penetration is only just starting to ramp up. In the absence of a wholesale market, developers sell their power through take-or-pay contracts  their output is purchased regardless of demand. Independent power producers account for the majority of commissioned capacity, although the publicly owned utilities participate retain a major equity share in all projects. For its part, Abu Dhabis state utility  which is also active in the northern emirates  has been unbundled, although Dubais remains vertically integrated. Both retain single-buyer status, while generation is the only sector open to private participation.

Zambia's power market is dominated by large hydro assets and Zesco, a vertically integrated utility owned by the Zambian government. Zesco generates, transmits and delivers the majority of the country's electricity. However, the sector is diversifying away from large hydro and Zescos monopoly over generation, with IPPs capturing the majority of market share in other generation technologies. The share of large hydro in installed capacity fell from 92% in 2010, to 78% by 2018 and 72% by 2019, as IPPs commissioned new PV and fossil fuel plants. There is a pipeline for new hydro projects including the 2,400MW Batoka Gorge Dam power project, and several existing large hydro facilities are also being upgraded by Zesco. A large and untapped potential remains for small-scale hydropower, especially for rural electrification, which may change pending the success of the second GETFiT round. Zambia is largely a power-exporting nation, except for in years of low rainfall and low hydro generation when it becomes a net importer.

State-owned ZESA is the holding company for both the national generation utility (ZPC) and the T&D utility (ZETDC). Hydro accounts for about half of Zimbabwe's overall power generation, supplied by the Kariba plant on the Zambezi river. Water levels on the river have been low over the past few years, which has contributed greatly to the country's severe load-shedding. The next largest source of generation is coal, which has also been unreliable due to fuel shortages and cost fluctuations. The market for power generation has been liberalized and is open to IPPs, of which there are several, though electricity supply is dominated by ZESA. Regulator ZERA has issued 30 IPP agreements in the past five years and most are for renewable energy (solar). However, only 14 are operational as of March 2020. Participation by the private sector is still low due to capital constraints. ZESA faces major challenges including validating infrastructure, insufficient foreign currency, power theft, and non-payment of bills.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Average wholesale power prices in Canada are lower than those in the U.S., thanks in large part to the country's cheap and bountiful hydropower. The average annual wholesale price of power in Canada has remained below USD 20/MWh for the past five years. Retail pricing in Canada is dynamic; customers can choose from time-of-use (TOU) or tiered pricing schemes which assign a higher price of power when demand is highest. Dynamic pricing incentivizes retail customers to consume power when it is most efficient for the system to provide that power.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Across the U.S., annual wholesale power prices spanned $20/MWh-$40/MWh in 2019, with the most expensive power in markets with particularly tight supply-demand dynamics: the Northwest (which relies on hydropower) and Texas (which is a high-renewables, energy-only market). These 2019 prices generally dropped from those in 2018 as natural gas prices fell and renewable generation ramped up. Retail prices also vary across markets with New York, New England and California maintaining retail rates upward of $160/MWh and all other regions spanning $80-110/MWh. Total energy spending accounted for under 4% of total U.S. personal consumption expenditures in 2019. The share of consumer spending that goes to energy continues to decrease with the rise of renewables and energy efficiency measures. Residential small-scale solar growth has been stagnant in the U.S. for the past few years with 11 notable market exits and bankruptcies since 2016. California remains the largest residential solar market in the U.S. As of the end of 2019, net metering at the full retail rate was available in 38 states and Washington, D.C.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices spiked under the Macri administration as customer subsidies were cut. Since 2015, industrial prices have soared by 1,082%, while residential and commercial rates jumped by 1,074% and 973% respectively, through 2019. Market administrator CAMMESA regulates tariffs and is also the offtaker for the RenovAr auctions. Auction bids associated with large-scale projects dropped in each round, averaging $59.6/MWh in the first, $54/MWh in the second, and $42.4/MWh in the last round.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Bolivia's electricity prices are set by the government and, as Bolivia is a natural gas producer, dependent on heavily subsidized gas-powered generation. However, only 60.8% of the 9.5TWh generated in 2019 came from gas plants, compared to 72% in 2017 and 68% from 2018. The share of hydro generation increased from 28% to 34% and the share of solar generation increased from 0.1% in 2017 to 1.9% in 2019. Electricity prices continue to rise, although rates remain low compared to most countries in Latin America. In 2019, the average commercial electricity price was $167.12/MWh, while industrial and residential electricity prices were respectively $97.29/MWh and $119.96/MWh. Rates on average increased 1% from 2018 prices.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail electricity prices jumped an average of 95% between 2010 and 2019 in local currency terms for commercial, industrial and residential consumers. This was mainly due to inflation and decreased hydropower generation. In 2019, Brazils retail tariffs were among the highest in Latin America, at $194/MWh for commercial, $165/MWh for industrial and $195/MWh for residential. Commercial and industrial (C&I) customers with power demand greater than 500kW are eligible to purchase electricity from Brazils deregulated wholesale market. Consumers with demand between 500kW and 2MW (special consumers) choosing this option must purchase wholesale power generated from incentivized renewable sources, including wind, small hydro, biomass and solar. The maximum threshold for special consumers will fall from 2MW to 1.5MW in January 2020 and decline by 0.5MW every January until 2023.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: In Chile, spot prices are determined by the node of delivery, which takes into account the marginal operating costs of plants, as well as demand at that specific location. Spot prices have shown high volatility in recent years during daytime hours. In 2018, spot prices slipped to zero at times during midday, while shooting back to $60/MWh at night. The same pattern had been observed in previous years, but the situation has improved with the interconnection of the countrys main power subsystems, the SIC (Sistema Interconectado Central) and SING (Sistema Interconectado del Norte Grande). In 2019, after the commissioning of an important transmission line (Cardones-Polpaico) spot prices across the main nodes converged and decreased considerably. The government applied a price stabilization mechanism to retail tariffs in 2019 in response to social unrest that erupted in the country.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Colombia is highly dependent on hydroelectric energy, which has supplied on average 70% of generation annually since 2010. Prices are subject to upward pressure from extreme weather, as seen in 2015-16 when a pronounced El Nino effect was observed.  Serious delays in commissioning of the hydro megaproject Ituango, previously expected online in December 2018, combined with drought more recently produced a jump in electricity prices. Commercial electricity tariffs rose 40% over 2018-19, while residential tariffs climbed 30%. Colombias heavy reliance on large hydro has contributed to volatile wholesale power prices. From 2018 to 2019, wholesale prices spiked 76%.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Costa Rica power prices rose in 2016 due to heavy use of diesel-fired generation to satisfy a 6.6% jump in electricity demand. Prices fell in 2017 but rebounded in 2018 and continued rising in 2019. Residential prices were most volatile, jumping 6.8% 2018-2019 to an annual average of $159.53/MWh. Commercial prices went from $186.9/MWh in 2018 to $197.09/MWh in 2019. Industrial prices were least affected, rising 5% year-on-year.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The annual average Dominican Republic residential power price dropped by a massive 35% in 2019 from the year prior, to $86.42/MWh. Commercial prices also were down, from $176.60/MWh in 2018 to $167.78/MWh. Average industrial prices decreased only slightly, to $143.45/MWh while wholesale prices ticked slightly up to $142.71. Substantial subsidies targeting the retail segment of the market have kept those prices particularly low. With the commissioning of the Punta Catalina coal-fired power plant in 2019, the government foresees the possibility of cutting back on subsidies without prices having to spike.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Commercial and residential power prices slightly increased in 2019 compared to 2018, the tariffs were $104.40/MWh for commercial and $102.80/MWh for residential, compared to $103.90/MWh (commercial) and $101.50/MWh (residential) in 2018. Industrial tariffs decreased $0.20/MWh, from $80.10 in 2018 to $79.90/MWh. Ecuadors wholesale electricity rate had the most variation, increasing by 28%, from $55.91/MWh in 2018 to $71.69/MWh in 2019.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: From 2015 to 2016, commercial, residential, industrial and wholesale electricity prices in El Salvador slipped by an average 20%. However, dry conditions in 2016 reduced reservoir levels, hurt hydropower production and fossil fuel generation ramped. Power prices rose as a result. In 2019, commercial prices dipped slightly to $213/MWh. Residential and wholesale prices rose 7% and 5%, respectively, over the same period, while industrial prices jumped 17%.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Average power prices slipped in 2019 in Guatemala. From 2018 to 2019, commercial and residential prices dropped to $142/MWh and $213/MWh, respectively. Industrial prices saw the biggest drop compared to 2018, sinking 12%. Only retail prices rose, from $60/MWh to $62/MWh. Guatemala now high some of the highest retail prices in Latin America.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices in Haiti have remained flat since 2009. The residential tariff was lowest at an average of $112.03/MWh in 2019. Commercial and industrial electricity prices in 2018 were $194.56/MWh and $198.25/MWh, respectively.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices in Honduras jumped from 2018 to 2019 with commercial rates rising most acutely. The average annual commercial price spiked from $169/MWh in 2018 to $212/MWh in 2019. Residential prices rose by a more modest $149/MWh to $162/MWh. Industrial prices were the least affected, rising just 3.7% from the prior year to $137/MWh.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Jamaica is home to some of the highest-priced power in the in Latin America and Caribbean region. In 2019, the average commercial electricity price slipped 8% to $249.40/MWh from the prior year but Jamaica remains second most expensive for commercial power in the region. Industrial and residential electricity prices stayed relatively flat in 2019 compared to the prior year at $191.90/MWh and $271.93/MWh, respectively.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Regulated power prices remained largely unchanged in 2019, and historically Mexican consumers have enjoyed among the lowest subsidized rates in the region. However, prices in Mexicos wholesale market slumped, dropping to $70/MWh on average in the National Interconnected System (SIN) in 2019 from $83/MWh in 2018. Prices in early 2020 fell further, reaching their lowest monthly average ever in the first half of the year. Lower prices for natural gas and fuel oil, as well as growing natural gas imports from the U.S., have played an important role in lowering power prices. A growing contribution on the grid from renewables in meeting afternoon and evening demand has also had a dampening effect on prices. The contribution from wind and solar nearly doubled in 2019 from the prior year, providing 8% of monthly generation on average. Off-takers with a load center of at least 1MW are classified as qualified users and are allowed to purchase electricity directly from qualified suppliers. There are now 25 such qualified suppliers active in the wholesale market, including CFE Calificados, a subsidiary of CFE. CFE continues to be the supplier of basic retail services to residential customers and small and medium-sized commercial customers under regulated tariffs. Regulator CRE sets the final retail and last-resort supply tariffs based on the cost of energy and ancillary services required.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: From 2018 to 2019, commercial power prices in Nicaragua rose 12% to reach $271/MWh, the highest in Latin America. Industrial tariffs spiked from $176/MWh to $192/MWh and at $198/MWh, Nicaraguas residential power prices are in the top quartile in the region. The countrys continuing reliance on imported fossil fuels for generation is largely to blame for the high-cost power. Renewables development represents a potential path to greater energy independence and lower-priced power.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Most of Panamas electricity generation comes from the burning of fossil fuels or from hydropower. Over the last four years, power prices across all of Panamas customer segments have been rising. From 2016-2019 commercial power prices jumped from $174/MWh to $210/MWh, industrial prices increased $168/MWh to $192/MWh, and residential prices moved from $153/MWh to $177/MWh. The wholesale price spiked from $59.19/MWh in 2016 to $90.68/MWh in 2019.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: In 2019, Paraguays average electricity prices kept flat when compared to 2018 prices. Residential prices stagnated at $71.59/MWh, while industrial prices were $56.81 and commercial prices $63.94. Paraguays electricity prices are the cheapest in Latin America.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Peru have risen considerably over the past years. Industrial electricity was the most inflationary, increasing 16%, from $79.71/MWh in 2016 to $92 in 2019. In the same period, commercial rates rose from $106.40 to $119.94 and residential from $137.57 to $156.30. Even so, Perus electricity prices rank among the cheapest in Latin America.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: As Uruguay is heavily dependent on hydropower, auctions have been a key mechanism to diversifying its power matrix. From 2009-2016, the country contracted over 300MW of wind through auctions. As a result, wind generation jumped from 144GWh in 2013 to 4,752GWh in 2019. Rising intermittent generation combined with flat overall demand has also, rather unfortunately, resulted in some curtailment issues in Uruguay. Power prices in Uruguay plunged in 2019 to their lowest levels in a decade, mainly due to abnormally high production from the countrys hydropower plants. Commercial electricity prices in 2019wereslumped 29% to $160/MWh, while industrial and residential prices dropped 18% and 8%, to $129/MWh and  $218/MWh, respectively.  The retail price plummeted a remarkable 81% to $7.58/MWh. System operator Administracin del Mercado Elctrico del Uruguay (ADME) attributed the drops to high precipitation levels and strong hydropower generation, which pushed spot prices to near zero many weeks of the year.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Afghanistan requires electricity imports to meet most of its power needs, making it highly reliant on neighboring countries. This impacts electricity prices. Average power tariffs for the commercial segment are expensive  double the level of industrial and residential clients at around $160/MWh in 2019.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices are fully regulated, although deregulation toward a wholesale market has begun. Residential tariffs are higher than commercial and industrial prices. Compared to neighboring Georgia, residential prices are much more expensive, although commercial and industrial prices are similar. Energy security is a major driver for the shift toward renewable energy, as Armenia imports all gas and nuclear fuel for its generation. The cost of clean energy is falling compared to new gas. The Masrik-1 solar auction price of $41.90/MWh was lower than governments expected, and it is likely to be used as a baseline tariff for future auctions.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Australias wholesale electricity markets have been extremely volatile over the past decade. Spot prices were low in 2011, due to an oversupply of generation. What followed was a period of capacity closures, rising fuel prices and failures in transmission assets, which drove average electricity prices to over A$150/MWh in some states by 2017. Spot prices have since softened; following the introduction of a raft of new policies aiming to bring down prices, a rapid build out of new renewable energy generation and a softening in fuel prices (particularly domestic gas and coal). Retail electricity rates paid by households remain stubbornly high, and are often among the highest in OECD countries. This is in part due to expensive network costs, which can make up to 40% of a households electricity bill.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices have significantly increased in recent years, as the government has attempted to shore up the viability of the power system. Soviet-era networks and generation assets require upgrades and will have to be supported by higher power prices. The issues with subsidized power prices and antiquated installations are common to most of Azerbaijans neighbors, with which it has interconnections. Generation is largely fueled by the countrys own natural gas, so costs will decline as power plants are upgraded to more efficient turbines. Gas may well present renewables with strong competition for a while to come.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Average power prices in Bangladesh are lower than its neighbor India, even though Bangladesh generates most of its electricity from more expensive natural gas compared to cheap domestic coal in India. To keep the retail tariffs low, the government provides subsidies at two levels  by selling fuel to power generation companies at below the market rate and by providing subsidies to the power distribution companies. The rate of increase in retail tariffs is low and these are not revised at regular intervals. For instance, the latest tariff revision was done in February 2020, more than two years after the last revision. Cross-subsidies are prevalent. While residential customers are not required to pay a time-of-day charge, industrial and commercial consumers have a time-based tariff mechanism.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Cambodias consumers pay some of the highest retail electricity rates in the region, at $0.14/kWh for residential consumers. These are higher than in its neighboring nations such as Vietnam and Thailand. These tariffs have declined by roughly 20% since 2015, as the government has sought to make power more affordable as it connects more villages to the grid. Tariffs are not cost-reflective but are subsidized by the government, which covers losses faced by electricity distributors. Because of the focus on rapid electrification and lowering costs, EDC and the government have favored large power plants with low per-megawatt costs, such as hydro and coal.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Chinas residential electricity prices are among the lowest in the world because the consumers are subsidized by commercial and industrial (C&I) users. It began to address this cross-subsidization in 2016, by lowering retail C&I power costs. Chinas Premier Li Keqiang announced further C&I retail tariff discounts in 2020, to help restore the Covid-19 battered economy. Levelized costs of solar and wind power have dropped significantly on the back of efficiency improvements and rising supply. Auctions introduced since 2019 are putting additional pressure on costs. Wind and solar subsidy-free projects  receiving only local coal power reference price  have been announced in two-thirds of the country.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17:
Georgias electricity prices are fairly low thanks to legacy hydro assets. Customers with very low demand qualify for a below-market rate originally developed for disadvantaged consumers, but the subsidized tariff does not require means-testing and has been widely applied.
Most of Georgias power is supplied by small and large hydro plants. In 2019, Georgia had a total installed capacity of 4,232MW and hydro plants accounted for 78% of the total (2,783MW of large hydro and 502MW of small hydro), followed by natural gas (913MW) and wind (21MW). Electricity generation in 2019 was 11,857GWh, of which hydro represented 75% of the total. 
Georgia has significant grid interconnections with Armenia, Turkey and Russia, which it uses to balance its supply. The country has ambitions to become an energy exporter. However, hydro capacity additions are slowing due to public opposition to new large-scale developments. Wind is popular, and output could increase significantly if the government approves the project pipeline.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Average retail electricity prices rose by 1.5% in the financial year starting April 2019, compared to a 2.7% rise in the previous year. Commercial and industrial consumers continue to subsidize agricultural and residential users. The government is attempting to lower the high prices paid by industries by cutting down on the cross-subsidy charges. On a levelized cost of energy (LCOE) basis, solar and onshore wind are the cheapest technologies for bulk power generation since 2018. India has the second-lowest LCOE in the world for solar and third-lowest for onshore wind. By 2023, onshore wind combined with battery storage will have a lower LCOE than new coal plants. The corresponding cross-over for solar with storage could happen in the late 2020s.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Indonesia are one of the lowest in the region: at $77-90/MWh for commercial and industrial users in 2019, and $78/MWh for households. The government subsidizes retail electricity tariffs. A subsidy is given directly to the national utility PLN to cover its electricity supply costs. The government has not changed electricity prices in 2018 and 2019. The levelized cost of solar and wind power is still not competitive with conventional generation technologies like coal and hydro in Indonesia, due to the limited overall deployment in the country and the high cost of finance for these projects.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The power retail price has been rising despite retail market deregulation in April 2016, due to a combination of different factors including the slow restart of nuclear reactors, the generous historic feed-in tariff rates coupled with growing renewables and Japans reliance on fossil fuel imports with rising commodity prices. In 2020, there may be a drop in the power price as oil prices are low. The levelized cost of electricity for solar and wind in Japan has been the world's highest. Capex and opex may fall to some extent but not enough to reach the global average.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices in Kazakhstan differ from region to region, and by the amount of electricity consumed. Average retail electricity price in the country is $0.04/kWh including distribution cost, value-added tax and other fees, due to government subsidies. In neighboring Russia and China, average prices are at $0.07/kWh and $0.08/kWh. Although recent auctions have helped bring down the cost of renewable energy in Kazakhstan, the average levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) for renewables is around 32 tenge ($0.083)/kWh more than double the average retail price in the country. Without restructuring retail power prices, bringing more renewables into the system will increasingly strain the resources of the Financial Settlement Company, which signs power purchase agreements with all renewable generators in Kazakhstan.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Korea has government-regulated fixed retail electricity rates. In 2019, retail customers paid an average of $9.8 U.S. cents(112 won)/kWh. On the generation side, coal remains the cheapest source of power generation with the levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) ranging between $59-71/MWh in 2020. The cost of building solar and wind projects in Korea is among the highest globally with LCOEs ranging between $73-146/MWh for solar and $78-142/MWh for wind. Market price distortion from subsidy (i.e. RPS), mountainous geography, and limited project scale due to difficulties around permitting and site acquisition lead to higher cost of renewable energy in Korea.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Kyrgyzstans residential, commercial and industrial electric tariffs, which are fixed, have remained stable since 2016, when they were increased under the countrys medium-term tariff policy (MTTP). An update to the MTTP in 2018 calls for a gradual increase in tariff prices again in 2022, as well as making them flexible and based on the time and period of consumption by the consumer. These increases are intended to improve the financial viability of the state-owned distribution and transmission companies, which suffer weak returns due to high electricity losses and periodic blackouts.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Laos are relatively low, due to its abundance of low-cost hydroelectricity. The government sets electricity tariffs and subsidizes industry, residential consumers, agriculture and small and medium enterprises with rates below the cost of service. Banks and hotels, on the other hand, have to pay significantly higher tariffs, which can make onsite solar competitive for a small segment despite the absence of net metering or other incentives. Rates have remained stable through 2017-2018. The government announced, at the beginning of 2019, that it will try to cut electricity prices for households and businesses.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Malaysian residential electricity is among the cheapest in the region at $53/MWh, while commercial and industrial tariffs are higher, at $92-105/MWh. Average power prices have remained the same across all segments for the last four years. The levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) for renewable technologies is still not competitive with conventional generation assets like coal and gas power. Small hydropower projects offer the cheapest renewable energy generation technology, followed by solar. However, in the auctions held under Malaysias third round of large-scale solar auctions, the lowest bid for solar power came in at 177 ringgits ($42)/MWh. The government expects the new 1GW mega-tender to further drive down prices in 2020-21.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail electricity tariffs in Mongolia range from 110.67 tugrik/kWh ($40/MWh) for households to 158.23 tugrik/kWh ($55/MWh) for commercial and industrial users. This level, having climbed 60% since 2011, puts the tariffs at a higher level than neighboring countries such as Kazakhstan, and just slightly cheaper than in China. Wholesale prices for general coal generators are at 80.86 tugrik/kWh, while the feed-in tariff ranges for on-grid renewables are: wind $80-95/MWh, small hydro $45-60/MWh, and solar $150-180/MWh. This level is generally more attractive than neighboring countries such as Kazakhstan and China. In general, energy costs are higher than in other countries due to transportation and limited know-how in the local market.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices were low and highly subsidized before July 2019, when they were raised to fund new grid investments. Prices rose by more than 60% for some commercial users. Industrial power tariffs were also increased. Residential rates remained the same for the smallest users (35 kyat/kWh), but rose sharply for those who use more than 30kWh per month. Even the highest residential rates remain well below those of neighboring Thailand. Residential users in India pay roughly three times more than the tariff in Myanmar.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: According to NEAs annual report, its average price of electricity sold was 10.62 rupees/kWh in fiscal 2019-20, or 0.26% lower than the previous year. Whereas the countrys average power tariff paid is 7.22 rupees/kWh to local IPPs and 7.86 rupees to India. The price could keep relatively stable, because any tariff-petition adjustment from NEA needs to go through the regulatory body in the government. The sales price is relatively low compared to neighboring countries such as India, mainly because hydro dominates Nepalese capacity mix and runs on low marginal cost. In 2019-20, NEA achieved a net profit (mainly due to better power sales) of 11,056 million rupees, or 12.36% up from the previous year. It thus successfully reduced accumulated losses down to 4,866 million rupees.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Hydro generation accounts for around 60% of New Zealands electricity supply, bringing the total supply from renewable energy to around 85%. The country aims to further increase the share of generation from renewables in the years ahead as part of its ambition to achieve net-zero carbon emissions target by 2050. With such a high reliance on hydro power, more investment in variable renewables will require additional firming technology  generation that operates counter to hydro seasons  or storage assets, in particular to deal with periods of extended drought. At this stage New Zealand does not have any specific mechanism to force new renewables or firming capacity into the system. It instead relies on established market signals and private investment to facilitate the required low carbon technologies.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Artificially low power prices, high transmission and distribution losses and unpaid customer bills contribute to more than $10 billion of circular debt. In June 2019, the International Monetary Fund agreed to a 13th bailout for Pakistan, worth $6 billion, focused on reducing debt in the power sector. Subsidy cuts on fuel and power tariffs are on the agenda. Consumers have already suffered several tariff increases since 2017, following an unstable electricity tariff policy. The government cuts tariffs to provide relief to consumers, only to raise prices months later to recover debt. The levelized cost of electricity of wind and solar continue to drop in Pakistan due to the global decline in equipment costs.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity in the Philippines ranks among the most expensive in Southeast Asia. While costs are declining, it is happening at a slower rate than in neighboring countries. A lot of this is due to the location of Philippines. It is far from the sources of its imported fuels, and power prices reflect that. Economies of scale are difficult to tap because the country is made up of more than 7,000 islands. Adding to this are ratepayer subsidies and spending on off-grid and grid-extension projects, which bump up unsubsidized rates.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Singapores power prices are linked to the price of oil: the city-state is 95% dependent on imported natural gas for generation, most of which is purchased at oil-linked prices. The average wholesale electricity price (Uniform Singapore Electricity Price or USEP) for 2018 was S$110/MWh  a slight increase after years of price-depression caused by a large system reserve margin. The reserve margin stood at 80% in 2018 but is expected to fall to 58% in 2019, and go further down to 40% by 2022 following the retirement of 2,600MW of generation capacity. Singapore fully liberalized electricity retail under the Open Electricity Market (OEM) regime in 2019. This may mitigate somewhat the upward pressure on electricity bills from potentially higher wholesale prices emanating from declining reserve margins.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: In general, Sri Lanka has among the highest tariffs in the world for residential users (45 rupees/ 28 U.S. cents per kWh), which partly explains the rapid uptake of rooftop solar in households. The current tariff structure for different types of end-users is cross-subsidized. For example, households that consume below a certain level of monthly consumption standard will be subsidized from payment from commercial customers and high-user households. The country also subsidizes low-voltage household customers by charging increased tariffs from large industrial consumers and hotels. Tariffs have not been revised since 2014.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Taiwan offers some of the worlds cheapest retail power prices  a deliberate government policy to benefit semiconductor and other manufacturing industries. In 2018, the residential tariff was the third lowest and the industrial tariff the fifth lowest according to Taipower, the vertically integrated utility that owns 64% of Taiwans total power capacity, and the International Energy Agency. The utility raised the average retail tariff by 3% in April 2018 for the first time in four years. Industry and large commercial companies will feel the brunt of the increase, while 80% of residents and small businesses are not affected. Adding new and potentially more expensive renewables and gas generation will further stress Taipower's balance sheet as the cost cannot be fully passed on to end-consumers: retail power rate hikes are capped at 3% every six months by law.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Tajikistan, like most former Soviet Union countries, has low power prices due to government subsidies. The 2019 average retail price stands at $43/MWh. The government has slightly adjusted rates in recent years in an effort to improve the financial health of its main energy company, Barqi Tojik, but not all tariffs have increased.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Thailand's retail tariffs consist of a base tariff that is reviewed every three to five years and an adjustment tariff component that is reviewed every four months. The adjustment tariff reflects changes in fuel costs, electricity purchase cost and the impact of government policies. The costs of various renewable energy schemes are passed through to retail consumers and have contributed to an increase in retail tariffs over the years. Compared to neighboring countries such as Malaysia and Vietnam, retail tariffs in Thailand are higher. A drop in equipment costs globally, the establishment of domestic equipment production bases and a reduction in development and balance-of-plant costs as developers gained experience, have all contributed to a constant decline in the levelized cost of electricity for solar and wind in Thailand.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power is rationed and effectively free of charge for consumers. It has been announced several times over the past years that this is set to change, with government attempting to force the installation of meters. To date, it seems that power is however still provided free of charge.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: In July 2019, Uzbekistans Cabinet of Ministers announced it was raising residential electricity rates by 18%, to UZS 295,000/MWh ($29/MWh) and increasing commercial and industrial rates to UZS 450,000/MWh ($44/MWh). The move is intended to boost the profitability of newly formed distribution utility JSC Regional Electric Networks and grid operator JSC National Electric Networks. All grid-connected customers pay a fixed rate for electricity. According to the Ministry of Energy, until citizens can be provided with stable power 24 hours a day, a time-based tariff will not be offered for customers.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail tariffs in Vietnam are heavily regulated and subsidized, and considered to be among the lowest in the Southeast Asian region. Retail tariffs below cost recovery levels challenged EVNs financial position. The tariffs remained almost flat from 2005 to 2010 and then began increasing until 2015, when they reached about $0.07/kWh. They remained flat in 2016 and 2017. In March 2019, average electricity retail tariffs increased by 8.36%. Coal is currently the cheapest source of generation in Vietnam, at $56-105/MWh. Vietnams wind and solar industries are still in the early stages of development, with a limited domestic supply chain. However, interest from local and international developers is strong and the levelized cost of electricity for both solar and wind is expected to decrease as equipment costs fall globally and the industry matures.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Changes to political regimes in the past have led to frequent changes in tariffs and law, causing price uncertainty. Feed-in premiums/contracts for difference are granted via auctions for renewable energy sources with more than 2MW capacity. Electricity prices in Albania are lower than those in the European Union. ERE, the Albanian energy regulator, sets the tariffs for energy each year. For certain sized projects, these tariffs apply. For larger projects, there is no guaranteed offtake and the terms can be negotiated.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Wholesale power prices are lower than in most of Austrias neighbors. That is in large part due to an abundance of large hydro generation. Cheap, low-emission hydroelectric power has long reduced the impetus to invest in other renewables, although this is changing as renewables costs continue to fall. Meanwhile, the countrys low-carbon power fleet has largely been shielded from the rising EU carbon price. Retail power prices have dropped for industrial customers but risen for residential users over 2010-19.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power tariffs are subsidized and are therefore some of the lowest for the region at around $94.45/MWh. Tariffs have been increased annually in the past decade, with the biggest increases in the residential segment.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Clean power LCOEs for utility-scale projects are generally higher than most mature renewables markets in Europe. For instance, the cost range for offshore wind was $83-$104/MWh in the first quarter of 2020, against $55-74/MWh in the Netherlands. For other technologies, the lack of a large-scale auction program has made it difficult to achieve economies of scale. Belgian wholesale prices are largely determined by outages affecting the countrys reactor fleet and those of its neighbors, from which it imports heavily. Spot prices tend to be slightly higher than those in France, Germany or the Netherlands. Residential and commercial retail power bills have, for their part, steadily risen over the last decade.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Prices are still partially regulated in Bosnia and Herzegovina  particularly in the region of Republika Srpska. There is not yet complete economic dispatch in the wholesale market in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, meaning prices can be distorted. At an average retail price of $93.08/MWh in 2019, tariffs are comparably cheap.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Bulgaria is among the last countries in Europe to liberalize its power markets, with residential customers paying fixed tariffs and state-owned generators continuing to sell electricity on a regulated basis directly to some of the countrys largest consumers. Power market liberalization is in process, with the intention being that reforms could bring the sector's significant deficit under control. The wholesale power exchange went live in 2016, but sales volumes have remained below 25% of final electricity consumption. From October 2020, all non-residential customers are set to purchase their electricity through the free market. In early-2019, several state-owned generators directed more of their output to the grid in response to rising power prices. The government's decision to switch existing renewables and other regulated generation to a contract-for-difference remuneration system is also intended to increase liquidity in the market.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Most of the electricity in Croatia still trades bilaterally between the state-owned utilities that dominate the generation and retail segments of the market. This has resulted in extremely low traded volumes in the wholesale power market, giving little value to the 50-100 euros/MWh prices that have come out of it. In terms of renewables cost, the $1.55 million/MW capex for onshore wind projects recorded in 2017 falls well within our $133-197 LCOE range for Europe.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Wholesale power prices in the Czech Republic have followed the overall EU downward trend. The country benefits from being well interconnected to its neighbors. Retail prices for all types of customer are also relatively low compared with surrounding EU countries, suggesting little impetus for households to install small-scale PV or corporates to undertake power-purchase agreements. While it is the third-largest net electricity exporter in the EU, concerns about energy independence have dominated discussions about phasing out coal. The country is also highly dependent on imported crude oil and gas, with almost all of its imported gas coming from Russia. The country wishes to diversify its gas supply, but has yet to clarify how this will be achieved  contracts with Russias Gazprom extend until 2035.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Wholesale power prices in Denmark are low, which has led to some concerns about a lack of investment in new firm capacity. This is a characteristic of all NordPool markets, which are dominated by low short-run marginal cost electricity sources like hydro and wind. In 2019, the average day-ahead baseload power price was 38.94 euros/MWh  5 euros lower than the EU average but just above the price in neighboring Sweden. Despite this, the average household retail price in 2019 was 295.40 euros/MWh, the second highest in the EU behind only Germany. Most of the retail price comes from levies and taxes, of which the renewable public service obligation (PSO) accounts for more than half. As a result, Denmark agreed to phase out the PSO tariff by 2021 in order to reduce electricity costs for consumers while the government gradually shifts the financing of renewable energy subsidies over to the state budget.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Finnish wholesale power prices are below average compared to other EU countries. The average baseload day-ahead price for 2019 was 44.2 euros/MWh. This is because Finland generates more than 50% of its power from technologies with low short-run marginal costs like hydro and nuclear. However, the country is more dependent on fossil fuels than other Nord Pool countries, meaning its wholesale price tends to be higher than its neighbors. Finland's average household retail price in 2019 was 173 euros/MWh, putting it slightly above its fellow EU member states. However, when adjusted for purchasing power the tariffs are among the lowest in Europe.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: French renewables are pricey compared to those developed in neighboring markets. That has much to do with relatively low deployment levels and reams of red tape, which pushes up development costs. Among the European markets surveyed in the first quarter of 2020, France had Europes most expensive LCOE range for onshore wind after Poland, at $43-65/MWh. That said, a low strike price of 44 euros/MWh ($52/MWh) was registered for Frances first offshore wind auction in June 2019. Frances retail and wholesale power prices are set to rise, partly due to the cost of maintaining the countrys ageing nuclear reactor fleet while adding renewables. However, a lack of flexibility makes France among Europes most volatile power markets.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: German onshore wind, offshore wind and utility-scale PV sit in the middle of global LCOE ranges. Wholesale prices have become increasingly volatile as renewables penetration increases, leading to a marked rise in negative pricing events. How prices evolve will depend on the speed with which renewables continue to replace existing capacity  uncertainty in this area surrounds the speed of the countrys phase-out from coal as well as a protracted slump in onshore wind deployment. Retail power prices have been rising steadily, although industrial users benefit from a patchwork of favorable tariffs and exemptions. That has led to an uptick in residential supplier switching, which had long remained low by Western European standards  a result of the persisting influence of local suppliers.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The exposure of the Greek power sector to rising carbon prices has driven the countrys wholesale power price up, and prices are volatile due to highly seasonal demand fuel price fluctuations. Full liberalization of the power market in line with the European target model has been delayed repeatedly but is set to be complete by October 2020. Retail prices are also high, as ratepayers subsidize higher costs on the non-interconnected island systems. Growing renewables penetration, increasing interconnection, and falling lignite generation exert downward pressure on power prices. Onshore wind and utility-scale PV are increasingly competitive with new gas, driving growing interest in renewables development. Competition in auction rounds is heating up and continuing to push prices down. Full market liberalization will finally allow developers to enter bilateral contracts directly with offtakers.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Hungary has relatively low retail power prices compared to its neighbors. While electricity prices for non-household customers increased in 2018 and 2019, the regulated household electricity prices have stayed at 30% below the average EU residential tariffs. Over 90% of households are on government-regulated tariffs. Tariffs fell substantially in 2013, when the government imposed a 20% reduction in regulated residential electricity prices, at the expense of power companies. Prices are still below cost, forcing utilities to cover the difference. The European Commission has repeatedly asked the government to enforce fully the energy directives and to adjust tariffs to reflect costs. For instance, in July 2018, the EC took Hungary to court over the exclusion of certain costs in electricity tariffs. Hungary's average household retail price in 2018 was 112 euros/MWh, putting it almost half below its fellow EU member states (208 euros/MWh). The electricity bill for households in Hungary decreased the most (-27%) among EU countries.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Average commercial, industrial and residential electricity prices declined by 2%-4% between 2018 and 2019. Meanwhile, wholesale electricity prices increased by almost 20% between 2018 and 2019. Looking back five years, electricity prices have all fallen steadily. Commercial, industrial and residential electricity prices fell by 13%-15% between 2014 and 2019. Ireland has relatively high retail electricity prices for households and industry compared with the EU average. This is likely caused by caused by the country's reliance on fossil fuels for power generation and fuel imports.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Italys power prices are higher than the European average largely due to limited interconnection and its large natural gas fleets exposure to commodity prices. This issue will only intensify after the countrys 2025 mandated coal phaseout. In fact, the phaseout will make coal prices irrelevant in the country and at greatly reduce the effect of carbon prices. BloombergNEF expects the power price in neighboring countries to become a key driver of Italian power prices. Italys focus on growing its renewable fleet will ease the pressure of global energy commodity price volatility on the countrys power prices. However, a low-wind winter, or cloudy summer, combined with a low hydro year could temporarily exacerbate Italys power price dependence on gas.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail electricity prices in Lithuania are relatively low compared to the EU average. However, new power interconnections with Poland and Sweden are to be commissioned in 2023 and could affect price dynamics. Residential tariffs are still regulated and are among the lowest in Europe, although a gradual deregulation is planned for 2021-2023. Lithuania has implemented generous investment incentives to convince consumers to install their own renewables systems.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The fossil-fueled Kuchurgan power plant, controlled by Russias Inter-Rao and located in the breakaway region of Transnistria, has maintained its near-monopoly supply status in Moldova, selling at a lower price than power imported from Ukraines DTEK. As a result, wholesale power prices in 2019 averaged around 987 Moldovan leu (49 euros) per MWh. Industrial and commercial retail electricity rates in 2019 declined slightly to an average of about 1.86 leu (0.1 euro) per kWh, while residential customers paid an average of 2 leu per kWh. Time-based retail electricity tariffs are not offered in Moldova.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Dutch offshore wind tenders have attracted headlines for record-low or even zero-subsidy bids. However, this trend should not be seen as the new norm for project costs in Europe, as the sites in the Netherlands have been closer to shore, and in shallower waters, than many others under development in the North Sea. In addition, the development and transmission costs are being covered by the Dutch government. The project owners are expected to hedge a significant part of future revenue via a corporate or utility PPA, or other financial instruments. Nonetheless, offshore wind projects in the Netherlands enjoy some of the lowest levelized costs of electricity in Europe. BNEFs estimates show that costs are continuing to drop, having reduced from $71-87/MWh in 1H 2018 to $55-74/MWh in 1H 2020.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: While North Macedonia has higher power prices than neighboring countries such as Serbia and Kosovo, it boasts low prices compared to EU member states. Electricity prices for fossil fuels are still subsidized, and North Macedonia has to import a substantial portion of its electricity to meet demand. Power producers are allowed to seek their own prices for electricity produced.  Due to the presence of cross-subsidies on electricity, household electricity consumers pay substantially less than the real cost, while other consumers pay more to compensate.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Norway is split into five power price zones and has one of the lowest wholesale tariffs in Europe. In 2019, the average baseload day-ahead price was 38.95 euros per MWh. There are public concerns that power prices will increase when interconnectors to Britain and Germany are activated. The system is dominated by zero-marginal cost hydroelectric power. The tariffs are split relatively evenly between taxes, the power price and network charges

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Wholesale power prices in Poland are relatively high and are trending upward every year as the carbon price rises, due to the countrys heavy exposure to coal. This is in contrast to the EU average which has been steadily decreasing since 2012 with the addition of zero-marginal cost renewables. Poland became a net electricity importer in 2016, as the country's aging coal fleet is inefficient and ramping it up to meet demand spikes is costly. Renewables are becoming more competitive, but their levelized cost in Poland is still the highest range in Europe among the countries tracked by BNEF. The slower uptake of competitive auctions, combined with the punitive wind act, has kept financing costs high.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Portugal and Spain share the Iberian wholesale power market (Mibel), which is coupled with the European day-ahead market. Electricity is dispatched in merit order, and power prices are generally higher than the European average due to limited interconnection and dependency on imported commodities. Power prices are primarily driven by gas and to a lesser extent coal and carbon. Portugals power price volatility is kept in check by a price floor and ceiling, which keeps the value of electricity between zero and 180 euros/MWh. This will have to change as the EU acts to remove all price constraints. The growth of wind, in combination with a large hydro fleet, has reduced the countrys dependence on gas. However, gas generation remains important as it fills the gap during low hydro or wind years.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Romania's power prices were historically lower than those in neighboring Hungary and Bulgaria, but they have been steadily rising at 1-2% per year thanks to higher carbon prices and an aging coal and nuclear fleet. The expected public listing of Hidroelectrica, the state-owned hydro asset company, in September 2020, and the sale of CEZs assets in Romania, are meant to spur competition and could put pressure on wholesale prices. Retail power prices in Romania soared in 2019, whereas demand grew modestly. In spring 2020 prices reversed to the lowest point in five years due to the Covid-19 pandemic but have since recovered. Planned investments in new nuclear capacity would likely push up consumer bills, through a proposed subsidy scheme.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
