column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Russia benefits from some of the lowest electricity prices for residential, commercial and industrial customers compared to its neighbors, though prices vary significantly by region. This is a result of the low cost of energy resources, as natural gas makes up the majority of power generation and Russia has an abundance of cheap natural gas. That said, electricity prices are increasing at an annual rate of roughly 5%. Rates are also likely to continue to rise on the back of planned modernization works on Russias ageing power fleet.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Commercial, retail and industrial power-price reforms were introduced in 2015. Previously, tariffs were set below the cost-recovery point for the state utility, EPS. The reforms also helped Serbia align with the EU's accession requirements. This has led to a steady increase of tariffs for end-users. At an average retail price of $97.77/MWh, tariffs are, however, still on the cheaper end.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Slovakia's power prices are slightly lower than the European average, and broadly align with neighboring Austria and the Czech Republic. The country is part of the 'Central' area, which includes Hungary, Poland, and the Czech Republic. Wholesale and industrial electricity prices in Slovakia rose in 2016 for the first time since 2011, along with the EU average. The driver was upward pressure from gas prices, which increased as a result of rising demand from cold weather and reduced nuclear capacity in the region. Commercial and residential tariffs in Slovakia continued to rise in 2019, increasing the incentive for install small-scale PV systems.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Slovenia's residential electricity prices saw an increase to 165 euros/MWh in 2019 after remaining steady at 160 euros/MWh over 2013-18. Following rising carbon prices, there has been upwards pressure on power prices in neighboring countries such as Italy and Austria. Several power and gas companies in Slovakia have also pushed prices up. The substantial penetration of hydro and nuclear power in Slovenia helps keep electricity tariffs low for consumers, as wholesale prices remain low. With such a mix, the addition of wind and solar only help to keep costs low. The limited subsidies the government hands out typically get added to electricity bills in the form of taxes and levies.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Spanish electricity prices are higher than the European average, largely due to limited interconnections with the rest of the continent. This has exacerbated the grid overcapacity and reliance on the country's internal market to balance the power system. Given the collapse of coal generation, gas is now the dominant price setter in the power market. Power prices are also sensitive to hydropower availability, as seen in 2017 when drought conditions halved Spain's hydro power generation and prices reached new records. Low hydro output caused more expensive gas and coal generators to ramp up production to meet demand, alongside a rise in imported energy from France and Portugal. As higher volumes of utility-scale onshore wind and PV projects are commissioned, either as winners of auctioned capacity or unsubsidized projects, a long-term squeeze on the country's gas sector is expected. Higher volumes of zero-marginal cost renewable energy generation will also likely place significant downward pressure on power prices.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: High renewables penetration means that power prices in Sweden are relatively low, with 62% of installed capacity from zero-marginal-cost wind and hydro. In particular, power prices in 2020 have reached record lows, averaging a mere 10 euros/MWh. Its electricity grid is also highly interconnected with other countries, including Poland, Germany, Estonia and the Netherlands, making it easier to balance the grid. Sweden enjoys the lowest LCOE for onshore wind in the EMEA region, at $37/MWh in 1H 2020. Capex costs continue falling, and many Swedish wind projects are large enough to take advantage of economies of scale and enjoy one of the highest capacity factors in Europe.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Industrial and residential electricity prices increased between 2018 and 2019, by 3% and 1% respectively in Switzerland. Wholesale electricity prices fell by more than 20% in the same period, while commercial prices remained almost flat. Abundant hydro generation means that wholesale power prices in Switzerland are generally low relative to the EU average.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Turkey have risen over the last five years, but are still kept low through intervention in the market. Wholesale power prices do not allow power producers to recoup their costs, which are rising along with fuel prices and heightened currency fluctuation. Gas plants especially struggle as the gas supply has been strained, and resources are diverted toward heat and away from power. Due to coals high capacity factor, BNEFs levelized cost estimate for coal power in Turkey is the lowest after onshore wind, but it does not have the same downward trajectory that wind and PV LCOEs have followed in Turkey over the last five years. Financing costs remain high, however, across all technologies, keeping LCOEs from falling as rapidly as in other regions.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Ukraine were regulated until the introduction of a wholesale market in 2019. New market rules have not brought full liberalization, however, as some state-owned power is price-capped to keep residential electricity tariffs low. The wholesale market is still heavily concentrated and dominated by fossil fuel plants owned by DTEK. To avoid excessive volatility, the wholesale market is operated with price caps. Both thermal and nuclear plants are in need of investment for renewal and life extension. It is unclear how this will be funded and how retail prices will change if and when price caps are lifted. Ukraines situation is further complicated by a shortfall in coal supplies from the east of the country, which has been destabilized by conflict with Russia. Coal imports have partially compensated for this, while some plants are retrofitting to run on gas instead.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices have remained relatively stable at between 38-50 pounds/MWh over the past decade, with the most important drivers of U.K. power prices being gas (and in the past, coal) prices. The U.K. has relatively high wholesale electricity prices compared with the rest of the EU because the country has a carbon price floor and only 3GW of interconnector capacity with mainland Europe and 4GW overall. Interconnection capacity represented just 6.5% of peak demand in 2018, compared to 33% in Germany and 20% in Spain, making the U.K. less flexible than its European counterparts. The country is a net-importer of power, but limited interconnection means that it cannot benefit as much from the low prices in France and Germany. In the long term, BNEF expects U.K. baseload wholesale power prices to face structural decline out to 2030 in nominal terms, amid pressure from wind and solar. These technologies are already cheaper to build than new gas plants.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Prices for clean energy are driven up by the requirement to use locally manufactured equipment. While the domestic solar manufacturing industry has started producing panels at scale, product costs remain far higher than those sold internationally. Retail electricity rates are relatively low by virtue of the countrys rich gas resources. Those rates have not been raised in recent years as low oil and gas prices have strained the public purse since they began to fall in 2014. The current political uncertainty renders reforms in this area unlikely.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: With an energy sector dominated by large hydro plants, Angola has not received significant investment in utility-scale clean energy plants in recent years. However, its 2025 energy strategy will require substantial investment in renewables, much of which is likely to come in the form of concessional financing.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: In previous years, the Government of Benin has contracted expensive thermal power generation to address outages, due to the unavailability of power imports arising from temporary supply challenges in Ghana and Nigeria. Power tariffs are regulated and have remained unchanged for many years, currently standing at an average of $151/MWh. The expensive generation mix and inability to cover costs has led the countrys distribution utility SBEE into financial distress.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: For decades, electricity in Botswana has been heavily subsidized, but this is slowly changing with tariffs having increased in recent years. Private consumers have paid low power prices, which has led to the Botswana Power Corporation (BPC) dispatching power at a loss. In an effort to create more cost-reflective tariffs, BPC has therefore gradually increased the tariffs and steadily reduced the subsidy from 2.4 billion Botswana pula ($220 million) to 1.4 billion Botswana pula and reduced it further to 800 million Botswana pula in 2019. Electricity tariffs have risen consistently over the last decade at an average of 10% annually.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity costs in landlocked Burkina Faso are at the higher end of tariffs in the region, because the country needs to import expensive diesel to run its thermal power plants. The regulator ARSE sets a national fixed electricity tariff of $190/MWh, with no distinction between prices for commercial, industrial and residential users. The tariff has been more or less stable over the last five years, but it is not cost reflective, meaning that the national utility Sonabel is reliant upon government subsidies.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity tariffs are set by the monopoly electricity supplier, Regideso. Power prices are extremely high, considering the high proportion of hydro, with average tariffs being among the world's most expensive. The lack of power supply has been driving these high tariffs, along with grid inefficiencies and a lack of investment into new infrastructure. In 2017, amid the lack of power supply, Regideso leased a 30MW gas power plant to supply the capital Bujumbura. The dependence on the thermal power plant has made electricity tariffs increase more since then.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The Electric Sector Regulation Agency (ARSEL) sets electricity tariffs in Cameroon. These are relatively high for the region, particularly for a hydro-dominated market, owing to high transmission costs (including grid distribution losses of about 30%). The government subsidizes the tariffs by transferring funds to the monopoly utility, Eneo, and it has paid out more than $20 million between 2012 and 2019. Hydropower remains Cameroons cheapest source of electricity, but recent growth in small-scale and off-grid solar suggests that these alternatives are becoming increasingly competitive in rural areas away from the three separate power grids. Grid operators must buy excess production from renewables installations, but no price is specified and they may not buy electricity at above-market rates, which limits the policys effectiveness. Eneo also recently implemented a retail program backed by prepaid meters, providing consumers with more transparency and control over their power consumption and pricing.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The government artificially keeps power prices low and financially supports the heavily indebted state-owned utility Enerca, which is unable to cover its costs. The utility is currently undergoing a reorganization with the support of the World Bank in order to improve its performance. Technology costs in the country are difficult to determine due to the low pipeline of any capacity additions. The very few projects that have been announced lack in detail and are currently on hold due to ongoing political disturbances, which prevent progress from being made.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Chads government subsidizes power retail tariffs, which have remained unchanged since their last adjustment in 2012. The government is committed to increasing the populations access to cheap electricity, so there is little probability of rates rising in the short term. The tariffs are nonetheless higher than most neighboring countries, at an average retail power price of $166/MWh.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail power prices are much lower than in neighboring Cameroon and the Central African Republic, and cheap when compared to the region as a whole. There is no differentiation between commercial, industrial and residential prices, and the only variation is by consumption band. Tariffs have been fixed since 1994 and are kept well below production costs through significant subsidies. Prices are unlikely to be increased in the near future, following the successful relaunch of recently-privatized state utility E2C.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The DRC has a regulated electricity tariff that has only marginally changed since 2009. Residential customers are charged one of the lowest tariffs in the world, which does not even cover the operating costs of the utility, SNEL. However, there have been recent increases to residential tariffs due to a devaluation in the Congolese franc, according to reports. There has been little change to the levelized costs of electricity in the DRC due to a lack of new projects being built in the last 36 years and poor maintenance of existing energy infrastructure. Electricity is mostly purchased by consumers for a fixed lump sum as meters are very scarce, leaving much of the billing at the discretion of officials. Furthermore, it is also common for public institutions (schools, health centers and public enterprises) to have large amounts overdue on their electricity bills.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity tariffs are regulated by ANARE for all sectors. Some large customers are eligible for special tariffs, as was the case with the Societ Ivoirienne du Raffinage. Tariffs have a fixed component depending on the maximum power required by the user. Residential and low voltage commercial users have two default options for their required power. In addition, industrial users face time-of-use tariffs with three differentiated periods, while small users have a fixed charge per kWh. Power producers are forced to sell their electricity to CIE. Take-or-pay contracts are common and they are calculated  on an individual basis in order to be profitable to the producer. There is little flexibility outside of this standardized method.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail power prices are being raised as part of the governments economic reform program. An announced phaseout of electricity subsidies by 2022 has been delayed until 2025  ostensibly as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Similar efforts are being made to remove subsidies for cooking gas, diesel and gasoline. Average residential bills have been raised from 240 Egyptian pounds/MWh ($40/MWh) to 1,070 Egyptian pounds/MWh ($63/MWh) over 2012-19. At $0.084/kWh, the feed-in tariffs awarded through the Benban projects are high by international standards, although recent auctions tendering individual projects have reached lower prices. Egyptian PV was cheaper than any other source of new bulk generation in 2019.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices are regulated in Eritrea and there is no differentiation between commercial, residential and industrial tariffs. Tariffs remain unchanged since 2017. Almost all on-grid capacity is powered by diesel, which is costly to import. Eritrea offers good conditions for clean energy deployment due to its strong wind and solar resources. Around half of the population still lacks access to power, so the potential for mini-grids is therefore high. The countrys levelized cost of energy for different technologies is difficult to determine due to the lack of detail on capacity additions.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Cheap hydro gives Ethiopia among the lowest power prices in Sub-Saharan Africa. Lack of exposure to fuel prices also has ensured minimal variation in prices. However, a rapid devaluation of the Ethiopian birr caused the Ethiopia Electric Utility (EEU), which manages the distribution grid, to increase retail prices by 50% to $0.03/kWh in 2018. Prices were kept flat during 2019, but EEU is expected to double retail prices again by 2022 to $0.06/kWh amid ongoing currency struggles. Even then, Ethiopia will still have among the cheapest power on the continent. Upon commissioning of the 6GW Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, the country plans to export cheap power to neighboring countries.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Ghana has some of the highest power prices in the region, due to an inefficient transmission and distribution system with high losses, PPAs with expensive thermal generation and a failure to effectively collect revenue. As a result, power prices increased through the mid-2010s, and became one of the main focuses of the 2016 election. In March 2018, the new government cut the electricity tariffs for industrial customers by as much as 30%, and the reductions were also extended further to residential and commercial customers. The new tariffs are not reflective of the cost of generation and transmission, and so are heavily subsidized. Despite the reductions, the tariffs are still one of the highest in Sub-Saharan Africa.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Guineas power prices are among the regions lowest at an average retail price of $128.77/MWh, even given a significant price rise in 2018. Prices were increased in order to ensure a better cost recovery, with substantial increases to commercial and industrial rates. Prior to this, tariffs had not been adjusted for more than seven years. The state subsidizes the national utility EDG to allow it to remain operational. With regards power purchasing, EDG agreed to pay China Water and Electric around $85/MWh for energy produced by the 240MW Kalta dam, which was completed in 2015. Investments in interconnectors aim to facilitate Guineas interest in becoming a net exporter in the mid-term.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The government heavily subsidizes electricity and fuel prices, with tariffs remaining unchanged since 2017 at around $42/MWh. The supply of electricity is unreliable and available for less than 15 hours a day. This has forced consumers to turn to private, predominantly diesel, generators for supply.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: 80 to 120 words

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices for consumers in Jordan are subsidized. Commercial consumers have traditionally paid the highest electricity prices. They subsidize residential, agriculture, consumers and hotels. This has led to a rise in behind-the-meter projects, with 351MW of small-scale PV net metering installed by the end of 2019 and around 222MW of wheeling projects. State utility National Electric Power Co. (Nepco) remains heavily indebted due to years of high fuel price imports. In January 2020, Nepco issued a statement confirming their debts amounted to 5.5 billion dinars ($7.8 billion), costing 120 million dinars a year to service. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) provided Nepco with a $265 million long-term loan in 2018 and has been working with the state-owned utility on financial forecasting and risk management. Electricity prices have been raised in the last years in an attempt to narrow the deficit. These prices hikes have not been welcomed by consumers, with activists calling for the government to review electricity tariffs earlier this year.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Kenyas electricity tariffs are set by the Electricity Act of 2006. In 2019, while residential prices were up 3%, to $158/MWh, commercial prices saw a 7% reduction and industrial prices kept flat from 2018.  Kenya Power introduced off-peak tariffs for commercial and industrial customers in December 2017, which are applicable during the night time if a customer meets a certain threshold of monthly power consumption. Power prices in Kenya are higher compared to neighboring economies such as Ethiopia, where cheap large hydro is available, and Tanzania, where the government keeps tariffs lower than generation costs.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Consumption of energy is heavily subsidized in Kuwait. Electricity prices are among the lowest in the Middle East. These subsidies distort the allocation of resources by encouraging excessive consumption, accelerating the depletion of natural resources and undermining the growth potential of renewables. This results in one of the highest per capita energy consumption rates in the world. The government increased electricity prices for the residential (expatriates only) and commercial sectors in Kuwait in 2017. However, electricity prices are much lower than the cost of generation, and the subsidy level is still very high even after the price increase. Theres more to be done to encourage rational use of electricity and investment in the renewable sector.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The government subsidizes electricity prices in the form of cheap diesel and heavy fuel oil for the state utility, Electricite du Liban (EDL), which sells electricity to the grid significantly below its cost of generation. Electricity retail tariffs have been frozen since the 1990s and this has put a massive strain on public finances. Yet, any movement toward more cost-reflective power prices remains politically untenable. Generation capacity is well below consumer demand. EDLs inability to meet electrical demand has spawned a large fleet of private diesel generators. These supply the grid during the daily blackouts, which may last three hours in Beirut and up to 12 hours in rural areas. Despite their illegality, these generators contribute an estimated 23% of all electricity and provide electricity at more than double the cost a typical EDL tariff. EDL also faces losses from technical issues and unpaid bills. Losses represent 43% of EDLs production. Some 17% of these are technical losses (such as transmission constraints and grid conjestion), 21% are non-technical losses (meter tampering, misbilling and theft), and 5% are losses from uncollected bills. The PPA for the first round of wind auctions was at $113/MWh. The LCOE of solar PV in Lebanon will likely be competitive in the context of the countrys diesel-dominated power sector. By the end of 2018, small-scale PV solutions totaled around 60MW, with more in development as solar costs continue to drop. A project funded by the National Council for Scientific Research estimated that rooftop PV in Beirut could provide up to a third of the capitals electricity needs.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices are extremely high in Lesotho. They were $0.77 per KWh in 2018, on a weighted-average basis, and in 2019 prices increased between 3% and 3.8% for all customer categories. Prices are elevated by the need to procure imports from South Africa. A growing domestic fleet, with low marginal-cost electricity, should help reduce local power prices.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Liberias retail electricity prices have declined significantly in recent years as a result of the refurbishment of Mount Coffee Hydropower Plant, which brought a low-cost supply to the heavily constrained power system. Substantial investment is required in the LEC grid, which may increase prices over time. Currently there are some citizens selling electricity outside of the regulated markets to their neighbors from diesel generators.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Madagascan power prices are relatively high compared to the average electricity tariff in Sub-Saharan Africa. Residential prices are comparable to the regional average of $122/MWh, yet commercial and industrial tariffs are 1.5 to 2-fold more expensive than the Sub-Saharan African average, at $213.74/MWh and $257.33/MWh respectively. All tariff types have increased in the last decade, despite government support for social retail tariffs. The steady increase in diesel prices and correspondingly high costs associated with the countrys dependence on fossil-fired generation continue to aggravate the financial situation of state utility Jirama.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power tariffs have steadily increased in recent years in order for the central utility to raise revenue and improve the energy deficit. For customers, price increases are highly upsetting in the midst of severe load shedding. Fuel prices are increasing significantly, which is bad news because the country increasingly relies on diesel generation for emergency power. Malawi does not have any significant interconnection to neighboring markets so is unable to import power. German financial aid has been secured to build a 400kV substation and 218 km power line between Mozambique and Malawi, which would improve power supply in the country and potentially bring down its price.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices are subsidized and have remained relatively stable for the past decade, yet are steadily increasing. The average electricity tariff was $0.17/kWh in 2019. State utility EDM operates at a loss, despite being supported by the Malian government. In contrast, the tariffs offered by independent power producers are cost-reflective, at around triple the price offered by EDM, leading to discontent and limited uptake by customers.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Generous subsidies have kept retail tariffs stable over the past few years. Compared to neighboring countries, Somelecs power tariffs are low at an average retail price of $127.01/MWh. However, the vast majority of citizens pay discounted social rates bankrolled by the state, while rural consumers are faced with steeper bills levied by microgrid operators. There is little regulatory clarity concerning how tariffs are determined and adjusted. The latter falls under the remit of regulatory agency ARE.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Power prices in Morocco are subsidized by the state utility, the Office Nationale de lElectricite et de lEau potable (ONEE), which does not pass on the full cost of generation to consumers and therefore operates at a loss. Government support of the energy sector is a strain on public finances but has been rationalized within a developmental context. Servicing the 5% growth rate in electrical demand and the acute evening peak remains a primary concern in securing new generating capacity, much of this slack has been met with expensive diesel generators. The difficulty and expense in meeting evening peak demand has necessitated storage requirements for Moroccan solar tenders and electricity tariffs that are 40% higher during the evening for commercial and industrial clients. The high cost of meeting evening peaks justified a PPA for the Noor I solar thermal project of $189/kWh in 2013, which includes five hours of storage. Since 2013, a maturing domestic industry, technological advances and hybrid-plant design with PV have driven down costs. In 2018, the PPA for the latest solar thermal (hybrid) project was signed at only $70/MWh. In 2016, the PPA for 850MW of wind projects awarded to the Enel, Siemens, and Nareva consortium set a world record price of $30/MWh on average. PPAs for solar PV auctions to date are unknown, however, most projects have been commissioned in the context of rural electrification and deferment of grid upgrades.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Despite a five-year freeze in the 2010-15 period, retail power prices have risen considerably over the last decade with commercial tariffs climbing more than eightfold, and residential bills more than doubling, as state utility Electricidade de Moambique (EDM) attempts to make up for longstanding revenue shortfalls. In 2019, the regulator increased the tariffs for both the industrial and residential bands by approximately 53% and 3%, respectively. Industrial prices had a big jump. Social tariffs, which apply to low-income users, have remained stable. Like most countries in Sub-Saharan Africa, Mozambique does not have a wholesale power market, but it belongs to the Southern Africa Power Pool, which is gradually increasing liquidity.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The Ruacana hydro plant dominates Namibias power fleet, accounting for 58% of installed capacity. Namibia has some of the strongest solar resources in the world, thanks to its proximity to the equator and its arid climate. Single-axis tracking solar PV projects have achieved an annual capacity factor of over 30.2%. High capacity factors and advances in solar technology have contributed to a swift decline in the levelized cost of solar. BloombergNEFs levelized cost estimates suggest they have halved for solar in sub-Saharan Africa between 2015 and 2019 (from $107/MWh to $53/MWh). Low costs and high output have contributed to Solar PVs rapid growth in Namibia, which has seen a doubling of solar capacity each year between 2014 and 2018. Solar PV currently represents 13% of installed capacity. At the moment, Nampower is the only offtaker with which IPPs can sign power-purchase agreements. However, the Electricity Control Board, the regulator, wants to switch from a single-buyer model to a modified single-buyer model, where IPPs can sell directly to local distributors and large consumers, and potentially also export power.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Nigerien power prices are subsidized and remain stable in the long term, yet were adjusted in 2018 to enable better cost recovery. Prior to that, prices had only been adjusted once since 2012, when a social tariff was also introduced. Compared to its neighbors, Niger offers some of the lowest electricity tariffs, with the average retail electricity price standing at $129.77/MWh. Equally, retail fuel prices are subsidized and have remain unchanged since 2013.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices are set by the Nigerian Electricity Regulatory Commission (NERC) under its multi-year tariff-order model. Distribution companies have said that the tariffs are not cost-reflective, and so investment has stagnated. Tariffs had not been updated since 2015 and so do not incorporate the significant drop in the price of solar that has occurred worldwide. However, on December 31, 2019, NERC disclosed its plans to immediately review electricity tariffs in the country from January 1, which was to take place April 1, 2020. But this has been delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This is a service-based tariff (SBT) where areas that receive over 12 hours of service (power) per day in a month will pay the higher tariff. NERC says this is to protect the poorer population, such that the richest 10% will cover up to 50% of the price hike. The yet-to-be-built on-grid PV projects partially agreed a tariff of $0.075-0.115/kWh, which falls within BNEFs global utility-scale fixed-axis PV LCOE range ($0.07-0.212/kWh, 1H 2020). No wholesale power market exists yet in Nigeria. Instead, NBET brokers transactions between generators and distributors. The Eligible Customer regulation allows bulk buyers to buy directly from a generator at a negotiated PPA rate. In 2018, BNEF carried out a detailed study about on-site solar in Nigeria and found that solar on commercial and industrial premises can cost between $0.1-0.2/kWh in Nigeria. PV alone is already cheaper than grid electricity tariffs or electricity from a diesel generator, which typically costs $0.28-0.32/kWh. Though for isolated residential-based solar hybrid mini-grids, BNEFs recent State of Global State Minigrids report found the LCOEs of minigrids in Nigeria to have a huge range, reaching $0.5-1.46/kWh.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Similar to other countries in the region, Omans electricity prices are highly subsidized for residents. Prices paid by consumers were static from the early 1990s until 2017 and only covered about 54% of production costs. In 2017, the country introduced a cost-reflective tariff that removed subsidies for customers whose yearly use exceeds 150MWh (effectively commercial customers), charging them set prices based on typical demand profiles for the season and time of day. A planned spot market for wholesale electricity trading by 2019-2020 may also introduce more competition into the countrys power market, which would lower the cost of power.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity in the Palestinian Territories is expensive compared to its neighbors, at an average retail price of $157/MWh. Most power is imported from Israel, and Palestinian consumers pay the same retail prices as set by the Israel Electric Co., despite the higher standard of living in Israel compared to Palestine. Power prices are determined by the regulator, and although they are high, Palestinian distribution companies (which are also the retailers) are unable to fully recoup their costs. Consumers are able to install rooftop solar panels, and high power prices incentivize their uptake.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Like other countries in the region, electricity prices in Qatar are heavily subsidized. The country is also the last among its peers that offers free electricity to its nationals. The levelized cost of electricity remains low, because natural gas, the primary source for power generation in Qatar, is abundant, and only 7% of natural gas is burnt to generate power. Tariff was increased for expatriates only in 2015.  With an absolute monarch dependent on citizen support, Qatar appears comfortable giving citizens unlimited free utility services.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices in Rwanda are among the highest in East Africa, and commercial and residential tariffs have increased considerably since 2010. The biggest driver of this is take-or-pay contracts administered by REG. These contracts compensate developers for the contractual offtake from their projects even at times when power cannot be taken. On top of that, the PPAs are signed in dollars and are exposed to commodity- and currency-price fluctuations. As a result, retail electricity is highly subsidized by REG and the government of Rwanda. Small hydro remains the most popular source of generation, due to the strong network of rivers in Rwanda, and the country has taken advantage of methane from gaseous lakes in the southwest to generate electricity.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: As with other countries in the region, Saudi Arabia has seen record low bids over recent years. These include a $21.30/MWh bid LCOE in January 2019 for Dumat al-Jandal, the countrys first auctioned wind farm. Meanwhile, falling equipment costs, free land, zero connection costs and cheap labor have made PV the most competitive source of new bulk generation. Saudi Arabia is moreover committing to an ambitious subsidy-removal program, stripping away measures keeping down the price of natural gas and oil. Although it looks like subsidies for generation fuel will remain in place for now, retail power prices are being increased for all customer types. Such efforts are aligned with Saudi Vision 2030, which aims to diversify the economy from oil while increasing the role of the private sector.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Only power generation has been liberalized in Senegal, with transmission and distribution remaining vertically integrated. Independent power producers, such as APR and Aggreko, operate a larger fleet than that of state-owned utility Senelec. The 1.2GW power mix is dominated by oil and diesel, with solar PV, large hydro, natural gas and coal filling in the remainder. Additional power is imported from two dams in Mali. A renewables transition is underway, with 169.5MW of solar installed in 2019 and a 158MW wind farm commissioned in 2020. However, government support for future additions is likely to be affected by the discovery of major gas reserves off Senegals coast, with extraction set to begin in 2022. A pivot back toward thermal energy is underway, as the government plans to modify oil plants to use natural gas and to build several combined-cycle gas turbines.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Sierra Leones grid customers are from the residential, small commercial or public sector. Electricity prices are regulated by the Water and Electricity Regulatory Commission, and they have risen. As of 2019, the residential grid-connected electricity price was 1,600 SLL/kWh, or 0.21 USD/kWh, which is far from being cost-reflective. Until 2018, and starting in 2016, the price was set at 1,475 SLL/kWh, or 0.20 USD/kWh. Finally, Sierra Leone subsidizes the first 25 kWh of residential electricity consumed in a month with a regulated price of 560 SLL/kWh, or 0.06USD/kWh, compared with its subsidy of the first 50 kWh in 2016. Based on the 2018 Integrated Household Survey, it is estimated that urban-area grid consumption was around 40 kWh/month per household. Off-grid electricity tariffs are also regulated, but cost-reflective and non-subsidized, at around 0.6 USD/kWh.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail power prices in Somalia are among the highest in Africa because electricity service providers still rely primarily on inefficient diesel generators with high fuel costs. Transmission infrastructure is fragmented and unreliable, and losses are high at around 40% compared to the sub-Saharan Africa average of 11%. Power grids are usually localized, which increases costs and prevents companies from realizing economies of scale. Finally, metering infrastructure and consumer rates are inadequate enough to incentivize efficient electricity use. Many electricity providers charge based on the number of appliances or light bulbs used, giving consumers little reason to use more efficient devices or to curb their consumption.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: As is common in the region, South Africa has no wholesale electricity market and the energy regulator (Nersa) determines final retail prices. Eskom has repeatedly argued for substantial tariff increases to pay back its billions of expenses. Overall, tariffs increased by an average of 13.7% a year between 2004 and 2018. Costs for renewables have also fallen. The winning tariffs dropped significantly in each renewables auction round: wind and PV fell 24% and 29% between rounds 3 and 4, after adjusting the tariffs for factors such as inflation and merchant tail. Overall, the LCOE for onshore wind in South Africa  at $62-89/MWh  falls in the middle of BNEFs benchmark estimates in 1H 2020, as its relatively low capex is counteracted by higher financing costs. It is a similar story for PV (without tracking), which has an LCOE of $60-66/MWh.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: The South Sudanese government subsidizes power prices for the few customers with access to the grid in the Capital, Juba, and charges one uniform tariff. The population has very little purchasing power, but the main issue is not the lack of demand, but rather a lack of installed capacity. Moreover, the national grid is often not operational. A handful of regional cities use heavy fuel oil-powered mini-grids, run either by the state utility or by local cooperatives. In contrast to those run by the state-owned utility, the grids run by the local cooperatives charge cost-reflective tariffs, which restricts customer numbers somewhat.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Sudanese consumers benefit from generous electricity subsidies, which result in some of the world's lowest retail prices at an average $21.24/MWh. A reduced social tariff benefits those who consume less than 200kWh/month, which is a higher threshold than found elsewhere in the region. These tariffs fall far short of meeting utility production costs, leaving the companies financially dependent on the government. The option of increasing tariffs is politically difficult given the countrys political instability. Following the breakaway of South Sudan in 2011, Sudan lost the majority of its oil assets, leaving it with little choice but to import the fuel needed for its thermal power generation. Sudans runaway inflation and currency devaluation compounds the challenge, making fossil fuel imports increasingly costly.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Retail electricity prices in Tanzania are lower than many other East African countries, averaging close to $0.09/kWh in 2018, and are regulated by the Energy and Water Utilities Authority. Prices are low partially due to the near-600MW of installed hydro capacity, but also due to heavy subsidization from Tanzanias Ministry of Energy, which is intended to attract industrialization in the country. With more hydro capacity under development, prices will remain low. In February 2016, TANESCO, the state-owned utility, lobbied for slightly lower retail prices to help the country reach its 75% electrification target in 2025, and fixed fees were scrapped for residential households.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Togos challenge is to expand power generation in a cost?efficient manner. The country relies heavily upon relatively unreliable imports from the West Africa Power Pool, which provided almost 75% of consumption in 2018. The price of imported hydropower and gas?fired generation ranges from $80 to $120/MWh. In terms of existing, national generation, Togos second-largest power plant  the 65MW Nangbeto large-hydro plant  was built in 1988. The German-based Voith Hydro was recently selected to rehabilitate the power plant by 2022, an effort that is estimated to require a $25 million investment. To increase its energy security, Togo signed a 25-year PPA with U.S.-based Contour Global in 2010 for a 100MW Heavy Fuel Oil (HFO) plant, at offtake prices as high as $170/MWh. Such high offtake prices offer an opportunity for large-scale renewables to be built at a considerably lower cost of generation. On October 31, 2018, Siemens, Eranove and TSK signed a memorandum to work together on the framework for the 65MW Kkli gas-fired electricity power station, which will supply 30% of the country's electricity needs for 25 years.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Due to the high level of subsidies, Tunisias average residential electricity prices were among the 10 lowest in Africa, at $52.50/MWh in 2017. Industrial and commercial prices  at $76/MWh and $87/MWh, respectively  are significantly higher than the residential tariff but still more than 50% below the regional average. In 2019, Tunisia signed a tariff of $24.40/MWh for 200MW of PV  a record low for Africa.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Uganda has relatively high retail prices compared to neighboring countries. This is largely due to the combination of cost overruns and expensive take-or-pay contracts with renewable (mostly large-scale hydro) projects. Umeme, the countrys transmission and distribution utility, guarantees shareholders a 20% return on investment, further boosting prices. Residential, industrial and commercial rates have all increased more than 50% in real terms since 2010.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Developers of solar utility-scale projects benefit from excellent irradiation levels, economies of scale and low development costs. Yet rock-bottom auction prices are also made possible by implicit subsidies, such as the fact that developers need pay for neither land nor a grid connection. Headline-grabbing bids have resulted, including a near-world record of $16.90/MWh recorded for Dubais latest solar auction in November 2019. Moreover, state utilities retain majority stakes in all utility-scale projects, reducing the cost of debt. Renewables are increasingly able to undercut fossil-fuel generators, for which fuel subsidies were removed in 2015. However, fossil-fuel generators continue to receive indirect support in the form of subsidized retail tariffs. For instance, residential prices have remained unchanged in Dubai over much of the last decade.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: Electricity prices in Zambia are historically stable and low, due to the fact that they are subsidized. Retail tariffs are below the cost of production, so Zesco faces significant financial pressure. The utility's overall debt is estimated at $1 billion. It has reportedly fallen into arrears on payments to IPPs after a 2015-16 drought led to the signing of emergency PPAs. For example, Zescos's debt to Electricidade de Mozambique (EDM) for importing power under one two-year contract stands at around $70 million. In 2017, average commercial electricity prices were increased as Zesco began implementing steps toward more cost-reflective tariffs, which was also necessitated by inflation. The tariff increase was approved by the Energy Regulatory Board, but subsequent upward revisions of retail tariffs planned for 2018 were canceled following direct intervention by the president, pending the local election cycle. Instead, in 2019, commercial and residential prices were down 20% and 23%, respectively. For renewables, high solar irradiation and declining technology costs hold strong potential for the development of PV capacity, but wind energy potential in Zambia is relatively limited. Zambia's hydro generation potential is estimated at more than 6,000MW, more than double what it is today.

column4: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column5: BNEF Take: Power prices and LCOEs
column17: National electricity tariffs are roughly USD $0.106 per kWh, compared to a regional average of USD $0.14 per kWh, according to ZESA. In reality, Zimbabwe's tariffs are among the highest in the region when accounting for exchange rates. In October 2019, Zimbabwe raised its average electricity tariff by 320% in response to rising fuel prices and inflation stoked by a rapidly depreciating Zimbabwe dollar, which was reintroduced earlier in the year. The tariff increases are expected to enable ZESA to undertake grid maintenance, repair aging coal-fired generation units and cover imports from South Africa and Mozambique. Tariffs were again increased by 20% in March 2020, followed by 50% hikes in both September and in October. The national regulator, ZERA, is operating at a loss and struggling to collect an estimated $1.3 billion owed by defaulters. ZETDC announced in April 2020 that it would begin to disconnect consumers for nonpayment. The government's mandatory rollout of prepaid meters was designed to bring in more stable revenue. According to ZETDC, the program has improved revenue inflows by 35%.
